L'ABERILDUT.— Depths.— The entrance to this tidal port bears E. by S. f S. nearly 12 miles from Stiff point lighthouse, Ushant, and S. | E. 3^ miles from the Four rock ; it is the only place between Brest and the river Abervrac'h where vessels drawing 12 feet can enter at high water, springs, and be perfectly sheltered from all winds. During neaps there are only 8 feet at high water. At low water, the port dries completely out 2 cables beyond the entrance, but, the bottom being soft sand, vessels lie aground with great safety. It is much frequented by Brest pilots and fishermen from the adjoining coast ; a considerable trade is also carried on, the principal exports being stone and sand ; a great deal of the stone used in the Thames Embankment came from here. Directions. — To enter l'Aberildut ; when about 2 miles off the entrance, bring the tower of Bredes church, seen amongst the trees about 2 miles inland, on with the tower of Lanildut church E. | S. ; this mark leads up to the entrance, passing about one cable northward of the Pierre de Laber rock, which uncovers 12 feet at low water and is marked by a red beacon turret, and between the Trois Pierres on the North and Men-Garo rock on the South, which latter covers at equinoctial tides only. On arriving at the entrance, which is about 150 yards wide, pass about 50 yards southward of a black rock con nected with the northern point of entrance by a jetty ; run on, keeping about 50 or 60 yards from the northern shore, and on round ing the point which forms the western side of the port of Laber, if having come in for shelter only, anchor when abreast of the first houses in that village ; but, if going to take in or discharge cargo, run on up to the quay where the grounding places are excellent, the bottom being sand and mud. The tide runs very strongly to the S.W. across the entrance during the first hour of the ebb, requiring a fresh breeze to stem it. It is advisable for a stranger to take a pilot, or, as there are none specially belonging to the port, a fisherman does as well. Argenton. — E. by S. \ S. about 1^ miles from the Four light house, is the entrance to this little harbour, which dries at low water, but has a bottom of sand and mud, is protected by a jetty about 75 yards long, and is completely land-locked, though the surf makes itself felt in north-westerly gales. The only practicable channel to the entrance is between the Four rocks and the Petit Melgorne, but its approaches are so barred by dangers as to render it hazardous for even the smallest vessels to attempt except in the hands of a skilful local pilot. A rather extensive fishery exists here, and the coasting trade is carried on by about 60 small vessels calling annually. Semaphore. — At 1\ miles northward of the entrance to Argenton is a Semaphore station on point Landunvez ; see page 12. ROCHES de PORSAL.— The body of this extensive ledge lies 4 miles north-eastward from the Four lighthouse and 5 miles west ward from the entrance of the Abervrac'h river ; the greater part of the rocks are covered at high water. There is anchorage amongst and several passages through them, but the navigation is too intricate to be attempted without a pilot. See charts, Nos. 2,694 and 2,644.

H.] ARGENTON.— PORTSAL.— CAUTION. 29 Portsal or Porsal.— This port, which is fronted by the roches de Porsal, comprises three distinct bays ; the western bay is that of Trernazan or du Chateau, the second is the bay of Kersaint, and at the head of the eastern bay stands the village of Porsal. In bad weather, the swell and surf within the port are so great as to render it dangerous. There is very little trade and no wharf s approachable by vessels ; loading or discharging is done by boats when the tide suits. Depths. — The harbour is dry throughout its whole extent by three quarters ebb ; vessels of 13 feet draught can enter at springs, and of 6 or 7 feet draught at neaps ; the bottom is generally of sand, but a mass of rocks which covers only at high tides occupies the middle of the harbour. Several channels lead to Porsal but all are intricate and none should be attempted without a pilot. The leading mark for the South or inner channel is, lurch rock just closed in by Men Gouziane E.N.E. ; both of these rocks are marked by beacons. From the North-west, the leading mark through the reefs to the inner channel is lurch rock on with Ploudalmezeau spire. Life-Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Porsal. Pilots. — The pilots of Porsal cruise near the Four rock and out side the roches de Porsal in small cutters, which may be known by their having an anchor on the mainsail, as described at page 14. They are qualified to conduct vessels as far as Brest, and if required for the inner channels of the roches de Porsal are reputed to be the best to be obtained. CAUTION. — The coast in the vicinity of Porsal and Four rocks is of moderate height, but being bordered by numerous dangers it should not be approached at night or in thick weather within the depth of 45 fathoms ; the bottom at that depth is generally of grey sand mixed with flint and other stones. L'Aberbenoit. — Between Porsal and l'Abervrac'h is a deep bight encumbered by rocks and shoals, into which the river Aberbenoit flows, forming a harbour of but little importance, though accessible to vessels of 11. feet draught, at springs, and of 4 to 6 feet draught at neaps ; it is approached by a deep entrance channel on either side of the plateau de Rusven, a reef which dries in places at low water. The eastern passage is the broadest and deepest, but, with westerly winds, the western passage is preferred, as it gives more room to clear the broken water caused by ile Guennoc. See char*-, Np. L' ABERVRAC'H.— The entrance to this river, nearly 6 miles eastward of Porsal and 4 miles westward of Correjou bay, is difficult of access, being much encumbered by numerous shoals, islets, and rocks. It, however, affords good shelter to wind-bound ships ; the outer roadstead is just within the entrance and about 1| cables south-eastward of the black and white beacon turret on the Petit Pot-de-Beurre rock. Depths. — The outer road has from 6 to 8 fathoms water over a sandy bottom at the lowest tides. The inner road is H miles in a S.S.E. | E. direction from the outer road, and the least depth is 5 fathoms, except 1£ cables north-eastward of Cezon isle, where there are only 2\ fathoms. The whole space between the outer and inner roads affords good anchorage to vessels of the largest size. The roads are separated from the port by a mole about 260 yards in length, where vessels discharge cargo and where water may be obtained. There are also two beaching places on the left bank of the river, one in Anges bay, the other a little farther eastward in St. Antoine bay ; the bottom in both bays is soft mud and dries 6^ feet at the lowest tides. Great expense has been incurred in the beacons, lights, and buoyage of this harbour, but since the increase of steam navigation its trade steadily declines, though a large number of boats are engaged in the fisheries. LIGHTS. — The entrance to Abervrac'h river is facilitated at night by the following lights : — lie Vrac'h. — A fixed red light shown on the eastern side of the entrance from a white square tower, 36 feet high, erected on the southern part of ile Vrac'h. This light is 59 feet above high water, and is visible 6 miles. Lanvaon. — A fixed ivhite light from a white square tower on Lanvaon heights, which bears S.E. by E. \ E. If miles from the tower on ile Vrac'h. This light is 171 feet above high water, and when in line with the light on ile Vrac'h leads through the Grand chenal to the entrance of the Abervrac'h. It is visible 14 miles, through an arc of 36°, i.e., 18° on either side of the line of direction. Two fixed lights are also exhibited on the left or western bank of the river, one ivhite, at the head of St. Antoine creek ; the other green, on the eastern point of Palue beach ; when in line, they show the direction of the inner anchorage. These lights are respectively 49 and 29 feet above high water, and are visible 11 and 8 miles. Life-Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at ile Vrac'h. See chart, No. 2,644.

II.] l'abervrac'h. — LIGHTS.— DIRECTIONS. 31 Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the hill over looking the village of Abervrac'h, which may be seen a long way off seaward ; see page 12. DIRECTIONS — The Abervrac'h river can be entered by three channels, all of which are accessible to the deepest ships at high water, and one, the Grand chenal, is available at any time of tide ; it leads in from the westward passing southward of Libenter ledge. The Chenal de la Malouine leads in from the northward between Malouine and Pendante ledges. The third is the Pendante channel between Libenter ledge and the Tendante ; its navigation is difficult, and should not be attempted without a pilot. The Grand Chenal is practicable for vessels of the deepest draught by day or night, with a fair wind, and wide enough for coasters to turn through, the narrowest part of the channel being 1\ cables wide. In approaching it from the westward, as soon as they are seen, bring the steeple of Plouguerneau church and the white light towers on ile Vrac'h and on Lanvaon heights in line, or, at night, the white and red lights in line bearing S.E. by E. \ E., which is the leading mark in ; but, when coming from the northward, the steeple of Ploudalmezeau church must be kept well open westward of the steeple of Lampaul church S. S.W. until the leading mark is on, in order to pass westward of the western patches of Libenter ledge ; there are never less than 25 feet on these patches, but a heavy sea runs over them in bad weather. In running through this channel, the leading mark must be kept exactly on, for although the vessel passes 1\ cables southward of the South extreme of Libenter ledge, marked by a black buoy, and about the same distance southward of the Grand Pot-de-Buerre ledge, on which is a black beacon turret, yet it leads only 55 yards northward of a 9^-feet patch, named the Basse du Chenal, and 80 yards south ward of the beacon turret on the Petit Pot-du-Buerre, which at night may not be seen. Having passed this beacon turret the vessel may either come-to in the outer anchorage, or proceed southward with the light tower in St. Antoine bay on with that on Palue beach ; or, at night, with the white and green lights in line S.E. by S. This being the line of direction for the inner anchorage, a berth may be taken as convenient, mooring N.W. and S.E. ; or, if capable of taking the ground, the vessel can steer for one of the beaching places. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the river Abervrac'h at 4h. 14m. ; equinoctial springs rise 29 -feet, ordinary springs 22 feet, and ordinary neaps 16 feet above the level of the soundings ; neaps range 10 feet. ILE VIERGE is a mass of rocks but little above the level of the sea and without any vegetation ; between it and the shore is a passage used by coasters and small craft only, and also the little bay of Portz- Malo where they anchor close to the shore and ground as the tide falls. lie Vierge lies 2 miles eastward of the entrance to the river Abervrac'h, and N.W. by W. \ W. 2\ miles from the western point of Correjou bay ; it may be recognised from some distance by the square lighthouse erected 109 yards from its eastern extreme. LIGHT. — The lighthouse exhibits, at 108 feet above high water, a fixed white light varied every four minutes by a red flash, pre ceded and followed by a short eclipse. The light is an excellent guide for the entrance to Abervrac'h and also for Correjou bay ; it is visible 16 miles, and the eclipses are not total within a distance of 6 miles. From ile Vierge. the lighthouse on Bec-pol, Pontusval, bears E. -J- S. nearly 9 miles ; the shoals fronting this part of the coast, of which the principal are the Plateau du Lizen-Ven, Plateau du Guern, Plateau d'Aman-ar-Ross, and the Basses St. Tregarec, extend H miles seaward of this line and the coast recedes nearly 2 miles. In coming from the westward, a vessel will clear all these shoals by keeping the tower of Ploudalmezeau church well open westward of ile Vierge until the lighthouse on Bec-pol bears S.E. by E. CORREJOU BAY.— In the western part of the bight named, is Correjou Bay ; Penenes isle lies in its northern part, and close north-eastward of the isle is Penvers ledge, which covers at high See chart, No. 2,644.

Chap. II.] ILE VIERGE. — CORREJOU BAY. — DIRECTIONS. 33 water with the exception of three heads, one at its southern, the second at its eastern, and the third at its northern extreme. A short distance eastward of the eastern head is the north-western end of the Bazughen ledge, which from thence trends 2\ cables in a south-easterly direction, its highest head uncovering 10 feet at the lowest tides. The Garrec-Crom ledge, northward of the Bazughen, covers at high water with the exception of one head at its eastern extreme. Depths. — The anchorage in this bay is south-eastward of Penvers ledge, and the depth is from 13 to 19 feet at low water, springs. The beaching place is southward of Penenes isle, but the bay is now quite abandoned by the coasting trade ; the bottom here is of sand, and it rises gradually towards the shore, at the foot of which it dries 16 feet above the lowest tides. Directions. — Correjou bay may be entered by two channels, the Western and Eastern channels ; the Western channel is between the coast and the southern part of the Lizen-Ven ledge ; the Eastern channel is between the Guern ledge and a ledge named the Chaussee de Carrec-Hir. To enter by the western channel, steer to the southward with ile Vierge lighthouse on a S. by W. bearing until the guard-house on the point of Kerisoc is on with the northern head on Penvers ledge S.E. \ E. Proceed with this mark on until half way between this rock and the Andolven rocks, when ile Vierge lighthouse seen over a remarkable gap or cleft in the Andolven rocks, just to the left of the most northern rock, becomes the mark ; and, passing north ward of Penvers ledge, that mark leads between Garrec-Crom and the Bazughen, and about 22 yards northward of a 4-feet patch nearly in mid-channel. Vessels may anchor in about 16 feet, sand, with this mark on, when Penvers and Mean-Yan are in line. Do not haul more to the southward for an anchorage before the highest head on the Garrec-Crom is northward of N.N.E., for the south eastern head of the Bazughen bears S.SW from this head ; and, in steering to the southward, the highest head of the Garrec-Crom must not be brought more easterly than N. by E. \ E. so long as the southern head on Penvers ledge is shut in southward of the North point of the bay. The swell is much felt in this bay above half tide, and, as no marks can be given for leaving it at night, it should only be used in the finest weather. The leading mark through the eastern channel is the steeple of Plouguerneau church on with the Mean-Yan rock bearing S.S.W. \ W. ; See chart, No. 2,644. B 3 SO 11886

Semaphore.— About a mile eastward of the anchorage in Correjou bay is a Semaphore station on the high land of Kerisoc ; see page 12. Between the Baie de Correjou and Pontusval are the small tidal harbours of Treisseny and Kerlouan, of little or no importance. LIGHT. — On Bec-pol, Pontusval point, stands a square lighthouse, from whence, at 59 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed white light, with a red sector between the bearings S.E. by E. \ E. and E. by N. \ N. showing over the Basses St. Tregarec and the shoals westward, but which sector does not cover all the shoal ground when approached within 2 miles. The light is visible from a distance of 12 miles. PONTUSVAL, the entrance to which port is about one mile eastward of Bee-pol lighthouse, and 1^ miles north-westward of the Greve de Goulven, is the only place on this part of the coast where the crew of a vessel, driven on a lee shore, could hope to be saved. It berths a large number of coasters, but the bottom is hard, and, in strong gales from the northward, it is not an unfrequent occurrence to see them wrecked at their anchors. Depths. — The port completely dries out at low water as far as abreast of the western entrance point, and, from thence, the bottom gradually rises to the head of the port. It admits vessels of 11 feet draught at high water, ordinary springs ; and of 5 feet draught at neaps. A vessel is moderately well sheltered on the eastern side of the port in a little bay named La Chambre, in which the bottom dries 13^ feet above the lowest tides. The least depth at low water in the entrance channel, until abreast of the western entrance point, is 13 feet ; the channel is bordered on both sides by sunken rocks and crossed obliquely by the tidal streams. Telegraph Cable.— The telegraph cable from Salcombe is landed at this port. A Life-Boat and mortar apparatus, &c, are stationed at this port. See chart, No. 2,644.

Chap. II.] 35 PONTUSVAL. — DIRECTIONS. — COAST. Directions. — To enter Pontusval ; when about half a mile from the entrance, steer to the southward with the beacon on the eastern shore of the port eastward of the Custom-house office, exactly on with the steeple of Plouneour church S. by W. \ W. This mark leads between the two rocks Blanche de l'entree and Ar-Neuden or Fil, only about 70 yards apart ; the former is on the western side of the entrance and its summit is always above water ; the latter, which has on it a black beacon turret with cylindrical top-mark, 14 feet above the level of the highest tides, is on the eastern side and uncovers 12^ feet. When abreast of the Blanche de l'entree, steer a little more to starboard, to pass nearly midway between the Blanche du centre and Vran rocks ; the former lies on the western side of the channel and never covers, the latter on the eastern side and uncovers 27 feet. Pass rather nearer the Blanche than the Vran, and when near the Blanche du dedans, a rock one cable south-westward of Blanche du centre, steer for the Custom-house office on a S. by W. W. bearing and it will lead into La Chambre, on the eastern side of the port. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Pontusval at 4h. 25m., and the tide rises in La Chambre about 16-g feet at equinoctial springs, and 5 feet at neaps ; here the bottom dries 13^ feet above the level of the lowest tides. The COAST. — From the lighthouse on Bec-pol, Pontusval, ile de Bas lighthouse bears East 13£ miles ; between the two are the Greve de Goulven, Anse de Kernic, Port Nevez, and other small bays and creeks, places of little or no importance, and so encumbered by rocks and shoals as to be very dangerous to approach. The most outlying shoal in the neighbourhood is Queyn Cos, with 3^ fathoms ; its outer extreme is 2| miles from the nearest land, and E. 5 N. 4£ miles from Bec-pol light. Greve de Goulven. — This deep sandy bay affords shelter from westerly winds to vessels that can take the ground, but it is difficult of access, its entrance being full of rocks. ANSE de KERNIC, or, as it is sometimes called, the port de Plouescat, has a narrow entrance choked by rocks awash ; it has a sandy bottom which dries at half tide, but, at high water, springs, there are from 6 to 15 feet ; it is reported to be gradually silting up, and much land has been reclaimed from the sea on its borders. It is used only by vessels of from 60 to 80 tons, but having neither quay nor wharf, they discharge cargo into carts alongside when left by the tide. See chart, No. 2,644.

II. lie de Siec* — This islet, lying between port Nevez and lie de Bas, from the western extreme of which its western rock, Golc'hedec, bears S.W. | W. 2| miles, is 5 cables long E.S.E. and W.N.W., and is connected with the land by a rocky ledge which uncovers at low water, thus affording shelter to an excellent anchorage well out of the tideway ; it was formerly much frequented by coasting vessels, with the wind from N.E. round by East to S.S.E. Approaching the anchorage from the westward, bring the spire of St. Pol-de-Leon college on with the Querelevran rock, which lies one cable southward of the western point of the isle, and anchor in from 5 to 6 fathoms, sand, when Golc'hedec rock, 2 cables north westward of the isle, bears N.N.E. 3 or 4 cables distant, Coming from the northward, bring the tower of Cleder church on with the eastern point of the entrance to port Nevez S.W. by S. ; this line passes 3 cables westward of Golc'hedec rock, but within 2 cables of the Calhic rock, which lies half a mile N.N.E. from the Golc'hedec and dries 18 feet at low water ; when arriving on the leading marks before given, steer in for the anchorage. ILE de BAS, or ile de Batz as it is frequently called, is a low island not visible from the deck of a vessel at a greater distance than 9 miles, though the lighthouse near its western end may be seen much farther ; it lies immediately off the promontory of Roscoff, and when bearing S.S.W. its outline becomes blended with the coast, from which it is only separated by a channel less than 7 cables wide at its narrowest part. It is about 2 miles long E.S.E. and W.N.W., and one mile wide ; it is bordered on its western, northern, and eastern sides by rocks and shoals extending from 5 cables to a mile from the shore, most of which cover at high water ; but one of the most prominent is the Penven, always above water, 4 cables northward from the central northern point of the isle. From ile de Bas light house, Bee-Pol lighthouse bears West 13£ miles, and Triagoz light house E. f N. northerly 16^ miles. LIGHT. — The circular lighthouse, erected on a mound half a mile from the western end of ile de Bas, exhibits a fixed and flash ing white light of the first order, showing a flash every minute. The light is 223 feet above high water, and is visible 22 miles. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on ile de Bas ; see page 12. * See Admiralty chart : lie de Bas and adjacent islands, No. 2,745 ; scale, m = 5 inches.

Chap. II.] ILE DE BAS.— CHANNEL INSIDE. 37 The island has a population of about 1,200, and on its southern side is the .village and harbour of Porz Kernoch. On its western side, the harbour is formed by a mole 570 yards in length connecting the shore with the Malvoch rock, marked on its south-eastern edge by a beacon ; and, on its eastern side, by a short jetty connecting that shore with the ile aux Moutons. The harbour dries at low water, has 6 feet at half tide, and 19 feet at high water, springs ; it is but little used now, the coasting trade decreasing with the growth of steam navigation and improved means of land transport. A Life-Boat and mortar apparatus are stationed at the western end of ile de Bas. CHANNEL between ILE de BAS and the COAST.— On account of its difficult navigation, this narrow channel is not much used except by vessels of light draught calling at Porz Kernoch or Roscoff. Vessels drawing about 19 feet may, however, if necessary, run through it with a fair wind at high water, slack. Anchorage. — The anchoring ground in this channel is comprised between the meridians of the chapel of Notre Dame de Bon Secours and the village of Porz Kernoch, and the depth is from 2 to ±h fathoms. There is a long and narrow swash way with from 11 to 15 feet between the northern edge of the Traverse, a shallow shifting sand bank which bounds the anchorage eastward, and the sand-bank bordering the southern side of the isle ; and, although the stream here runs with great strength, coasters prefer it to the anchorage just described, as they are well sheltered, and, if necessary, can beach on the sands in Porz Kernoch, where the bottom dries only 6 or 7 feet at the lowest tides. Directions. — When bound through the chaunel between ile de Bas and the coast from the westward, Ste. Barbe western obelisk on with the white patch on the Loup rock S.E. by E., leads northward of the Basse Plate, a rock which only dries 3 feet, and on which a block of masonry about 10 feet high has been placed, on which a beacon turret is to be built, and of the Lavandieres rocks, which never cover, in not less than 5 fathoms towards the red beacon on the Oignon rock, which uncovers 22 feet and must be left to the southward. When about a cable westward of this rock, or when the eastern mill on ile de Bas and the little pyramid beacon on Kernoch isle (seen over the mole) are in line, steer E.S.E. for the anchorage, leaving the red beacon on the Tehibihan rock also on the starboard hand ; or, if not going to anchor, steer for point Pen-ar-Chleguer until the western mill (westward of Kernoch village) is on with Kernoch See chart, No 2,745. There is an anchorage of small extent within ile Pighet, over a bottom of gravel and broken shells, where a vessel can wait for a favourable moment either to run through the channel or to enter port Roscoff. ROSCOFF.— This little tidal harbour is about a mile S.S.E. from the south-eastern extreme of ile de Bas ; it is formed by a mole or breakwater of solid construction extending with an outward curve from the western shore a distance of 575 yards. Works are also constructed at Penar-Vil, on the opposite side, to break the force of the sea during north-easterly gales ; in bad weather, however, the swell within the harbour is so great as to cause inconvenience and even danger. The town has railway connection through St. Pol de-Leon with the general system of France ; it has a population of about 1,000, and a thriving trade is carried on by vessels up to 200 tons, both English and French ; fruit, vegetables, fish, &c, are the chief exports. Depths. — It is accessible to vessels of 12 feet draught at high water, springs, and to those of 5 or 6 feet draught at neaps. The grounding places dry from 12 to 19 feet at the lowest tides ; the breakwater affords the only quay accommodation. LIGHTS.— A fixed white light, 22 feet above high water, visible 7 miles, is exhibited from an iron standard on the extreme end of the mole. A fixed red light, 38 feet above high water, visible 8 miles, is shown from an iron support at the life-boat station at the head of the harbour. The two lights in line lead into the harbour by the northern channel. See chart, No. 2,745.

Chap. II.] 39 ROSCOFF.— DIRECTIONS.— COAST. Directions. — Roscoff has several intricate approaches for fishing craft ; two channels only are available for vessels of from 150 to 200 tons, viz., that from the eastward, and that from the direction of the anchorage within ile Pighet ; for which latter, the leading mark by day is, the white spot on the magazine at the head of the harbour on with the extreme end of the mole ; and, by night, the two leading lights in line. Approaching the port from the eastward, keep the south-eastern extreme of ile de Bas open northward of Tisaoson isle until within 8 cables of the latter, when the beacon turret on Astan rock will bear about N.N.W., then steer for Bloscon point, on the summit of which stands Ste. Barbe chapel, on a W. by S. f S. bearing, leaving the black beacon buoy of the Basse de Bloscon on the port hand, and the red beacon turret of Mean Guen Bihan on the starboard hand ; pass about half a cable northward of the fortified islet at the foot of this point, and run through the channel limited by this islet and Penar- Vil on the eastern side, and by the rocks Rannic and la Vache, marked by two red beacons, on the western side ; the outer of these two beacons stands only 164 yards north-westward of the islet. This channel is difficult to navigate even at high water, and impracticable on the ebb. Life-Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Roscoff. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in port Roscoff at 4h. 49m. The tide rises above the soundings at the anchorage in the eastern part of the channel between this port and ile de Bas, 30 feet at equinoctial springs, 23 feet at ordinary springs, and 17 feet at ordinary neaps. Neaps range about 11 feet, The Coast. — From Pointe de Bloscon, the eastern entrance point of Roscoff harbour, to the northern point of Grande ile, which lies S. by E. | E. 4-V miles from Triagoz lighthouse, and is itself sur rounded by other numerous isles and rocks, the bearing and distance is East 15^ miles, nearly the whole of the dangerous plateau de la Meloine lying seaward of this line. Between these points the coast recedes and forms two deep bays, the shores of which are fringed by numerous rocks, many of them upwards of 1^ miles from the land. The bays are separated from each other by Primel point, westward of which is Morlaix bay, with the entrances to the rivers Morlaix and Penze or St. Pol-de-Leon at its head ; and, eastward, the little harbour See charts, Nqs. 2,745 and 2,641. There is good anchorage in Morlaix road for vessels of the deepest draught, and also in the eastern bay off the mouth of the river Lannion. PLATEAU de la MELOINE is a group of rocky heads with deep water between them, commencing N. by E. 1\ miles from Primel point, extending 5 miles in an E. by N. \ N. direction and forming a most dangerous obstacle to navigation, especially to vessels entering Morlaix from the eastward. The western extreme of the ledge is called the Trepieds, of which the highest rock uncovers 9 feet ; the marks for it are, the steeple of Plougaznou church on with Carrec-an-Ti rock S. \ E. ; and, the two spires of St. Pol-de-Leon church on with the Bisayers rock W. by S \ S. southerly. At the eastern extreme of the plateau is the Carrec-an-Hir with 10 feet water only, and one mile westward of it is the Pongaro reef, awash at the lowest tides. In the centre of the plateau is a group of large rocks always uncovered. Buoy. — A black buoy is moored off the western extreme of the Trepieds. Clearing marks. — After passing ile de Bas, the plateau de la Meloine may be cleared on its north-western side by bearings of ile de Bas lighthouse. Coming from the eastward, by bearings of Triagoz lighthouse ; or, if in-shore, the Corbeau rock on with la Clarte church tower E. by S., leads 7 cables northward of the Carrec an-Hir and Pongaro ledges. There is an in-shore passage between the Meloine and the Chaises de Primel, the rocky ledge extending 2\ miles eastward from Primel point, for which the leading mark is, the clock tower of Creiskar, St. Pol-de-Leon, on with the northern side of Vezoul ile W. \ S. southerly. This channel should never be taken except by day. St. Pol-de-Leon or Penze river, has its entrance on the western side of Morlaix bay. At 2^ miles southward of Roscoff is the town of St. Pol-de-Leon, easily distinguished by the two lofty spires of its cathedral ; adjoining is the little tidal harbour of Pen poull, between which and the ile de Callot, If miles distant, is the entrance to the tortuous channel of the Penze river, beaconed in accordance with the French system, and crossed by a bridge 4 or 5 miles within the entrance at the village of Penze, up to which point See charts, Nos. 2,745 and 2,644.

Chap. II.] PLATEAU DE LA MELOINE. — MORLAIX. 41 it is navigable, at high water, springs, for coasters. Both flood and ebb streams follow the direction of the channel, and at half tide, springs, run at the rate of 3 or 4 knots. Vessels bound either to Penpoull or Penze, after passing Tisaoson ile at 2 or 3 cables distance, should steer to the southward, not coming westward of S. by W. \ W. until the turret on Benven ile and that on the northern end of ile de Callot are in line bearing S.S.E. \ E., which mark leads between the Guerheon rock, on which is a red turret, on the West ; and the Cordonnier rock, awash at low water, on which is a black turret, on the East, in not less than 2 fathoms ; and, when St. Sebastian tower, the second towe/ south ward of Ste. Barbe chapel, is on with the steeple of Roscoff church N.W. \ N. the vessel is at the entrance of the river and should proceed no farther without a pilot. MORLAIX RIVER.* — The entrance to Morlaix river is on the eastern side of Morlaix bay, between the ile de Callot and Primel point. Two principal channels lead into it, the eastern or Treguier channel, and the western or main channel ; the former, although not so deep as the latter, is generally preferred by coasters as its width admits of tacking. The channels unite between the isles Louet and Noire, which are half a mile apart, from whence the single channel takes a S. | E. direction for 3 miles through Morlaix road to the spot where it is joined by the little river Dourdu. Above this are quays on either side where vessels may lie aground, and a small gridiron, and still higher is the lock entrance to the wet dock, nearly a mile in length, with a width of from 82 to 193 feet, and a depth of from 8| feet at the upper to 16f feet at the lower end. The dimensions of the lock are much more than equal to the require ments of the basin. Depths. — The river is accessible to vessels of the deepest draught at all times as far as, and a mile beyond, Morlaix road. From thence it shoals rapidly, and is reported to be only navigable for vessels of 9^ feet draught up to the wet dock. At the head of the wet dock is the town of Morlaix, with a population of about 14,000, and a railway station on the line connecting Rennes with Brest, The railway here crosses the river on a granite viaduct on 14 arches ; it is 973 feet in length and 183 feet above the level of the quays. LIGHTS.— To enable vessels to enter Morlaix river at night, three lights are exhibited ; one from Noire islet, lying just within the entrance of the river, 4 cables south-eastward of Chateau du Taureau isle and half way between it and point Barnenez ; another from Louet isle If cables from point Pen Lann ; and, the third from Lande tower on the left or western bank of the river. Noire isle lighthouse is a square tower, from which is exhibited at 46 feet above high water, visible 12 miles, a fixed light showing red, green, and white sectors. It shows red from S. 27° E. to S. 51° W., green from S. 27° E. to N. 75° E., and white in other directions. Louet isle light is shown from a square white turret at 52 feet above high water ; it is a fixed ivhite light, with a green sector from S. 81° W. to N. 37° W., and is visible 9 miles. Lande square light tower, standing on the high land at the head of the road, exhibits, at 285 feet above high water, a fixed and flashing white light, with a two-min ute period, visible in clear weather 15 miles ; the flashes are preceded and followed by eclipses. Louet isle light on with Lande light S. by W. £ W. leads up to the Main channel, passing eastward of ile Ricard, until the vessel enters the green sector of ile Noire light. The Noire light on with Lande tower light S.S.W. \ W. leads through the Treguier channel. Approaching Morlaix, or whilst waiting for a pilot, it is useful to know that with the whole of ile de Bas open northward of Tisaoson, a double-headed rocky islet 8 cables from the eastern end of ile de Bas, a vessel is northward of all the shoals in the mouth of the bay. Pilots.— Though the channels leading to Morlaix road and river are well marked by buoys, beacons, and lights, they are so narrow and intricate that a stranger should always take a pilot. Tides and tidal Streams.— It is high water, full and change, in Morlaix road at 4h. 53m. ; equinoctial springs rise about 31 feet, See chart, No. 2,744.

Chap. II.] MORLAIX.— TIDAL STREAMS. — DIRECTIONS. 43 ordinary springs 24 feet, and ordinary neaps 18 feet above the sound ings ; neaps range 12 feet. The streams turn at high and low water, with half an hour's slack ; and at springs, when at their strength, run at the rate of 4 knots. Both streams follow the course of the various channels. Tide Signals, see page 12* should be made from Noire isle light house, but they are not attended to with regularity. It is better to trust to the indications afforded by the height of the water on the various rocks ; for instance, when the Cadou rock covers there are 17 feet in the Treguier channel. DIRECTIONS. — Main channel. — Entering the Morlaix river by the Main channel, steer towards the eastern end of ile de Bas until Tisaoson isle is seen. Having passed between the red beacon turret on Astan rock and the black buoy off the Trepieds, 4^ milesapart, with Tisaoson bearing W. by N. about 3 miles, and the beacon turret on the Duon rocks W.S.W. about 1^ miles, the vessel will be at the entrance of the channel and more than half a mile N.E. E. from the Basse N.E. du Pot-de-Fer, a 4-feet patch marked by a red buoy on its north-eastern side, the patch lying E. f N. 2\ cables from the Pot-de-Fer rock, which uncovers 7 feet at the lowest tides. From this rock, Louet isle lighthouse is just open westward of ile Ricard S. \ W. ; and, the beacon turret of the Duon rocks is on with the chapel midway between St. Pol-de-Leon and Roscoff. Lande light tower on with Louet isle lighthouse S. by W. \ W. leads through the Main channel eastward of the Pot-de-Fer and Duon rocks, and between the Vielle rock which dries 23 feet and is marked by a red beacon turret, and the Stolvezen, a 1-foot patch marked by a black buoy on its north-eastern edge. Vessels of light draught with a fair wind, or steamers with a proper rise of tide according to their draught, may continue with this leading mark on until abreast of the Calhic rock turret, passing eastward of ile Ricard and close to the beacon off its north-eastern end, as well as to that on the Morlouine rock which dries 4 feet at low water, springs. This is the narrowest part of the channel, as, only about 70 yards from the Morlouine rock, a small plateau of rocks on the opposite side is awash at low water. Before entering the narrows at ile Ricard, the Roche d'Equinoxe, with li fathoms, lies exactly on tho line of the leading mark ; it is easily avoided by opening the Lande light-tower west ward of Louet isle lighthouse until past it. There are also other See chart, No. 2,744.

[Chap. II. 44 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. patches of 15 and 9 feet in the narrows of the channel, though the general depths are from 4 to 6 fathoms until close up to the Morlouine beacon. When abreast of the beacon on Calhic rock, steer about South to pass between the beacon on the Corbeau rock and that on the western part of the ledge extending from the northern end of Chateau du Taureau islet, and then S. \ E. past Louet isle and the red buoy marking the north-eastern edge of the Barre de slot ledge. When southward of Louet isle and clear of the Barre de slot, anchor as convenient in Morlaix road. Vessels of deep draught should pass westward of ile Ricard ; for which purpose, when nearing Vezoul isle, they should quit the line of Louet and Lande light towers in line, and bring the Pierre de Carentec (white) on with the white gable of Kergrist farmhouse S.S.W. \ W. ; this leads between the Petit-Ricard and Noire rocks, both of which have beacons on them, and passes more than half a cable eastward of Fourche and Courgik beacons. When near the latter rock, which uncovers 14 feet, steer to bring the Paradis white beacon turret on with that of l'Enfer orTrepied JauneN.N.W., which leads between the foul ground south-westward of ile Ricard and tlie Bezinnennou beacon up to the Calhic rock, from whence the directions already given lead to Morlaix road. Caution.— Both the Calhic and Corbeau rocks extend a consider able distance from their beacon turrets into the channel, and great care is required in passing them. From the direction of the ile de Bas, the Main channel may be entered by passing southward of the Duon rocks ; for which the leading mark is, ile Pighet beacon turret on with the eastern mill on ile de Bas, N.W. westerly. This line passes close north-eastward of the Menk, Bisayers, Cochons noirs, and Vielle shoals, and leads up to the leading mark for the Main channel. Treguier channel.— Vessels intending to enter by this channel must ascertain that the tide has risen sufficiently to enable them to pass over the shallow flat, nearly awash at the lowest tides, lying in the narrows of the channel, and a mile in extent north-eastward and south-westward of Blanche isle. If coming either from the west ward or eastward outside all the shoals, bring Lande light tower on with ile Noire lighthouse S.S.W. \ W. as soon as they are seen ; this See chart, No. 2,744.

Chap. II.] MORLAIX. — DIRECTIONS. — ANSE DE PRIMEL. 45 leads half a mile westward of the black buoy on the Trepieds ledge ; eastward of the Pierre Noire, Tourghi, Grand Areman, and Chambre rocks, all marked by beacons ; and, westward of the Jaune, Cadou, Vielle Chambre, and Plate rocks, and also of the beacons on Petit Aremen, Menheur, and Blanche isle. The Pierre Noire dries b\ feet, Tourghi 13 feet, Grand Aremen 13 feet, and Chambre 5£ feet ; the northern rock of the roches Jaunes dries 8 feet, the Cadou 12^ feet, Vielle Chambre 1^ feet, Petit Aremen 8 feet, and Menheur 13 feet. When abreast of the beacon on Blanche isle, steer W.S.W. until the western part of ile Ricard touches the eastern part of Chateau du Taureau isle S. \ E. easterly, which is the line of direction for Morlaix road and also for the channel of the river. Entering by this channel at night, bring Lande fixed and flashing white light on with the red sector of Noire isle light S.S.W. W., to clear the reefs as before directed. Follow this line until the green sector of Louet isle light is entered, then haul up to W.S.W. until the green sector of Noire isle light opens out, when the vessel should keep away again to S.S.W. \ W., and when out of the green sectors of both lights, she will be clear of the Barre de Hot shoal, and may anchor in Morlaix road as convenient. When near the Jaune rock in the Treguier channel, or the Fourche beacon in the Main channel, vessels may, if necessary, change from one channel to the other, the leading mark for this purpose being, the beacon turret on ile de Callot open southward of the Colombier rock. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the high land about one mile southward of Primel point, on the eastern side of Primel harbour ; see page 12. Anse de Primel. — When leaving Morlaix river for Lannion road, 10 miles E. by S. from Primel point, a vessel will pass the little harbour of Primel lying just westward of the point ; it has a very narrow entrance, for which the leading mark is, the white chimney of Repredou farmhouse on with a white mark on a wall. Vessels pass close to theZamegues rock, 14 feet above high water, and still closer to the red beacon on the Raoul rock, where is the narrowest part, and within which is a small anchorage where vessels of considerable draught may lie afloat at all times, but the holding ground is very bad, and the few small craft which use this harbour usually ground on sandy bottom higher up the bay. Strong See chart, No. 2,744.

Vessels bouud for Lannion road may pass northward of the Chaises de Primel rocks by keeping the clock tower of Creiskar, St. Pol-de-Leon, on with the northern side of ile Vezoul W. \ S. southerly, and when these rocks bear S.S.W. they may steer about E. by S. f S. to pass a cable southward of the Taureau rock which lies in front of Lannion roads, uncovers 28 feet at the lowest tides, and therefore is very seldom covered. The steeple of Guiodel church, on the left bank of the river Lannion, a little open north ward of the guard-house on Serves point, the northern point of the river entrance, or, by night, keeping within the white sector of Begleguer light, leads to the anchorage in the roads, which is exposed to the westward, but well sheltered from North round by East and South to S.W. The Coast between Primel point and the Lannion river is foul and bordered with dangers. S.E. by E. \ E. 7 miles from Primel point is Locquirec, a little tidal harbour formed by partially enclosing a small bay on the eastern side of the promontory of that name by throwing out a stone pier about 130 yards in a south-westerly direction ; it affords indifferent shelter to a few small craft, Toul an-Hery, also an inconsiderable port, lies at the bottom of the sandy bay adjoining Locquirec, where the little river Douron falls into the sea. Toul-an-Hery affords better shelter than Locquirec, but it is more difficult of access. South-eastward from Locquirec point is pointe de Plestin with another deep sandy bay beyond ; and, N.E. \ N. 3J; miles from Locquirec point is the Taureau rock off the bay of Lannion. The Farou and Felestrec, two dangerous rocks uncovering from 4 to 6 feet at low water, springs, lie between Locquirec and Lannion bay ; Lesangar mill on with point Landevelin leads westward of them and up to the entrance of Lannion river. TIDAL STREAMS.— The flood stream coming from the direction of ile de Bas runs directly over the plateau de la Meloine and towards the entrance of Lannion river, especially during the first 4 hours of the rising tide. Southward of the Meloine, it sweeps past Primel point and round the bay, setting to the northward along the eastern side and out between the Crapeaud rock and the isles off the point of the bay. The ebb stream takes an exactly See chart, No. 2,644.

Chap. II.] COAST. — TIDAL STREAMS. — LANNION. 47 opposite direction. In the offing, both streams turn 2\ hours later than in-shore. Lannion roads and port. — The dangers in approaching Lannion are numerous but well-marked. On the northern side the Crapeaud rock, ?>\ miles north-westward from point Bihit, dries 13 feet at low water, springs, and has a beacon turret, as has also the Four rock which dries 12 feet ; and, a black conical buoy is moored westward of the f-fathoms patch lying westward of the Crapeaud beacon turret ; the Taureau reef uncovers 28 feet. On the southern side is the red turret on the Kinierbel rock. The anchorage in the roads is in from 7 to 3i fathoms. Entrance. — Depths. — The entrance to the river, named the Guer or Leguer, is between points Dourvin and Serves ; it is fronted by a bar which dries at low water from 3 to 5 feet, and may be entered by vessels of 17 feet draught at high water, springs, and of 11 feet at neaps. The town of Lannion, with a population of about 6,000, is 3t? miles from the entrance in a direct line and nearly double that distance following the sinuosities of the river, which is 160 yards wide at Lannion, and has extensive quays on either side considering its very limited trade. Tides. — Bore. — The flood stream begins to make up the river, at the entrance, about one hour after low water, but not until 2 hours later at Lannion, at which place the ebb stream does not begin until one hour after high water. The flood stream has a maximum speed of 2 knots, the ebb stream, of 2\ knots. This river, as high as Lannion, is occasionally subject to the phenomenon known as the bore; this takes place only when strong south-westerly winds are veering to N.W., and always on the ebb ; the bore then comes up the river sometimes twice or thrice in one tide, and with sufficient violence to capsize small boats. LIGHT. — On Begleguer point, half a mile northward of the entrance to the river, from the western face of the keepers's house, is exhibited at 161 feet above high water and through an arc of 125°, a fixed light with green, white, and red sectors, visible respectively 7, 13, and 9 miles. The green sector covers 80°, from N. by E. f E. easterly to E. by S. \ S. The white sector covers 13|°, from E. by S. \ S. to S.E. by E. \ E. easterly. The red sector covers 31|°, from S.E. by E. \ E. easterly to S.S.E. f E. easterly. The green sector shows See chart, No. 2,644.

II. over the Kinierbel rock and all the foul ground southward of the road stead ; the white light, over the ground clear of all danger as far westward as the Chaises de Primel ; and, the red light, over the Taureau, Four, and Crapeaud rocks, which latter dangers are also covered when coming from the northward or eastward by the red sector of the Triagoz light. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station at point Bihit on the northern side of Lannion roads ; see page 12. Between Lannion and Perros bays is a promontory of which ile Grande, almost connected with the shore, and point Ploumenac'h or Mean Ruz, are the north-western and north-eastern extremes. Besides the Crapeaud and adjacent ledges already mentioned, the coast, in this part is bordered by innumerable islets, rocks, and ledges, extending 2 miles from the north-western shore, and making any approach to it extremely dangerous. N. by W. \ W. 5 miles from the centre of ile Grande is Triagoz lighthouse ; and Sept-iles light house lies N. by E. 2f miles from point Mean Ruz. PLATEAU de TRIAGOZ.— This dangerous ledge is about 4£ miles in extent W. by N. \ N. and E. by S. \ S. and about one mile wide ; its eastern end, on which are high rocks always uncovered, lies W.N.W. more than 4 miles from the Sept-iles. There are numerous rocky patches on the body of the ledge, but near its western end there is one, named the Fouillie, with only 14 feet water, from which Triagoz lighthouse bears S.E. § E. 3 miles ; ile de Bas lighthouse W. by S. \ S. 14^ miles ; and, the Fourchie, the highest rock at the eastern end of the ledge S.E. by E. \ E. 3 miles. The summit of the Fourchie is 34 feet above the highest tides. The channel between the plateau de Triagoz and the Sept-iles is 4 miles wide, safe, and clear of danger. LIGHT. — The lighthouse, a square stone tower, 82 feet high, stands on Guen Bras rock, Plateau de Triagoz, and, from it, ile de Bas light bears W. f S. 16^ miles, and Sept-iles light E. by S. £ S. 6| miles. The lighthouse shows, at 98 feet above high water, a fixed and flashing light, the flashes are alternately red and white every half minute, visible 16 miles. Between the bearings N.N.E. E. and N. \ W., over the shoals westward of ile Grande, the light shows entirely red, the flashes being visible 16 miles and the fixed light 10 miles. See ohart, No. 2,644.

Chap. II.] PLATEAU DE TRIAGOZ. — SEPT-ILES.— LIGHTS. 49 Fog bell.— During foggy weather, a bell is sounded every four seconds ; see fog signals, page 12. Caution. — At night, as soon as the light on ile de Bas is sighted a vessel running eastward with the flood stream should steer to pass well northward of it, and after passing it should not bring it westward of S.W. by W. J W., in order to clear the Triagoz ledge by 3 miles ; for, this stream sets strongly to the South-east and does not turn in the offing until 3J hours after high water by the shore. The SEPT-ILES, or Seven isles, are high and barren, and in clear weather may be seen 21 miles distant. The lighthouse on them bears W. by N. 16-} miles from Heaux lighthouse, and E. by S. S. 6^ miles from Triagoz lighthouse. The isles, with their rocks, ledges, and adjacent shoals, occupy a space 2\ miles wide and 4^ miles long in an E. by N. and W. by S. direction. LIGHT. — From a square lighthouse attached to a circular tower 52 feet high, on the eastern end of the southernmost isle, the ile-aux- Moines or Monk's isle, is exhibited, at 184 feet above high water, a fixed ivhite light, varied every three minutes by a flash. The flashes are preceded and followed by short eclipses which are not total within a distance of 6 miles. The light is dioptric, of the third order, and is visible 20 miles, except when bearing about S. 85° W., when it is obscured through an arc of 3° by Rougic isle and the eastern end of Bono isle. Bell-buoy. — To facilitate the navigation of the channel between the Sept-iles and the mainland, a black bell-buoy is moored south ward of the Dervinis, the southernmost rocks of the group. A Life-Boat is stationed at the ile-aux-Moines. The dangers between Sept-iles and the Plateau des Heaux mostly rise from depths of about 18 fathoms. Vessels passing outside Sept-iles and steering eastward should therefore keep well outside that depth. Sept-iles lighthouse kept bearing southward of West until Heaux lighthouse is seen, and it, in turn, kept well southward of S.E. when within 5 or 6 miles of it, leads well outside all dangers. The channel between Sept-iles and the mainland though narrow is available in case of need for the largest ships ; the tidal streams through it are very strong, at springs, rendering it dangerous to small vessels in bad weather with wind against tide. See chart, N». 2,644.

PLOUMANAC'H LIGHT— On Mean Ruz, the north-eastern extreme of Ploumanac'h point, at 69 feet above high water, is exhibited from a square lighthouse, 36 feet high, a fixed red light, visible 5 miles. Semaphore. — There is also a Semaphore station on Ploumanac'h point, and westward of the point is the little tidal harbour of Ploumanac'h ; see page 12. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Ploumanac'h at 5h. 15m. ; springs rise 24J feet, neaps 18^ feet above the soundings. ANSE de PERROS.— Depths.— This bay, 1% miles wide at the entrance, is 2\ miles south-eastward from Mean Ruz ; it affords good shelter from westerly winds to vessels that can take the ground. Those of light draught may lie afloat in the outer part of the bay, between which and the port at its head, which is almost dry at neaps, and has only 7 or 8 feet at high water springs, the beaching places, on a bottom of muddy sand about 9^ feet above the lowest tides, are excellent. Tome, a narrow islet nearly a mile in length N. by E. and S. by W., is one mile north-eastward from the western point of the bay ; its outer rocks, the Couillons de Tome, N.N.W. 7 or 8 cables from the northern end of the islet, are marked on their western sides bjT a red spindle buoy. The highest part of the islet is about a third of its length from the northern end. The little town of Perros-Guirec has about 2,800 inhabitants ; its port is protected on the east byT the Lenquin jetty 165 yards in length, a great portion of which is available as a quay, the total quay frontage of the port being no less than 515 yards. There is little or no trade, the harbour being used chiefly as a refuge for coasters, which frequently run from the outer roadstead for shelter at high water, springs, but in so doing run the risk of being neaped. LIGHTS. — At Nantouar, in Perros bay, two fixed white lights are exhibited ; that close to the shore, near Nantouar bridge, is 33 feet above high water, and visible 10 miles ; the inner light, at Kerjean, S. 20° E., 750 yards from the former, is 253 feet above high water and visible 14 miles. Nantouar light is attached to a white house ; Kerjean lighthouse is a white tower near a farm-house. The two lighthouses in line by day, or the lights by night, lead into Perros bay through the north-western passage. See chart, No. 2,644.;

Chap. II.] ANSE DE PERROS. — LIGHTS. — DIRECTIONS. 51 Two fixed white lights are also exhibited at the port of Perros, viz., the Colombier light, shown from a house at 110 yards behind the Colombier day-mark, 89 feet above high water, visible 14 miles ; and, an inner light, from a gibbet on a house, at Kerprigent, S. 59° W. 3,133 yards from the other, 259 feet above high water, also visible 14 miles. The two lighthouses in line by day, or the lights by night, lead into the bay through the eastern channel. None of these lights are visible more than 18° on either side of the direction they are intended to indicate. The Colombier day-mark is a white tower serving as a beacon and visible many miles seaward. A Life-Boat is stationed at Perros. Directions.— Coming from the westward in-shore, Rougic ile hidden by the ile de Bono, Sept-iles, leads between the Triagoz and all the shoals northward and eastward of ile Grande ; and, when the southern end of ile Tome is open of Mean Ruz, a course of about E. | S. leads between the Sept-iles and the northern end of ile Tome, bearing in mind that the tidal stream sometimes sets through this channel at the rate of 5 knots. If desirous of entering Perros bay from the north-westward, steer in for the southern end of Tome until Nantouar and Kerjean lighthouses are in line ; with this mark on, pass westward of two pointed rocks named the Bilzic, marked by a black beacon turret, which lie nearly a mile off its western side and uncover 22 and 32 feet, and eastward of the Fronde rock, marked by a red spherical buoy, and of the red beacon turret on Bernard rock, about 2 cables from the western point of the bay. Four patches, of which the highest is awash at low water, lie between this latter rock and the Pierre du Chenal, marked by a beacon turret painted with red and white bands ; therefore, at low water, do not proceed farther southward than to have Perros church opening southward of the hill on the western point of the bay. But, if proceeding to the port of Perros-Guirec, with a proper rise of tide, be careful to haul to the westward in good time to bring the Kerprigent and Colombier lighthouses in line, which mark leads up to the port ; and great care is necessary, for a vessel overrunning this line will be upon the rocks. Bound into Perros bay from the eastward, through the north eastern channel, which has as little as 3 feet water at one part at lowest equinoctial springs, pass north-westward of the black conical See chart, No. 2,644.

II. 52 buoy marking the Guazer rocks at the outer edge of the Four ledge, by not going southward of the line of the high steeple of Notre Dame de Clarte on with the highest part of ile Tome. As soon as the Colombier and Kerprigent lighthouses are seen, bring them in line and steer for them. This leading mark clears all the reefs ex tending from the mainland, including the Crebineyers, marked by a black buoy ; it also passes very close on the starboard hand the Pierre Jean Rousic, off the southern end of ile Tome, which un covers one foot, and the Pierre du Chenal beacon turret, which bears about S.W. | S. 5 cables from the southern end of ile Tome and which rock uncovers 14 feet. After passing close southward of this beacon turret, the vessel may anchor about 1| cables south-westward of it, in from 11 to 14 feet water ; or, with a proper rise of tide, the same mark will lead her on past the black beacon turrets on the Roc'h Hu and Barr Goalenou on the port hand, and the red beacon of Craou on the starboard hand ; and, after passing the latter, she may haul up for the pier-head and enter the port. By night. — Nantouar and Kerjean lights in line lead through the western passage into Perros bay ; Colombier and Kerprigent lights in line, through the eastern passage. Vessels entering by the western channel should observe the caution already given and leave the line of the two former lights in one, the moment the Colombier and Kerprigent lights come in sight, to avoid overrunning their line of direction. PORT BLANC. — From Perros bay to point du Chateau, the western point of entrance to the river Treguier, the coast trends East 9 miles and is fronted by innumerable rocks both above and below water, extending from 1^ to 2 miles off-shore. About midway is a little inlet with from 3 to 2\ fathoms named port Blanc, with Chateau Neuf isle and the Four ledge on the western side of its entrance, and Leverette and St. Gildas isles on the eastern side. The port is well sheltered and affords safe refuge for coasters during south-westerly gales but is open to winds from N.W. round by North to N.E., and vessels caught by such winds frequently run ashore under the lee of St. Gildas isle on a soft weedy bottom. With the wind eastward of N.E. the anchorage is considered preferable to that in Perros bay. The leading mark in is, Comtesse white mill on with the white beacon tower just eastward of the Voleur rock S. § E. easterly. See chart, No. 2,644,

Chap. II.] PORT BLANC— TREGUIER RIVER. 53 Harbour light. — From a small turret on the Voleur rock at the head of the harbour is exhibited a fixed green light, visible, approxi mately, between S. 3° W. and S. 27° E. at a distance of 5 miles. Depths. — A vessel will not have less than 22 feet by anchoring north-westward of the Louet, a large rock on the eastern side of the port, but better shelter in less water may be found farther in. If she can take the ground, good beaching places may be found East and E.S.E. of the Voleur, where the bottom is 10^ feet above the level of the lowest tides. Semaphore. — -There is a Semaphore station at port Blanc; see page 12. TREGUIER or JAUDY RIVER, the entrance to which is 9 miles in an E.S.E. direction from the north-eastern ledge of the Sept-iles plateau, and 3^ miles westward of Heaux light house, fully described at page 57, affords good shelter but is difficult of access to sailing vessels, and with gales from N.N.W. to E.N.E., a heavy sea runs at the entrance on the ebb. Depths. — The entrance, otherwise deep, is crossed by a bar with only 3 feet water between ile d'Er and Corne rock, which bar has over it at high water, springs, 29 feet, and at neaps 24 feet, The general depths, when within, are from 5 fathoms near the entrance to 2 fathoms near Treguier ; to which depths must be added for high water, a rise of 25 feet at springs, and 18^ feet at neaps. From the entrance nearly up to the little town of Treguier, a distance of 6 miles, the channel is generally over 300 yards wide ; near the town it narrows, and at one place is only 50 or 60 yards wide. The town has about 3,500 inhabitants, has good quays with soft mud berths alongside, but being 16 miles from the nearest railway, has little or no trade. The river is spanned by a suspension bridge at Treguier. The three channels leading to the river entrance are, the Grande Passe, Passe du N.E., and Passe de la Gaine. They are all well buoyed and beaconed on the French uniform system ; see page 14. Grande Passe leads to the entrance from the north-westward and is practicable for vessels of any draught at high water. For this channel, keep St. Antoine mill exactly on with the mill of Port de la Chaine, or, the white lighthouses of la Chaine and St. Antoine in one S.S.E. \ E. easterly, and the vessel will pass about 3 cables westward of the black conical buoy marking the Crublent shoal and the same distance eastward of the Renauds rocks, which See chart, No. 2,669 *.

[Chap. II. 54 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. never cover, and over a patch of 22 feet, which, with the leading mark on, is the least depth in this channel ; she will also pass about a cable eastward of Pierre a l'Anglais rock which uncovers 8 feet, and still closer to the red spherical buoy marking the Petit-pen-ar- Guezec shoal, the highest heads of which dry 3 feet ; and, 2 cables westward of the black beacon on the Corbeau rock, which uncovers 19 feet. By night, the red and white lights in line S.S.E. easterly lead through the Grande Passe. Passe du N.E. — The large spire of Treguier cathedral exactly on with the white tower on the Skeiviec rock, which tower is 30 feet above the level of high water, bearing S.W. southerly, leads to the entrance of the river ; but, this line crosses the Jument ledge, the western extreme of which lies N.W. by W. nearly 2 miles from Heaux lighthouse and is marked by a red conical bell-buoy moored off its northern edge ; the leading mark must therefore be left, both on entering and leaving the river, to pass westward of the ledge and buoy. Vessels not drawing more than 17 feet, having rounded the western end of the Jument, may, with this leading mark on, cross the Basses de Roc'h Hir after half flood, or if the Petit Roc'h Hir is covered. This rock lies on the north-eastern part of the ledge and uncovers 13 feet. This channel should only be used with smooth water. Passe de la Gaine, the most easterly channel, is practicable with smooth water for vessels of 14 feet draught after 3^ hours' flood, and is useful when approaching from the eastward if there is sufficient wind to stem the tide. The entrance is between the Heaux and Sark rocks ; the leading mark is, the white beacon wall in the south-eastern part of the village of Plougrescan on with the white pyramid of Men-Noblance, on the southern part of ile d'Er, bearing W. by S. This leads a vessel nearly half a mile southward of Heaux lighthouse and over the Pont de la Gaine, a narrow cut in the ledge extending from the southern end of the Duono rocks, with only one foot water at the lowest tides. LIGHTS. — Three lights are exhibited at the entrance of the Treguier river. La Chaine. — Near the harbour mill of port de la Chaine is a fixed white light, visible 9 miles, 36 feet above high water, exhibited from the keeper's house, which is white. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Corne rock. — From a lighthouse on the Come rock, on the eastern side of the entrance, is exhibited a fixed light, 38 feet above high water, showing sectors of green, red, and ivhite, as follows : — green on a W.S.W. bearing, through an angle of 1\°, or between the Petit Pen-ar-Guezec and the shoal of port Beni ; red eastward of the green sector ; and ivhite on an E.N.E. bearing, through an angle of 1\°. The green light is visible only 4 miles, the red 5 miles, and the white 9 miles ; but the light is unwatched and therefore cannot be implicitly relied on. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on Creach-ar-Maout hill nearly a mile N. 77° E. from port de la Chaine lights ; see page 12. Life-Boat, &C. — A life-boat and mortar apparatus with other life-saving a'ppliances are stationed at port de la Chaine. Pilots. — The pilots of Treguier seldom cruise off the port, it being difficult for their small boats to keep or get to sea with on-shore winds. In such a case, a vessel from the westward would do well to secure a pilot at Ploumanac'h ; or, if from the eastward, at ile de Brehat. Anchorages. — From abreast of the Skeiviec rock, H miles within the entrance, to the town of Treguier, the river is deep enough* for coasters always to remain afloat. It has three anchorages, well sheltered from wind and tide, of which the best and most convenient is the Palamos anchorage, about 2 miles within the Skeiviec, where the depths are from 2\ to 4 fathoms. After passing between the beacon on the Taureau and the Corne rock, which rocks are about 1£ miles within the Petit Pen-ar-Guezec buoy (and, between them, the channel is not more than 150 yards wide), and southward of the Taureau bank red buoy steer up the river keeping midway between the rocks bordering its banks. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the Treguier river at 5h. 22m. ; equinoctial springs rise about 35 feet, ordinary springs 26 feet, and neaps 21 feet above the soundings. The flood stream, which sets into this river, rounds the northern shore of ile d'Er until the bank connecting this isle with the main is covered, which takes place at about half flood ; it then slackens at the entrance of the river and runs eastward. THE COAST.— Baie de Saint Brieuc— Between the plateau des Heaux and ile de Brehat is the north-eastern entrance to the Trieux river, and on the opposite side of the ile is its eastern entrance. Between ile de Brehat and cape Frehel, distant 28^ miles on a S.E. h E. bearing, the coast line falls back, forming the deep bight named the Baie de Saint Brieuc. The approach to the western entrance of the bay is indicated at night by the fixed white light on the plateau des Heaux, and in the day by Creach-ar-Maout hill, about 3 miles S.S.W. from the light, This hill forms the abrupt termination northward of the high land separating the river Trieux from the Treguier ; on its summit is a guard-house with the Sema phore before described close to it. The bay is on all sides much encumbered by rocks and shoals both in-shore and in the offing. The land is generally high and may be seen in clear weather about 22 miles distant. In very clear weather, the summits of the central chain of Bretagne hills are visible, and amongst others the Mener-Bel-Air and the Mener-Bre ; the former rises southward, and the latter south-westward of the bay. When bound westward from cape Frehel, the parts first seen are cape d'Erqui and Bien-Assis wood on the eastern side, and then Plouha point and the small town of Plouzec on the western side of the bay. The Rade de Brehat, with the ports of Trieux, Paimpol, Portrieux, and Binic, are on the western side of the bay ; in the southern part is port Legue and the town of Saint Brieuc, with the large shallow See chart, No. 2,669 b.

BRIEUC BAY. — ROCHES-DOUVRES. 59 Anse d'Yffiniac adjoining ; and, on the eastern side is the port of Dahouet, north-eastward of which is the high and steep point of Pleneuf, which juts out boldly from the land 3| miles W.S.W. of cape d'Erqui. The Verdelet, a conical-shaped islet, lies 2 cables north-westward of Pleneuf point, between which point, and cape d'Erqui the shore is generally low and exposed to the North-west, but the rade d'Erqui affords good shelter with easterly winds. The hills, at this part, rise suddenly a short distance within high-water mark and unite with the high lands in the interior ; Bien-Assis wood, on their summit, may be recognised at a great distance. Cape d'Erqui is a lofty promontory terminating in a steep slope on its western face ; between it and cape Frehel, 7£ miles eastward, the shore is composed of high rocky cliffs, with the exception of a small sandy beach under the village of Pleherel. The little inlet, Bouche d'Erqui, lies 3 miles eastward of the cape of that name. CAUTION. — As all dangers between ile de Brehat and cape Frehel rise from soundings of less than 18 fathoms, the prudent seaman will at night or in thick weather keep without that depth. The off-lying dangers, Basse Maurice, plateau de Barnouic, and plateau des Roches-Douvres, are not included in this caution, they being surrounded by much deeper water. PLATEAU des ROCHES-DOUVRES. — This dangerous rocky ledge, the outermost of the off-lying dangers fronting St. Brieuc bay, occupies a space 3^ miles long N.N.W. and S.S.E. and 2h miles wide ; from it rises a group of 12 rocky heads which never cover. The highest head of the plateau is about 9 feet above the highest tides, and is in the middle of the group ; on it stands a white iron lighthouse. The north-western edge of the ledge bears N.E. | E., and the south-eastern edge E.N.E. northerly about 15^ miles from Heaux lighthouse. For tidal Streams in this vicinity, see Table on following page, and also general description at page 224. LIGHT. — From the white iron lighthouse at 180 feet above high water, is exhibited a white flashing light, visible 20 miles, showing a flash every four seconds, with a dark interval of three seconds. III.] ROCHES-DOUVRES. — TIDES. — PLATEAU DE BARNOUIC. 61 From Roches-Douvres lighthouse, Hanois lighthouse, Guernsey, bears N.N.E. § E. 20 miles ; Gautier rocks on Barnouic ledge S. by W. | W. 5 miles ; Heaux lighthouse S.W. by W. £ W. 15f miles ; and Grand Lejon lighthouse S. -} W. 22 miles. Fog" Signal. — During foggy weather a bell is sounded giving fourteen strokes at intervals of one second, then an interval of six seconds, then a double stroke, then another interval of six seconds, then fourteen strokes, &c. ; see page 11. PLATEAU de BARNOUIC— About 12| miles E. by N. \ N. from Heaux lighthouse, and N.E. \ N. 8|- miles from the Horaine rock, are the Gautier rocks, near the middle of the Plateau de Barnouic , a dangerous rocky ledge, of which the southern edge lies E. f N. from Heaux lighthouse. The Gautier rocks uncover 14 feet at the lowest tides, and are awash at low water, neaps. The Barnouic rock, of conical form, bears E. \ N. about 7£ cables from the Gautier rocks ; it uncovers 2'&\ feet, covers 2\ hours before high water, springs, and is awash at high water, neaps. This plateau, of which the Barnouic and Gautier are the highest rocks, extends from the Barnouic rock about one mile eastward, about 1\ miles S.S.W., 2\ miles N.W. by W., and 2 miles N.N.W. The most westerly rocky patches, one of which has only 3 feet water, bear N.E. by E. f E. 11^ miles from Heaux lighthouse. There are from 10 to 15 fathoms on parts of the plateau, but the sea at times breaks over its whole extent. The Roches-Douvres and Barnouic ledge are separated by a channel more than 2 miles wide, carrying a depth of from 20 to 30 fathoms. It should, however, be avoided by sailing vessels, as the streams set with great strength over both ledges. If forced to pass through it, endeavour to keep nearer the Douvres than the Barnouic. A vessel will keep westward of both ledges by not bringing Heaux lighthouse more westerly than S.W. \ W. Basse Maurice is a small rocky patch in the channel between the Plateau de Barnouic and the shore ; from its shoalest spot of 7 fathoms, Heaux lighthouse bears W. § S. southerly nearly 7 miles ; Paon lighthouse, ile de Brehat, S.W. | S. 6 miles ; the guard-house on Creach-ar-Maout hill is on with the Louet rock beacon W.S.W. ; and, See chart, No. 2,669 b.

62 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. Ill- Plouha point is a little open westward of the Horaine rock, S. by W. Although the depth is never less than 7 fathoms on this shoal, it should be avoided in bad weather, as a heavy sea runs over it during a weather tide. Roc'h.-ar-Bel.— This shoal patch of 20 feet lies at the north-eastern extreme of the great rocky flat extending 5 miles from the shore which separates the entrances of the rivers Trieux and Treguier, and of which the Heaux rocks form a part. From it, Heaux lighthouse bears W. £ N. 3^ miles ; and, the guard-house on Creach-ar-Maout hill is on with the Sark rocks. Carec-Mingui, a rocky patch of 11 feet, lies 3 cables westward of the Roc'h-ar-Bel. Heaux lighthouse bearing W. £ S. leads southward of the Basse Maurice, and northward of the Carec-Mingui and Roc'h-ar-Bel shoals, over which shoals the tide, at springs, sets with a velocity of 5 knots. Extensive rocky ledges, lying in a general easterly and westerly direction, extend 5 or 6 miles eastward and south-eastward of ile de Brehat, and on them several rocky heads dry at low water. The northernmost ledges are the Horaine and Echaudes ; the southern most, Men-Marc'h and Ringue-bras ; between them are navigable channels leading to Brehat road. Outside of the rocky limits, and 5i miles from the nearest land, pointe de Plouzec, numerous banks of sand, under the general name of Banes de Sable, extend 4£ miles in a S. by E. direction from their northern end, near the eastern extreme of the plateau de Men-Marc'h ; on some of these banks the depth is as little as 2\ fathoms. PLATEAU de LA HORAINE.— Refuge beacon.— This rocky ledge is 1J miles in extent, N.E. and S.W., and one mile wide ; it has many rocky heads awash and nearly awash at low water, and one head, the Horaine rock, on which is a refuge beacon, about a mile within the northern extreme the ledge, bearing S.E. by E. | E. 6§ miles from Heaux lighthouse and E. by N. N. 3 miles from Paon lighthouse, uncovers 22 feet at the lowest tides, and is awash about 2j hours before high water. The Horaine rock refuge beacon has been so often washed away that it cannot as yet be depended on ; the new beacon, of more solid construction than its predecessors, was completed in the summer See chart, No. 2,669 b.
