III. 64 PLATEAU de MEN-MARCH.— Bell-buoy.— This plateau is south-eastward of the Horaine and Echaudes reefs ; and, between them is a channel leading to Brehat road. It is 3 miles long E. by N. | N. and W. by S. \ S., and 1J miles broad at its widest part ; the only rocky head visible at the lowest tides is the Men- Marc'h in the south-eastern part, which then uncovers 2 feet, and is at all times dangerous on account of the eddies in its vicinity. Numerous shoal patches of from 2 feet, near the western edge, to 1|- and 3| fathoms at the north-western part of the ledge, lie west ward and northward of this rock. A red conical bell-buoy is moored off the north-eastern end of the plateau in about 10 fathoms. PLATEAU du RINGUE-BRAS is the next ledge southward of the Men-Marc'h, and between them is a channel leading to Brehat road ; it is 3 miles long East and West, and about a mile wide at its broadest part towards the eastern end. The Basse de l'Ascension, the highest head on this ledge, is near its eastern extreme, and has only from 3 to 6 feet over it at the lowest tides. Directions. — Vessels from the westward bound to any of the ports in St. Brieuc bay, or to St. Malo or Granville, generally pass between Barnouic and Horaine ledges. This channel is 7 miles wide, the tidal streams follow its direction, and, as before stated, the Basse Maurice, the only rocky patch in the channel, need be avoided in bad weather only. A vessel using this channel should steer to pass within 4 miles of Heaux lighthouse, and as it is approached keep it well southward of S.E. to avoid the dangers westward of it. When eastward of its meridian, it should not be brought westward of W, \ S. until the guard-house on Creach-ar-Maout hill is on with the Sark rocks S.W. by W. | W. The vessel is then eastward of the Roc'h-ar-Bel, and the lighthouse may be brought to bear W. f N., on which bearing it leads between the Basse Maurice and the red bell-buoy of the Horaine. From the south-eastward, a vessel is in the fairway of this channel when Heaux lighthouse bears W. | N., and it is necessary to have it on this bearing before she is abreast of the plateau de la Horaine, which position will be ensured by not crossing the line of Ste. Barbe mill on with the highest part of the crest of St. Riom isle bearing about S.W. until the old mill on ile de Brehat, without sails, a red roof, and a broad white band below the roof, is quite open westward of the white pyramid on Ar-Morbic rock, or until the See chart, No. 2,669 *.

Chap. III.] SHOALS. — TIDAL STREAMS.— TRIEUX RIVER. 65 Heaux rocks appear quite open northward of the Sark rocks. To avoid the Roc'h-ar-Bel, Heaux lighthouse must he brought to bear W. S. Having passed westward of the meridian of Heaux light house, and until 5 or 6 miles from it, keep it well southward of S.E. to avoid all dangers westward of it. Tidal Streams. — Between the plateau de Barnouic and Basse Maurice the flood stream sets S.E. by S., and ceases about an hour after high water by the shore at ile de Brehat ; its greatest velocity, about 4| knots, is at about half flood. The ebb runs in the opposite direction, and ceases about an hour after low water by the shore ; its strength is nearly equal to that of the flood. At a mile north ward of Heaux lighthouse, the flood sets S.E. by E., the ebb N.W. by W., with about the same strength. Close to the edge of the rocks it is somewhat stronger, running at the rate of 5 knots past the Heaux, over the Roc'h-ar-Bel, and both round and over the north eastern edge of the Horaine. The whirls and eddies occasionally met with in the channel between the Horaine and Barnouic ledges, are strong but not dangerous ; the most considerable is produced by the Basse Maurice. TRIEUX RIVER. — Four channels lead into this river, which is tidal as far as Pontrieux, 16 miles above Paon point lighthouse ; one only, the Grand Chenal or Trieux channel, is available for large ships at all times by day or night, and neither of the others should be attempted without the aid of a pilot. The Trieux channel is the northern entrance between the Roc'h ar-Bel and Horaine ledges. Small vessels may enter from the westward at any time of tide, by day, through the Moisie and Men-du-Castrec channels ; and, from the eastward, through the Ferlas channel, which latter is practicable for vessels of deep draught from half flood to half ebb, but can be used only by coasters at low water, springs. Depths. — The least depth in the main channel of the river as high as the suspension bridge above Lezardrieux is, at the lowest tides, 4 fathoms ; at high water, springs, 9 fathoms ; and at neaps, 1\ fathoms. Above the bridge the depths are considerable and the river navigable for small craft as far as Pontrieux, where it is dammed. Everywhere within the entrance above the anchorages, however, the channel is extremely narrow and tortuous. Buoyage. — The several entrance channels are all well buoyed and beaconed in accordance with the French uniform system. See charts, Nos. 2,669 * and 2,567.

66 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. III. Anchorages.— Several anchorages in the entrance of this river afford refuge to vessels of deep draught, but they are difficult of access, especially on the ebb. As the holding-ground is bad and the stream rapid, in the middle of the river, ships should anchor as near the edge of the mud-banks as possible on either side. Pomelin road is on the northern side of the river, about 2\ miles within Paon light, and the marks for the best anchorage, in 30 feet and out of the tide, are, the old mill on Brehat just open northward of the ruins on ile Verte ; and, the new mill of Loguivi seen between point du Gouern and Conan rock. A vessel should moor North and South in Pomelin road. There is also anchorage north-eastward of this, near the outer edge of the mud-banks which uncover as far southward as the line of Croix rock lighthouse on with Loguivi mill ; vessels should moor here W.N.W. and E.S.E. Another good and well sheltered anchorage in which the streams have not much strength, and with sufficient room and depth for large ships, is near the edge of the mud-banks south-eastward of the ile de Bois, a high steep island close to the western point of entrance to the river, on which stands a guard-house. The anchoring ground here extends in a south-westerly direction from the line of the beacon turret on Vieille de Loguivi rock on with Arcouest mill ; anchor in 7^ fathoms with the two lighthouses at Coat-Mer in line ; and, Loguivi guard-house between the two mills, rather nearer the old mill than the new ; moor here also W.N.W. and E.S.E. The first anchorage within the river for a vessel of deep draught is near the right bank with Coat-Mer lighthouses in line, and north westward of a large rock named Melus, which lies fronting the Douane or Custom-house office on the Roc'h-ar-On ; a large vessel should not venture beyond this at night, but should anchor the moment Heaux light is shut in by ile de Bois. There is room for two moderate sized vessels between Bodic light tower and Sabot-du- Sud rock ; also, excellent holding-ground on both sides of the river out of the strength of the stream southward of Coat-Mer cove, and south-westward of a water-mill abreast of the cove. Lezardrieux, a little port on the left or western bank, on the opposite side to the deep channel of the river nearly 2\ miles above the Custom-house office on the Roc'h-ar-On, is full of rocks and dries at low water of all tides, though it has as much as 30 feet in the entrance at high water, springs, and 20 feet at neaps. III.] TRIEUX RIVER.— ANCHORAGES.— LIGHTS. 67 light draught are neaped within it for 4 or 5 days ; but. at its entrance among the rocks, there is a bottom of soft mud, on which two or three coasters can ground without being neaped. Vessels of 6 to 8 feet draught can generally remain afloat between this port and a rocky ledge on the western side of the deep channel. Those bound up to Pontrieux, anchor here to wait for sufficient water when they arrive during neaps ; or, during springs, to await the aid of a local pilot, without whomno vessel should attempt the difficult passages in the river between here and Pontrieux. The first of these passages named Ar-Toul-Tane, is at a sudden turn in the river, 4 cables above Lezardrieux suspension bridge, which bridge spans the river 108 feet above the lowest tides. The second passage is in the turn of the river under the high land and chateau of Roche- Jugut, one mile above which on its eastern side the Trieux receives the waters of the little river Left'. Pontrieux. — The little port of Pontrieux is on the right bank of the river, about half a mile below the town of that name, and 8 miles above Lezardrieux bridge. It has about 400 yards of quay frontage, all on the eastern side ; the berths at the foot of the quay dry about 22^ feet above the level of the lowest tides. The town is built on both sides of the river and has a population of about 2,500. Its trade is insignificant, and is carried on chiefly by coasters of from 30 to 100 tons, though it is possible for vessels of 300 tons to ascend as high as Pontrieux. The railway station at Guincamp, on the Paris and Brest line, is about 10 miles distant. LIGHTS. — On Paon point, at the north-eastern end of ile de Brehat, from a square lighthouse, is exhibited at 67 feet above high water, a fixed light, showing white through an arc of 8°, between N.N.W. \ W. and N.W. by N. ; also white through an arc of 45°, between N.E. \ E. and E. S. ; and obscured towards the land through an arc of 45°, between N. | E. and N.E. \ E. In all other directions it shows red. The white light is visible 13 miles, the red light 8 miles. On Rosedo hill, ile de Brehat, and 1,761 yards W. by S. \ S. from Paon point light, is a square lighthouse from which is shown, through an arc of 32°, a flashing white light 90 feet above high water, visible 15 miles. On entering the river, it also leads south-eastward of the red beacon turrets on Vieille du Treou, Rodello, Kerrannets, and Moguedhier rocks, and north-westward of the beacon turret on Petit-Pen-Azen, coloured with black and white bands, as well as of all the dangers off ile de Brehat, including the large pointed rock Chandelier, bordering on the North the entrance to the Kerpont passage, and the black beacon turret of Gosrod at the southern side of its entrance. Chap. III.] TRIEUX RIVER. — LIGHTS. — DIRECTIONS. 69 Gosrod beacon turret stands on a rock which uncovers about 13 feet, and is only 150 yards eastward of the fairway. The red beacon turret on the Moguedhier is about 1^ cables N.N.W. from the Croix lighthouse. Having arrived at a position 3 or 4 cables north-eastward of the Croix lighthouse, or before the vessel is abreast of the Moguedhier beacon turret, haul a little to starboard lo pass a safe distance west ward of the Croix lighthouse ; after which, bring the keeper's house on Coat-Mer peninsula on with the square white tower of the inner light, which leads to the inner anchorage between ile de Bois and Coat-Mer. By Night, enter the river with Croix and Bodic lights in line. and when Bodic light is hidden by Croix light-tower, as it will be to an eye 8 feet above the sea, when it is 1,800 yards distant, open out Bodic light westward of Croix light and pass the latter on its western side. Afterwards, proceed with the two inner fixed red lights in line to the anchorage of Coat-Mer. Moisie channel commences at the Moisie red beacon turret near the Sark rocks, and joins the Trieux channel near the red turret marking the Vieille du Treou. The flood stream, at springs, sets through at 4-^ or 5 knots in the direction of the channel until near the rock Noguejou-bian, on which is a red beacon, when it inclines south-westward towards ile St. Mode. The ebb is not quite so strong and takes more the direction of the channel as the tide falls. The leading mark is, the spire of St. Michel chapel, ile de Brehat, on with Rosedo white beacon tower S. 3° E. The channel is very narrow, but is convenient for vessels of moderate length and draught entering the river Trieux with a scant wind. Men-du-Castrec Channel has its entrance between the shoals Ar-Mesclek on the West and Men-du-Castrec on the East, and joins the Trieux channel at the same point as the Moisie. The tidal streams run at the rate of 4£ or 5 knots but follow the direction of the channel. The leading mark, the white pyramid on Arcouest point on with the red beacon turret of Vieille du Treou, leads through in mid-channel until near the latter, but over the eastern head of the shoal Ar-Gazec on which there are only 6 feet at low water, springs. As with the Moisie channel, this passage is used by vessels which cannot weather the Men-du-Castrec and Sirlots shoals See chart, No. 2,557.

Ferlas Channel. — This channel is available by day for vessels of 8 feet draught at low water, springs ; for vessels of 13 feet draught at low water, neaps ; and, for vessels of any draught at high water. To run from Brehat road into Trieux river through this channel, with the best water, weigh when the rock at the south-western point of Logodec islet has just covered ; it uncovers 22 feet at the lowest tides. Steer westward to pass midway between the black and white beacon turret on the Piliers and the red and white turret on the Vis-Argent rocks, and towards the Rompa red and black beacon turret, passing half a cable northward of the summits of Rouray, Conan, and Levret rocks, which latter border the southern side of the channel and never cover ; and southward of the Rout-ar-Linen red beacon, of the Trebeyou red turret, and of the Rompa beacon turret, which latter, however, may be passed on either side at half a cable ; after passing it, bring it and the Piliers beacon turret in line, and this mark leads into the Trieux channel, southward of the Tranquet rock and of the Vieille de Loguivi red and white beacon turret, and up to the direction of the two lighthouses of Coat-Mer in line. There is a passage connecting the Ferlas and Trieux channels east ward of the Tranquet and of the beacon on the Trou-blanc, named the Trou-blanc channel. The leading mark through is, the new mill of Loguivi kept on astern between the Conan rock and the steep declivity of the northern point of Gouern cove S. \ W. There are also other intricate channels connecting the Ferlas and Trieux channels. Loguivi. — Near the western entrance of the Ferlas channel is the little fishing port of Loguivi, useful to pilots and fishermen but of no importance. The harbour dries from 6 feet at the entrance to 22 feet within, at low water, springs. Pilots. — The Brehat and Trieux pilots keep at sea when the weather permits, and in fine weather may be found cruising or fishing as far seaward as the Roches-Douvres ; fishing-boats are often found near Heaux lighthouse, and their masters are generally good pilots and very useful until proper pilots are met with. If a vessel is bound to Pontrieux, or anywhere above the ile de Bois roadstead, See chart, No. 2,557.

Chap. III.] CHANNELS INTO TRIEUX RIVER.— ILE DE BREHAT 71 a river pilot is required. The head quarters of these pilots is at Lezardrieux. Tidal Streams. — The tidal streams off the entrance of the Trieux river have been already noticed at page 65. Within the entrance, between St. Mode isle and La Croix lighthouse, they follow the direction of the channel ; but, outside or north-eastward of Saint- Mode, they cross the channel with great strength, and it requires a fresh fair wind to keep the leading mark on. For time and rise of tides at the entrance of the Trieux river, see tides around ile de Brehat, page 77. ILE de BREHAT.— The south-western point of this isle is less than a mile from Arcouest point on the mainland, and it extends from thence 2 miles in a N.E. by N. direction to Paon point, but is nearly divided into two about its centre. The most conspicuous objects on it are, the lighthouses on Paon point and on the little mound of Rosedo, St. Michel chapel, the northern mill, the southern mill (le Vieux Moulin) which has no sails, a red roof, and a white band 9 feet wide below the roof. The most remarkable irregularities of outline are at Paon point, at the small hill where the chapel stands, and at the hillocks crowning both points of entrance to port Clos. The isle appears distinct from the coast on a South, S.W., or North bearing, but, unless very near, it becomes blended with the land when bearing between W.S.W. and N.W. The white pyramids placed on the Ar-Morbic, Louet, and Quistillic rocks, which front the eastern part of the isle, are also conspicuous Objects and may be seen at some distance. lie de Brehat has a population of over 1,000, mostly hardy fisher men and sailors, and it has three small ports, viz., Port de la Corderie on its north-western side, port Clos on its south-western side, and port la Chambre on its south-eastern side ; the first is entered from the Trieux channel, the last two from the rade de Brehat. The dangers already described surrounding this isle seaward are comprised between the lines of Heaux lighthouse bearing West, and the mill on the high land a little northward of Pomelin bay on with the south-western point of ile de Brehat N.W. by W. The tidal streams, especially at springs, rush with great velocity through this chain of dangers, and produce a violent race, which, at low water, can only be passed through without risk by thenarrowcut called the Brehat See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *. 1. III. 72 channel, which is 2 miles long in a S. \ W. and N. \ E. direction, passes about a mile eastward of Paon point, between the rocky ledges fronting the eastern side of the isle and the plateau des Echaudes, and is fully described at page 74. Semaphore.— There is a Semaphore station on ile de Brehat on the highest part of the island, about 260 yards southward of the lighthouse on Rosedo hill ; see page 12. A Life-Boat is stationed at Paon point, ile de Brehat. Port de la Corderie, on the north-western side of ile de Brehat is a grounding place where vessels of moderate draught find shelter, and at this little port is the government store of buoys, moorings, &c. its entrance, on the eastern side of the Kerpont channel, is only half a cable wide and open to the westward ; it is southward of the large rock Kervarec, 150 yards south-eastward of which is a rocky ledge marked by two black beacons. Only 100 yards southward of these is a red beacon marking the extreme of the rocks on the southern side. Depths. — Three mooring buoys lie in mid-channel to assist vessels in taking up their berths. At the outer buoy the harbour dries 5 feet at low water, springs, and there are from 26 feet at high water, springs, to 18^ feet at neaps. At the middle buoy there are 3 feet less water, and at the inner buoy 4 feet less than at the outer buoy. Vessels he aground on a bottom of mud and sand from the entrance to the head of the port. The best berth for vessels of about 15 feet draught is 2 cables within the entrance. Small coasters lie eastward of this position, and sometimes in the middle of the little cove at the head of the port, where there are from 5 to 6 feet less water than in the channel. Port Clos, on the southern side of ile de Brehat between the southern entrances of Kerpont channel and Brehat road, dries through out at low water, and although difficult of access, affords refuge to coasting vessels capable of taking the ground, having within the causeway described 20 feet at high water, springs, and 12 feet at neaps. Three rocks, in a straight line N.E. and S.W., divide the entrance of this port in two parts. The most southern, named Men-Allen, is near low-water mark and uncovers about 19 feet ; the second is about half a cable farther in, and also uncovers 19 feet ; the third is about a cable northward of the second and uncovers 26 feet. See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 b.

Chap. III.] PORTS C0RDERIE, CLOS, AND CHAMBRE.-BREHAT ROAD. 73 This latter rock is joined to the western shore of the port by a cause way, which serves as a landing place, and which, when uncovered, shelters the inner part of the port. The bottom at the foot of the causeway dries 1-| feet at the lowest tides ; the best berth is half a cable N.N.E. of the rock at the end of the causeway, where the bottom dries nearly 11 feet. Most vessels, however, lie outside the causeway, about half a cable S.S.E. of the rock ; the grounding places here are good, but anchors have but little hold, and at high water it is exposed to winds from between W.S.W. and S.S.E. Port la Chambre. — If surprised in Brehat road by strong easterly winds, a vessel that can take the ground will find good shelter in port la Chambre, between the south-eastern part of ile de Brehat and Logodec and Lavrec islets. It dries at low water, and its principal entrance, about 100 yards wide, is between the rocks at the south-eastern point of the isle, and those adjacent to the western side of Logodec. A vessel cannot proceed farther into this port than the large islet lying abreast of the northern end of Logodec, which divides the channel into two branches. The best berth is about 150 yards southward of that islet, where the bottom dries about 9 feet, and where there are 22 feet at high water, springs, and 14 feet at neaps. A clump of trees surrounding Ste. Barbe chapel bearing about S.S.W., and touching the eastern side of a large rock named the Chateau, just westward of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest leads to the entrance. Rade de Brehat, on the southern side of ile de Brehat, is the only place between Heaux lighthouse and cape Frehel in which vessels of moderate draught can find shelter during strong winds from N.N.E. to N.N.W. The best holding-ground trends East and West, in the direction of the white guard-house on ile de Bois on with the southern face of a high rock named Men-ar-Vran W. by N. i N. ; its eastern limit is the eastern face of Mets de Goelo islet on with the Men-Gam rock, on which rock is a beacon turret with black and white horizontal bands and black topmark, denoting the point of separation of the Ferlas and Lastel channels ; and, its western limit, Ste. Barbe mill on with La Trinite point S. by W. \ W., westerly. The best anchorage is with ile de Bois guard-house on with the southern face of Men-ar-Vran ; and, Ste. Barbe mill, or the trees of Ste. Barbe chapel, on with the summit of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *. E 2 SO 11886

DIRECTIONS for approaching RADE de BREHAT from the WESTWARD.— If wishing to seek shelter in this road from strong winds between N.N.W. and N.N.E. when pilots are not to be found in the offing, wait if possible N.N.E. of Heaux lighthouse until half flood, when the tide will have risen in the vicinity of ile de Brehat about 18| feet. At this time, a vessel may run through Brehat channel into Brehat road without risk, for the channel, which is only 2 cables wide at low water, is then 5 cables wide. Chenal de Brehat. — Having rounded the Roc'h-ar-Bel ledge, the leading mark through Brehat channel is, the white pyramid beacon on the Cormorandiere rock on with the white beacon tower at Port Moguer, near Plouha point, bearing S. | W. ; this line leads 6 cables westward of the Pain de Bray rock and leaves the whole plateau des Echaudes on the port hand, passing its nearest rock, the Cadic, which has 15 feet on it at low water, at 1£ cables. It also leaves on the starboard hand, the Roc'h-ar-Bel at 4 cables, the Men du-Castrec at 8 cables, and the Pen-Azen rocks at 4 cables. Until southward of Paon point, both flood and ebb streams set strongly across the channel, as they do again when Ferlas channel opens, but under cover of ile de Brehat the streams take the direction of the channel. Follow the leading mark given, leaving the red buoy with conical top-mark of the Roc'h Guarine on the starboard hand, until the red tower on Men-Garo rock comes on with the white pyramid on Quistillic rock, then haul more to the westward and bring the Piliers beacon turret on with Lannevez mill W. by S. This latter mark leads into Brehat road, passing 150 yards south eastward of the Basse de Men-Garo, a small patch on which there are about 26 feet, and a long cable north-westward of the Cain-ar-Rat, a 6-feet patch on which there are 23 feet at half tide. Entering CHENAL de BREHAT from MEN-du- CASTREC or MOISIE CHANNELS.— Sailing vessels rounding Roc'h-ar-Bel from the westward, with wind and tide from that direction, are liable to be set eastward of the entrance to the channel, and lun a risk of being thrown on the Horaine or Echaudes ledges ; See charts, Nos. 2.557 and 2,669 h.

III.] RADE DK BREHAT.— DIRECTIONS.— KERPONT CHANNEL. 75 and, to those leaving the channel with easterly winds during the ebb, there is similar risk of not being able to weather the Roc'h-ar-Bel and other shoals on the western side. In the former case, and to avoid this risk, vessels pass in-shoie of Roc'h-ar-Bel through the Moisie or Men-du-Castrec channels, see page 69 ; and, crossing the Trieux channel, proceed to Brehat road either by the Kerpont or Brehat channel. If taking the Men-du-Castrec channel with this object, the leading mark as already given is, the white pyramid on Arcouest point on with the red beacon turret on the Vieille du Treou ; this line should be held only until the Moisie beacon turret is on with Heaux lighthouse, and then this latter mark leads between the Sirlots and Men-du-Castrec ledges, northward of Pen-Azen ledge, into the Brehat channel. From half flood to half ebb, vessels of 14 feet draught may run through this passage without any risk. With the wind between N.N.W. and W.S.W., and, even at low water, pilots use it not only for vessels bound to Brehat road, but also for those bound to ports in St. Brieuc bay. If taking the Moisie channel, the leading mark through is, the spire of St. Michel chapel, ile de Brehat, on with Rosedo white beacon tower S. 3° E. ; but, as this channel is very narrow, the services of a pilot are indispensable. As Vieille du Treou beacon turret is neared, the mark should be opened a little as it leads very close to that beacon ; cross the Trieux channel in the direction of the entrance to the Kerpont channel, and proceed through that channel by the directions following. Kerpont Channel. — This channel separates ile de Brehat from ile Beniguet and leads into Brehat road, but is only practicable for vessels of moderate draught after 4 hours flood, when that stream begins to slacken. A rocky ledge which dries 9 feet, named le Pont, connects the two islands ; at high water, springs, there are 22 feet, and at neaps 1±\ feet over it. Here the tide at its full strength runs 6 knots. The leading mark through is, the white pyramid on Arcouest point seen in the middle of the space between the high rocks bor dering each side of the channel bearing S. by W. ; which mark may also be used for the Men-du-Castrec channel. The Kerpont channel is practicable for vessels drawing 14^ feet so long as the Vieille du Treou rock is covered, the least depth in the Kerpont at that time being 1G\ feet. See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 b.

The Kerpont has two outlets to the southward ; one, midway between the south-western point of Brehat and the Noires ledge marked by a red beacon turret on the Petite Pierre Noire, its northern rock, and by a red beacon on the Grande Pierre Noire, its south-eastern rock, which uncovers 17 feet. The other outlet is between this ledge and the large rocks off the eastern side of Raguenezbras isle, marked on their eastern edge by a beacon on a rock which uncovers 19 feet at low water ; the leading mark for this passage is, the rock Beg-ar-Raz on with the westernmost house of Brehat. APPROACHING RADE de BREHAT from EAST and S.E. — The channels by which the road can be entered from the eastward are not much used, as the tidal streams cross them obliquely, but there is sufficient water for vessels of deep draught even at low water. The first channel eastward of Brehat channel is that between the Horaine and Echaudes ledges on the North, and Men-Marc'h ledge on the South. The leading mark through is, the summit of the high rocky islet Menou, half a mile eastward of La Trinite point, on with the two mills of Lande-Blanche S.W. W. westerly ; the mills are nearly 'in line from this direction. Follow this mark until Arcouest mill is on with a large forked rock lying close north westward of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest W. S., from whence a direct course may be steered for the road ; or, the Ferlas channel may be run through as directed at page 70, if bound for the Trieux river. The next channel to the southward is between Men Marc'h and Ringue-bras ledges ; the leading mark is the highest point of St. Riom isle on with Lande-Blanche north-eastern mill S.W. by W. \ W. until Arcouest mill is on with the large forked rock W. \ S. With a moderate breeze, the Ringue-bras can be crossed at neaps from half flood to half ebb, by keeping Lande-Blanche north-eastern mill on with the highest point of St. Riom isle. The Banes de Sable may also be crossed under the same circumstances of wind and tide, by keeping Arcouest mill on with the large forked rock as before lescribed. To pass southward of the Banes de Sable, and it is not prudent to cross them at low water, springs, bring the white pyramid on See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *.

III.] RADE DE BREHAT. — DIRECTIONS. — TIDAL STREAMS. 77 Quistillic rock between the old Mill and St. Michel chapel, He de Brehat ; this leads close southward of their southern extreme, a short distance southward of the Basse Pomoriou on which there are only 9 feet, and between Cain-ar-Monse rock, awash, marked on its western side by a conical buoy with top-mark and painted with red and white bands, and a small patch named the Carec Mingui on which there.are only 8 feet at low water, springs. W. leads close westward of the highest heads of the Basse St. Brieuc, 1^ miles off Minar point and marked by a red buoy on their eastern side ; these rocks are awash at the lowest tides ; also, over the north-eastern extreme of the Calemarguiers ledge, a short distance westward of the highest part of a sand-bank between this ledge and the Charpentiers ledge, close north-eastward of the Charpentiers" ledge, marked by a red beacon turret, and of the white pyramid on the Cormorandiere rock. Follow this leading mark until Arcouest mill is on with the large forked rock, when proceed as before for Brehat road. Tides and Tidal Streams.— It is high water, full and change, around ile de Brehat, at 5h. 51m. ; equinoctial springs rise about 39 feet, ordinary springs 31 feet, and ordinary neaps 23| feet above the soundings. In Brehat road, the direction of the stream at the com mencement of the flood, or 5 hours before high water, is S.W. by W. ; its greatest rate is 2 knots at 2^ hours before high water when its direction is E.S.E. The stream begins to run to the N.W. a few minutes after high water. Its greatest rate, 1^ knots, lasts from 3 to 4 hours after high water, when its direction varies from W.N.W. to W. by N. Winds from E.S.E. to S.S.E. cause a heavy sea in the road during the flood. The streams are not strong in Ferlas channel, which is a con tinuation westward of this road ; the streams follow its direction as long aB the banks are uncovered ; the east-going stream then sets towards Arcouest point. About 20 minutes before high water, an eddy comes from Paimpol bay and, after rounding Arcouest point, it sets with some strength towards the south-eastern point of See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *.

Its rate decreases about the time of high water, but it regains strength when the ebb stream makes, which latter stream takes the direction of this eddy until the banks are uncovered, when it runs westward in the direction of the channel. ANSE and PORT de PAIMPOL— This deep bay, formed between the high points of Trinite and Plouzec, is dry throughout nearly its whole extent at the lowest tides. Guilben point divides the bay into two parts, and northward of this long neck of land are the principal beaching places, and the port of Paimpol, the entrance to which is between the Kernoa pier, projecting 200 yards from the southern shore, and the North extreme of the quays on the opposite shore. The little river Quinic flows through it and forms a very tortuous channel through the sands of the bay when they uncover. Depths. — The port dries throughout ; it has a depth of from 13 to 19 feet at high water, springs, and only 5 to 11 feet at neaps. Buoyage. — The entrance to the harbour, as well as the various channels leading up to it, are buoyed and beaconed in accordance with the French uniform system ; see page 14. The harbour is about 380 yards in length and 250 yards in breadth at its widest part, and the bottom is everywhere \ soft. The quay frontage, including the pier, is not less than 450 yards in extent, the berths good, and any swell of importance very rarely felt. The bottom however being above the level of half tide, vessels of any size arriving when the tides are taking off are liable to be neaped for several days. A wet dock, 672 feet long and from 252 to 328 feet wide, with the sill at the entrance 16£ feet above the level of the lowest tides, has been constructed on the eastern side of the tidal harbour. The town of Paimpol has about 1,500 inhabitants ; it has the advantage of railway communication with the main line from Paris to Brest by means of a short line direct from the town to Guincamp on the main line, and is a place of some importance from its extensive deep sea fishery, which employs about 40 or 50 schooners of from 120 to 200 tons. A Life-Boat is stationed at Paimpol. See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *.

Chap. III.] 79 PAIMPOL. — BEACONS.— ANCHORAGES. Beacons, &C. — The bay of Paimpol is easily recognised from seaward ; on its northern side, by point Arcouest with a guard-house on its summit and its white pyramid beacon, northward of point de la Trinite, and by St. Riom isle, high, rocky, and with indented summit ; on its southern side, by the island Mets de Goelo, 6^ cables north-eastward from Plouzec point, high and with rounded grassy top sloping abruptly to the sea on all sides, with Ost-Pic lighthouse at its eastern end, and Torel, a little sugar-loaf islet, between it and Plouzec point. Whilst, marking the off-lying reefs in the central part of the bay, are the Cormorandiere white pyramid and the two beacon turrets marking^the Charpentiers and Gouayan rocks, the former red, the latter black. Anchorage. — There is anchorage both south-westward and south eastward of St. Riom isle, in the narrow channel separating the mud-banks of Paimpol bay from those which dry at the southern end of this isle. There are two red beacons on the Plateaux des Fillettes, westward of St. Riom. A vessel will have a good berth by mooring North and South, south- westward of the isle, in 4 fathoms, muddy bottom, with the guard-house on Arcouest point on with the eastern extreme of Trinite point ; and, the white pyramid on the Cormorandiere rock between the red beacon on the Denou rock and the north-western rock of the Roho ledge. There is not much sea here, even during strong easterly winds, except at high water. The holding-ground south-eastward of St. Riom isle is good but the anchorage is more exposed to easterly winds. It lies in the direction of the black beacon on the Ar-zel rock on with the summit of ile Blanche de Guilben, W. by S. ; its north-eastern limit is Heaux lighthouse just opening out from behind Arcouest point ; and, its south-western limit, the guard-house on Minar point a little open eastward of Plouzec point. Beaching places.— The best grounding places in this bay are in front of port Paimpol, northward of Guilben point, and those most used are on the flat between the channel and the rocks bordering the shore from the port to the point. The bottom is mud and sand, and dries about 16£ feet. The sea is rough here at high water, springs, when it blows hard from the eastward, but the bottom is soft, and the sea goes down before a vessel takes the ground. See oharts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *.

80 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. III. There is also a good beaching place between the extreme of Guilben point and ile Blanche de Guilben. The best berth is about H cables northward of the isle, where the bottom is soft mud and is about 10 feet above the level of the lowest itides. Another good position, where vessels lie up during the winter, is in the northern part of the bay, in front of the hollow in the shore under the high coast of Lande de Portzdon. At this place, a vessel drawing 10£ feet will be neaped only one day. Port Lazo, also, in the south-eastern part of Paimpol bay under the high land of Plouzec point, is a good position to beach a vessel of moderate draught. The berths do not dry more than 9^ feet and are well sheltered. LIGHTS. — Portzdon. — From the gable end of the keeper's dwelling on Portzdon point, on the northern shore of the bay, one mile from the entrance to Paimpol harbour, is exhibited at 35 feet above high water a fixed light, showing white and red sectors. It shows red through an arc of 7^° between N. 63° W. and N. 70|° W. ; and, ivhite through an arc of 3^° between N. 70^° W. and N. 74° W. ; in all other directions the light is obscured. The white light is visible 11 miles ; the red light, 7 miles. Ost-Pic. — On the Ost-Pic rock, at the eastern end of Mets de Goelo island, on the southern side of the bay, from a square tower 44 feet high, and at 64 feet above high water, is exhibited an occulting light showing white and red sectors. It shows white from S. 59° W. through West to N. 89° W. ; red from N. 89° W. to N. 51° W. ; white from N. 51° W. to N. 13° W. ; obscured from N. 13° W. through North to S. 57° E. ; ivhite from S. 57° E. to S. 46° E. ; and red from S. 46° E. through South to S. 59° W. The white light is visible 12 miles ; the red light, 8 miles. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the summit of Plouzec point which may be seen from a great distance seaward ; see page 12. CHANNELS LEADING to ANSE de PAIMPOL.— There are five channels leading to the anchorages near St. Riom isle, viz., the Trinite, Lastel, St. Riom, Denou, and Jument channels. They are all difficult of access, lying in the midst of the dangers by which Paimpol bay is surrounded in all directions ; and, of the five, See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 b.

Chap. III.] PAIMPOL. — LIGHTS.— CHANNELS INTO. 81 two only, the Denou and the Jument, are, after half flood, practicable without a pilot. Trinite Channel, the entrance to which is southward of Brehat road between the Piliers rocks and those off the northern end of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest, is generally taken by vessels bound to Paimpol in charge of pilots, who have conducted them through the Moisie or Men-du-Castrec and Kerpont channels, see pages 69 and 75. It unites with the Lastel channel half a mile northward of Trinite point. Lastel channel is a narrow passage southward of the Men- Gam rock and of the rocky ledge extending from the southern end of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest. Pilots generally take vessels to sea from Paimpol through this channel. St. Riom channel is the narrowest of all, and is but seldom used. It is close to the north-western side of St. Riom isle, between it and the Vras rock. Denou channel is just eastward of St. Riom isle, between Garap and Rohan-heir ledges. It carries a depth of 19 feet and bas the advantage of lying in the direction of the flood stream, but it is narrow and, including the space which separates it from ile de Brehat, can only be navigated by the aid of a good local pilot, and with a fair wind. After half flood, if the leading mark can be seen, a vessel may run through without risk. Jument Channel. — The entrance to this channel is about 1\ miles northward of Plouzec point, between two large and remark able rocks one mile apart in a N. by E. \ E. and S. by W. \ W. direction ; the one is the Ost-Pic, already mentioned, at the eastern extreme of Mets de Goelo island, on which stands the lighthouse ; the other, at the south-eastern edge of the Roho ledge. The channel has only 1\ feet at low water, springs, but at half flood there are 22 feet on the bank extending from the southern part of the Roho ledge to the Jument rock. The J ument, Gueule, and Gouayan rocks divide this channel into two parts, both of which are practicable for vessels of moderate See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 b.

82 [Chap. III. HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. draught. The Jument uncovers 1\ feet, the Gueule 3 feet, and the Gouayan 16 feet at the lowest tides. The Jument and the Gouayan have beacon turrets, the Jument being painted with red and white bands, and the Gouayan, black ; the Gueule lies midway between the beacons, about half a mile E.S.E. of the Jument, and is marked on its northern side by a black buoy with cylinder top-mark. DIRECTIONS.— Denou channel.— If bound to Paimpol bay from the northward, through the Brehat channel, and intending to run through the Denou channel to the anchorages under St. Riom isle, to the harbour of Paimpol, or to any of the beaching places in the bay ; having passed through Brehat channel by the directions already given at page 74, steer S.S.W. f W. with Rundavi mill on with the red beacon on Denou rock, which rock is only about 2\ cables E.S.E. from the eastern point of St. Riom isle. Pass within 25 yards westward of this rock as the Basse du Denou, nearly awash at low water, is but 60 yards westward of it, leaving a channel only 50 yards wide through which the tide runs with great strength. Having passed the Denou, the black beacon on Ar-zel rock on with the summit of ile Blanche de Guilben W. § S. leads to the anchorage south-eastward of St. Riom isle, or the vessel may be steered for one of the beaching places in the bay. The leading mark given, Rundavi mill on with Denou rock beacon, passes very closely westward of la Petite Moisie black beacon, the Moisie rock which does not cover, the Rohan-hier ledge, and the Guillaume rocks, of which the western but deepest end touches the line of direction ; and, eastward of Lei-Done, the north-western rock of Bongreve ledge, the Garap ledge and black beacon, the Valve rock, and the rocks extending eastward from St. Riom. Jument Channel.— If the Jument channel be preferred ; having run through Brehat channel, bring Ost- Pic lighthouse on with the white pyramid on the Cormorandiere S.S.W. and the vessel will pass eastward of the Ca'in-ar-Monse rock, described at page 77 ; when southward of this rock, or when the guard-house on Arcouest point bears W. \ N., steer south-eastward to bring Plouzec mill on with the eastern fall of Mets de Goelo islet S.W. by S. This line leads a cable eastward of the Cormorandiere bank. From thence, Plouzec mill on with Ost-Pic lighthouse, S.W., leads eastward of the Charpentiers ledge, marked by a red beacon turret, and to the entrance of the channel, for which no leading mark can be given, but pass northward of the See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 *.

Chap. III.] PAIMPOL.— DIRECTIONS. — TIDAL STREAMS. 83 beacon turrets on the Gouayan and Jument rocks and anchor, or steer for a beaching place as before directed. Approaching from the south-eastward, a vessel should pass between the coast and the off-lying shoals between Minar and Plouzec points, and between the Ost-Pic and the Calemarguiers rocks, by keeping the summit of the large rock at the south-eastern part of the Roho ledge on with the eastern point of Ar-Morbic rock N. \ W. This rock is on the eastern side of Brehat, and on this bearing appears as part of it ; the eastern point of Brehat is high, well defined, and is the eastern extreme of land seen to the northward. Give the Ost-Pie a berth of about 2 cables in rounding, and from thence steer for the anchorages or grounding places, passing southward of the beacon turrets on the Gouayan and Jument. At night. — Vessels approaching Paimpol anchorages at night can only enter by the Jument channel, and if from the eastward or southward must be guided by the red and white sectors of Ost-Pic and Portzdon lights in so doing. Coming from the northward through Brehat channel, a vessel should enter the sector of white light shown from Paon point, and keep within its limits until Portzdon white light is seen, towards which she must then steer ; Paon point light will then change to red, and finally become obscured ; half a mile farther, Heaux light will be masked by St. Riom isle when the anchor should be instantly let go, and the vessel will be in about 5 fathoms. Tides and Tidal Streams.— It is high water, full and change at Paimpol at 6h. Om.; springs rise 31 feet, neaps 23^ feet above the zero of soundings ; but, the bottom being above the level of half tide, there are only 13 feet in the harbour at high water, ordinary springs. The flood stream which enters Paimpol bay, after rounding the south western part of ile de Brehat, sets S.S.W. and S.S.E.; but, at about four hours flood, its direction is S.S.W. and S.W. and an eddy begins to follow the windings of the shore from Mets de Goelo towards Arcouest point. The breadth of this eddy increases rapidly ; at one hour before high water it extends to the anchorage south-eastward of St. Riom isle, and at this time, and even after half flood, a vessel running from Brehat road to Paimpol with a light wind, had better pass eastward of St. Riom isle, and even of the Cormorandiere rock, rather than attempt the Trinite channel, which can only be taken when the wind is sufficiently strong to stem this eddy. See charts, Nos. 2,557 and 2,669 b.

84 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. III. The ebb stream follows the same direction as the eddy on the flood and forms an eddy behind each projecting point of the coast ; but, as the banks uncover, the body of the stream trends more and more towards Brehat, southward of which it divides, one part passing eastward of the isle ; the other, after crossing Brehat road, running through Kerpont channel, and between the islets and rocks westward of it. The velocity of both streams increases in the narrow channels, but around the Cormorandiere bank, as well as eastward of Mets de Goelo and of Minar point, it does not exceed 4 knots at springs and 2 knots at neaps. st GRAND LEJON is the highest head of a rocky ledge 9 cables in extent, N.E. by E. and S.W. by W., nearly midway between ile de Brehat and Cape Frehel ; it is near the southern edge of the ledge, dries 23 feet at low water, and covers 2\ hours before high water, springs. On this head stands the lighthouse, and from it, Heaux lighthouse bears N.W. northerly 19^ miles, with Paon point lighthouse a little open westward and distant 14^ miles ; Harbour island lighthouse S.W. by W. f W. 1\ miles ; and, Cape Frehel lighthouse P.E. by E. 14J miles. From it also, the steeple of Plourhan church is on with St. Quay Point and with the lighthouse on Harbour isle ; and, Turquet mill is on with the most southern of the high lands of Erqui S.S.E. \ E. easterly. The Bouillons, shoal patches of from 3 to 15 feet, lie 5 cables north-eastward of the light house ; and the Basses du Sud-Est, with 2^ fathoms least water, lie 8 cables southward of it. LIGHT. — From the lighthouse on Grand Lejon rock, which is 76 feet high from base to vane, a light is exhibited at 52 feet above high water ; it is alternately fixed and flashing at intervals of twenty-five seconds ; it shows red through an arc of 43° be tween N.E. by N. northerly, and E. by N. \ N., covering the dangers included between the Caffa shoal and St. Quay rocks ; also red through an arc of 67°, between N. § E. and N.W. by W. \ W. covering the dangers included between the Rohein rocks and the Grande Liviere ; in all other directions it shows white. The fixed white light is visible 12 miles, the flashing white light 17 miles ; the fisted red light 8 miles, and the flashing red light 12 miles. See charts, Nos. 2,5*7 and 2,669 *.

Chap. III.] LEJON ROCKS.— TIDAL STREAMS.— COAST. 85 Fog signal. — In foggy weather, a bell is sounded twice every eight seconds with an interval of one second between the two strokes ; see fog signals, page 11. Wreck buoy. — About 3^ miles W. by N. \ N. from the lighthouse is a green buoy marking the wreck of the British barque Spark. In October, 1894, the mainmast of this vessel was 30 or 40 feet above the level of low water, springs, at which time there were about 12 or 14 feet water over her deck. PETIT LEJON.— The highest head of the Petit Lejon bears S. by E. 3j miles from the Grand Lejon lighthouse and it uncovers only 9 feet. From it, the northern mill of Plevenon is on with the northern face of the Rohinet rock S.E. by E. \ E. ; and, Tur quet mill is on with the northern part of Lahoussaye point S.E. \ S. southerly. There are several shoal patches of from 4 to 6 fathoms nearly in line between the Grand and Petit Lejon besides the Basses du Sud-Est already described ; these patches are sur rounded by depths of from 9 to 13 fathoms, the bottom hereabouts being rocky and uneven. Bell-buoy. — A black bell-buoy with a reflector is moored off the western side of the Petit Lejon. Tidal Streams. — The flood stream sets into the Baie de St. Brieuc from the north-westward and the ebb stream out of the bay in the opposite direction. Amongst the dangers surrounding the bay, the flood stream makes about half an hour after low water at St. Malo, and the ebb stream half an hour after high water at that port ; in the offing each stream is about an hour later. The streams run with great strength in the vicinity of the Grand and Petit Lejon, from 2 to 4 knots, and the sea is heavy in bad weather. Around the Petit Lejon the streams are rotatory, the flood commenc ing by running westward, shifting through S.W. and South, at its maximum strength, and finishing at East ; the ebb commences at N.E., acquires its maximum at about North and ends at N.W. The Coast. — From Pointe de Plouzec, Minar point bears S.S.E. \ E. 1^ miles. Rocks extend 3 cables from the foot of this point, which is high and surmounted by a white pyramid visible many miles seaward ; from it St. Quay point bears S. by E. \ E. 7 miles, and See chart, No. 2,669 *.

III. the coast between is steep and inaccessible, except to boats during off-shore winds, on the beach of Brechech bay about If miles southward of Minar point, and on the beach fronting St. Quay village about 3 cables westward of St. Quay point. Plouha point, 4£ miles S. \ E. from Minar point and 1\ miles N.N.W. f W. from Bee de Vir, is the highest point in St. Brieuc bay ; it terminates in a perpendicular rocky cliff 330 feet high, visible in clear weather 25 miles distant. Bee de Vir point is If miles northward of St. Quay point, which latter is steep but much lower than the point north ward of it. Taureau rock — Beacon turrret. — The Taureau rock, which uncovers 33 feet at the lowest tides, lies in the bight between Minar point and the Mauve rock, and is marked by a stone beacon turret painted with red and black bands. The white pyramid on the Cormorandiere rock open about half a point eastward of Minar point, leads eastward of it. The Mauve is a large rock off Plouha guard-house, 4 cables from the shore, and 3 cables north-eastward of the Pommier rock, which atter is close to the shore and has its top whitened to serve as a daymark. The Mauve never covers, and forms with other rocks surrounding it a ledge 4 cables long East and West. The Place de Greve, the Traverse, and the Oiseaux, are shoal patches nearly on the parallel of Plouha point, and 1\ to 2\ miles from it. The Place de Greve, the shoalest and nearest the shore, carries a depth of 3 fathoms, and, from it, the southern mill of Plouzec is on with the centre of the Mauve rock ; the other two patches have from 5 to 7 fathoms over them. Abreast of the Bee de Vir and 5^ cables from the shore is the northern end of St. Mark bank, which, from thence, extends about a mile southward with a least depth of 2| fathoms. Anchorage. — The shore between Minar and Plouha points is clear of dangers, with the exception of those just described, and with off-shore winds may be approached within half a mile. With the wind between E.N.E. and South, however, a vessel should avoid approaching too near, as the streams set into the bight. If obliged by a calm to anchor, endeavour to do so when the steeple of Treveneuc church is on with the Comtesse de Gueredon, a large rock at the foot of Plouha point, bearing South. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. III.] TAUREAU ROCK.— ROCHES DE ST. Q "AY. 87 Semaphore. — A Semaphore is established on the highest part of St. Quay point ; it may be seen some distance seaward over Harbour isle and the St. Quay rocks generally ; see page 12. ROCHES de ST. QUAY.— Beacon Turrets— This rocky group, fronting the western coast of St. Brieuc bay abreast of St. Quay point, covers a space nearly 5 miles long N.W. by N. and S.E. by S., and 2\ miles wide ; from its northern extreme, the steeple of Plouha church is nearly on with the rocks terminating Bee de Vir point W. by N. O.j and, from the Caffa buoy at its south-eastern edge, 3^ miles from the nearest land, Etables church bears W. by N. \ N., and Roselier point S. by W. \ W. 4^ miles. Harbour isle, the principal rock, is a large, round, steep, and isolated islet with a lighthouse on it, lying north-westward of the main group of rocks and islets, and one mile E.N.E. from St. Quay point ; only 10 or 12 heads cover on this part of the group. The northernmost rock is the Tour de l'eau ; it uncovers 6 feet, and is about 6 cables northward of Harbour isle and nearly 2 cables in the same direction from the Madeux beacon turret, which is painted with black and white horizontal bands ; Plouha church steeple well open northward of Bee de Vir point, leads clear of the northern edge of the rocks. On the south-eastern part, all the rocks cover with the exception of the Houesse, the summit of which is 35-j feet above the lowest tides and only covers at the highest springs, the Ronde and Longue rocks which dry 25 and 26 feet respectively and are not covered at high water, ordinary neaps, and the Caffa rock which uncovers 2 feet only. The Ronde is marked by a black beacon turret, and the Longue by a red beacon turret. The Caffa, the south-eastern head of the group, bears E. £ N. 4 miles from the eastern pier-head of Port Binic. The highest head of the Comtesses rocks, off Point Pleneuf, on with cape Frehel, or Etables and Plourhan church steeples in line, N.W. by W., lead south ward of it. Plateau des Hors lies eastward of the principal rocks of the St. Quay group and is separated from them by a channel 3 cables wide, which is bounded on the West by the Petit Aubert, a rock which uncovers 12 feet, and on the East by a patch named Grande See chart, No. 2,669 b. Buoys.— The following buoys mark these dangers on their eastern, south-eastern, and southern sides. A red bell-buoy, surmounted by a reflector, is moored 3 cables eastward of the plateau des Hors. LIGHT. — The lighthouse on Harbour isle, the principal rock of the St. Quay group, is a square tower ; it exhibits at 49 feet above high water, a fixed white light, visible 10 miles. From the lighthouse, the eastern end of the Banes de Sable bears N.N.E. 9 miles ; Grand Lejon lighthouse N.E. by E. | E. 7i miles ; and, the Petit Lejon rock E. \ S. 7| miles. PORTRIEUX is in the northern part of Portrieux bay half a mile southward of St. Quay point ; the St. Quay rocks, lying exactly in front of it, form a natural breakwater both to the harbour and roadstead. The town contains about 1,300 in habitants, and, being a watering place, its population is more than doubled during the summer months. The harbour is formed by a stone pier, extending 373 yards in a southerly direction from the northern point, which pier also serves as a quay- ; the harbour is 550 yards in extent North and South, and about half that width. The navigable entrance between the coast and the pier being not less than 200 yards in width, there is sufficient space for small vessels to tack if the wind should be scant on entering or leaving. Depths. Portrieux is used by vessels capable of taking the ground, and dries 13 feet at the lowest tides, but at high water, springs, it has from 26 to 19 feet, and at high water of the lowest neaps, 10 feet ; and, consequently, has more water than any other port in St. Brieuc bay. A Life-Boat is stationed at this port as well as all other life saving appliances. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. III.] PORTRIEUX. — ROAD. — DIRECTIONS. 89 Harbour Light. — On the pier-head at Portrieux stands a white iron lighthouse, from which at 34 feet above high water is exhibited a fixed red light, visible 5 miles. Portrieux road, between the St. Quay rocks and the coast, has good holding -ground and sufficient depth for vessels of 14 feet draught. It should not be used, however, with strong easterly winds, except at the lowest neaps, and then only when the shelter on the eastern side of the bay in Erqui road or under Pleneuf point cannot be reached. The anchorage is comprised within the following limits: — Hergue and Pommier rocks in one (the Hergue is a remarkable rock N.N.W. 6 cables from St. Quay point and has a white beacon turret, the Pommier is a similar rock before mentioned close to Plouha point, and has a whitewashed mark) ; the Hergue on with the foot of the steep declivity of Plouha point ; Caruhel Mill on with the Four rock white beacon turret ; and, Portrieux church on with the centre of Portrieux pier. The depths are from 14 to 18 feet between the southern limit and the line of St. Michel mill on with the pier-head. On this latter line, from West to East, there are from 10 to 20 feet ; and, between it and the northern limit, from 11 to 12 feet. The best berth with most water is, with Etables steeple on with the Four rock beacon turret ; and, St. Michel mill and the pier-head in line. Directions. — Vessels approaching either the roadstead or port of Portrieux from any direction, may do so by passing between St. Quay rocks and the coast, or by rounding the southern end of these rocks, according as tide and wind best serve. To pass between St. Quay rocks and the coast ; bring the Mouliere red beacon turret on with Four rock white beacon turret about S. W. This mark leads between the northern part of St. Quay rocks and St. Mark bank, and should be kept on until the vessel has arrived within 3^ cables N.E. by E. of St. Quay point, when Herflux black beacon turret and Longue red beacon turret will be in line and should be steered for to clear the Mouliere rocks which uncover 15 feet, until the Four white beacon turret is on with the lofty spire of Pordic church S. by W. | W. ; follow this direction until the leading mark for the southern part of the channel comeb on, viz., the Hergue white beacon turret and Pommier rock in line N.N.W. \ W., passing between the conical black buoy of the Noirs on the port hand, and See chart, No. 2,669 *. In steering with the Four beacon turret on with Pordic spire, if the vessel is above 14 feet draught, do not wait until the Hergue and Pommier rocks are in one, but leave that direction the moment the Hergue is on with Plouha point. The vessel, if not drawing more than 14 feet, may now either anchor in Portrieux road, as directed, or, if the tide suits, she may run on S.S.E. J E. with Hergue and Pommier rocks in one, remembering that this mark leads over the Basse Meridionale de la Rade, shoal of 6 feet ; close to another of 8 feet, 3 cables N.W. of the 6-feet shoal ; and, over the Traverse, a sand-bank which trends upwards of 1\ miles in a S.S.W. direction from the southern part of St. Quay rocks and on which the least water is 4 feet. When Etables steeple is on with that of Plourhan N.W. by W. ; or, when cape Frehel lighthouse is on with the highest point of the Comtesse rocks, the vessel may either haul to the eastward with the latter mark on, or steer for Port Binic, avoiding the Ours-Seul rock, which uncovers 9 feet and is 4 cables from the shore 1£ miles northward of that port, and 1\ miles southward of the Four rock, by keeping the Mouliere red beacon turret on with the eastern end of the Mauve rock. Approaching the roadstead by the southern passage, it is necessary to ascertain that there is a sufficient rise of tide to cross the Traverse bank and other shoal patches just named. The height of the tide by the Ronde and Longue rocks, which uncover 25 and 26 feet, is a useful indication of the depth on these shoals. To enter the port of Portrieux, the leading mark is Portrieux spire on with the extreme end of the pier ; this leaves at a short distance on the port hand the Four, Vache, and Pannerais rocks. The Vache uncovers 7 feet, and the Pannerais 12 feet, at the lowest tides. Pilots. — The pilots for Portrieux also take vessels to ports Binic and Legue ; they generally cruise as far seaward as the Lejons. No stranger should attempt the channel between the roches de St. Quay and the coast, or enter either of these ports without a pilot. Tides.— It is high water, full and change, at Portrieux at 6h. 0m. ; ordinary springs rise 32 feet ; neaps 23^ feet above the zero of soundings. The tidal streams in Portrieux road follow nearly the See chart. No. 3,669 b.

Chap. III.] 91 PILOTS.— PORT BINIC. direction of the Hergue and Pommier rocks in line. At springs, the greatest strength of the flood between Harbour isle and St. Quay point, as well as among the rocks northward of the road, is 4^ knots ; the strength of the ebb is rather less. PORT BINIC is less than 3 miles southward of Portrieux, about 5 miles N.W. f N. from Roselier point, and dries from 10 to 20 feet at low water ; it is at the head of a little bay half a mile wide and open to the eastward. It consists of an outer and inner harbour. The outer harbour is formed by the Penthievre mole which extends 384 yards from the northern point of the bay in a south-easterly direction, its outer portion turning abruptly southward ; at its outer end is the lighthouse. The entrance to the inner harbour is between two stone jetties ; it is 550 yards in length eastward and westward, and has an average breadth of 93 yards. It is greatly sheltered by the Penthievre mole, though, as the bay is naturally quite open eastward, the swell and sea caused by easterly gales are much felt in both, but improvements to obviate this inconvenience are now (1896) in progress. Depths. — The outer port dries 10 feet in the entrance at low water ; it can be entered by vessels of about 10 feet draught at high water, ordinary neaps, and those of 14 feet can enter it from 1^ hours before to 11, hours after high water, springs. It affords good shelter, with winds from South round by West to N.N.W. ; with strong winds from North round by East, the shelter is bad, but will be improved by the breakwater now under construction ; with these winds, it is necessary to enter at the top of high water. The berths at the foot of the eastern inner jetty dry 17 feet, and those near the landing creek at the upper end of the port 25 feet above the lowest tides ; those alongside l'Estacade, the southern jetty, are the highest. The town of Binic has over 1 ,000 inhabitants and its chief industry consists in its deep sea fishery, several vessels leaving the port annually for the Newfoundland cod fishery. LIGHT. — A fixed white light is exhibited from a circular granite tower on the mole-head at port Binic ; it is 36 feet above high water and is visible 10 miles. Several small lights are shown within the harbour during the progress of the new works especially a small red light on the See chart, No. 2,669 b.

HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. III. 92 new breakwater end, between which and the principal white light vessels have to pass in entering. Directions.— When bound to port Binic, if the wind is between N.N.E. and W.S.W. a vessel with a sufficient rise of tide, may pass between the shore and St. Quay rocks ; with the wind between N.N.E. and E.S.E. she can pass on either side of these rocks ; but, if between S.E. and S.W., she should keep eastward of them. With strong winds from N.E. to East, a vessel should always pass eastward of them, but should not venture so far into the bay until the tide has risen sufficiently high over the broad flats in front of the port, allowing for the 'scend of the sea, to prevent all risk of striking the ground in crossing them. In entering, keep between the jetty and the buoys in the interior of the harbour. Passing eastward of St. Quay rocks, which it is generally prudent to do at neaps ; if, after rounding their south-eastern extreme, it is found that the vessel cannot fetch port Binic, shelter may be sought under Roselier point, 5 miles south-eastward of Binic ; see also Directions at page 96. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Port Binic at 6h. 3m.; springs rise 30 feet, neaps 22| feet above the zero of soundings. When the Longue rock, at the southern part of the St. Quay group is awash, there are 14f feet at the foot of the outer pier-head of port Binic ; 11 feet at the entrance of port Legue ; 12^ feet at the entrance of port Dahouet ; and, nearly 23 feet on the grounding places close southward of Roselier point. When the highest head of the Trahillions ledge, or the Grand Lejon rock, cover (they both uncover 23 feet at springs) there are 11| feet at the outer pier-head of port Binic ; 7| feet at the entrance of Legue ; 9^ feet at the entrance of Dahouet. Anchorage. — Vessels waiting tide to enter either port Binic or port Legue can anchor, in fine weather, abreast of Binic on a bottom of clayey mud in about 3 fathoms, with the Pommier rock and Hergue white beacon turret in line N.N.W. £ W. The COAST rises in height gradually from St. Quay point to Binic, between which place and Roselier point it is high and steep, except at Rosaires beach south-eastward of Pordic Point, where boats can always land with off-shore winds. The bank bordering the See chart, No. 2,669 *.

Chap. III.] PORT BINIC— COAST.— ROSELIER POINT. 93 shore dries out one mile abreast of Binic, and 5 cables at Rosaires beach. On the bank northward of Binic are several rocks besides the Four and Ours-Seul, both already described. Close westward of the Four is Fille rock, which dries 19 feet, and 2 cables southward of it is Noyes ledge, which dries 2 feet above the bank. The Equerrets, Petit-Gripet, and Grand-Gripet, three small rocky ledges abreast of Rosaires beach, are dangerous to vessels borrowing too closely on the shore. The highest head of the Equerrets bears E. by S. \ S. 8 cables from the foot of Pordic point and uncovers about a foot. The highest head of the Petit-Gripet uncovers about a foot, and is about 5 cables from the shore, with the Martin rock on with the foot of Roselier point S. by E. \ E. The Martin is a high rock which never covers and is near the shore northward of Roselier point ; shoal water extends 1\ cables eastward of it. There are more than 14 feet water on the Petit-Gripet when the eastern extreme of the Martin rock is covered. The Grand-Gripet, with 2 feet over it, bears N. by E. § E. nearly ly miles from the Martin, the summit of which is then a little east ward of the principal house of a large farm on the high land. ROSELIER POINT, 5 miles S.E. S. from port Binic, is high and steep on its northern and southern sides, but terminates in a gentle declivity eastward. If a vessel can take the ground, there is excellent shelter close southward of this point on the northern shore of a little bay called port Aurelle, protected from all winds from South round by West to N.E. The bottom, of muddy sand, dries only 3 feet above the lowest tides, so that, if of about 14 feet draught, she can run for shelter from two hours before to two hours after high water. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on Roselier point ; see page 12. The COAST between Roselier and Pleneuf points, which bear E. £ N. and W. i S. distant 6f miles from each other, falls back to the southward and forms the head of St. Brieuc bay, in which are port Legue, the Anse d'Yffiniac, and port Dahouet. Several dangers front this part of the shore, of which the farthest in the offing are the Trahillions, Basse Herbaut, Trois Tetes, and the Dahouet. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

[Chap. III. HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. 94 The Trahillions.— Beacon turret.— These rocks form a ledge, about 9 cables in extent E.S.E. and W.N.W. at the edge of the bank, which, abreast of Guettes point, dries more than a mile from the shore at low water, springs; the ledge is terminated at its eastern end by a rock which uncovers 23 feet, on which is a black beacon turret ; and, at the western end, by another rock which uncovers 8^ feet. Beacon. — Basse Herbaut and the Dahouet rock, the latter described at page 96, are both awash at the lowest tides. A rock with only 4 feet water lies N.E. by E. \ E. 1\ cables from the Herbaut. The Trois Tetes, lying between the Herbaut and Dahouet rocks, have only 2 feet over them, and their inner head, called the Armelent rock has on it a red beacon. A vessel will pass outside all these dangers by keeping the summit of cape d'Erqui open northward of Petit Verdelet islet about the width of that rock ; or, by keeping Rohinet rock, off cape d'Erqui, on with the highest head of the Jaunes rocks, off Pleneuf point, N.E. by E. § E. ; and, 200 yards westward of the Trahillions, by keeping the spire of the church of St. Pierre at St. Brieuc, or the mill near the church, on with the houses of Sous-la-Tour, a little hamlet in front of Cesson tower, at the foot of the high land which forms the southern side of the entrance to the river Gouet. LEGUE or PORT de St. BRIEUC is about a mile within the mouth of the river Gouet, the entrance to which is 1\ miles southward of Roselier point and between Chatern and Cesson points, the latter being the north-western extreme of Yffiniac bay. Legue owes its importance to the proximity of the large town of St. Brieuc, only a mile distant and with a population of 16,500. St. Brieuc is in direct railway communication with Paris and Brest, and also with the Morbihan coast line. The port extends to the bridge above the town of Legue and has over 1,500 yards of wharfage, besides a wet dock 325 yards long and averaging 71 yards wide, which has, however, only 14^ feet water, at springs ; there are also two careening slips 230 and 131 feet long, and 164 and 98 feet wide respectively. Between 500 and 600 vessels enter the port annually, their average tonnage being 54 tons, and one-third of them are either English or Norwegian. A considerable steam traffic exists at certain seasons between here and the Channel islands. Depths. — The bottom between Cesson point and Sous-la-tour hamlet dries 15 feet, the berths at the foot of the quay 20 feet, and See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. III.] ST. BRIEUC— DIRECTIONS.— DAHOUET. 95 those near the bridge 22 feet, above the lowest tides. There are 16 feet in the entrance at high water, springs, and about 8 feet at neaps. On the summit of Cesson point are the ruins of Cesson Castle, of which the tower serves as a landmark and can be seen from a distance of 15 miles. From a little northward of Chatern point, the channel into port Legue is marked by beacons and buoys, red on the northern and black on the southern side. LIGHT. — A fixed ivhite light, visible 10 miles, is exhibited at 43 feet above high water, from a circular tower on Aigle point, at the northern side of the entrance of port Legue. Bane de Chatern and Galettes rocks are the only dangers to be avoided when entering port Legue. The bank trends in a S. by W. direction from Roselier point and rests upon Chatern point. The Galettes is a small ledge which uncovers 10 feet, 3 cables eastward of Cesson point. Directions. — When bound to Legue, if from the westward, follow the directions given at pages 64, 74, 89, and 96, until southward of the St. Quay rocks ; or, if from the eastward, those given at pages 102, 104, until past the Rohein rock ; then steer to bring Roselier and Cesson points in line S.S.W. § W., which will be the leading mark until within 2 miles of Roselier point ; then steer towards Pature point until the northern tower of the church of St. Michel, at St. Brieuc, is seen between the southern tower of the same church, on which there is a telegraph, and the most southerly houses of Sous-la-Tour hamlet, which mark leads to the entrance of the port. Vessels before bearing up for the port should carefully estimate the depth of water over the sands in its front by observing the height of the tide at the Longue rock, or at the Martin rock. When the eastern head of the latter is awash, there are only 3 feet in the channel from off point Aigle to Sous-la-Tour hamlet ; when the next head to this is awash, there are 1\ feet at the same place ; and, when the Longue rock is awash, there are 11 feet. ANSE d'YFFINIAC — This deep bight, between Cesson and Pature points, is choked by sands over which the tide flows at high water, but which are uncovered for miles at low water ; a good mark See chart, No. 2,669 *.
