III. for their outer edge is, a line drawn from the Martin rock to the Trahillions beacon turret ; and, to keep well outside this edge, the mark is, Bien-Assis wood open northward of the old semaphore of Dahouet. DAHOUET.— The entrance to this little inlet bears E. -\ S. 5f miles from Roselier point, and is 1\ miles south-westward of Pleneuf point ; it is between the shore on the port hand and the pier-head on the starboard hand ; there is also a red beacon light turret on the Petite Muette rock in the entrance, to be left on the star board hand. The port is open to the North-west, but affords fair shelter to small vessels which can take the ground. The trade is chiefly with the Channel Islands but is inconsiderable. There are about 300 yards of quay frontage, and the village consists of 30 or 40 houses, with about 200 inhabitants. Depths. — The bottom dries 13 feet above the level of the lowest tides abreast of the pier-head ; 18 feet in front of the western part of the quay ; about 22 feet at the angle of the quay ; and, 24 feet near the mill sluice at the head of the port. At high water, springs, there are 19 feet abreast of the pier-head, and 10^ feet at neaps. When the Longue rock is awash, there are 12^ feet water at the entrance ; when the Bignons des Jaunes are awash there are 10^ feet, and when the highest head of the Trahillions covers there are 9^ feet. Harbour light.— From the beacon turret on the Petite Muette rock, at 24 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed light showing red, white, and green sectors, thus : — red between S. 33° W. and S. 17° E., white between S. 17° E. and S. 49° E., and green between S. 49° E. and N. 72° E. The red light is visible 4 miles, the white light 7 miles, and the green light 3^ miles. The principal dangers in approaching the port from the northward are, the Bignons des Jaunes, the Godiche, and the Dahouet rock. The Bignons des Jaunes are at the south-western edge of the plateau des Jaunes, described at page 98, and uncover 24 feet ; when they are awash there is plenty of water over the Godiche, 10^ feet at the entrance of the port, and 4 or 5 feet at the grounding berths within. See chart, No. 2,669 *.

Chap. III.] 97 DAHOUET.— DANGERS. — DIRECTIONS. The Godiche is a small patch of 6 feet, 5 cables westward of the Bignons, with the Petit Bignon a little open southward of the summit of the Jaunes. Dahouet Rock. — Buoy. — This rock is 8 cables north-westward of the entrance of the port, and is awash at low water, springs ; it is marked by a red spindle buoy on its northern side. Should the buoy be gone, the small steeple of Pleneuf seen over the downs, and open about half a point northward of the steep coast, northward of the point, leads northward of the rock. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at port Dahouet at 6h. 5m. Springs rise 32 feet, neaps 23^ feet above the zero of soundings. Springs rise at the foot of the western part of the quay from 16 to 20 feet, neaps from 5 to 6 feet. Directions. — When bound to ports Binic, Legue, or Dahouet from the westward, follow the directions given for passing between the Barnouic and Horaine ledges, see page 64 ; or, for passing through the Brehat channel, see page 74. If from the eastward, follow those given at pages 103-105 until past the Rohein rock. If the Brehat channel is taken ; when Paon point and Heaux lighthouses are in line N.W. | N., haul to the south-eastward and steer with this as the leading mark until the -two mills of Lande Blanche are on with Lemenez isle W. \ S.; the vessel is then about one mile westward of the Banes de Sable, and a S. by E. | E. course leads between the St. Quay and Rohein rocks, passing about one mile eastward of the red bell-buoy of the plateau des Hors. When southward of the St. Quay rocks, a vessel may haul up for Binic or steer for Legue as already directed. If for Dahouet, when southward of the Rohein which bears N. by W. 4f miles from the entrance of the port, the only dangers to be avoided are the Bignons, the Basse Godiche, and the Dahouet rocks, already described. With the wind between S.W. and S.S.E. a vessel should always pass eastward of the Horaine, in rounding which take care she is not set too far eastward by the flood. When southward of the Grand Lejon, and to avoid the Petit Lejon, do not open the summit of the Comtesses westward of the southern extreme of Bien-Assis wood ; and, in approaching the Rohein ledge, keep Guettes point well open See chart, No. 2,669 b.

[Chap. III. 98 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. westward of the Rohein rock until the vessel is southward of that rock. In standing to the westward, be careful not to approach too near the St. Quay rocks ; Pature point kept open westward of Mener- Bel-Air hills, at least double the apparent distance between their eastern and western peaks, leads a safe distance eastward of them, and when Cape Frehel lighthouse is on with the highest head of the Comtesses, or when Etables and Plourhan church steeples in line bear N.W. by W. she is southward of their south-eastern extreme. At Night, after rounding the Horaine, the Grand Lejon white flashing light is an excellent guide for entering St. Brieuc bay. A vessel should pass about 2 miles westward of it, and, on entering its western red sector, edge to the eastward to cross that sector and enter the white flashing sector of light ; having done which, she should steer about S.S.W. between the St. Quay rocks and the Rohein, keeping carefully within the white flashing sector of Grand Lejon light. Having brought port Binic white fixed light to bear W. by N. \ N. she will be southward of all danger and may, if desired, haul up for it and anchor in from 3 to 5 fathoms to await daylight. If for port Dahouet, keep in the white sector of its light. The general aspect of the coast from Pleneuf point to Cape Frehel has been already given at page 59. A description of the numerous rocks and shoals by which this shore is fronted will now follow. THE ROHEIN and COMTESSES ROCKS, are two rocky ledges, the first 5 miles and the second 3j miles in a W.N.W. direction from cape d'Erqui. The Rohein rock, at the south-western extreme of the Rohein ledge, is high above the level of the highest spring tides, and, from its isolated position, is easily recognised from some distance. This ledge is about one mile in diameter, many heads are uncovered at low water, and others awash, or nearly so. On its southern edge, eastward of the Rohein rock, the Basse Ronde uncovers 26 feet, and the Basses du-Sud-Est, 24 feet. At its northern extreme, the Basse des Daouelins is a dangerous patch ; from the least water on it, 3 feet, the extreme of cape Frehel touches the southern side of the Rohinet rock E. f S. southerly ; and, Pature point is a little open westward of the Rohein S.W. by S. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. III.] ROHEIN, COMTESSES, AND OTHER ROCKS. 99 The Comtesses are 5 cables in extent E.S.E. and W.N.W., and uncover at low water throughout. The two westernmost heads never cover. Between the Comtesses and the Rohein ledges, the Lue rock uncovers 24 feet at the lowest tides. Basse des Comtesses is a small ledge about a cable long, and its highest head, which uncovers 3 feet, bears N. \ W. 5 cables from the highest rock of the Comtesses ; from it, this latter rock is on with the eastern face of the Verdelet rock S. \ W. PLATEAU des JAUNES, 1\ miles northward of Pleneuf point and S.S.W. nearly 2 miles from the Comtesses, is nearly a mile in extent East and West, and the highest rocks on it, towards the north-eastern end, never cover ; the Bignons des Jaunes, described at page 96, form the south-western edge of the plateau. There is but little water between this ledge and the Verdelet rock, but coasters pass between by keeping the whitened summit of the Rohinet rock open the width of the turret northward of the red beacon turret of the Evette. / Guyomere and Ecarets ledges. — The water is shallow for a mile off-shore, between Pleneuf point and cape d'Erqui, and several rocky ledges nearly bar all approach to it at low water. The highest of these are, the Guyomere, the highest head of which uncovers 16 feet ; and, the Ecarets, which uncovers 2 feet at the lowest tides. The latter rock bears N.W. by N. nearly a mile from Carouel point, on which there is a stone windmill ; from it, Turquet mill is on with the southern extreme of the steep coast near Lahoussaye point E.by S.; and, the northern extreme of Bien-Assis wood is on with a country house standing on the brow of a hill a little westward of a remarkable white spot in the steep declivity of the coast. Trois Pierres. — Buoy. — These rocks uncover 23 feet and ex tend 1^ cables from the land in a south-westerly direction, just southward of cape d'Erqui, and form the northern boundary of the rade d'Erqui. A black conical buoy is moored 75 yards N.W. \ W. from the Trois Pierres. Plateau des Portep d'Erqui.— Beacon turret.— This ledge, about 1^ miles westward of cape d'Erqui, has on it four rocky heads which uncover from 26 to 29 feet, and the greater part of the reef is awash at high water, neaps. The highest head is the Evette, near the eastern end, on which is a red beacon turret ; one cable eastward See chart, No. 2,669 b.

100 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. III. of this is the Izard rock, at the edge of the ledge, which uncovers about 6 feet. Pierres-du-Banc are two rocky patches 3£ miles E. by S. \ S. from the Petit Lejon. There are never less than 2\ fathoms water on them, but they are dangerous in bad weather when there is a heavy sea over them on a weather tide. They lie close together, with the eastern side of Verdelet rock on with Tournemine mill S.S.W. \ W.; and, the summit of the Grand-Pourier rock between the Rohinetrock and the chapel on St. Michel islet S.E. \ S. The Landas are two rocks rising from the southern part of a ledge, 4 cables in extent East and West, on which there are only from 5 to 8 feet at the lowest tides ; the eastern rock is then awash and the western rock uncovers 2 feet. These rocks lie midway between the Pierres-du-Banc and the Grand-Pourier ; from them, cape Frehel lighthouse is seen between Amas-du-Cap and Bonnetot rock (which latter lies 1\ cables eastward of the Landas and uncovers 20 feet) E. by S. \ S. ; and, the chapel and mill of Pleherel are between the Rohinet and the Grand-Pourier S.E. f E. Buoy. — A red spindle buoy is moored 240 yards north-westward of the plateau des Landas. GRAND-POURIER, ROHINET, and JUSTIERES, are the highest ledges of a rocky plateau, of which the south-western extreme bears N. by E. 5 cables from cape d'Erqui ; it extends more than 2^ miles in a north-easterly direction, and is 1^ miles broad at its widest part. The Rohinet never covers, the eastern summit of the Grand-Pourier only covers at the highest tides, and the Justieres uncover 28 feet. Except between the Justieres and Rohinet, nearly the whole plateau uncovers at low water, springs. Buoys. — Two red buoys mark the southern side of this plateau ; one is moored off its southern extreme 5 cables from cape d'Erqui, the other on the south-eastern edge of the Justieres. The Bignons are half a mile eastward from the Justieres and uncover 6 feet. Several rocky patches of from 9 to 18 feet lie near them. Grande and Petite Liviere are two rocky patches north westward of cape Frehel. The Grande Liviere, with 14 feet water, See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. HI.] DANGERS. — AMAS-DU-CAP. — CHENAL D'ERQUI. 101 lies N.W. | W. 3 miles from the cape, with the lighthouse nearly touching the southern extreme of Amas-du-Cap. A vessel will pass northward of this patch by keeping the summit of Amas-du-Cap on with the lighthouse. At night, the light should not bear more easterly than S.E. by S. Pleneuf point on with the low extreme of cape d'Erqui leads half a mile northward ; and, the spire of Plurien church on with the summit of the Renard rock, described at page 103, S.S.W. W. leads about 2 cables eastward. The Petite Liviere, with only 9 feet, bears S.S.W. 8 cables from the Grande Liviere. When on this patch, cape Frehel lighthouse bears S.E. by E. § E. easterly 3 miles ; the summit of Amus-du-Cap is on with the most southerly of two houses on the summit of the cape ; and, Garenne mill, the westernmost of two mills near the coast, is on with the north-western extreme of St. Michel islet, S.W. | W. The spire of Plurien church on with the Renard, which leads clear of the Grande Liviere, almost touches the eastern edge of the Petite Liviere. AMAS-du-CAP, a large and remarkable rock W. by N. £ N. 4 cables from the western extreme of cape Frehel, never covers ; when approached from the N.W., it is not easily distinguished from the granite cliffs behind it, but from eastward or westward, when clear of the land, it may be seen from a long distance and resembles a wedge with the high end to the northward. Westward of Amas-du-Cap, between it and St. Michel islet, are several rocky clusters 7 or 8 cables off-shore ; the principal are, the Plate St. Michel, on which stands a red beacon with conical top-mark, the Mouillee which uncovers 13 feet, the Malicorne, the Truie, nearly awash, and the Jars which uncovers 12 feet at the lowest tides. ERQUI BAY is a small beaching place on the southern shore of the peninsula terminated by cape d'Erqui, opposite the village of Erqui which is in the south-eastern corner of the bay. Vessels ground on a bottom which dries about 16 feet above the lowest tides, and are sheltered from N.N.W. round by East to South. The southern side of the bay is formed by the lofty point of Lahoussaye, which is prolonged seaward by an islet and some rocks. A jetty in the northern angle of the bay, 1£ cables westward of the little hamlet of La Chaussee, affords shelter against westerly See chart, No. 2,669 *.

HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. III. 102 winds to vessels capable of taking the ground, and is now (1896) being lengthened ; it should be left to port on entering. A black beacon with cylindrical top-mark is placed about 130 yards southward of the pier. A small red light is shown from the end of the masonry. About 150 coasting vessels enter this little port annually. Rade d'Erqui, close southward of cape d'Erqui and fronting Erqui bay, is the only anchorage on the eastern shore of St. Brieuc bay affording tolerable shelter, in 5 or 6 fathoms water, from easterly winds. The holding-ground is good, but it is prudent to leave it, especially in the winter season, if the weather is threatening and the wind likely to veer to the westward. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the summit of cape d'Erqui ; see page 12. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Erqui roads at 6h. ; equinoctial springs rise 43 feet, ordinary springs 33j feet, and ordinary neaps 24^ feet above the soundings. CHENAL d'ERQUI is the passage between the belt of rocks bordering the coast from cape d'Erqui to St. Michel islet, on the one hand, and the Grand-Pourier, Rohinet, and Justieres ledges on the other. The depth is not less than 2\ fathoms in the fairway of this channel at low water, springs, when it can be navigated only by small coasters ; with a free wind, vessels of deep draught may pass through from half flood to half ebb. Anchorage. — If windbound with strong northerly gales, some shelter may be found during neaps by anchoring southward of the Plate St. Michel rock, with the Rohinet rock nearly touching the eastern shore of St. Michel islet. The depths here are from 19 to 22 feet, with good holding-ground of muddy sand. Bouche d'Erqui. — This inlet is nearly 3 miles eastward of cape d'Erqui and about a mile in extent ; it dries at low water and its shore is formed of white sandy downs. About half a mile north ward of Champ du Port point, the western point of the inlet, is the islet of St. Michel before alluded to, which is joined to the coast at low water and on which stands a chapel, very useful as a seamark This is the only place on this part of the coast where, in bad weather and when compelled to do so, a vessel can run ashore with See chart, No. 2,669 b,

Chap. III.] ERQUI BAY.— DIRECTIONS. 103 the hope of saving her crew. The vessel even might be saved if she were beached southward of Champ du Port point about an hour after high water. Renard rock.— Buoy.— Off the eastern side of Bouche d'Erqui bay and near the shore is this rock, which never covers, and is a useful mark : it stands out in dark outline against Bouche d'Erqui white sandy beach, and has a black buoy with cylindrical top-mark moored on its south-western side. Life-Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Pleherel, a fishing village about 2 miles eastward of Bouche d'Erqui and 3 miles westward of cape Frehel. DIRECTIONS. — Vessels bound eastward and surprised by easterly winds when in the neighbourhood of the Lejons, may bear up for shelter and run for the rade d'Erqui by the Landas channel, by that between the Rohein and Petit Lejon, or between the Rohein and the Jaunes to leeward of all the outer shoals, as wind and tide may best serve. Through the Landas Channel.— If far enough to windward, this channel, between the Petit Lejon and Pierres du Bane, is practicable for vessels of the deepest draught after half flood. Three sand-banks, dangerous only from the heavy sea they occasion when it blows hard on a weather tide, lie in this channel ; from the largest, on which there are 4^ fathoms, Tournemine mill is on with the Verdelet rock S.S.W ± W. Run through this channel with Tournemine mill on with the highest summit of the Comtesses S. by W. \ W. westerly until Turquet mill comes on with Trois Pierres point, half a mile south ward of cape d'Erqui, S.S.E. E. Follow this latter mark until within about 5 cables of cape d'Erqui, when steer for Erqui road. A vessel will keep eastward of the Petit Lejon by having the Verdelet rock open eastward of the summit of the Comtesses ; she will also pass north-eastward of the Basse des Comtesses, and of the Comtesses, by keeping Turquet mill in sight eastward of Lahoussaye point, which mark will also ensure her not being too close to the eastern part of the Portes d'Erqui, marked by a red beacon turret. The dangers on the eastern side of the channel may be avoided by not standing eastward of the line of Turquet mill just touching the high land of cape d'Erqui. See chart, No. 2,669 b. SO 11886

[Chap. III. 104 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. The Channel between the Rohein and Petit Lejon may be taken when seeking shelter in Erqui road, either on the flood or ebb. The summit of the Comtesses on with the southern extreme of Bien-Assis wood S. by E. | E. leads 5 cables westward of the Grand Lejon and 2 cables westward of the Petit Lejon, close to the black bell-buoy marking the latter. Steer with this mark on until past the Petit Lejon, when Turquet mill will be on with Lahoussaye point ; haul up for it, opening the mill a little eastward of the point to avoid the Comtesses, &c, and this will lead into the road as before. In following this route before half flood, great care must be taken to avoid the Daouelins and Comtesses patches, and the Izard rock, Portes d'Erqui, on the southern side of the channel, as well as the Petit Lejon on the northern side ; also, at low water and in bad weather, a 21-feet patch S. by E. \ E. 1\ cables from the Petit Lejon. The Channel between the Rohein and the Jaunes may be taken by a vessel too much to leeward for either of the others, and it is sufficiently deep for vessels of moderate draught even at low water. Having passed the Rohein rock, and in working up for the rade d'Erqui, when standing northward, cape Frehel lighthouse open southward of the summit of the Comtesses clears the southern part of the Rohein ledge ; and, the lighthouse on with the large pointed rock at the foot of cape d'Erqui clears the southern part of the Portes d'Erqui. In making the southern board, cape Frehel lighthouse open northward of cape d'Erqui leads northward of the Jaunes ; and, Turquet mill well on with the steep coast which separates the beach of Erqui bay from the beach of the large bay to the southward, keeps her northward of the Ecarets rocks, which uncover 2 feet at the lowest tides. Pleneuf point bearing S.W. by W. leads northward of the Guyomere and of the Ecarets, and between the Portes d'Erqui and the cape. Through Erqui Channel. — If surprised by strong easterly winds between cape Frehel and St. Malo, a vessel may bear up for shelter in Erqui road by passing through the Erqui channel between half flood and half ebb. For this purpose, having rounded cape Frehel, steer to the westward with the southern end of Amas-du-Cap islet touching the extreme of the cape E. \ S. ; this mark leads northward of the Jars. Round cape Frehel it runs with great strength, at least 5 knots, and there are strong eddies occasioning a heavy breaking sea in bad weather. CAPE FREHEL. — This promontory is the northern extreme of a high narrow neck of land a mile in length, 1\ miles eastward of cape d'Erqui, and nearly 12 miles westward of St. Malo. It is bordered on all sides by steep perpendicular cliffs about 150 feet high, and in clear weather may be seen from a distance of 15 or 18 miles. On the summit of some level land 550 yards S.S.W. from its extreme is the lighthouse, an octagonal tower 72 feet high, and about 40 yards westward of the ruins of the old lighthouse ; from it, Heaux lighthouse bears N.W. \ W. westerly 33^ miles ; Grand Lejon lighthouse N.W. by W. 1\\ miles ; Corbiere light, at the south western extreme of Jersey island, N.N.E. 29^ miles : and, Grand Jardin lighthouse, at the entrance of St. Malo, E.S.E. 9£ miles. LIGHT. — The lighthouse on cape Frehel exhibits a fixed and flashing white light of the first order, showing a flash every half minute. It is 259 feet above the level of high water, and is visible in clear weather 23 miles. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on cape Frehel half way between the lighthouse and the extreme point ; see page 12. Vessels from the westward prevented rounding cape Frehel during easterly winds by the ebb stream, may await the turn of tide under the lee of the cape by making short tacks within the following limits : — Amas-du-Cap seen between the extreme of the cape and the lighthouse ; Amas-du-Cap between two and three times its apparent breadth northward of the cape ; and, Plurien church spire between the Renard rock and the eastern point of Bouche d'Erqui. This latter point is steep and high, whilst the Renard rock, as before observed, never covers, and stands out boldly against the white beach of Bouche d'Erqui. See chart. No. 2.669 b.

The COAST.— From cape Frehel lighthouse, pointe du Roc or cape Lihou, on the southern side of which promontory is the port of Granville, bears East 29 miles, and the lighthouse on Pierre de Herpin E. by S. 20 miles. The general direction of the coast line from point to point is south-easterly for nearly 7 miles from cape Frehel to the ile des Ehbiens ; from thence it is easterly for 15 miles to pointe de Grouin, the western point of the large but shallow Baie du Mont St. Michel ; here the coast trends suddenly southward for about 6 miles, then eastward for about 15 miles, and, lastly, northward about 8 miles to pointe de Champeaux, the eastern point of the bay, which bears from pointe de Grouin E. § S. 11 miles, the coast line following the circuit of the bay being at least thrice that distance. From pointe de Champeaux, pointe du Roc bears North 5| miles.* About half way between cape Frehel and pointe de Grouin is the large and important port and town of St. Malo, at the entrance of the river Ranee ; between it and cape Frehel are several small harbours and deep but shallow bays with anchorages fairly sheltered against westerly winds, but the whole of the coast between these two points is fronted by numerous dangerous rocks and ledges extending from one to*4 miles from the land. IV. 108 Between Cape Frehel and point de Grouin the general aspect of the shore is rocky, rugged, and moderately high ; but, within the bay of St. Michel, from Chateau Richeux point eastward, it is very low, flat, and marshy. It again rises in the vicinity of pointe de Champeaux, a bluff and nearly perpendicular headland, and from thence to Granville is of moderate height, the flat sands extending off it in this neighbourhood being interspersed by low, flat, rocky ledges. ANSE des SEVIGNES, a small bay open to the N.E. between cape Frehel and Latte point, has many dangers within it, and should not be run for as a place of shelter in heavy weather from the S.W., on account of the great overfalls in it caused by the steepness of the coast, and the violent squalls off the land to which it is subject. Bane de FEtendree lies off the northern part of Sevignes bay ; from the Etendree rock at its western end, which uncovers 14^ feet, it extends about 8 cables in a S.E. by E. direction, and is 2^ cables wide ; some parts are nearly awash at the lowest tides. Basse de la Latte and Basse Raimonde. — These rocks, lying southward of the bane de l'Etendree, render the approach to Sevignes bay or to within a mile of this rugged and precipitous coast very dangerous, though the fishermen congregate here occasionally in great numbers. The Latte bears N.N.E. E. 3^ cables from the fort on Latte point, and uncovers a foot at the lowest tides ; the Raimonde bears N.N.W. \ W. 4 cables from the fort, and uncovers 9 feet. BAIE de la FRENAY, between Latte and St. Cast points, affords good shelter with off-shore winds 'but is quite exposed to those from the N.E. The entrance is 2 miles wide, and from thence the bay trends 3^ miles in a S.W. by W. direction to its head, but more than 2 miles of that expanse dries at low water. The surrounding land is high, and its northern shore free from danger. The holding-ground is good, and the best anchorage is in from 4^ to 5 fathoms, about half a mile off Cierge point, just south ward of Latte point, with cape Frehel lighthouse seen between Cierge See chart, No. 2,669 *.

Arguenon bay. — From St. Cast point, at low water, dry sands connect the shore with the ile des Ehbiens Imd with the opposite coast in the vicinity of St. Briac harbour, the two deep bays of Arguenon and Lancieux, separated by a narrow promontory ending in point Roche, being then dry throughout. ILE des EHBIENS, about a mile in circumference, is off point Roche, just described, at the head of the bight between cape Frehel and St. Malo. It is surrounded by high rocks, and near its centre is a large and conspicuous tower which may be recognised from a great distance. It is joined to the shore at low water by the bank of sand which borders the coast from St. Cast point to the entrance to St. Briac. Close southward of Ehbiens is a well-sheltered grounding place, much frequtnted by coasting vessels formerly but not much used since the channels into St. Malo have been well lighted and marked. It is formed by a natural causeway of shingle, always uncovered and uniting the south-western extreme of the island with some high rocks 2 cables to the South-west. The bottom is muddy sand and seaweed, and dries 7 or 8 feet above the lowest tides, which rise from 28 to 35 feet above it at springs, and 18 or 19 feet at neaps. The best place for grounding, sheltered from all winds, is about half a cable from the southern end of the island, with Agot island entirely shut in by the south-eastern extreme of Ehbiens. BRIAC. 111 southern sides of the bay are several rocks, of which the Mouliere, marked by a beacon, dries 31 feet : the Rochefort dries 39 feet, and the Gautrat, marked by a red and black beacon, dries 17 feet. Directions. — When running for the grounding place at the southern end of Ehbiens, as soon as the island is made out, steer to pass about 1^ cables eastward of the Haches, a ridge of rocks, of which some are always uncovered, extending 5 cables in a north-easterly direction from its northern point. When Ehbiens tower bears N.W., haul close round the south-eastern point of the island and anchor, or, if necessary, run the vessel on the beach. If obliged to beat in, be careful to avoid the Platus and other rocks just described, as well as a half-tide rock one cable eastward of the high rocks at the southern end of the causeway. St. BRIAC. —This little tidal harbour has little or no trade, is difficult of access, and should never be attempted without a pilot. It is at the entrance of a narrow valley H miles eastward of Ehbiens and about 8 cables southward of the high projecting point of Haye. The entrance, 2 cables wide, is between the Perronais black beacon marking the westernmost rock of the ledge extending south westward from the southern end of Perron isle, about one cable. distant from it and which dries 12 feet, and a red beacon on the extreme of a rocky ridge projecting northward from the peninsula of Lancieux ; this latter rock dries 15 feet at the lowest tides, and, in entering the harbour, a vessel should steer to pass between these two beacons. Approaching the harbour from the north-westward, the leading mark up to the entrance is, Marche mill, which stands south eastward of the village, just touching the mound of the calvary of St. Briac. The channel narrows considerably half a mile within the beacons at the entrance, and a vessel has then to pass between rocky heads, marked by beacons, the highest of which uncovers 19 feet, leaving red beacons on the starboard hand, black beacons on the port hand, and passing the Bouche beacon, in the middle of the channel, on either side ; after which she may anchor or ground as desired ; three warping buoys are placed to assist vessels to their berths. The tides run with great strength in the channel, and the harbour is exposed to a heavy sea with strong north-westerly winds. Depths.— Pilots berth vessels N.N.W. of the town of St. Briac, See ahart, No. 2,669 4.

From it, cape Frehel lighthouse bears W.S.W. llf miles ; Chausey lighthouse E. \ N. 11£ miles ; Grand Jardin lighthouse at the entrance of St. Malo S. by W. \ W. 8f miles ; and, the nearest rocks of the Minquiers group, fully described at pages 153 — 161, are only 5 miles distant to the northward. Chap. IV.] tLE DE CEZEMBRE. — ST. MALO. 115 Directions. — When steering eastward along the coast between cape Frehel and Grouin point, at or after half ebb, bear in mind that so. long as the Herpin rock, which a stranger must remember is not the rock on which the Herpin light stands, see page 144, is twice its breadth open northward of the Rochefort black and red beacon turret, the vessel will pass northward of the Vieux Bane, and of all dangers between it and the Rochefort ; also, that in coming from the eastward, with cape Frehel lighthouse open northward of the Rochefort, there is nothing to fear from the Tintiaux or from any of the shoals in the immediate vicinity of Grouin point -. this latter is, however, a very distant mark. ST. MALO.*— The town of St. Malo stands at the mouth of the river Ranee, on the eastern side, on what was formerly a small rocky island, since connected with the mainland by the Sillon, a narrow causeway three quarters of a mile long. In the construction of the modern Inner harbour, this causeway has been greatly widened and strengthened and now forms the northern side of the Bassin de St. Malo, with extensive quays and railway accommodation. The whole area of the former island is occupied by houses, and the walls are flanked by towers washed by the sea. The manufactures are hosiery, cordage, soap, fishing nets, &c, but they are not extensive ; there is also a tobacco factory. Shipbuilding is carried on, and besides building slips there are two gridirons for repairs, but no facilities for extensive repairs to iron hulls or machinery. Vessels are fitted out for the foreign and coasting trades, the former being chiefly with England and the northern countries of Europe, and for the whale and mackerel fisheries ; about 1,000 vessels enter the port annually. The imports consist chiefly of coal, iron, pitch, &c. ; the exports of barley, butter, potatoes, fruit, wine, provisions, &c. Regular steam communication is maintained with the Channel islands, and from thence with England, by the steamers of the London and South-Western Railway ; and there is regular communication with Cardiff, Hull , St. Brieuc, Granville, and Havre by lines of steamers. Steam ferries ply between Dinard, on the opposite shore of the Ranee, St. Malo, and St. Servan. The population of St. Malo is about 10,000, and that of the adjoining town of St. Servan 12,000 ; St. Servan stands on higher ground and may be considered a suburb of St. Malo. MA.LO PORT, protected by the town and Mole des Noires, is much frequented, and, with St. Servan, has 2,560 yards of quay frontage ; it is difficult of approach, the flood rushing into the river entrance with great strength, and equinoctial tides rising to the height of 44f feet above the level of the lowest tides. It is also inconvenient of access to vessels of deep draught during the winter months, owing to the fact of high water, full and change. occurring at 6h. 5m., i.e., before daylight in the morning and after dark in the evening. The harbour of St. Malo contains no dry dock, though two were originally projected ; it consists of the Avant-port sheltered by the Mole, and the Bassin-a-Flot, from which the Bassins of St. Malo and St. Servan are entered. The Bassin-a-Flot is entered from the Avant-port by a passage 320 feet wide between the Bourse quay of St. Malo and the end of the wall and embankment projecting from the northern point of St. Servan ; there is in it a careening pontoon for 300-ton vessels, two gridirons for the same class, and many warping buoys. On its eastern side is an interior reservoir, 66 acres in area, used for flushing purposes and for laying up dismantled shipping. A stone sill, used as a footpath when uncovered, crosses the entrance to the Bassin-a-Flot, and regulates the depth of water retained in this Bassin ; it is raised 11 feet above the level of the lowest tides. Depths. — The anchorages in St. Malo and Dinard roads are accessible by the Grand Chenal at all times of tide to vessels of the deepest draught. The Avant port dries from 6 to 9 feet at the lowest tides, and has from 31 to 34 feet water at ordinary springs, and 10 feet less at neaps. The Bassin-a-Flot has 29i feet over the sill at high water, springs, and 19 feet at neaps ; the general depth within the Bassin-a-Flot, after the water has fallen to the level of the sill, is from 12 to 16 feet.. The Bassin of St. Malo has an area of 38 acres, a length of 1,143 yards, and a width of 152 yards ; that of St. Servan an area of 33 acres, a length of 826 yards, and a width of 207 yards. The lock entrances are in each case 305 feet long between the gates. Vessels of 13 feet draught can enter the basins at neap tides, and of 23 feet draught at ordinary springs ; but, from the shape of the basins, there is not moorage accommodation for vessels over 295 feet in length and 22 feet draught. Vessels can enter or leave the basins from 1\ hours before to 1\ hours after high water in the day time, See chart, No. 2,700.

Chap. IV.] ST. MALO. — LIGHTS. 117 but they are not opened by night except by special request, and a special charge is made. Coals are always obtainable, from 3,000 to 4,000 tons being usually in stock ; vessels coal alongside the quays, where there is always sufficient water for steamers of frcm 1,000 to 1,200 tons. The Mole des Noires, a neat and substantial stone pier, built on the Noires rocks at the south-western angle of the town, in addition to its great convenience for landing passengers, protects the port from the heavy roll of the sea, to which it would be other wise exposed with north-westerly winds. The pier is 1,290 feet long, about 16 feet wide, and at its head is a lighthouse. A Life-Boat is stationed at St. Malo. LIGHTS. — Five lights are established at and in the vicinity of St. Malo to assist the intricate navigation amongst the numerous dangers which mark the approaches to this port, viz. : — 1. — Grand Jardin. — On the south extreme of Grand Jardin islet is a circular lighthouse from which is exhibited a fixed and flashing light ; the light shows white, varied every twenty seconds by alternate red and green flashes, each flash being of two seconds' duration. The light is 66 feet above high water, is visible 14 miles, and in conjunction with that on Rochebonne is a leading light. 2. — Rochebonne light, northward of the village of St. Hydeuc. bears E. by S. \ S. (N. 89° E. true) 4| miles from Grand Jardin light, and is about 2^ miles eastward from St. Malo. It is shown from a square light tower, white at base and black at summit ; it is a fixed red light, 128 feet above high water, and visible 16 miles from seaward, but only 9° on either side of its line of bearing from Grand Jardin light. 3. St. Malo. — At the head of the Mole des Noires is a white circular lighthouse, from which, at 33 feet above high water, is shown a fixed white light, visible 10 miles. 4_ Anse des Sablons. — From a square white house on the southern shore of this bay is exhibited at 60 feet above high water an occulting green light with a period of four seconds; it is visible 8 miles, and in conjunction with Balue light, gives the direction for the entrance of the harbour. 5.— Balue.— On Balue hill S.E. by S. (S. 51° E. true) 1,804 yards See chart, No. 2,700.

IV. from the Sablons light, from a square tower with a top, is exhibited at 221 feet above high water, a fixed green light visible 11 miles for 8° on either side of the line of bearing of Sablons light. PILOTS. — The St. Malo pilots cruise in all weathers in two cutters : one is stationed near cape Frehel, the other cruises off the port, between it and the Chausey isles ; in bad weather the latter frequently takes shelter under the lee of Cezembre island. There are 10 pilots belonging to St, Malo and 5 pilots at St. Cast ; these latter can always pilot vessels to the roadsteads, but not into the basins unless no St. Malo pilot presents himself ; they may generally be found off ile de Brehat and near the Roches-Douvres. With westerly winds, vessels from the westward requiring pilots should keep near cape Frehel : with north-easterly winds, near the Minquiers rocks. It is the duty of all masters of vessels to facilitate the boarding of a pilot, and to make signals at night by blue lights and flare-up lights ; also, by day, to keepthe pilot jack up until the Bassin is entered. Every pilot has a silver anchor attached to a button-hole of his waistcoat, and has a livret or pocket-book which he is bound to produce on demand. ROADSTEADS. — There are two fair roadsteads at the mouth of the river Ranee, where vessels of deep draught generally anchor to unload, or to await tide to enter the port ; they are, the Rade de St. Malo and the anchorage of Dinard. The Rade de Solidor, off the bay of that name and abreast of St. Servan, is too shallow and confined to receive vessels of large size. RADE de St. MALO is on the eastern side of the entrance to the Ranee, 4 cables westward of the town of St. Malo ; it occupies a space about 2 cables long, North and South, is a cable wide, and has from 27 to 32 feet water throughout. It is bounded on the North by the Basse Broutard, on the East by the sand-bank which fronts the town and dries at low water, and on the South by the Plateau de la Ranee, the northern head of which bears S. \ E. 2| cables from the Broutard . The Petite Rade is southward of the plateau de la Ranee. Basse Broutard is a small rocky patch about 130 yards long E.S.E. and W.N.W., and 60 yards wide, with only 8 feet water ; from it, the sentry box on Varde point is seen between Grand and Petit Bey islets ; and St. Hydeuc church steeple is a little open See chart. No. 2.700.

Chap. IV.] 119 ST. MALO. — ROADSTEADS. — DANGERS. northward of the northern bastion of the ramparts of St. Malo. bearing East. Plateau de la Ranee.— Buoys.— This rocky ledge, 2^ cables in extent North and South and one cable wide, has on it six dangerous heads, two of which uncover, one 2 feet the other 3 feet, at the lowest tides, when there are from 1 to 2 feet only on three of the other heads, and 16 feet on the sixth, which is at the northern part of the ledge. Two buoys, the northern one black and white, the other black, mark the North and South-west extremes of this danger. Clearing marks. — The Bourse of St. Malo, on the quay south ward of the town, just opening of the S.W. bastion, leads northward of this ridge. The western head of Bizeux rock on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point S. \ E. leads 65 yards eastward. The Merciere beacon on with the eastern head of the Bizeux S. by E. \ E., leads westward, and the Bourse on with the Noire mole-head leads southward of the 2-feet head near the southern end of the ridge. The Bizeux is a large high rock, lying East and West, to the southward of the Bane de Solidor, described at page 121. Two deep clefts divide its summit into three conspicuous heads. Eastward of this rock is the Petit Bizeux marked by a red beacon. Anchorage. — The holding-ground in St. Malo road is fairly good, and vessels moor nearly North and South in the direction of the tidal streams. The best position is in the middle of the road, with the eastern head of the Bizeux on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point ; and, the mound on Garde Guerin point a little open southward of the summit of the Grand Vide. Vessels of light draught anchor a little eastward of this. The road is well-sheltered from all winds between West and N.E. round by South and East, but northerly and north-westerly winds, when they blow with any strength, send in a heavy sea during the time the ledges outside the river are covered, i.e., from 2h. before to 2h. after high water, at springs. The flood stream in the road never exceeds 3 knots ; and the ebb, which Bechard point turns towards the opposite shore, never runs with sufficient strength to prevent communication with the port. See chart, No. 2,700. II SO 11886

CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. IV. 120 There is fair holding ground in from 18 to 22 feet in the Petite Rade de St. Malo, a short distance southward and south-eastward of the Plateau de la Ranee. When at anchor in the centre of this road, the extreme of Bechard point is on with the middle of the Bizeux, and the outer angle of St. Louis bastion is open about half a point southward of the mole-head. ANSE de DINARD.— This bay is abreast of St. Malo on the western side of the Ranee, between points Dinard and Vicomte ; grounding places extend along its western shore, from the old ship yard below the village to the new one beneath the mill on Dinard point. The bottom here dries from 12 to 15 feet, with a very gradual slope towards the edge of the bank ; springs rise above it from 18 to 24 feet, neaps 9 or 10 feet ; it is composed of stiff mud covered with seaweed, and when it blows hard from the N.E. vessels strike heavily in grounding, and, as the anchors of small vessels bite with difficulty, care should be taken to bury them in the mud at low water ; avoid also grounding eastward of the line on which Grande Conchee fort begins to open eastward of Dinard point, as the bottom there is deeply furrowed. Dinard anchorage. — Vessels of deep draught, unable to enter port St. Malo during neaps, often await spring tides at this anchorage, where they are well sheltered from all but northerly winds. It is just outside the outer edge of the mud in Dinard bay, and is half a mile in extent from the Petit Palais rock to the Basse Schevre ; its outer limit does not extend eastward of the line of the Muriers rock, close to the south-western point of Cezembre island, just opening and shutting in with the eastern slope of Dinard point. The best anchorage, where the depths are from 26 to 30 feet, is limited northward by the line of the Solidor tower seen between the extreme of Bechard point and the little fort ; aud, southward, by the same tower open its own breadth northward of the high steeple of St. Servan church. This roadstead is the general rendezvous for vessels of war ; it is preferable to that of St. Malo road, being better sheltered against the prevailing winds, though the holding-ground, except close to the edge of the mud, is not so good, and the tides are stronger. Ships at this anchorage should always be ready to weigh or slip, as bad weather may at any time make it necessary to take shelter farther up the Ranee. See chart, No. 2,700.

Chap. IV.] ST. MALO.— DINARD AND SOLIDOR ROADS. 121 ANSE de SOLIDOR, on the western side of the town of St. Servan, is a cable wide at the entrance, and its shores are almost entirely occupied by the military establishments of the town. Merchant vessels remaining some time in the bay are usually placed at the entrance, between the quai des Corbieres and the rocks at the foot of Solidor tower, where the bottom dries 12 or 13 feet, and springs rise from 25 to 32 feet above that level, neaps about 15 feet. A stone slip with a wooden platform at the end, for the accom modation of passengers from Dinard, extends from near the Solidor tower to the edge of the sands which dry ; this is very dangerous to vessels entering Solidor bay. When the Petit Bizeux rock, marked by a red beacon, is awash there are 15 feet water over the platform at the end of the slip. A small grounding place called St. Pere port, in the northern part of the bay at the foot of the peninsula of La Cite, northward of the Solidor tower, is about 84 yards wide, 270 yards deep, and will contain 14 or 15 vessels of the tonnage and draught of those employed in the Newfoundland trade. The grounding places towards the middle of this bay dry 10 feet. Vessels of about 13 feet draught can enter at high water, neaps. Solidor road is a small deep, parallel with the shore, 2 cables long North and South, and only about 80 yards wide between the beach which dries in front of Solidor bay and the Solidor bank, which also dries about 8 feet ; the soundings are shallow, and, being so narrow, long-heeled vessels occasionally take the ground, the greatest depths at low water being 18 feet. The road is sheltered on all sides so long as the bank is uncovered ; but when it blows hard from the westward and the bank is covered there is considerable swell. Two mooring buoys occupy the best positions in this road, and a black beacon on the North extreme of the Zorieux rocks marks its southern extreme. Bane de Solidor bounds Solidor road to the westward, and uncovers 8 feet. Its northern extreme is 85 yards southward of Bechard point ; from thence it extends 3 cables S.S.E. and terminates less than 100 yards northward of the Bizeux rock. It is about a cable broad, and is composed of fine white sand mixed with broken shells. See chart, No. 2,700. SO 11886 H 2

RIVIERE de LA RANCE — The Ranee is tidal as far as Dinan, 14 miles above St. Malo, and navigable at high water the whole distance ; but, the last anchorage at which vessels of moderate size can lie afloat at low water is at Jouvente, only 3 miles above St. Malo. Tides and tidal Streams.— It is high water, full and change, at port St. Malo at 6h. 5m. ; equinoctial springs rise 45 feet above the zero of soundings, which is the level of the lowest tide known, see page 4 ; ordinary springs rise 40^ feet, ordinary neaps 30 feet. The water rises above the sill of the entrance to the bassin-a-flot 33^ feet at equinoctial springs, 29^ feet at ordinary springs, and 19 feet at ordinary neaps. The height of the tide above this sill is shown on three tide scales, one painted on the outer face of Noire mole-head, another on the quai of St. Malo, near the entrance, and a third on the face of the jetty of St. Servan. The streams run with great strength during springs at the entrance of the Grande and Petite Conchee channels, the flood north-eastward, the ebb south-westward. Their rate is about 4 knots at half tide, across the Grand chenal de la Ranee until as far in as the Buron beacon turret. Southward of the Buron beacon turret the flood curves and sets into the river with the same velocity. The ebb from the river divides, one part running out by the Grand chenal, the other by the Decolle passage. Both streams take the direction of the latter passage and run at about the same rate, 3 to 4 knots. CHANNELS leading into the RANCE— All the channels leading into St. Malo are between Garde Guerin and Varde points, through the midst of the numberless dangers by which the coast is so thickly studded. These channels lead between rocks, some always above water and many others which uncover between a quarter ebb and low water, and amongst sand-banks and shoals, of which some are dry or nearly awash at low water, springs ; several small islets, however— such as Cezembre, described at page 114, Grande Conchee, Harbour isle, the Beys, and the higher rocks— serve as good marks by which these dangers may be avoided. The main course of the Ranee extends 3^ miles north-westward beyond Dinard point and St. Malo, through the Grand chenal de la Ranee, with its double opening through the Grande and Petite See chart, No. 2,700,

Chap. IV.] ST. MALO.— RANCE RIVER.— DECOLLE PASSAGE. 123 Porte channels. Entering by the Grande or Petite Porte channels, there are not less than from 4 to 5 fathoms at low water ; this entrance is, therefore, navigable at all times by vessels of deep draught. Besides this channel there are five others through which pilots take vessels with a proper rise of tide ; they are, the Decolle, close to the land south-westward of the Grande Porte ; the Petite and Grande Conchee ; the Petits Pointus ; and, the Bigne. The four last are all eastward of the ile de Cezembre. With easterly winds, pilots prefer entering the Ranee by the Conchee, in preference to the Grande or Petite Porte channels, the eddies with these winds not being so violent in the Conchee as in the other channels. DECOLLE PASSAGE lies close along shore westward of the entrance to the Ranee, from Dinard point to Decolle point, on which latter is a Semaphore ; it can be navigated by vessels of moderate draught from half flood to half ebb ; in case of need, those of deep draught may use it with a leading wind, at springs, from one hour before until one hour after high water. Pilots prefer this channel with an off-shore wind, as the sea is then smooth ; its limits are defined by beacons on rocks, nearly all of which cover at high water, springs, and its western entrance is between Decolle point and the Mouilliere rock where its breadth does not exceed half a cable. Directions. — Vessels entering the Decolle passage from the westward generally pass between Agot, a high and narrow islet about one mile westward of Garde Guerin point, and Nerput, a high isolated rock which uncovers 40 feet, 8 cables northward of that point, and on which is a red beacon turret 13 feet above high water. This entrance has the advantage of being directly with the tide, but in stormy weather it cannot always be taken, as breakers sometimes extend completely across' the pass between Decolle point and La Mouilliere. Mole des Noires lighthouse just open northward of the high rocks at the extreme of Decolle point E.S.E., leads between the Nerput rock and the Grande Brousse bank, on which there are only 11 feet water (but at the time of tide when this passage is navigable there are at least 30 feet over it), and l\ cables northward of the See chart, No. 2,700.

124 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. IV. Platier des Lardieres. Keep this mark on until the steeple of St. Hydeuc church is on with the summit of the Grand Buzard E. | S., which leads in the deepest part through the western entrance of the passage, about 150 yards southward of the red beacon on the Mouilliere rock ; if the Grand Buzard is covered, keep Parame church and St. Hydeuc windmill in sight between Fort Royal and Harbour isle, with the church the same distance northward of the fort as the mill appears southward of the isle. Having passed these narrows, proceeding with La Latte fort on with the Nerput NW. by W. \ W., or with the southern mill of Talard, white, twice its width open northward of the Mole des Noires lighthouse and on with the end of the white mark on the Mole, the vessel may run eastward between the Petit Buzard and Petit Genillet rocks and between the Mouille and Rochardien rocks, all of which have beacons, and, when near the latter, the dome of St. Servan church will be seen between the two chimneys of the house in fort La Cite, which from thence is the leading mark until the maregraphe at point Bechard is on with a little clump of trees between points Corbiere and Aiguille, or until the highest of the Cheminees rocks is on with the cleft in the Mouille rock, either of which marks leads into the fairway of the river between the Pierres d'Amourette and the Roches Bonnes, and between the Pourceaux rocks and Mi-Maree rock off Dinard point, all of which rocks are also marked by beacons. If the tide is low, the dome of St. Servan church will not be visible, but only the standard of the lightning conductor on its summit. The Mouille rock is at the western end of the Pourceaux bank, and it uncovers 39 feet at the lowest tides ; when it is more than 3 feet above water, a vessel must pass between Dinard point and the Pourceaux rocks by the directions just given, but when the Mouille is covered, or is less than 3 feet out of water, vessels of considerable draught may run across the bank between that rock and the Pierres d'Amourette rocks, there being then at least 4 fathoms over it. To cross the bank, steer E. by S. with the mound on Garde Guerin point, seen over the land of Decolle point, well open northward of the Grand Vide rock, which never covers ; this mark leads up to St. Malo road, where vessels generally anchor until there is sufficient water to enter the port. This track is often followed by vessels See chart, No. 2,700.

Chap. IV.] ST. MALO. — DIRECTIONS TO SOLIDOR ROAD. 125 leaving St. Malo on the ebb by the Decolle passage, the narrow and dangerous pass between the Pourceaux beacon turret and Dinard point being thus avoided. Vessels often pass northward of the Nerput rock and enter the Decolle passage either by running between the beacons on the Mouilliere and Petit Pot-de-Beurre rocks, or by passing close eastward of the beacon on the latter. Either of these channels has the disadvantage of a beam tide, but the former has a good depth of water and is nearly a cable wide. To steer through it, keep well northward of the Nerput, and bring the white marks of Roche Pelee and Pival in line bearing S.S.E. | E. ; this leads through the centre of the channel up to the leading marks already given for the Decolle passage, leaving on the starboard hand at 4 cables a 19-feet patch named Rat du Nord-Est, at nearly one cable the Basses des Marechaux, and at 70 or 80 yards the outlying rocks of the Mouilliere. On the port hand, it passes 120 yards from the Sauts-aux-Chiens, 100 yards from the Grande Basse, and close past some rocks awash at low water extending more than a cable south-westward from the beacon on the Petit Pot-de-Beurre. To pass over the reefs and eastward of the Petit Pot-de-Beurre, bring St. Enogat mill on with the northern extreme of the little patch of white sand just westward of Pelee point S.E. by S. ; this mark leads over the Sauts-aux-Chiens, a rocky patch on which there are 10 feet at low water and from 30 to 36 feet at half flood, and half a cable eastward of the Petit Pot-de-Beurre beacon. When this beacon is passed, haul a little southward to enter the Decolle passage and to avoid a small rock which uncovers 4 feet a cable southward of the Grand Pot-de-Beurre. As soon as the leading marks for the Decolle passage come on, proceed as before directed. From St. Malo road to Solidor road.— When southward of the plateau de la Ranee, the two principal dangers to be avoided between St. Malo and Solidor roads are the Rat de la Merciere and the Merciere ridge ; the former is a small isolated rock, with only 4 feet water, in mid-channel NW. \ N. 3^ cables from Bechard point ; when the Pourceaux rocks are covered there are 17 feet on this danger, and 22 feet when the tide reaches the foot of the Pierres d'Amourette beacon. The Merciere ridge is half a cable westward of La Cite peninsula. The highest head on this ridge uncovers 20 feet at the lowest tides, covers a quarter of an hour before half flood at springs, and is marked by a red and black beacon. Set- chart. No. 2,700.

[Chap. IV. 126 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. At neap tides, vessels bound to Solidor road may pass on either side of the Rat de la Merciere ; but, at springs, they should keep as much as possible over towards the eastern bank of the river, to avoid the strength of the tide, and pass eastward of the Rat. For this purpose, when abreast of St. Malo, keep the eastern head of the Bizeux rock and the Merciere beacon in one S. by E. \ E. until the Mole des Noires lighthouse is on with St. Malo church ; then steer to pass 150 yards westward and southward of the Merciere beacon. In case of necessity only, a vessel may run between the Merciere beacon and La Cite peninsula by keeping the Mole des Noires light house on with the north-western side of the Calfats rock ; but the tides run strongly in this passage, which is only 130 yards wide and has a depth of 13 feet at low water. On account of the eddy during the flood occasioned by Bechard point, the most favourable time for entering Solidor road is at high water. Vessels entering before that time, when rounding Bechard point and for the space of about a cable East and West, experience the flood stream setting with great velocity south-westward, and the eddy, not less strong, setting north-westward. The eddy begins to be felt near the shore about 2 hours before high water, and its breadth and strength increase as the tide rises. To enter the road, Grand Larron tower on with that of Solidor leads between Bechard point and the Solidor bank ; when within the latter, anchor as convenient ; but, to take up a safe berth, the services of a pilot are necessary. GRAND CHENAL DE LA RANCE— Grande and Petite Porte channels. — The Grande and Petite Porte channels are the only passages into the Ranee navigable at low water. They are westward of Cezembre island, are divided from each other by the Pierres des Portes and other rocks, and unite between the Grand Jardin and the Pierres de la Savatte, at the entrance of the Grand chenal de la Ranee ; they may be used by vessels of the deepest draught at all times- ; no large square-rigged vessel, however, should attempt either channel except with a leading wind of sufficient strength to enable her to keep the leading marks on and to stem the tide, bearing in mind that the course when within the narrows is about S.E. by S. The tidal streams in the vicinity of the chain of scattered rocks which divide these two channels are very strong during springs, Set' chart, No. 2,700.

Chap IV.] ST. MALO. — GRAND CHENAL. — DANGERS. 127 attaining a velocity of 4 or 5 knots, and making them always dangerous at low water, as well as at other times, when the wind is fresh on a weather tide, by reason of the overfalls they occasion. A description of these rocks now follows :— The Buharats rocks, of which the highest head has only 6 feet water, is the westernmost of this rocky chain, its shoalest spot bears W.N.W. 1^ miles from Grand Jardin lighthouse, with the Nerput rock beacon turret on with the summit of the mound on La Haye point S.W. ; St. Malo church steeple on with Petit Bey fort S.E. -§ E. ; and, Grande Conchee fort midway between the northern point of Cezembre and Meinga point E. J S. Bell-buoy. — A black bell-buoy is moored off the southern side of the Buharats, about 50 yards from the edge of the bank. Pierres des Portes.— Beacon turret.— The Pierres des Portes are three high rocks, of which the central one uncovers 37 feet, NW. by W. 6^ cables from Grand Jardin lighthouse ; a black beacon turret surmounted by a ball stands on the western most rock, which dries 25 feet at low water, springs, and scarcely covers at high water, neaps. Several shoal rocky patches extend about 2 cables in a westerly direction from the beacon turret ; they are named the Couillons de la Porte, and E. by N. N. at 2 cables distance are the Basses Nord-Est des Portes, extending a cable farther in the same direction, with as little as 3 feet water on one small pinnacle ; also the Basses a Louise and the Fontaines des Portes, with one shoal spot of only 3 feet at the western end of the latter. Buoy. — A black conical buoy is moored on the southern side of the Pierres des Portes rocks, one cable S.W. by W. --V W. from the beacon turret. The Btinel, Hupions, &C. — The Bunel, the north-eastern rock of the chain, is the only one lying eastward of the Petite Porte channel ; it uncovers 12 feet, and bears N. \ E. 6 cables from Grand Jardin lighthouse. The Hupions, on which there are 27 feet water, and the Grande Hupee, with only 3 feet, lie, the first 6^, the other 5 cables N N.E. from the beacon turret on the Pierres des Portes. The Grande Hupee is very dangerous ; the marks for it are, the highest head of the Pierres des Portes on with the summit of Bellefard point S. by W. h W. westerly ; and, the southern end of the fort on See chart, No. 2,700.

S.W. 2 cables from the Grand Hupee is the Rat des Courtis, of 27 feet ; and, westward one cable from it, La Nouvelle Decouverte, a patch with as little as 11 feet. A red buoy near the north-eastern edge of the Traversaine, about 1| cables S. £ E. from the Grand Jardin beacon. GRAND CHENAL de la RANCE is Z\ miles long from the Grand Jardin to St. Malo road. It is bounded on the western side by the Pierres de la Savatte ; by the Pierre Salee flats, which have from 3 to 12 feet on them ; by the Buron, an isolated conical rock which uncovers 24 feet and has on it a red beacon turret surmounted by a ball ; and, by scattered rocky heads as far up as the Pourceaux rocks. On the eastern side, it is bounded by the off-lying rocks of the Grand Jardin ; by the Pierres Gamier, of which the highest head uncovers 5 feet ; and, by the rocky beads on the western slope of the Ouvras ridge, of which the greater part uncover at low water. The narrowest part of this channel is between the Basse du Buron, a small rocky head with only 3 feet, and the Buron rock ; they bear E. by N. \ N. and W. by S. \ S. from each other, and are 1^ cables apart. At 2 cables north-eastward from the Basse du Buron is the Ouvras beacon, on the highest head of that reef, which uncovers 17 feet. Buoys. — The eastern side of the channel is marked by the following four black buoys : — 1. The first or outer buoy is moored near the south-western edge of the Pierres Gamier S.E. 3^- cables from the Grand Jardin beacon. 2. The second buoy is moorad on the western edge of the Clefs d'Aval, the northernmost rocks of the Ouvras ledge ; it bears S.E. | S. 5 cables from the outer buoy. 3. The third buoy is just westward of the Basse du Buron, and, with the Buron beacon turret opposite, marks the narrowest part of the channel ; it bears S.S.E. 4 cables from the second buoy. 4. The fourth buoy is near the southern edge of the Ouvras ; it bears S.E. by S. 2 cables from the third buoy. DIRECTIONS.— Grande Porte channel.— The leading mark through this channel is, Grand Jardin and Rochebonne lighthouses in line E. by S. \ S. This direction leads 130 yards southward of the Buharats black bell-buoy ; close southward of a rocky head of 20 feet ; a cable southward of the Pierres des Portes black buoy ; See chart, No. 2,700.

Chap. IV.] ST. MALO.— CHANNELS. — DIRECTIONS. 131 Petite Porte Channel. — If entering the Grand chenal de la Ranee by the Petite Porte channel, Harbour island fort open west ward of Grand Jardin lighthouse S. by E., or the lighthouse on with the mill on Dinard point, leads through the clearest passage up to Grand Jardin ; but, to reduce as much as possible the turn round the southern extreme of the Grand Jardin, it is usual to pass through the chain of reefs farther westward. For this purpose, when approaching the entrance, bring the western end of Cezembre island on with the centre of the town of St. Malo, and, when within 2 miles of the island, steer to the southward to bring Grand Jardin and Balue lighthouses in line S.E. by S. ; this leads between the Grande Hupee and the Rat des Courtis and northward of the Basse Nord-Est des Portes ; when within 2 cables of the lighthouse, steer to round the Grand Jardin and proceed as before directed. Grand Jardin lighthouse on with Jeannet windmill S. by W. W. leads between the Bunel rock and the shoals 2 cables westward of the western end of Cezembre ; but, in using this channel, a vessel must edge away to the South-west to round the Grand Jardin as soon as either Parame or St. Hydeuc church steeples open of the south-western point of Cezembre. The PETITE CONCHEE CHANNEL is only practicable for vessels of deep draught between half flood and half ebb. Its entrance is 2 cables eastward of the Petite Conchee rock, between the Rousse and Ronfleresse rocks, where the channel is less than a cable wide. The Petite Conchee is the only rock between Cezembre island and Grande Conchee that does not cover at springs ; the Rousse uncovers 33 feet, and the Ronfleresse 28^ feet. Directions. — The western side of Petit Bey fort seen between La Cite citadel and the little fort on Bechard point S. £ E. leads through the Petite Conchee channel nearly up to the Crapauds du Bey rocks, leaving the Rousse, the Rats, and the Queue des Rats westward ; and the Ronfleresse, the Pierres aux Normands, and the Roches aux Anglais eastward. A red beacon, on a rock which dries 12 feet, marks the centre of the Pierres aux Normands ; and, near the northern end of the Roches aux Anglais is a red beacon on a rock which uncovers 11 feet ; the south-eastern part of this latter reef is also marked by a red buoy moored within its edge. The leading mark given passes within 50 yards westward of a sunken rock off the western point of the Ronfleresse, with only See chart, No. 2,700.

CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. 3 feet at low water, springs ; it must be kept on until St. Lunaire mill, or the mound on Bellefard point, opens out southward of Harbour isle ; the vessel will then be 1^ cables westward of the beacon on the Anglais, and should haul more to the westward to bring the western head of Bizeux islet on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point bearing S. 5 E., which mark leads between the Basse Sud-Est des Ouvras and the black buoy of the Crapauds du Bey up to St. Malo road. Crapauds du Bey. — Buoy. — These rocks, marked by the black buoy on their northern side just mentioned, bear N. by W. £ W. 2^ cables from Petit Bey fort, they uncover 5^ feet. GRANDE CONCHEE CHANNEL derives its name from the Grande Conchee rock, and, like that of the Petite Conchee, can only be entered by vessels of moderate size between half flood and half ebb, and is chiefly used by those from the north-eastward. The shallowest part, as with all the channels eastward of Cezembre, is that over the flats in front of Grand and Petit Bey forts, where there are only 2 or 3 feet on the leading line at dead low water. The entrance is bounded on its western side by the Haies de la Conchee, the Rimponiere, and the Grande Conchee ; and, on its eastern side, by the Rousses and the Plate ; its position may be recognised by Grande Conchee fort, which may be seen from a great distance. Haies de la Conchee, Rousses, and Plate rocks- Beacon turret. — The Haies de la Conchee, 3 cables northward of Grande Conchee fort, is a ridge of high rocks whose summits do not cover. The Rimponiere between the Haies de la Conchee and Grande Conchee, dries 36 feet. The Rousses are rocks, of which one isolated head has only 6 feet water ; the marks for it are, the Grand Chevreuil, a high rock near the shore westward of Meinga point, on which stands a kiosk, making it very conspicuous against the land, a little open southward of the guard-house on the inner part of Meinga point ; and, Roche mill on with the eastern gable of the barracks of Petit Bey fort S. by W. f W. The Plate, half a mile S.E. from Grande Conchee, uncovers 18 feet, and has on it a stone beacon turret 10 feet above the highest tides, painted in red and black bands. Although the sea is nearly always breaking on the Plate, its northern and western sides may be safely approached ; but, off its southern side See chart, No. 2,700.

Buoy. — The Bouton rock is marked by a red and black buoy moored about 50 yards southward of it. Several other patches are scattered about the entrance to this channel ; the most dangerous are, the Becfer, the St. Servantine, and the Rat de St. Servan. The Basse de Becfer, with 15 feet water, lies North 2| cables from the two north-westernmost heads of the Haies de la Conchee. The Basse de la Conchee, with 22 feet, bears N.E. St. Servantine is a dangerous isolated rock, which uncovers 2 feet at the lowest tides ; the marks for it are, the summit of the Ronfleresse rock on with the foot of Garde Guerin point W.S.W. ; and, St. Hydeuc steeple on with a mill about 800 yards southward of it. Bell-buoy.— A red bell-buoy is moored about 50 yards south eastward of the St. Servantine rock. As a guide to the depth of water over these shoals, it is useful to know that when the Ronfleresse is covered there are at least 25 feet over the St. Servantine ; and, that when the rock on which the Plate beacon turret stands is covered, there are 30 feet over the Rat de St. Servan, 33 feet over the Rat du Rocher, and 34 feet over the Teto rock. Directions. — When running for the Grande Conchee channel from the eastward, be careful to keep the mound on Garde Guerin point open northward of the Petite Conchee S.W. by W. f W. to pass northward of the Basse des Pointus which has 18 feet water, the St. Servantine, and the Rousses. The leading mark to enter the channel is, Mole des Noires light house touching the eastern side of Grand Bey island S. | W. ; this mark leads If cables eastward of Grande Conchee fort and 2| cables westward of the Plate beacon turret. Keep this mark on until See chart, No. 2,700.

The PETITS POINTUS CHANNEL is the next channel east ward of the Grande Conchee ; its entrance is between the St. Servantine red bell-buoy and the Grands Pointus rocks, of which the highest head is 8 feet above high water, and is therefore an excellent See chart, No. 2,700.

ROCHEFORT ROCK. — Beacon turret. — The Rochefort rock lies \\ miles north-westward of Meinga point, and, with the Platier ledge which dries 3 feet, forms a rocky group 2| cables long E.N.E. and W.S.W., and one cable wide. The highest head of the Rochefort shows at about 2 hours ebb, uncovers 34 feet at the lowest tides, and does not cover at neaps. On it stands a beacon turret 13 feet above high water, painted in red and black bands, and surmounted by a ball. The marks for it are, the guard-house on the summit of Varde point, its own breadth open westward of the Bigne S.W. by S., and St. Vincent belvedere on with the western bluff of Benard point S. £ E. The mound on Garde Guerin point open northward of Grande Conchee leads northward of the Rochefort ; and, Parame church on with the Bigne leads westward. Directions. — In steering for the entrance of the Bigne channel between the Tintiaux group, north-eastward of Meinga point, and the Rochefort rock, bring the Crolante rock, which lies at the foot of Varde point and uncovers 38 feet, on with the western side of Grand Bey fort S.W. by W. \ W. Run in on this line until the Bigne rock bears N.E. by N., or until St. Lunaire mill is on with Bellefard point W. by S. \ S., when keep it so until St. Jeannet mill opens northward of St. Enogat steeple ; then proceed as before. The first mark leads a cable south-eastward of the Basse aux Chiens, which lies half a mile south-eastward of the Rochefort and uncovers 3 feet ; about the same distance from the Basse du Durand, lying 6 cables southward of the Rochefort with only one foot water ; and, about 100 yards south-eastward of the Petite Bigne, marked by a red beacon at its eastern end. On the other hand, it leads within half a cable of the reef extending from the Durand, of which some rocks dry 12 feet ; and, at a greater distance outside the Aiguillon and Graine-de-Lin rocks, the former uncovering 21 feet, the latter L2 feet. W., and run in on the eastern side of the Rochefort until within 2\ cables of the Bigne, then edge away southward, to round the Petite Bigne at a safe distance, and then bring on the leading marks already given, and proceed as before. The tides in this channel between St. Malo and Varde point never have much strength ; they run strongly, however, north-eastward of that point. GENERAL DIRECTIONS.— To St. Malo from the West- ward. — When bound to St. Malo from the westward, with southerly winds, Ushant and the French coast may be kept aboard ; but, with northerly winds and at night, a prudent distance should be main tained off-shore until the Sept-iles and Heaux lights are made out. With the assistance of these lights, a position may be obtained about 4 miles northward of the Heaux, from whence a S.E. \ E. course for about 33 miles, following the directions at page 64, leads north ward of the Roc'h-ar-Bel and Horaine ledge, and crosses- the meridian of cape Frehel about 6 miles northward of the cape. The vessel is then in a good position to run for the entrance of the Ranee through the Decolle passage or Grande Porte channel, according to the state of wind and tide. This route may be followed either with the flood or against the ebb with the wind from N.N.E. round by West to South, but if between S.W. and South it is better to give cape Frehel a closer berth. With a fresh leading wind, a sailing vessel passing the meridian of Heaux lighthouse at the commencement of the flood, or 5 hours before high water at St. Malo, should enter the Ranee by high water, the distance being about 43 miles ; but, with a foul wind, it takes two flood tides to make the passage. With a head wind, make short tacks in sight of Heaux lighthouse until the commencement of the flood, then stretch into the channel See charts, Nos. 2,700 and 2,669 h. I 2 SO 11886

[Chap. IV. 138 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. between the Barnouic and Roc'h-ar-Bel. The boards in this channel should not exceed 2 miles in length, but when eastward of the Horaine they may be extended to 7 or 8 miles. By following these directions, cape Frehel should be made towards the latter part of the flood, and the vessel may anchor or make short tacks under shelter of the cape during the ebb ; or, if not so far to windward, she may anchor in the rade d'Erqui, see page 102, weigh again when the flood makes, and work up so as to reach, if possible by about half flood, one of the entrance channels to the Ranee. To St. Malo through Grand Ruet passage.— The channel between the Roches-Douvres on the West, and Guernsey, Jersey, and the Minquiers ledge on the East, called by the French pilots the Grand Ruet, would seem from its great breadth to offer a safe and easy route to St. Malo or Granville ; the streams, however, run through and across it with such velocity at springs, that, during westerly winds, with stream and wind in the same direction, a sailing vessel runs great risk of being drifted between the islands and dangers in their vicinity ; and, if surprised by fog or night, the danger is imminent, the constant changes in the set of the stream making the dead reckon ing unreliable ; see Tide table, page 60. At springs, with a westerly wind and flood tide, ships should keep well to the westward, make the coast of France about the Sept-iles, and proceed southward of the Barnouic ledge, as already described ; but, at neaps, with a steady northerly wind irrespective of tide, or, at springs, with an ebb tide and a westerly wind, a vessel may use this channel with due care as follows : — With a steady westerly wind, and being about 8 miles W.S.W. of Hanois light, off the western end of Guernsey, at the commencement of the ebb stream or 2,\ hours after high water at St. Malo, steer S. | E. for about 38 miles, or until within 6 or 8 miles N.N.W. of cape' Frehel, when St. Malo may be steered for as before directed. This course leads about 4 miles eastward of the Roches-Douvres, and its lighthouse should be sighted to correct the reckoning ; 6 miles eastward of the Barnouic ledge ; and, about 8 miles westward of the Minquiers. During nearly the whole of this run, the wind being on the starboard side counteracts the effect of the stream, which, for the first four hours will be on the port beam, the fifth hour a little on the bow, and at last on the starboard beam, the flood beginning earlier as the French coast is neared. See charts, Nos. 2,675 b, and 2,669 *.

Chap. IV.] 139 DIRECTIONS, ST. MALO. To St. Malo through the Deroute passage.- The shortest and best route from cape de la Hague to St. Malo, with fresh leading winds, is through the Race of Alderney, see pages 386-388, and between Jersey and Serk through the Deroute passage see page 298, the dis tance being about 75 miles ; it should not be used, however, by strangers at night during light winds or in thick weather. To take this route under the most advantageous circumstances, endeavour to enter Alderney Race on the slack or last of the north eastern stream, which is about 4 hours after high water at St. Malo. Having cleared the Race, steer about S.W. to enter the Deroute passage in mid-channel, and to ensure passing south-eastward of the Blanchard rock. This distance being run in about 2^ or 3 hours, or about the time of low water at St. Malo, continue the course so as to be in a good position westward of the meridian ot the Minquiers at the first of the flood. This stream is felt more as the vessel advances southward ; it is therefore most necessary to determine by correct bearings the course to'be steered, and to pay strict attention to the directions given at page 160, in passing those dangers. When clear of the Minquiers, steer for cape Frehel where pilots are always on the look out. To St. Malo through the Cotentin passage. — I ull directions are given at pages 214-220 for this passage when bound to Granville ; the same directions should be followed for St. Malo until the vessel has arrived within 4 or 5 miles of the beacon turret on the Etat, a remarkable rock on the northern edge of the Chausey group, which group is described in the following chapter, whim she should keep to the westward so as to round the north-western part of the group about 1^ miles distant. When abreast of the Rondes de l'Ouest, a rocky ridge forming the western end of the group, steer S.W. or more southerly, keeping within 3 miles of the rocks until the ruins of the old castle on Grande ile open southward of the Corbiere, the high and remarkable rock at the south-western extreme of the Chausey group, on an E. by S. h S. bearing ; then steer about S.W. \ S. for one of the channels into the Ranee. Great care must be taken to make proper allowance for the set of the tidal stream, which, in clear weather, can easily be done by frequent bearings ot objects on the Chausey isles. At night, when Chausey light is sighted, steer for it on a S.W. | S. bearing until within about 2 miles of the Chausey group, See charts, Nos. 2,669 n and b.
