When abreast of the western end of the group, haul to the southward, taking care not to approach the rocks within 2 miles ; and, if the night is clear, by the time Chausey light bears E. by N. both the Herpin and Grand Jardin lights will be in sight. From St. Malo through Cotentin passage. — Vessels leaving St. Malo and intending to take this route, should so time their departure as to enable them to enter the Cotentin passage with the first of the north-eastern stream, which makes 3| hours before high water at St. Malo. From one mile northward of the Grande Conchee, steer about N.E. | E. ; this line passes about 2 miles north-westward of the Rochefort beacon turret, and 4 miles south-eastward of the Sauvages, due allowance being made for tide. When within 3 or 4 miles of the Corbiere rock, steer to pass about 1 \ miles westward of the Rondes de l'Ouest and clear of Corbiere bank. Round the north-western end of the group at the same distance, passing about 2 miles south-east ward of the Ardentes ; and, when Gros-Mont Semaphore is on with the Enseigne beacon tower S. f W. steer to the eastward to bring the Etat and Huguenans beacon towers in line S. by W. westerly ; this mark on astern leads northward between the Shamrock knoll and Basse le Marie, when follow the directions given at page 218. If after the first quarter flood, and unable to weather the western end of the Chausey group, bear up and pass round the eastern end, where, by that time, there will be a good rise of tide over the numerous shallow patches by which that part of the channel is encumbered, sei pages 177-179. Granville church on with the northernmost chimney of the south-western barrack keeps a vessel 5 cables northward of the Videcoq rock, marked by a red and black ball-buoy ; and, Coutances cathedral on with Mont Martin church N.E. by E. leads between the Haguet and Admiralty banks, but over and amongst patches with as little as 3 feet at low water, springs, when southward of the latter. From St. Malo through the Deroute passage.— Vessels of deep draught bound eastward, leave St. Malo road when the flood See charts, Nos. 2,669 a and b.

Chap. IV.] DIRECTIONS, ST. MALO.— ROTENEUF. 141 begins to slack ; and, with a fair wind, when clear of the Ranee, they may adopt the Grand Ruet passage, see page 138 ; but, with the wind between South and West, the distance may be much shortened by running through the Deroute passage and the Race of Alderney. A vessel averaging 7 knots should reach the middle of this passage in 6 hours after leaving St. Malo, and from thence, steering for the Race with a fresh fair wind, may stem the remainder of the south western stream. The Race would then be entered a little after the commencement of the north-eastern stream. French coasters generally adopt this route, and to ensure entering the Race on the slack or last of the south-western stream, they sometimes wait for a leading wind at anchor under the ile des Ehbiens. ROTENEUF.— This little harbour, about 4 miles eastward of St. Malo and midway between Varde and Meinga points, has a narrow entrance but opens out into a space about three quarters of a mile wide and half a mile deep, but it is choked with sand, over which the tide only begins to rise at half flood ; the approach also is rendered dangerous by several rocks which cover. Vessels of 15 or 16 feet draught may beach within it at high water, springs, but they must keep within 50 yards of Benard point, the high bluff eastern point of entrance, when passing it. Vessels ground and lay up for the winter in the creek eastward of this point, where the bottom is everywhere of sand and the shelter excellent. A remarkable tree open eastward of a large house leads up to the entrance of the harbour, passing eastward of the Rochefort and westward of the Hautieux and Guimereux rocks ; the Hautieux uncover 25 feet, the Guimereux, lying between the Hautieux and Benard point, 23 feet. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the summit of Benard point ; see page 12. OFF-LYING ROCKS.— Three off-lying rocks, always covered and very dangerous to deep vessels, lie off this part of the coast eastward of the Rochefort rock, described at page 136 ; they are the Basse Rault, Basse Grune, and Basse du Nid. Basse Rault. — This rocky head lies H miles E. by N. \ N. from Rochefort beacon turret ; N. by E. H miles from Meinga point ; and, W. by N. i N. northerly 4f miles from Pierre de Herpin lighthouse. Set chart, No. 2.669 b.

It has only 16 feet water, with from 9 to 10 fathoms round it, and should be carefully avoided at low water by vessels of deep draught, as also by small craft when it blows hard as it then causes a dangerous swell. The marks for the Rault are, the mound on Garde Guerin point a little open southward of the Rochefort beacon turret W. by S. f S. ; and, the eastern slope of Meinga point almost shutting in Terquete belvedere. The mound on Garde Guerin point on with Grande Conchee fort W.S.W. leads northward ; and, Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock S.E. \ E. leads well north-eastward of it. Basse Grune is a dangerous isolated rock, with only 7 feet on it and from 10 to 12 fathoms close around, lying NW. W. 3^ miles from Pierre de Herpin lighthouse, with Rochefort beacon turret a little southward of the mound on Garde Guerin point ; Granville church perceptibly open southward of Granville lighthouse; and, Cancale church its own length open westward of the eastern Haut- Bout mill S. \ E. This rock occasions great overfalls even in moderate weathsr, and is much in the way of vessels from the westward bound to Granville or Cancale road. Granville church open northward of Granville lighthouse E. \ N. leads well northward of the Basse Grune ; Garde Guerin mound on with Grande Conchee fort leads half a mile north-westward ; Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin . rock S.E. \ E. leads southward between it and the Basse du Nid ; and, a vessel is eastward of it when Cancale church opens eastward of Haut-Bout eastern mill. In moderate weather, vessels of any draught may pass between the Grune and the Nid at all times by keeping Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock bearing S.E. i E. The lights of cape Frehel, Pierre de Herpin, Granville, and Chausey are all visible from the Basse Grune. Basse du Nid, a small rocky patch about 1\ miles S.S.W. from Basse Grune, and \^ miles E. by S. \ S. from the Rault, has 17 feet water over, and from 8 to 9 fathoms round it. From it, Meinga point bears S.W. by W. %\ miles ; Herpin lighthouse E. by S. | S. 3^ miles ; St. Malo church tower is seen over Varde point touching the Petit Chevreuil; and, Mont St. Michel is on with the rocks extending from the northern point of Landes island. Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock S.E. J- E. leads well northward of it. See chart, No. 2,669 //.

Chap. IV.] 143 TINTIAUX AND OFF-LYING ROCKS. When the Pierre de Herpin rock, on which the lighthouse stands, is covered, there are at least 37 feet water over the Grune, and 46 feet over both the Rault and Nid. The TINTIAUX are a group of rocks about 1^ miles long E.S E. and W.N.W., and half a mile wide, their western end lying 4 cables north-eastward of Meinga point ; most of the rocks appear at 4 hours ebb, and the highest, near the centre of the group, dry about 30 feet at low water, springs, and do not cover at neaps. Rochefort beacon turret on with cape Frehel lighthouse, or on with Grande Conchee fort, leads northward ; and, Duguesclin fort bearing S.S.W., or Haut-Bout eastern mill on with the guard-house on Verger point, the eastern point of the first sandy beach westward of Grouin point, leads eastward. Tintiaux passage, between the Tintiaux and the land, is used by coasting vessels with southerly winds ; the tide runs very strongly through it, but follows the direction of the channel. The leading mark when coming from the eastward is, the Bigne rock midway between Grand Jardin lighthouse and the south-western point of Cezembre isle W. \ S. ; this leads 100 yards southward of all the Tintiaux, and between them and the northern rock of the Cadins, which dries 3 feet. Give Meinga point a berth of 2 J cables in passing, and then run out between the Tintiaux and the Basse aux Chiens, with St. Vincent belvedere, on the heights at the head of Roteneuf harbour, touching the eastern part of the high land of Benard ; or, if entering St. Malo, bring the leading marks on for the Bigne channel ; see page 136, if the tide is sufficiently high to take that channel. The Coast. — Meinga point, 3| miles westward of Grouin point, is very remarkable ; it is nearly as high as cape Frehel, is narrow and steep on all sides, and extends in a slope more than half a mile northward. Between it and Grouin point, the coast presents nothing worthy of notice with the exception of the small bay between Nez and Nid points, where, in its south-eastern part, is a sandjT beach defended by Fort Duguesclin. This fort stands 3 cables westward of Nid point on a rocky islet joined with the. shore at low water by a ridge of rocks. Vessels of .deep draught should keep well off-shore between points Meinga and Grouin ; indeed, as previously stated, the navigation of Si-e chart, No. 2,669 h.

IV. 144 this coast is so fraught with danger, both from its numerous rocks and strong tides, that the safety of his vessel calls for the utmost vigilance on the part of the mariner. POINTE de GROUIN, the western point of Mont St. Michel bay, is high, rocky, and precipitous on its north-western and south eastern sides, but forms a narrow slope towards the N.E. The sudden change in the direction of the coast at this point is very remarkable, and makes it easy of recognition at a great distance in the offing. Southward of the point are the two windmills of Haut- Bout. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station near the extreme of the point ; see page 12. North-westward of Grouin point and peninsula are many rocky patches from 5 cables to one mile from the shore ; and, on the northern side of one -of them, the Grande Bunouze, at about 4 cables northward of the point, is a small red buoy. On the eastern side of Grouin point, Landes island, with the Herpin, Pierre de Herpin, Fille rock, and a few shoal patches extending 2 miles eastward of the point, form a broken rocky barrier through which vessels pass when seeking shelter in Cancale road or in the anchorage off La Houle. He des Landes. — This high, narrow, rocky islet, steep on all sides and inaccessible when there is any swell on, lies 2 cables eastward of Grouin point, and, at high water, is about 4 cables long N.E. and S.W. and about a cable wide ; but, at low tide, it is lengthened 3 cables to the N. N.E. by some rocks then high above water and by others which are covered. Its direction is nearly parallel with the shore, from which it is separated by a channel called the Vieille Riviere, only 164 yards wide at its narrowest part, through which, at springs, the stream runs 6 knots. The eastern side is steep-to from end to end, there being from 18 to 20 feet water alongside the rocks. On the north-eastern part of the island are the ruins of a fort and guard-house. The Pignonet rock, with only 10J feet, lies in mid-channel between the north-eastern extreme of Landes island and the Herpin rock. The Herpin rock is a high pyramid rock about 66 feet above the level of high water, springs, and its base a cable in diameter at low water. It bears E.N.E. 1\ cables from Grouin point, and is See chart, No. 2,669 //.

IV.] GROUIN POINT.— HERPIN LIGHT. 145 nearly 2 cables from the north-eastern extreme of Landes island ; its shape, great height, and isolated position, render it a remarkable object from a great distance. Coasters find shelter under this rock with the wind from West round by South to East. There is also good anchorage in from 7 to 9 fathoms with the rock bearing N.W. W. from 1 to 1^ miles ; the ground, however, so far out, is rather coarse. PIERRE de HERPIN.— The highest head of this small rocky ridge, on which stands the lighthouse, uncovers 32 feet, and bears N.E. by E. E. 8 cables from the Herpin rock. At springs, it begins to show at about one third ebb ; at neaps, it does not cover. Another rocky ridge, with from 22 to 24 feet water, lies S. by E. 2^ cables from the Pierre de Herpin. LIGHT. — From a circular lighthouse, 81 feet in height, on the Pierre de Herpin, at 61 feet above the level of high water, is exhibited a light showing fixed white for 30 seconds, and then five green flashes during the next 30 seconds. The light is visible 13 miles. From this lighthouse, cape Frehel light bears W. by N. 20 miles ; and, Granville light, pointe du Roc, E.N.E. 10 miles. The passage between the Pierre de Herpin and the Herpin rock, called the Grand Ruet, is the principal entrance to Cancale road from the North-west ; but, the Basse du Milieu, a shoal with only 4 feet W. \ S. 2§ cables from the lighthouse, narrows the passage to 4 cables between it and the Herpin rock ; this passage is otherwise deep enough for vessels of any draught at all times. They should, however, pass within a cable of the Herpin on the flood, as this stream sets strongly over the Basse du Milieu and Pierre de Herpin ; the flood begins to make through the passage about 5f hours before high water at St. Malo or Granville, and as it runs S.E. and E.S.E. there is no danger of being drifted over the Banchets. The Fille rock.— Bell-buoy.— This rock lies E.N.E. 3 cables from Pierre de Herpin lighthouse, and is the easternmost of these dangers ; it uncovers 11 feet at the lowest tides, and a bell-buoy, with red and black bands, marks its northern side. From the rock, Grouin point bears W.S.W. southerly 2 miles ; the summit of the Herpin rock is on with the northern head of the Pierre de Herpin ; ,$,.« chart, No. 2,669 b.

There are 8| fathoms in the passage between the Pierre de Herpin and the Fille, and it may be safely used by keeping from 1# to 2| cables from the lighthouse ; but, this passage places a vessel too much to leeward if seeking shelter from strong westerly winds in Cancale road. Bane des Renardieres, of from 6 to 7^ fathoms, sand and shells, bears N.N.W. W. If miles from the Herpin rock ; it is only a cable wide and 5 cables long N. by W. and S. by E., aud lying nearly across the streams it causes a heavy sea on a weather tide. From its shoalest part at the southern end, the fort near Varde point appears midway between Grand and Petit Chevreuil W. by S. | S. ; and, the Herpin rock is on with the north-eastern extreme of Pointe de Gogre, Mont St. Michel bay. South-eastward of Grouin point, between it and pointe de la Chaine, is the Grande rade de Cancale, already referred to and presently described. Besides the dangers extending eastward from Grouin point, of which the Fille rock is the most eastern, there are, on the western side of the road, the Bane de Chatry ; on the northern side, the Banchets shoal ; and, on the eastern and southern sides, the Brehaut, Corbieres, ile de Rimains, and other rocks in-shore, of which the principal are the Petit Rimains and the Chatellier, above water ; a large rock near Chaine point which uncovers 22 feet and is marked by a beacon ; and, the Thomen rock within low water mark off La Houle, marked by two beacons on its northern heads. Bane de Chatry runs parallel with the shore and bounds Cancale road on the West ; it has from 6 to 9 feet for a distance of 5 cables on its shoalest parts, and is joined to the coast at Chaine point by a bed of sand, over which there are 11 or 12 feet ; its northern end is abreast of a small creek named port Mer, leavin° between it and the shallows extending from the shore the Fosse de See chart, No. 2,669 6.

Chap. IV.] 147 BANCHETS AND OTHER SHOALS. Chatry or Chatry deep, a swashway 3 cables wide, in which the depths are from 26 to 32 feet. From the northern part of the bank, Haut-Bout eastern windmill is on with the northern declivity of Chatry point ; and, from its eastern edge, the Cormorandiere and the Hubert, two remarkable rocks adjoining Rimains island, are in line ; the Cormorandiere, at the northern extreme of the island, is high and pointed ; the Hubert, about 150 yards eastward of the fort, is wedge-shaped. The BANCHETS.— This bank of sand and broken shells of from 10 to 24 feet water is in the fairway of the entrance to Cancale road, 3 cables northward of the Bane des Corbieres, and E.S.E. 7 cables from the old fort on Landes island ; together with the small knoll of 23^ feet at 2 cables on its north-western side, it is dangerous to vessels of deep draught at low water, springs. The bank is 5^ cables long N. by W. and S. by E. ; the shoalest parts form two small ridges parallel with each other, and athwart the direction of the streams. On the north-western ridge are 17 feet, and only 10 feet on the highest part of the other, near the eastern part of the bank. The marks for the 10-feet ridge are, the steep point of Chateau Richeux open 1° eastward of Chaine point ; and, the slope of Grouin point open the same distance northward of the guard house on Landes island. The sand forming this bank is said not to shift, but there is reason to think that the depths often change during strong gales. The mark for the small knoll of 23^ feet water is, Haut-Bout eastern mill on with the northern point of port Mer bay. The mill just open southward of the point leads between this knoll and the Banchets ; and, on with the summit of the same point, leads north ward of the knoll. There are two other knolls, with 24 and 25 feet water, a cable northward of the Banchets. The Brehaut is an extensive flat of sand and rock south eastward of the Banchets and half a mile eastward of the northern part of the Bane des Corbieres ; the soundings are from 7 to 10 fathoms, but as the ground is very foul it should be avoided. Bane des Corbieres, bounding Cancale road eastward, is about 1^ miles long from the line of Haut-Bout eastern windmill on with the northern declivity of Chatry point, to the same windmill on with See chart. No. 2,669 b.

IV. the Cormorandiere rock ; it is about 5 cables wide and is joined to the sandy shore of Mont St. Michel bay by flats on which the depth decreases gradually from 20 to 8 feet, and from thence to the sands which dry. The general depths on this bank are from 2 to 4 fathoms, but a small patch about 3 cables long North and South with only 10 feet water rises on its southern part, about 5 cables eastward of the fort on Rimains island. From the northern end of this patch, the guard house on Chaine point is on with Cancale church steeple ; and, from the southern end, the steeple is between the Chatellier rock and Petit Rimains islet, which joins the northern end of that rock at low water. GRANDE RADE de CANCALE.— This excellent anchorage is northward of Rimains island, 7 cables from the shore between Chatry and Corbieres banks ; it affords good shelter for ships of deep draught during westerly winds. A vessel should moor North and South with open hawse to the westward, and the best holding-groun I is with the Cormorandiere rock seen between Rimains island and the Hubert rock ; its eastern limit is, the Cormorandiere touching the eastern side of the fort on Rimains ; and, its northern limit, Haut- Bout eastern mill on with the middle of Portz Picain, a small white sandy beach close southward of Chatry point. North-easterly winds sometimes cause a swell, but vessels are seldom obliged by sudden shifts of wind to quit this anchorage. There is also good holding ground in the southern part of the road in from 26 to 30 feet, clay and mud, about 2 cables eastward of Rimains island, with Cancale church steeple on with the middle of Rimains fort, and Grouin point a little open westward of Landes island. A vessel under 10 feet draught may anchor southward of Rimains island, with that island bearing North about 5 cables ; in running for this anchorage at low water, keep within 2^ cables of the island, to avoid the 10-feet patch on the Bane des Corbieres. At this anchorage, if unable to ride out heavy weather from the north-eastward, take the top of high water and run aground on the mud southward of Cancale church with good sail on ; here both vessel and crew will be saved. Mooring buoy.— A large mooring buoy is placed about 5 cables S.S.W. \ W. from the southern end of Rimains island ; there are only 4 feet water at this spot at low water, springs. See chart. No. 2,669 b.

Chap. IV.] RADE DE CANCALE. — HOULE LIGHT. 149 Anchorage East of Bane des Corbieres.— Vessels of deep draught sometimes anchor eastward of the Bane des Corbieres, but they are less sheltered than in Cancale road and more exposed to north-easterly winds, which, when strong, throw in a heavy sea, causing vessels to roll heavily on a weather tide. The anchoring ground extends southward from the line of Haut-Bout eastern mill on with Portz Picain to that of Cancale church steeple on with the southern side of the Chatellier rock. The best berth is in from 6 to 7 fathoms, blue tenacious clay, with Dol church steeple on with the foot of the eastern slope of Mont Dol ; and, Cancale church steeple between the Chatellier and the fort on Rimains. This position is 1£ miles outside Rimains island, but the Corbieres prevents a nearer approach, consequently that island affords but little shelter from the westward. Vessels remaining any length of time at this anchorage should sight their anchors occasionally, or they bury themselves deeply and are difficult to weigh. Merchant vessels generally prefer anchoring southward of the Bane des Corbieres, where the holding-ground is good and the depth from 19 to 22 feet. The best berth is close southward of the line of Haut-Bout eastern mill on with the Cormorandiere rock N.W. £ W, or with the mill between the fort and the northern point of Rimains island, but the safest position is in the southern part of Cancale road. Anchorage in Fosse de Chatry. — Vessels of moderate draught may anchor here in from 26 to 32 feet, with Haut-Bout eastern mill on with Portz Picain ; and, Mont Dol on with the eastern point of Petit Rimains, the little island just northward of the Chatellier rock. This is a good anchorage during neaps, but, at springs, the streams run from 4 to 5 knots. Small craft may anchor a little more in shore, but not westward of the line of Mont Dol touching the western side of the Chatellier. Vessels that can take the ground are well sheltered with the wind from N.E. round by North and West to S.S.W. on the deposit of soft mud which borders the northern part of the little bay of port Mer. LIGHT. — On Fenetre rock, port of Houle, Cancale, a fixed red light, visible 6 miles, is shown from a white circular tower at 33 feet above high water. See. chart, No. 2,669 *.

La Houle, the port of Cancale, nearly dry at high Avater neaps but with 7 or 8 feet in it at springs, has been formed by connecting the Fenetre rock with the shore by a short pier above the level of high water, and by a prolongation to the southward from that rock, with an elbow to the westward. The port has a large fishing industry and valuable oyster beds ; its trade otherwise is insignificant. Its beaching places westward of the Fenetre are good and safe for small craft. The town of Cancale stands on the cliffs and La Houle at their feet ; their united population is about 7,000. St. Malo is about 8 miles distant by road. Directions. — When running from the westward for Cancale road from a position about 2 miles N.N.E. from Cezembre island, steer E. by N., keeping the mound on Garde Guerin point open northward of Grande Conchee fort, until Mont St. Michel opens of Grouin point ; then haul up for it, and keep the Mont on with the Herpin rock bearing S.E. \ E. ; this leads between the Grune and Nid shoals. When within about 5 cables of the Herpin rock, steer through the Grand Ruet, passing only a cable eastward of the rock if the flood is running, as that stream sets strongly over the Basse du Milieu and Pierre de Herpin ; and, from thence, haul to the southward for the road. ... The passages between Grouin point and Landes island, called the Petit Ruet, and that between the north-eastern extreme of Landes island and the Herpin are too dangerous to attempt without a pilot. BAIE DU MONT ST. MICHEL, between Grouin and Champeaux points which bear E. \ S. and W. N. from each other distant 10s miles, is much exposed to north-westerly and northerly winds ; the anchorages, however, off Cancale and La Houle in the north-western part of the bay, as just described, afford excellent shelter against westerly winds. .The head of the bay falls back a great distance south-eastward ; nearly three fourths of it is occupied by an immense bank of sand which dries at low water, and a large portion does not cover at high water, neaps. The Coast. — On the western side of the bay the land is high for the space of 4 miles from Grouin to Chateau Richeux point, and the coast generally steep. The low lands called the marsh of Dol, begin at Chateau Richeux point and extend 15 miles eastward to the mouth of the river Couesnon, the course of which separates the See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. IV.] BAIE DU MONT ST. MICHEL. 151 department of fie-et-Vilaine from that of La Manche. A strong dyke protects this marsh from the invasion of the sea, its surface being in several places below the level of high spring tides. The only remarkable rise on this part of the coast is the small isolated hill named Mont Dol, and a chain of hills, which, seen from the northward, seem to form a long promontory, of which the western extreme is known locally as point de Gogre. Mont Dol rises from the midst of the marsh land 6 miles south-eastward of Chateau Richeux point, and, on its flat top stands a windmill, a Semaphore, and a few cottages. Point de Gogre is the nearest point to the sea of the; chain of hills about three quarters of a mile inland between Mont Dol and the river Couesnon. The little harbour of Vivier is at the mouth of the river Guyoul, S. \ E. about 7| miles from Grouin point ; it can only be entered by the smallest coasters having good pilots. Mont Dol Semaphore bearing S. f W. leads up to it. There is a small quay, alongside of which vessels lie to load or unload. Small vessels can ascend the river Couesnon, at springs, as far as the town of Pontorson, but the navigation is difficult and seldom attempted. The entrance channel through the sands commences at the western foot of Mont St. Michel. Mont St. Michel and Tombelaine islet, rising from the sands in the eastern part of the bay, form by far the most remarkable objects on this part of the coast. Mont St. Michel is a pyramidal block of granite 4 cables in diameter, which at the highest tides is completely surrounded, but from which at low water the sea recedes to a great distance, leaving dry sands for about 6 miles. Its summit is surmounted by large buildings and an ancient abbey church, of which the steeples are 420 feet above the level of the beach. It bears S. E. nearly 7 miles from Champeaux point, and in appearance strongly resembles Mount St. Michael in Cornwall. Harbour lights. — On the western side of Mont St. Michel, from the Gabriel watch tower, at 41 feet above high water and 54 feet above the ground, is exhibited a fixed red light visible 6 miles. It is shown only from 2 hours before high water until one hour after. See chart, No. 2,669 b. K SO 11886

[Chap. IV. 152 CHAMPEAUX POINT. A fixed green light is shown from the eastern point of entrance to the Couesnon river, about 1,100 yards from the Mont. This light ie maintained by fishermen and is not exhibited unless a vessel is expected. The two lights indicate the direction of the chenal de Couesnon. The Tombelaine is a barren islet almost as large as Mont St. Michel but much lower. It bears N. by E. \ E. If miles from the Mont, and, when seen from the northward or southward, has the appearance of a crushed pyramid inclining to the eastward. A deep sandy bight lies eastward of Mont St. Michel and Tombelaine, from the northern shore of which Tombelaine is distant 1\ miles. The shore from thence continues very low for about 3 miles farther northward, until near Champeaux point, when it begins to rise. CHAMPEAUX POINT is the eastern point of Mont St. Michel bay ; from it, pointe du Roc, Granville, bears North 5f miles. It is a bluff and almost perpendicular headland, unapproachable from seaward on account of the broad slate which dry out a long waSy from the shore, but very useful as a landmark, especially for vessels navigating between Chausey and Granville, or bound northward by the Cotentin channel. Between Champeaux point and Granville the coast curves slightly to the eastward and is generally of moderate height ; but, in some places it is low, sandy aud dangerous to approach with westerly winds, being bordered by a sand-bank interspersed with flat rocks, which extend a mile from tbe shore. As Granville is approached, tkese dangers become more marked, but, as they especially concern the pJkrtage of that port, a full description of them is given in the next chapter. 153 CHAPTER V. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE, INCLUDING PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS AND fLES CHAUSEY.* VARIATION in 1897. lies Chausey 16° 30' W. 17° O'W. Cape de la Hague - Before proceeding to a description of Granville and the adjacent coast, it will be well to give a detailed account of the vast beds of rocks and islets in the offing, which, in conjunction with the Channel islands to the northward, render the navigation and all approach to the ports on this coast so exceptionally dangerous. PLATEAU des MINQUIERS, situated 9 miles southward of Jersey, and 13 miles from the nearest French land both southward and eastward of it, is a tangled mass of reefs 1 6 miles long East and West, by 8 miles wide. The most dangerous part occupies a space near the middle, about 7 miles long East and West, by 4 miles wide. The masses of rock at this part lie closer together in ridges and are higher, a large number being generally awash at high water ; only a few scattered rocks rise from 10 to 20 feet above that level. These rocky groups are generally connected by extensive banks of shingle, gravel, and sand. There are, however, some narrow tortuous channels through this part of the reef, but from the strength of the tides and absence of good marks, those available being mostly so distant as to be useful only in the clearest weather, the pilotage is too difficult for any but the fishermen and passenger steamers plying between St. Helier's and St. Malo, by whom they are frequented. The whole of the sunken part of this reef, eastward, is studded with dangerous rocks, of which some dry 7 feet at low water, but a far greater number are either just awash or have not more than from 3 to 6 feet over them at that time. Of the rocks which never cover, the most remarkable in order of magnitude are, Maitresse ile, Maisons, Haute Grune, Faucheurs, Figuier,Red Frouquie, Blanc roque, Calfateurs, Roches du Sud, Grand Vascelin, and Pipette rocks.
