A light-buoy exhibiting a fixed white light is moored about a mile westward of the Brisants du Nord-Ouest. 2. A spindle buoy with a perch is moored about 2| miles S. by W. from the above light-buoy. 3. About 1\ miles south-westward from the Brisants du Sud is a light-buoy standing about 26 feet above the water level ; it shows a fixed white light. An additional buoy showing also a fixed white light is moored about a cable south-westward of the principal buoy, and an automatic whistle buoy about the same distance westward of it. Thus the Brisants du Sud are marked by a group of three buoys.* 4. A spindle buoy is moored about E. by S. 2f miles from the group of buoys last described. 5. A light-buoy showing a fixed white light is moored about one mile south-westward of Le Four rock. 6. A black nun buoy is moored close to the southward of the Souarde reef. Maitresse ile, near the south-eastern side of the high middle part of the reef before referred to, is the largest islet of the group, See chart, No. 2,669 *. * An experimental automatic trumpet buoy, with a conical black buoy to mark its position were added to this group ot buoys in May, 1894.

Chap. V.] PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. 155 although barely 200 yards long and 100 yards wide ; it is also the highest, although only 25 feet above high water. There is a little soil on this islet and some faint traces of vegetation, but it is quite destitute of fuel or subsistence of any kind, nor is there any fresh water except that deposited in the interstices of the rocks by rain. Stone was formerly quarried from the western part of the ile and used in the construction of Fort Regent, St. Helier. There are several small stone huts on the islet belonging to Jersey fishermen, who, during the summer season, which is 8 months of the year, fish over all parts of the Minquiers reef. From 16 to 18 boats are generally engaged in the lobster fishery, each boat containing 2 men ; the boats lie on the south-eastern side of the islet, where they receive partial shelter from the surrounding rocks. Vast numbers of lobsters are caught and sent to the London market ; also congers and a variety of other fish, all of which find a ready market at Jersey. The Maisons are three remarkable steep rocks with yellowish heads W.N.W. 4^ miles from Maitresse ile ; they are the highest and most conspicuous rocks at the western side of the high central portion of the reef, although not so high as Maitresse ile, being only 15 feet above high water. Haute Grune, South nearly one mile from the Maisons, rises from the centre of a large mass of rock connected with the Faucheur by a reef, of which many of the highest heads are awash at low water, springs. The Haute Grune never covers, being 5 feet above the highest tides ; it therefore serves as a good mark for other dangers in the: neighbourhood. The Grune de Norman, a reef of which the highest head uncovers 14 feet, lies W. by S. S. 5 cables from the Haute Grune. The Faucheurs is the name given to a large extent of rocks, of which three heads never cover ; they lie W. £ N. 3 miles from Maitresse ile, and S.E. by S. If miles from the Maisons ; they are remarkable from their superior size as compared with other rocks in the neighbourhood, and therefore of great service as a mark. The Figuier is a rock always above water N.W. by N. 1| miles from Maitresse ile. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

[Chap. V. 156 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. Red Frouquie is a rock of nearly the same size, height, and character as the Figuier, about midway between it and Maitresse ile. Calfateurs are four small rocks, always uncovered, a cable east ward of Maitresse ile, with which they are connected at low water. Rocher du Sud is a large rock, always uncovered, S. by W. i W. 4 cables from Maitresse ile. Grand Vascelin, NW. by N. 3 miles from Maitresse ile, uncovers 43 feet. This is a large flat rock with two heads always above water, very conspicuous from its size, and, from its position, a very useful mark. The Petit Vascelin bears N.E. by N. 1\ cables from the Grand Vascelin and lies close to the edge of the reef near deep water, but, being 13 feet lower than the Grand Vascelin, it is covered for a considerable period during spring tides. The Pipette rocks are a group at the north-western extreme of the high part of the Minquiers reef. The highest point, like the Grand Vascelin, uncovers 43 feet, and is therefore always above water. The outer rock of the group is the Grand Haguet ; it covers at high water and bears NW. 4| cables from the high head of Pipette ; N.W. W. 5 miles from Maitresse ile ; W. f N. 2| miles from the outer part of Petit Vascelin ; and, E. | S. 2^ miles from the Grune du Nord-Ouest. St. Peter's spire, Jersey, over the quarry at Le Fret point leads over the rock. The rocks just described are all within the limits of the middle or higher portion of the reef ; westward of this part, the most remark able are Deree Anglaise, Grune du Nord-Ouest, Brisants du Nord- Ouest, Brisants du Sud, and Deree Francaise. Southward, the danger line is marked by the Four, Souarde, and Sauvages. Eastward, numerous sunken rocks extend nearly 6 miles from Maitresse ile. Deree Anglaise is a small cluster of rocks, of which the largest and highest dries 27 feet and lies W.N.W. 2 miles from the Maisons, Maitresse ile being on the same line of bearing. There is a 3-fathoms passage between this rock and the Maisons, but it lies very close past Deree, and is only 5 cables wide ; a long string of rocks extends from the Maisons westward for 1^ miles. i See chart, No. 2,669 *.

Chap. V.] PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. 157 Grune du Nord-Ouest, on the extreme northern edge of the plateau des Minquiers, bears W. £ N. 2\ miles from the Grand Haguet, the outer rock of the Pipette group ; and, N.N.W. \ W. 1^ miles from Deree Anglaise. This rock dries 5 feet at low water ; it is steep-to on its northern and eastern sides but has numerous sunken rocks southward and south- westward of it. Brisants du Nord-Ouest, westward of which lies the light-buoy described at page 154, form the north-western extrenrff of the Minquiers reef and are connected with the Grune du Nord-Ouest by a rocky sunken ledge. The highest head of the Brisants dries 3 feet only and lies with the Faucheur and Haute Grune in line S.E. by E. From a height of 30 feet, Maitresse ile may be seen open northward of the Maisons, the apparent breadth of the latter ; Grune du Nord- Ouest bears E. \ S. \\ miles, the outer parts of the Pipette group and of Petit Vascelin being on the same line of bearing ; and, St. Ouen spire, Jersey, on with the white Semaphore house on the high land of La Moye bears N.N.E. \ E. From this rock, sunken reefs extend west ward nearly a mile with from one to 2 fathoms water. Clearing mark. — St. Ouen spire on with La Moye quarries, marked by a white streak on the cliff outside them, bearing N.E. by N. leads 7 cables westward of all these dangers. Deree Frangaise consists of two rocks which uncover 6 feet nearly East and West '&\ cables distant from each other. From the eastern rock, Prince's tower, Jersey, is seen touching the eastern side of Deree Anglaise N.E. \ N. ; and, Maitresse ile appears open south ward of the Faucheurs, East. Brisants du Sud, marked to the south-westward by the group of buoys described at page 154, are near the south-western edge of the plateau, \\ miles south-westward from Deree Francaise, and W. \ S. southerly 9^ miles from Maitresse ile ; they consist of a small patch of rocks with from one to 2 fathoms over them. Another small patch of sunken reef lies 2\ cables W.N.W. of this, and is the outer danger on this side. The Pointus rocks form an extensive reef about 2 miles S.W. \ W. from the Faucheurs, of which many rocky heads uncover. They are \\ miles in length N.W. by W. and S.E. by E. aud about 1\ cables in width. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

[Chap. V. 158 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. Le Four, the highest head of a small group on the southern edge of the Minquiers, uncovers at half ebb and dries 18 feet at low water; from it, La Moye white Semaphore house on with the middle Maison rock bears N. £ E. ; and, Chausey lighthouse on with the Corbiere rock S.E. by E. f E. South-westward of this rock is the light-buoy described at page 154. The Souarde is a group of low rocks nearly a mile in length with a break in the middle and a 9-feet patch a short distance to the southward, at the southern edge of the Minquiers ; the highest head, near the eastern end, bears E. by S. § S. 2f miles from the Four and dries 7 feet at low water ; from it, the Corbiere rock, Chausey, on with La Tour point, bears S.E. by E. \ E.; and, the Maisons rocks are a little open westward of the Faucheurs N. by W. \ W. The black nun buoy, described at page 154, is moored about Z\ cables S.E. \ E. from the highest head. The Sauvages are a cluster of dangerous rocks detached from the southern edge of the Minquiers reef, their western end lying 2 miles E.S.E. from the eastern end of the Souarde ; they are 8 cables long E.S.E. and W.S.W. and 2\ cables wide, with from 2 to 15 feet water over them. From the 2-feet rock near the middle, Chausey lighthouse is a little open northward of the Corbiere S.E. by E. \ E. 1\ miles ; La Moye white Semaphore house, Jersey, is a little open westward of Maitresse ile ; and, the town of Granville is wholly open southward of Chausey. St. Peter's spire, Jersey, on with Maitresse ile, North, leads close westward of the Sauvages ; Granville church spire open northward of Chausey castle S.E. by E. leads northward ; Chausey castle open southward of Corbiere rock leads southward ; and, Terquete belvedere open eastward of the high land of Meinga point leads eastward ; as does also, Cancale church on with Haut-Bout mill. The Cocq, S.E. by E. \ E., nearly 1| miles from Maitresse ile, uncovers 16 feet ; from the rock, the southern extreme of Maitresse ile and the Maisons are in line ; and, Champeaux point is just in sight southward of Chausey island. This rock is the outer and most important danger south-east ward of Maitresse ile ; La Ronde, the next in importance on this side, bears from Le Cocq N. by E. \ E. 5^ cables and is awash at low water. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. V.] 159 PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. The Faucheur uncovers 29 feet E. by N. one mile from Maitresse ile. The Rat uncovers 12 feet N.E. f E. If miles from Maitresse ile. The Trois Grunes uncover 35 feet N.E. by E. 4 cables from Maitresse ile. Grune de Turbot uncovers 12 feet N. by E. \ E. \\ miles from Maitresse ile. From this, the highest rock of the Turbot group, a number of low rocks extend both northward and westward for %\ cables. Grune Gauvin uncovers 5 feet, and is the centre of a rocky mass of less height, about %\ cables in diameter. It is about a mile within the northern edge of the Minquiers reef, and N. by E. 2 miles from Maitresse ile. From Grune Gauvin, St. Peter's spire appears a little open of point de But and on with the eastern part of the town of St. Aubin beyond that point, bearing North. The Demies uncover 17 feet W.N.W. nearly \\ miles from Grune Gauvin, and N. by W. \ W. 2| miles from Maitresse ile. From the eastern rock, St. Peter's spire appears open eastward of Bergerie house N. \ E. A small reef nearly awash at low water, springs, lies E.S.E. 7 cables from the Demies. The best passage into Maitresse ile is between this rock and Grune Gauvin. The Caux des Minquiers extend from the Rat rock in an easterly direction for 4^ miles, their eastern end, named the East Danger, forming the eastern extreme of the Plateau des Minquiers. The whole of this line is so thickly studded with rocks as to render the navigation amongst them perilous, even for boats, at low water ; but, as none of the rocks dry more than 7 feet, there is never less than 11 feet over them at half tide ; from half flood to half ebb, therefore, it is not at all uncommon for vessels of light draught to sail over them. Turnabout rock dries 4 feet at low water, and is then the easternmost danger visible in this reef. From it, Seymour tower appears westward of Mont Orgueil, midway between it and Seymour house, N. \ E. ; and, the Maisons and Figuier rocks in line W. \ N. ; the reef extends beyond Turnabout rock eastward as far as the East Danger. See chart, No. 2,669 4.

[Chap. V. 160 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. East Danger, the eastern extreme of the Minquiers reef, has only 3 feet over it, and lies E. £ N. nearly 6 miles from Maitresse ile. From it, the Maisons are touching the northern side of the Figuier rock ; and, Seymour tower appears about midway between the inner part of Mont Orgueil castle and St. Martin's church N. | W. Buoy. — A red buoy is moored 1£ cables north-eastward of the East Danger. Directions.— As already stated, St. Ouen spire, Jersey, and La Moye quarry bluff, appearing as a white streak just westward of the white Semaphore house of La Moye, in line N.E. by N. lead 7 cables clear of the western extreme of the Minquiers reef ; St. Ouen spire a little open westward of the Corbiere leads 4 miles westward ; Amas du-Cap midway between cape Frehel lighthouse and Tertre Morgan mill S. by W. J W. leads 1£ miles westward of the reef ; and the Grand Larron semaphore, St. Malo, on with the eastern end of Cezembre island S.S.E. clears the south-western extreme by more than 2 miles. To clear the eastern end, St. Martin's spire and Seymour tower in line N. f W. leads 6 or 7 cables eastward of the red buoy marking the eastern extreme of the reef. St. Peter's spire and Hermitage rock, St. Helier's, in line N.N.W. W. is a wider mark, clearing the reef by 1^ miles. Chausey lighthouse on with the beacon on Enseigne islet S. f E. leads 2 cables eastward of the reef. Coutances cathedral well open northward of Agon church E. by S. £ S. leads 1\ cables northward of all the foul ground in the neighbourhood of the Caux des Minquiers. Eastward of East Danger there are 8 or 9 fathoms, gravelly bottom, and the soundings are tolerably regular. In foggy weather or at night, in rounding the western end of the Minquiers reef from the northward during the flood, a berth of at least 3 or 4 miles should be given it, and should anything less than 16 or 17 fathoms be obtained, haul out to the westward at once. The first part of the flood sets strongly over the reef, and no vessel should risk a near approach to its northern edge until 4 hours flood ; after which, the stream setting along and off the reef is no longer dangerous. Pipette rock is always above water, as well as other rocks eastward of it ; and, during the first or dangerous part of the flood tide the sunken rocks westward throw up strong ripples. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. V.] 161 PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. — ARDENTES. To round the eastern end of the reef ; if from St. Helier's, Jersey, after clearing the dangers near that port, bring St. Peter's spire a little open westward of the Hermitage to pass eastward of Icho bank, which lies 2-| miles southward of the coast of Jersey ; when St. Martin's spire comes on with Seymour tower run with that mark on past ihe red buoy marking the eastern extreme of the Minquiers, and when Maitresse ile bears W. \ N. either haul up westward to pass between the Minquiers and Western Ardentes, or bear up eastward of the Ardentes. The Etat beacon turret, Chausey, on with Point de Champeaux S.S.E., or, if these cannot be seen, a bearing of Chausey will lead eastward. To pass westward of the Ardentes, between them and the Western Ardentes, bring the Enseigne beacon turret, Chausey, a little open eastward of the beacon on Grande ile. The Maisons rocks and Maitresse ile in line also lead midway between the Ardentes. The northern and western sides of the Chausey group are steep, and may be safely approached to 5 cables. The Corbiere bank however, of 3^ fathoms, lies one mile from the western shore, having a 5-fathoms channel inside it. When the Corbiere rock, Chausey, bears South, a vessel is on the line of the Western Ardentes, after passing which she may round the western end of Chausey at about L| miles. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the Minquiers at 6 h. 6 m. ; springs rise 35 feet, neaps 26 feet above the soundings. At and above half tide there are not less than 11 feet water over any part of the Caux des Minquiers. In moderate weather, light draught vessels may then safely pass over them, provided they do not venture westward of Icho and Prince's towers in line N. \ E. When navigating in the neighbourhood of the plateau' des Minquiers, the state of the tide and the effect of the tidal stream on the vessel's course must be most carefully considered and allowed for. THE ARDENTES, 1\ miles E.S.E. from Maitresse ile and 3£ miles northward of the Chausey group, consist of two small banks of sand, shells, and stones, each having also a few rocky heads which dry 6 feet at low water ; their western edge bears E.S.E. 7 miles from Maitresse ile. The banks are 5 cables apart, in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction, and are steep-to all round. The marks for the See chart, No. 2,669 b.

[Chap. V. 162 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. southernmost rocky head of the western bank are, Granville light house on with the southern side of the Etat rock S.E. by S., or, Granville church thrice its own length open southward of the Canue ; and, the high land of La Tour point, Chausey, wholly open eastward of the Enseigne beacon turret S. \ E. Buoy. — A red buoy is moored off the south-eastern extreme of the eastern bank of the Ardentes. The Western Ardentes are about 7 cables south-westward of the Ardentes, and the bank is of much the same character as the latter, but no part of it ever uncovers ; it has a general depth of from 15 to 18 feet, except over one rock near its western end on which there are but 5 feet at low water. This spot bears N. \ W. nearly 3| miles from the Rondes de l'Ouest, the north-western rocks of the Chausey group ; and, from it, Mont St. Michel is in sight eastward of Grande lie, S.S.E. ; the remarkable trees on Mont Huchon are nearly on with Agon church E. \ N. ; and, Prince's tower appears a little open westward of Grouville mill, which latter is somewhat difficult of recognition as it has no sweeps. Nearly midway between the Ardentes and the plateau des Minquiers is another rocky ledge of from 9 feet to 3^ fathoms. Between the Ardentes and the Chausey isles there is a good clear channel with from 7 to 9 fathoms, but great care is required in its navigation, owing to the strength of the tidal streams. Anchorage is good near the middle of the channel ; but, to prevent danger in case of driving during the strength of the stream, care must be taken to anchor clear of the line of tide of any of the dangers. THE CHAUSEY ISLES, lying between the Plateau des Min quiers and Granville, form an extensive group of little islets and rocks 6f miles long in an E.S.E. direction from the Rondes de l'Ouest to the Founet, the easternmost rock ; they are about 3 miles wide, and occupy a space of nearly 16 square miles. Grande ile, Chausey, on the southern side of the group, is the principal and largest islet ; from the lighthouse on La Tour point, the south-eastern point of the ile, Granville lighthouse bears S.E. by E \ E. 8^ miles ; Maitresse ile N.W. \ N. 11 \ miles ; and Pierre de Herpin light S. by W. \ W. 8£ miles. It is about a mile long N.N.W. and S.S.E., 3^ cables wide, See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Chap. V.] WESTERN ARDENTES.— CHAUSEY ISLES. 163 deeply indented by small bays, of which the projecting points are topped by hills, and near its centre, which is rather high, is some cultivated land.* On the southern part of the islet are the lighthouse, a chapel, and a fort ; in the central part, the ruins of an old castle, a farm-house, several cottages in which about 200 stone-cutters reside, and two or three small blacksmiths' shops ; and, on the eastern summit of Gros- Mont, at the northern end, is the Semaphore station, see page 12. The lighthouse and Semaphore stand high, and are prominent objects from seaward in all directions, showing well above all the other islets of the plateau. Grande ile has several granite quarries, of which a large quantity is sent to France. Longue ile, 6 cables eastward of the lighthouse, is very useful as a mark in rounding the south-western part of the group. On ile de la Meule, N.W. \\ miles from the lighthouse, are the ruins of a convent and a well of good water. The western part of the group contains 15 or 16 islets and numerous rocks. The Chausey group, although dangerous and intricate to navigate, is steep-to on the northern and western sides, but the southern side should be approached with caution, especially at low water, at which time the eastern side is quite inaccessible to vessels of deep draught, on account of the sand-banks which almost close the channel between it and Granville. The anchorage generally resorted to by vessels of war is Port Marie road, off the southern side of Grande ile. There are several harbours among the rocks completely sheltered from all winds, of which Chausey Sound, between Grande ile on the western side, and the Puceau and other rocks on the eastern side, is most used ; it is, however, very narrow, difficult of access, and only frequented by small government cruisers, fishermen, stone boats, and other small craft capable of taking the ground. LIGHT. — Chausey lighthouse is a square tower, 56 feet high, and stands on the summit of the hill which crowns La Tour point, the south-eastern extreme of Grande ile ; it exhibits a fixed white light, varied every four minutes by a red flash, which is preceded and followed by a short eclipse, not total within 6 miles. The light is of the third order, 121 feet above high water, and visible 16 miles ; the lighthouse open southward of the Corbiere rock leads southward of * See Admiralty plan of Chausey isles, No. 63 ; scale, m = 5 inches.

164 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. [Chap. V. the Sauvages and of all the rocks in the south-eastern part of the Minquiers ledge. The Corbiere is a high and remarkable rock at the south-western edge of the Chausey group N.W. by W. £ W. 1*7 miles from the lighthouse and about 5 cables south-westward of Meule islet. Commencing with the Bane de la Corbiere in the West, and proceeding in order by the southern, eastern, and northern coasts, a description of the principal dangers which fringe the plateau of the Chausey isles will now be given. Bane de la Corbiere, off the western end of the Chausey isles and composed of sand and shells, extends 1^ miles in a S. by E. and N. by W. direction with an outward curve, and is about 2 cables wide. Its general depths are from 3^ to 4^ fathoms, the shoalest water being near the middle of the bank. From the southern end in 4 fathoms, the Corbiere rock bears E. 4 N. 8 cables ; and, from the shoalest part of 3^ fathoms, the lighthouse is on with the Corbiere S.E. by E. J E. Between this bank and the isles, the depths are from 5 to 10 fathoms, the deepest water being near the isles. The Cancalaise. — Beacon. — The Cancalaise is the highest head of a small rocky ridge 2^ cables from the southernmost rocks of the Chausey group and in the space between are several rocky patches with from 1 to 7 feet only. The ridge is a cable long East and West, and the highest head, at the eastern end, uncovers 12 feet at the lowest tides, at which time a rock is awash at the western end. A floating beacon is moored just westward of highest head. The northern end of the eastern ile des Huguenans touching La Tour point E. \ S. southerly is the mark for the highest head. To clear the Cancalaise when rounding the south-western end of Chausey, keep the Rondes de l'Ouest in sight westward of the Corbiere until the southern house on Longue ile comes well open southward of La Tour point. Basse du Cancalaise, a rocky patch about a cable in diameter, is 1£ cables E. by S. of the Cancalaise ; the highest head, on its western side, uncovers 6 feet, and another head, on the northern side, uncovers 5 feet. Between the Basse du Cancalaise and the Chausey isles there are rocky heads which uncover from 4 to 8 feet. See chart, No. 63.

Chap. V.] CHAUSEY ISLES AND ROCKS. 165 Basse du Chateau, of which the shoalest spot bears S.W. southerly 4^ cables from Chausey lighthouse, is about 1\ cables long N. by E. and S. by W. and one cable wide ; it has 14 feet water at its northern end, 20 feet near the middle, and 27 feet at its southern end ; from which, the highest and northernmost head of the Epiettes touching La Tour point bears N.E. \ N. The Huguenans beacon turret on with the highest head of the Piliers E. \ N. leads 2 cables southward. Roches de Bretagne, about a cable southward of Bretagne point, form a ridge 1^ cables long N.N.W. and S.S.E. and one cable wide. The northern head of the ridge uncovers 16 feet, the middle head 14 feet, and the south-western head 12 feet at low water, springs, when there are from 6 to 11 feet over the southern end of the ridge. The mark for the southernmost head of 11^ feet is, the beacon on the Epiettes a little open southward of La Tour point. The Tour patches are three small rocky heads about 2 cables southward of La Tour point. The two westernmost patches have only 6 feet water, bear N. by E. E. and S. by W. \ W. from each other, and are about 50 yards apart. The eastern head has 11 feet water, and bears E. by S. half a cable from the south-western patch. Basse des Epiettes. — This small patch, half a cable long N.N.W. and S.S.E., has two small rocky heads with only 3 feet water. The Enseigne beacon turret on with the eastern slope of Grande ile N.^ W. leads between the Basse des Epiettes and the Tour patches, but directly towards the Tonneau rock, which dries 12 feet about a cable south-eastward of La Tour point. Basse de l'ile Longue is a rocky head with only 3 feet water S. | W. nearly 4 cables from Longue ile ; and, S.E. 4 E. 8 cables from Chausey lighthouse. From it, the Conchee rock touching the southern end of the eastern ile des Huguenans bears E. \ N. ; and, the northern and southern heads of the Epiettes in line bear N.W. by N. Fis-Cous and Basses du FiS-C0US.— Midway between Longue ile and the Huguenans are the Fis-Cous and Basses du Fis-Cous, two rocky patches which may be dangerous to a vessel working along the southern side of the Chausey group. See chart, No. 63.

[Chap. V. 166 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. The Fis-Cous is about 50 yards in extent, uncovers 9 feet, and is marked by a beacon. It bears S.E. by E. 6i cables from the southern end of Longue ile ; and, S.W. f W. 3 cables from the Grand Cheval rock. A small rock, awash at low water, lies a cable eastward of the Fis-Cous. The Basses du Fis-Cous, about a cable in extent, lie one cable westward from the Fis-Cous. One head of this danger is awash at the lowest tides, and others have only from one to 4 feet over them. Gros-Mont semaphore on with Tourette rock (the leading mark for the south-eastern channel into Chausey sound) N.W. \ W. leads very close south-westward of the Basses du Fis-Cous. lies des Huguenans.— Beacon turret.— These are small islets on the southern edge of the Chausey group 2 miles eastward of the lighthouse, and, with a few rocks which join them at low water, form a small rocky cluster 4 cables long E.N.E. and W.S.W. On the summit of the Grand Huguenan, the largest and most eastern islet, is a stone beacon turret painted with black and white hori zontal bands, which, when in line with a similar turret on the Etat rock N. by E. \ E. shows the western limit of the fishing grounds. The summit of the eastern islet is covered with grass, and sheep from Granville often graze there. The Conchee. — This rock is 5 cables eastward of the iles des Huguenans, on the eastern side of the Conchee passage ; its summit is about 20 feet above the highest tides. The Basse de la Conchee uncovers 7 feet about 3 cables E. \ S. from the Conchee. Haute Foraine, E. \ N. a long mile from the Conchee, is the easternmost high rock connected with the Chausey group and is marked by a beacon. Its advanced easterly position renders it very conspicuous, and Granville pilots use it in estimating the height of the tide. It uncovers 28^ feet at the lowest tides, and when it covers there are from 15 to 16 feet water at the entrance of Granville harbour. A sand-bank of some extent, with 9 feet water, lies 3 cables north-eastward of the Haute Foraine. The Tomin is a small and dangerous rock which uncovers 18 feet at 2\ cables south- westward of the Haute Foraine and a little north ward of the line of the lighthouse on with the northern point of the eastern Huguenans. See chart, No. 63.

Chap. V.] 167 CHAUSEY ISLES AND ROCKS. The Pignon, an isolated dangerous rock N.E. f N. 6 cables from the summit of the Haute Foraine, uncovers 10 feet at the lowest tides and does not show at ordinary neaps. A floating beacon is moored on this rock. A cable south-eastward of it there is a flat with only 2 feet water. The Founet, the easternmost rock of the Chausey group, uncovers 7 feet ; the marks for it are, the Canue and Etat rocks nearly in line N.W. northerly ; Coutances cathedral its own breadth open eastward of Mont Martin mill ; and, the top of Conchee rock perceptibly open southward of the little hillock which crowns the southern point of the eastern Huguenans. Buoy. — The Founet is marked on its south-eastern side by a red bell-buoy. Basse du Founet, an isolated rocky patch with 3^ feet only, bears N.N.E. \ E. If cables from the Founet ; between it and the Pignon are patches of from 10 to 14 feet. Clearing marks. — The summit of the Conchee rock on with Chausey lighthouse W. by N., or on with the Huguenans beacon turret leads southward of the Founet, Haute Foraine, and Tomin rocks ; and, the Etat rock twice its apparent breadth open northward of the summit of the Canue leads northward of the Basse du Founet. Even at low water, springs, Chausey pilots take vessels between the. Founet and Pignon rocks, but strangers should use this passage only at low water, neaps, or at 2 hours' flood at springs, and then only when the Haute Foraine is uncovered or its beacon plainly visible. The Canue rock lies E. by N. § N. 3^ miles from Chausey lighthouse, and its summit is 6 feet above the level of the highest tides. South-eastward of the Canue, a reef named the Canuettes, many of whose heads dry from 7 to 21 feet, extends 7 cables in the direction of the Founet. A wooden beacon stands on the Canue tte, one of these rocks, about 6 cables S.E. easterly from the Canue rock. The Etat rock.— Beacon turret.— The Etat is a remarkable rock on the northern edge of the Chausey group ; on its summit is See chart, No. 63. L SO 11886

168 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. [Chap. V. a stone beacon turret, similar to that on the eastern Huguenans, which bears from it S. by W. | W. ; it is painted with black and white horizontal bands. These turrets in line show the western limit of the fishing grounds, and are also of great use as a leading mark between the Marie ledge and Catheue banks northward of Chausey isles. From the Etat rock, the Dechiree ledge, at the north-western extreme of the Chausey group, bears W. by N. 2>\ miles. The northern edge of the plateau, which is here steep-to, is indicated by several rocks which seldom or never cover, of which the Selliere, H miles westward of the Etat, is a useful mark ; and, by many more which uncover as the tide falls, of which the principal are, the Petite Entree, which uncovers 36 feet and is marked by a beacon ; the Grande Entree, which uncovers 38 feet ; the Pointue, which uncovers 41 feet ; and the Dechiree ledge of which the highest part uncovers 33 feet. L'Enseigne. — Beacon turret. — This small islet, about 8 feet above the level of the highest tides, is one mile nearly within the northern edge of the plateau, and 2 miles northward of La Tour point ; it is remarkable from the uniform convexity of its surface, and has a small white stone beacon turret on its summit. Rondes de la Dechiree, a rocky ridge at the north-western side of the Chausey group, is 3 cables long in a N.E. and S.W. direction ; the northernmost head uncovers 39 feet, and the highest head, near the middle of the ridge, uncovers 45 feet, and therefore only covers at the highest equinoctial spring tides. There are several other low heads on the ridge ; that at its southern extreme, uncovers only 4 feet, with the north-western point of the Pointue rock touching the south-eastern extreme of the Dechiree E. by N. \ N. ; and, Chausey lighthouse on with the Chapeau rock S.S.E. | E. Basse du Chenal.— This small rocky patch, between the Rondes de la Dechiree and the Rondes de l'Ouest, is exactly in the fairway of the entrance to the Rondes anchorage, is about 150 yards from the northern extreme of the Rondes de l'Ouest, and has only 5 feet water. The marks for it are, the Pointue rock just open southward of the Dechiree ; and, the lighthouse a little open south-westward of of Gros-Mont semaphore. See chart, No. 63.

Chap. V.] CHAUSEY ISLES. — ANCHORAGES. 169 Rondes de l'Ouest is a rocky ridge, 6 cables long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and 2 cables wide, forming the western extreme of the Chausey group. Several of its heads never cover and serve as good marks for the south-western limits of the group. ANCHORAGES— SOUND de CHAUSEY, so called from the secure anchorage it affords to vessels of light draught, trends NW. by N. and S.E. by S. along the eastern side of the Grande ile, and occupies a space 6 cables long. At low water, springs, it is surrounded by rocks and banks of sand and mud, which form a natural harbour where vessels capable of taking the ground find capital shelter ; if remaining longer than one tide, or at springs, they should, however, moor head and stern to prevent tailing on the banks. The Sound is sheltered on all sides except from S.S.E. to E.S.E., and strong wands from that quarter throw in a heavy sea at high water. Fresh winds from N.N.E. to N.W. are also much felt, causing a heavy swell throughout the whole extent of the Sound from one hour before until two hours after high water. Depths. — Two entrances lead into Chausey sound, one from the southward, the other from the northward ; the latter dries as much as 15 feet in places, and therefore has from 20 feet at high water springs, to 11 feet at neaps. The southern entrance is the best, and is divided by the Epiettes rocks into the South and S.E. channels : the South channel has only one foot water in it at the lowest tides, but at high water, springs, has 36 feet, and 27 feet at neaps. The S.E. channel dries 6 feet, and therefore has 7 feet less water than the South channel. Although the deepest parts of the Sound do not dry, there remains but little water in them, and the soundings are very irregular. There are, however, two narrow gullies with space for three or four short vessels of from 10 to 11 feet draught to remain afloat. The largest, at the entrance of the Sound, is 325 yards long and from 55 to 65 yards wide, with depths of from 10 to 17 feet, but it is occupied by three mooring buoys for the use of the guard-vessel protecting the fisheries. The second is only 173 yards long, with from 8 to 1 5 feet, and is a little northward of the former, in front of the farm-house and chapel, and abreast of the Crabiere rock which uncovers 24 feet ; this anchorage also is usually occupied by one of the fishery cruisers secured with a mooring chain on each bow and quarter. The best place for grounding is on the lowest part of the See chart, No. 63. L 2 S;0 11886

[Chap. V. 170 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. beach between the Crabiere and Tourette rocks, where the bottom is soft mud, but there are many scattered heads of rock beneath the mud, rendering the surface uneven and liable to damage vessels of any size ; those up to 60 or 65 feet in length may, however, beach here in safety. DIRECTIONS.— The South channel, between La Tour point and the Epiettes, is accessible to vessels drawing 10 feet when the Tonneau rock covers, and has 12 feet in mid-channel at two hours flood. In taking this channel, bring the Enseigne white beacon turret just in sight eastward of the eastern slope of Grand ile N. 3° W., which leads between the Epiettes and La Tour patches. The beacon on the south-western rock of the Epiettes may then be steered for and approached to within half a cable ; then steer northward in mid channel parallel with the shore of the isle, and, if intending to run northward of the Crabiere, pass between its beacon and the beacon 100 yards eastward of it, giving the Crabiere a berth of at least 30 or 40 yards to clear the tail which runs out from it in that direction. The South-East channel is eastward of the Basse des Epiettes ; the leading mark is Gros-Mont semaphore on with the Tourette rock NW. W. The Tourette is a short steep whitewashed point on the beach a cable north-eastward of the farm-house. When passing Longue ile, to clear the ledge off its southern end, open the Semaphore a little westward of the Tourette, taking care to bring them quickly on again, after passing it ; the mark then leads directly towards the Crabiere, passing the Loup beacon, which s ands at the northern end of the rock, on the port hand, and the Ebauche beacon, on the western part of that ridge, on the starboard hand, and over a bank of mud which dries at low water, springs, northward of the Epiettes, when a vessel may either anchor or proceed as if coming through the South channel. The mud bank referred to completely bars the channel, and can only be crossed by vessels above 10 feet draught after 2h hours flood. When the highest head of the Loup covers, there are 16 feet water on this bank. The North entrance into Sound de Chausey is northward of the Enseigne, between the rocks extending 2 cables eastward of Pointue rock and the Grande Entree ; this latter is a small group of rocks, of which the highest head uncovers 38 feet, 3£ cables eastward See chart, No. 63.

Chap. V.] 171 CHAUSEY SOUND.— DIRECTIONS. of the low rocks extending from the Pointue. The highest head of the Pointue uncovers 41 feet. The inner portion of this channel, southward of the Etardiere, is completely barred at low water by vast sand-banks uncovering generally only a few feet, but between the Sauniere and Vieux they dry as much as 15 feet in places. Most of the rocks being marked by beacons, strict attention to the following directions render it safe of access between half flood and half ebb to vessels up to 10 feet draught; no stranger, however, should attempt such a channel without a pilot. From the entrance, the channel takes a southerly direction between the western edge of a rocky group named Longues, on the western edge of which is a beacon, and the Basse de l'Etardiere, a flat rock at 2 cables distance which uncovers 8 feet a cable eastward of the Etardiere, to which rock it is joined at low water, springs, by a sand-bank. From thence, the channel takes a W.S.W. direction between the Etardiere rock, which never covers, and the Enseigne ; and then, a southerly direction, leaving on the port hand the low rocks extending from the Petite Enseigne, the Sauniere a small islet 56 feet above the lowest tides, and the Petite Fourche ; and, on the starboard hand, the Massue and a rocky group eastward of the Vieux, and from thence to the Sound. The Massue has a beacon off its north-eastern extreme and a whitewashed rock at its south eastern ; a rock with a beacon lies off the northern end of the Petite Fourche nearly in the fairway, and a vessel may pass it on either side. In entering by the North channel, the leading mark is, Chausey lighthouse on with the Enseigne beacon turret S. E. ; keep the lighthouse, however, twice its breadth open eastward of the beacon turret whilst passing eastward of the low rocks extending from the Pointue, and twice its breadth open westward whilst passing the Longues rocks. In passing the Basse de l'Etardiere, when the two white patches on the Massue and the Chapeau rocks are in line, or when the southern end of Meule islet is just touching the northern end of the Massue S.W. \ W., run in that direction until the light house is on with the south-western point of Sauniere islet S. by E. \ E.; this leads up to the Sauniere ; give it a berth of half a cable in passing, and also leave the beacon off its southern end close on the port hand, and, after passing it, steer in mid-channel between the beacons marking the rocks on either side of the channel abreast of the Gros-Mont. See chart, No. 63.

[Chap. V. 172 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. Enseigne anchorage is a small space where vessels of 10 feet draught, with good pilots, may find shelter afloat at low water from S.W., South, or S.E. winds. With northerly winds, no vessel should anchor there except to await water through the North channel into Chausey Sound, as from its limited extent there is neither room to veer nor drive without tailing on the sand-bank, which, at low water, dries 1^ cables northward of the Enseigne. Run for this anchorage through the North entrance with the same mark as if bound for Chausey Sound until the vessel is well south ward of the Pointue ; then bring the lighthouse on with the south western slope of the Enseigne, and when the southern end of Meule iilet touches the northern end of the Massue rock, anchor, and the vessel will be in the best berth and deepest water, 22 to 36 feet, sandy bottom, midway between the Basse de l'Etardiere, and the Longue. Between half ebb and half flood, great care must be taken to estimate the depth, as the soundings, when southward of the Pointue rocks, vary from 7 feet only to 22 feet at low water, and also to avoid a small rock with only 4 feet, nearly in the fairway of the entrance. PORT MARIE is the little bay between La Tour and Bretagne points, in front of which, 2 cables off-shore, is a small space capable of affording shelter from winds between N.W. and N.E. to two or three vessels of 10 feet draught. Anchorages. — The inner anchorage off Port Marie, between the Bretagne rocks and Tour patches, is not more than 3 cables in extent. Approaching from the South-west, bring the Etat beacon turret on with La Tour point N.E. § E. ; or, the northernmost and highest head of the Epiettes quite shut in by La Tour point leads over the Chateau patch, south-eastward of the Bretagne rocks, and north-westward of the Tour patches ; and, when Huguenans beacon turret is on with the Grand Cheval rock E. £ S. southerly, anchor in about 24 feet, sandy bottom. From the South-east, the westernmost point of Grand ile, forming port Homard, touching Bretagne point N.N.W. \ W., leads outside the Tour patches and north-eastward of the Chateau patch and Bretagne rocks ; when the northernmost head of the Epiettes is shut in with La Tour point, anchor. Port Marie outer road is a good anchorage for large vessels of war, and is, in fact, the principal roadstead of Granville, the greater See chart, No. 63.

Chap. V.] CHAUSEY. — PORT MARIE.— ETAT ANCHORAGE. 173 part of the shipping bound for that port remaining here until the water on the banks is sufficiently high to proceed. The best position for a vessel of deep draught in this road is, with the lighthouse bearing N. by W. i W. distant from 5 cables to a mile, in from 7 to 11 fathoms. When at anchor, Coutances cathedral should be open northward of the eastern Huguenans, and the Enseigne white beacon turret should be open eastward of La Tour point. Here she will be sheltered from the wind, if northward of N.W. by N. Should it be inclined to draw more westerly, with an appearance of bad weather, the first opportunity should be taken to weigh and get to windward with the ebb. or to run for shelter either to Cancale road, see page 148, or to the eastward or northward of the Chausey group, according to the direction of the wind. Conchee anchorage.— With the wind from N.W. by W. to N.N.E. the Conchee anchorage in 4^ or 5 fathoms is to be preferred ; the marks for it are, the old castle in ruins on Grande ile on with the Huguenans beacon turret W. by N. \ N., and the Selliere and Culas siere rocks in line N.W. by N. The Etat anchorage. — With the wind southward of West, the anchorage under the Etat rock should be resorted to. Anchor in from 5 to 7 fathoms, from 5 to 8 cables from the rocks, with Chausey lighthouse on with the Canue, or on with the Etat beacon turret, according to the direction of the wind. Indeed, all the northern shore of the Chausey group afford-s shelter against southerly or south westerly winds, and, being bold, may be approached without fear. Rondes de l'Ouest anchorage, on the western side of the Chausey group under the Rondes de l'Ouest ridge, is the only shelter the group affords to large vessels during easterly winds. It can be reached at any time of tide either from Port Marie road or from the Conchee or Etat anchorages. When proceeding towards it from Port Marie road, keep Huguenans beacon turret on with the highest rock of the Piliers E. \ N., to pass southward of the Chateau patch ; and, when Gros-Mont semaphore bears N.E. \ N. haul gradually in, but not farther than to have the middle of Longue ile on with La Tour point, to avoid the Cancalaise. When the large and remarkable round rock of the Ronde de l'Ouest ridge is in sight westward of the Corbiere, haul in to within 2^ cables of the rocks, passing between Corbiere bank and the. Chausey group, aucL See chart, No. 63.

174 [Chap. V. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. anchor in from 7 to 9 fathoms, sandy bottom, 5 cables westward of the Rondes de l'Ouest and the same distance north-eastward of the Corbiere bank, with the lighthouse midway between Gros-Mont and the western extreme of Grand ile, or touching the southern end of Meule islet ; and, the Etat beacon turret about midway between the Enseigne beacon turret and the Grande Entree rock E. \ S. Anchorage between the Rondes de L'Ouest and the Dechiree. — This anchorage is similar to that of the Enseigne, and affords partial shelter with the wind from South round by East to N.E. It is about 3 cables long and 2 cables wide, and has from 2>\ to 6^ fathoms, sandy bottom. The entrance, with a least depth of 5 fathoms, is 1\ cables wide between the Basse du Chenal, a small rock with only 5 feet at the lowest tides, and a rock forming, the south-western extreme of the Rondes de la Dechiree, which uncovers 4 feet. The leading mark in, is, the lighthouse on with Gros-Mont semaphore S.E. by S., and when the Pointue rock appears midway between the Dechiree and Grande Entree rocks the vessel is in the middle of the anchorage. There is another anchorage with from 2-|- to 5 fathoms, called the Dechiree, eastward of that just described ; it is entirely surrounded by high rocks, which cover at the last quarter flood, forming between half ebb and half flood a natural harbour accessible at all tides, but no vessel should use it in changeable, boisterous weather, or without a good local pilot ; it is not more than 5 cables long and 2%j cables wide, the broadest part being between the Dechiree and a rock to the southward which uncovers 24 feet. To enter this anchorage, proceed as before with the lighthouse on with the Semaphore ; and, when the Pointue is half its apparent breadth open southward of the Dechiree, the vessel is southward of the Rondes de la Dechiree and should haul to the eastward, taking care to avoid two rocky patches awash at low water, springs, on the southern side of the anchorage. When the lighthouse is on with Massue rock S.S.E., anchor in from 4 to 5| fathoms water, with rather coarse ground. With the aid of a good pilot, the Enseigne anchorage and the northern channel into Chausey Sound are often entered by this route within 2 hours before or after high water. Beauchamp anchorage is 2\ cables north-westward of the Huguenans, and, with a good pilot, might afford shelter to one or See chart, No". 63

Chap. V.] RONDES DE L'EOUST AND BEAUCHAMP ANCHORAGE. 175 two vessels of deep draught. The principal entrance has a least depth, at low water, of 4 fathoms, and therefore has nearly 10 fathoms at high water, springs, and 8Jj fathoms at neaps. The anchorage consists of a kind of basin or deep about 4 cables long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and 1£ cables wide ; it has from 5 to 6 fathoms at low water springs, with excellent holding-ground, between the lines of the lighthouse on with the southern extreme of the Ango rock, and of Gros Mont semaphore on with the northern hillock of Grande Ancre or Saddle island. It is tolerably well protected throughout the tide at neaps, but at high water, springs, fresh winds from N.W. to N.E. cause a heavy tumbling sea, which, however, soon subsides as the tide falls. Vessels usually moor N.N.E. and S.S.W., but, if intending to remain, they should be secured with anchors on each bow and quarter. Two sets of moorings with mooring buoys for the use of the small French steam-vessels employed in protecting the oyster fishery occupy the central part of the anchorage. Southern entrances.— A vessel of considerable draught with a fair wind and an experienced pilot, may enter the Beauchamp anchorage from the southward at all times by passing between the Grand Piliers and Tournioure rocks ; the latter has on it a beacon, which, however, is sometimes washed away and should not be depended on ; or, between the Tournioure and Chapelle rocks ; but these narrow passages cannot be used at all times without steam or a sufficiently commanding breeze to stem the tidal streams. The leading mark to pass between the Tournioure and Piliers is, the summit of Roche Noire on with the Culassiere rock N.N.E. Great care is required in passing the Tournioure at half flood, the stream immediately outside it setting strongly to the eastward, whilst between it and the Piliers it takes the direction of the channel. Having passed the Tournioure beacon, steer north-eastward towards the Petit Huguenan to get into the fairwayy and then more northerly to pass midway between that islet and Roche Noire, after which the summit of the rock Caniard du Sud open westward of the Culassiere N. by E. \ E. leads to the anchorage. The entrance eastward of the Tournioure is the deepest, but is only 50 or 60 yards wide between the Tournioure and Chapelle rocks, and should never be attempted during the strength of the tide ; the best time is within an hour of high water, and the nearer high water the See chart, No. 63.

[Chap. V. 176 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. better. A vessel having passed midway between the Tournioure and Chapelle rocks and also between Roche Noire and Petit Hunguenan may proceed to Beauchamp anchorage as before directed. Passe de la Conchee, with a sufficient rise of tide, is the safest entrance to Beauchamp anchorage from the south ward for vessels of light draught ; it lies between the iles des Huguenans and Conchee rocks, and from thence north-westward between two mud-banks, which dry from 3 to 7 feet. The entrance is between the Gaillard d'Avant rock which uncovers 29 feet and has just northward of it the Artimon rock which uncovers 19 feet, and some small heads close south-westward of the Conchee which uncover from 9 to 17 feet. The leading mark is, the Selliere and Petite Mauvaise rocks in line N.N.W. until the lighthouse comes on with the middle of the Ango rock ; then haul to the westward for the anchorage and cross the mud-bank extending northward from the Huguenans. When the small heads close south-westward of the Conchee are covered and the Artimon rock is awash, there are not less than 13 feet on any part of the mud-bank which must be crossed in running for the anchorage. Passe Orientale de FEtat. — The Beauchamp anchorage may also be reached from the north-eastward through this passage, which is a clear space through the rocks in the north-eastern part of the Chausey group ; the tide, however, must be sufficiently high for a vessel to cross the sand-bank, which extends over the greater part of the passage and dries from 2 to 5 feet above the level of the lowest tides. The entrance to this passage, H cables wide, is between the Pouillou rock which uncovers 32 feet, and some small rocky heads connected with the Petit Etat which uncover from 5 to 10 feet. From thence the passage is bounded on the western side by the Caniard du Sud which uncovers 38 feet, and by the Mauvaise, always above water ; and, on the eastern side, by the Plate du Hibou, a small rocky group of which the highest head uncovers 26^ feet, and by the Culassiere rock which is never covered. The leading mark is, Petite Ancre islet on with the Mauvaise S.W. \ W. until within about 1\ cables of the latter, then steer southward See chart, No. 63,

Chap. V.] CHAUSEY ISLES. — DANGERS OFF GRANVILLE. 177 to pass between it and the Culassiere, and from thence to the anchorage. There are several other entrances to the Beauchamp anchorage on the northern and western sides of the group, of which two admit vessels up to 10 feet draught at low water, but all are so intricate as to be of use only to fishermen and coasters thoroughly acquainted with the localities. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the Chausey group, at 6h. 9m. ; equinoctial springs rise 46 feet, ordinary springs 35 feet, and neaps 26 feet above the zero of soundings ; neap range 17 feet. The stream turns at the eastern end of the group, between Founet and Pignon rocks, from 25 to 30 minutes earlier than in the middle of the passage between the Founet and pointe du Roc, Granville ; that is to say, the flood or northern stream begins to be felt about 4^ hours before high water at Granville, and the southern stream one hour after. Admiralty bank. — This narrow ridge of sand lying between the Chausey isles and the mainland is not more than 2 cables wide, and extends 1^ miles N.E. by N. and S.W. by S. with only 7 feet water on the shoalest part close to its northern end ; from it, Granville lighthouse bears S.S.E. 4T miles ; Coutances cathedral midway between the church and mill of Mont Martin N.E. by E. \ E. ; the Conchee rock on with the eastern ile des Huguenans ; and, the Etat beacon turret just northward of the Canue rock N.W. \ W. Coutances cathedral on with Mont Martin church leads eastward of this bank ; the Etat twice its own breadth open northward of the Canue, or Mont St. Michel twice its own breadth open westward of Champeaux point S. \ E. leads north-eastward. DANGERS Off GRANVILLE. — The navigation between Granville and the Chausey isles at low water, springs, is rendered both difficult and dangerous for vessels drawing more than 7 or 8 feet by the numerous banks and knolls of sand, which form a bar having only from 14 to 17 feet water on the deepest parts, and with several patches of from 2 to 6 feet ; small coasters, however, by following the directions given for this passage, may pass between these banks and the Admiralty bank in not less than 10 feet at losv water. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

178 [Chap. V. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. Tombelaine bank.— The flats extending from 1} miles W. by N. of pointe du Roc to Champeaux point, on which there are from one to 6 feet water, extend 3j miles from the shore westward of St. Pair ; they then gradually narrow until nearly abreast of Champeaux point, where the bank again projects seaward in a long narrow spit having 9 feet at its outer end, which bears N.W. \\ miles from Champeaux point. The highest of these flats are, the Tombe laine bank, awash at low water, springs, and another little ridge of sand which uncovers one foot. The northern part of this latter lies S.W. about 2\ miles, and the highest part of the Tombelaine S.W. § W. 1\ miles from Granville pier-head light. Basse Dorriere is a small isolated rock, rising from a sandy bottom, with only 4 feet water ; it is a cable N.N.E. from the northern end of the Tombelaine bank, with Granville lighthouse bearing N.E. by E. f E. one mile ; and the West pier-head light E. \ N. 1\ miles. The Haguet bank consists of a number of shoal heads with from 2 to 6 feet on them and from 9 to 15 feet between. It extends 2| miles in a N. by W. and S. by E. direction, and the northern head with 6 feet bears N.W. \ N. 3| miles from Granville lighthouse. Between this head and the southern end of the Admiralty bank there is a passage about 2\ cables wide with 11 feet water. Chausey lighthouse touching Chapelle rock W. by N. \ N. is the leading mark through. The southern end is nearly joined to the Tombelaine bank by a narrow ridge of sand which almost dries at low water, springs, thus forming at that time the shallow bar between Granville and the Chausey isles before mentioned. Bane de Rondehaie, a small patch of sand, gravel, and rock, with 10 feet water, bears W. by S. \ S. 4^ miles from Granville lighthouse. The spire of Granville church open northward of the lighthouse leads nearly a mile northward of the bank ; the Culassiere rock, Chausey, on with the Huguenans beacon turret N. \ E. leads westward ; and, Culassiere rock midway between the Huguenans and the Conchee N. § W. leads eastward. There is a small knoll with 23 feet water N.N.W. about 3 cables from the Rondehaie. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

■Chap. V.] 179 DANGERS OFF GRANVILLE.— GRANVILLE. The Videcoq.— Bell-buoy.— This small rock uncovers 2\ feet, and has from 18 to 20 feet, sandy bottom, on all sides. It is marked on its eastern side by a bell-buoy painted with red and black bands. The rock lies westward of the Haguet bank, with Granville light house bearing E. by S. 3£ miles ; Chausey lighthouse N.W. \ N. 5^ miles ; Granville church is on with the second southernmost chimney of the south-western barrack; and, the Culassiere rock is nearly on with the Conchee rock. Granville church on with the northernmost chimney of the south western barrack leads 5 cables northward of the Videcoq rock ; the same church on with the southern chimney leads 2\ cables southward ; the Mauvaise rock on with the Conchee leads 5 cables eastward ; and, the Mauvaise on with the Huguenans leads westward. A sand-bank about 8 cables long N.W. and S.E. and 2--J cables wide, with only 6 feet water, lies 5 cables northward of the Videcoq. The Mauvaise rock midway between the Huguenans and Conchee leads westward of it ; and, the three mills of Breville a little open northward of the foot of Menars point leads northward. Basse Parisienne is a small rocky ridge, steep-to, with 13 feet water over it and 6 or 7 fathoms on all sides ; from it, Granville light house bears E. N. 5| miles ; Chausey lighthouse N. by W. \ W. westerly 5j miles ; and, Pierre de Herpin lighthouse S.W. \ W. nearly 5 miles. The marks for it are, Haut-Bout eastern mill well open westward of the Herpin rock S.W. | W. ; and, Granville lighthouse between the steeple of Granville church and the barracks. These barracks are high, and, standing on the top of the precipice of Roo de Granville north-westward of the steeple, are very conspicuous. The Petits Banes are six or seven small sandy ridges, with from 6 to 9 fathoms on them, S.S.W. 3^ miles from Chausey light house ; they occupy a space 1^ miles long N.W. and S.E. and 5 cables wide. They are not dangerous, but when it blows hard they should be avoided by small vessels as they cause a heavy sea. GRANVILLE. — The port of Granville is between pointe du Roc and Gautier point, which latter bears S.E. by E. \ E. 9 cables from the south-western extreme of Roc point. Gautier point See chart, No. 2,669 b.

[Chap. V. 180 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. is high, and on its summit is a fort which commands the entrance to Granville harbour. The town of Granville is built in the form of an amphitheatre at the foot of the eastern part of the high, narrow, steep peninsula of Le Roc, which is nearly a mile long W. \ S. and E. \ N., BOO yards wide, and united with the mainland by a narrow isthmus half a mile northward of Gautier point. The upper town is sur rounded by walls and occupies the eastern part of the peninsula ; the lower town stands on the isthmus at the entrance of a narrow valley enclosed between high hills, and watered by the little river Bosc which separates the suburbs from the lower town, its waters when swollen by rains running over the sands westward. The Outer harbour is on the western side of the lower town at the foot of Le Roc, which, with the adjacent land, shelters it from winds from N.W. round by North and East to S.S.E., and the pier protects it from the heavy sea caused by south-westerly winds, but it is open from South to S.S.E. The water is smooth in the harbour when it blows hard from North to N.W., but vessels should then be well moored to resist the violent squalls which rush down from Le Roc. The pier is built on the rocks which uncover at the foot of the south-western part of Le Roc. It begins at 65 yards west ward of the last houses in the lower town, and from thence extends in a southerly direction about 390 yards ; it then turns eastward for about 210 yards, and is terminated by a broad pier-head. The eastern pier approaches the western pier from the north-eastward, leaving a passage about 142 yards wide between the pier-heads. Depths. — The bottom between the pier-heads is of hard sand and gravel and dries 10 feet above the level of the lowest tides; here there are 27 feet at high water, springs, and upwards of 17 feet at neaps. Inside it dries 19 feet, but the bottom is of soft mud, and affords good berths for the crowds of fishing craft, by which it is usually occupied. This harbour can be entered by the vessels which usually frequent it at ordinary neaps from 1^ hours before to.l^ hours after high water. The Inner harbour is a wet dock or basin, having its entrance from the eastern side of the outer harbour by means of a lock 246 feet in length and 54^ feet wide ; its outer sill has 30 feet, and its inner sill 24 feet over it at high water, ordinary springs, which latter See chart, No. 2,669 b.

Another small basin lies on the eastern side of the main basin and communicates with it by means of an opening, without gates, 39^ feet wide ; vessels of 14 feet draught are neaped in this inner basin during several tides, and it can only be entered from one to 1^ hours before or after high water, according to the height of the tide. Communications, &C. — Granville is in direct railway com munication with Paris, the distance occupying about 8 hours ; the steamers of the London and South-Western Railway Company also ply regularly between it and Jersey, thus connecting it with England. It has a considerable trade, but one of its principal industries, the oyster fishery, has entirely failed of late years. The rocky bed forming the base of the western. part of Le Roc uncovers 3| cables in a southerly direction from pointe du Roc, and 2 cables North and N.W. from the north-western part of the peninsula, which latter part is marked by a beacon surmounted by a globe, the upper part of the beacon white, the lower part black. Loup rock. — Beacon turret. — This rock, the nearest danger to the harbour, is marked by a beacon turret painted with red and white bands ; it lies S. by W. | W. 2f cables from the extreme of the western pier, and uncovers 21 feet ; it forms a natural breakwater during south-westerly gales. The west pier-head lighthouse on with the gap which separates Le Roc from the hills north-eastward of it, leads a cable westward of the Loup ; and, the same lighthouse on with Granville church steeple leads half a cable eastward. The rock covers at half flood, at which time there are 10 feet between the pier-heads, and 16^ feet over the Tombelaine bank. LIGHTS. — Granville lighthouse, a circular tower 43 feet high, stands on pointe du Roc or cape Lihou, and exhibits, at 154 feet above high water, a flashing white light of the third order, visible 15 miles. It shows groups of four flashes reproduced every fifteen seconds. From it, Chausey lighthouse bears N.W. by W. J W. 8^ miles ; Pierre de Herpin light W.S.W. 10 miles ; and Senequet rock light N. | E. 15£ miles. Fog signal. — During thick or foggy weather, at pointe du Roc, a trumpet worked by hand gives a blast of five seconds duAtion every minute; see fog signals, page 12. See chart, No. 2,669 b.

DIRECTIONS.* — Entering Granville. — Bring the West pier-head lighthouse open of the fall of the land under the eastern end of Garrison bluff, to pass between the tail of the Loup and the rocks on which the pier is built ; or, if wishing to pass eastward of the Loup rock, open Granville church its own breadth eastward of See chart, No. 2,669 b. * Directions for navigating the Cotentin passage between cape de la Hague and Granville will be found at pages 214-220.

Give the pier-head, when rounding it, a berth of a ship's length only, shoot as far to the westward as possible when within it, and drop the anchor when convenient. A vessel drawing 10 feet must not attempt to round the pier-head until 4 hours flood, especially if there be any sea. All possible sail should be carried when entering the harbour, and, in the event of a sudden shift of wind, a vessel should be prepared either to anchor or to run out a hawser to the v>arping buoy between the Loup rock and the plateau Jean-la-Blanche. When it blows hard between N.W. and S.W., the great inequalities of the rocky ridge extending southward from Granville lighthouse occasion a heavy sea outside the mouth of the harbour, and the outer part of this ridge, which uncovers 9 feet at the lowest tides, is then very dangerous ; there is also a heavy breaking sea in the passage between the pier and the Loup with strong winds between N.W. and West. This dangerous part is avoided by keeping St. Nicholas church steeple on with the southern slope of Gautier point. Should the wind be light, endeavour to maintain a position off the harbour, so as to be carried towards the entrance from 1-Js hours before to half an hour after high water, while the stream is running East and E.N.E. ; but do not attempt to enter before high water, or the vessel may be carried westward of the pier, and even on pointe du Roc, by the eddy on the flood, which leaves the harbour after traversing the quays from East to West, and runs along the shore towards pointe du Roc. The strength of this eddy is from one to H knots at springs, it runs from half flood to high water, and it is in order to stem it that plenty of sail should be carried when entering the harbour. When arriving off the harbour before there is sufficient water to enter ; if the wind is strong enough to stem the tide, keep southward of the line of St. Nicholas church steeple on with the southern slope of Gautier point. With the wind from N.E. round by North to W.N.W. keep northward of this line and make short tacks southward of the Chausey islets, between Chausey lighthouse and the Conchee ; and, with the wind from W.N.W. round by West to South, short boards should be made between Grouin point and the Basse Pari sienne, not standing southward of an imaginary line drawn from Pierre de Herpin lighthouse to Champeaux point. As soon as there is water sufficient to enter the harbour, steer for it, keeping the West See chart. No. 2.669 u. M SO 11886

In working towards the harbour from the S.W., make a long board to the northward of the line of St. Nicholas church steeple on with the southern slope of Gautier point, but avoid being carried too far northward by the flood stream. The last board should be made south-eastward of the Loup, taking care to avoid the Norocher, a ridge of rocks of which parts uncover from 10 to 12 feet. From thence, stand for the harbour eastward of the Loup, on which side that rock may be approached to within half a cable without danger. At low water, neaps, small coasters arriving off the harbour with the wind off-shore may anchor to await tide between the Loup rock and Tombelaine bank, where they will then find 10 or 12 feet water over a bottom of sand and broken shells ; at low water, springs, there are only 2 or 3 feet water here. There are also a few rocks in the eastern part of the anchorage, but with Mont St. Michel open of Champeaux point, a vessel is 2 cables westward of them. Leaving Granville, a sailing vessel of deep draught should wait for a leading wind, and, if bound westward, advantage should be taken of off-shore winds, particularly those between East and South. If the wind is between E.S.E. and S.S.E. and strong enough to stem the tide, leave as soon as the vessel floats and steer to pass 2 or 3 miles northward of Cezembre island and of cape Frehel. If between South and W.S.W., haul out to the warping buoys as soon as she is afloat and make sail from the outer buoy. Short boards must be made as far as Thar point, 2--V miles southward of the harbour, and from thence they may be lengthened, coasting at a safe distance from the in-shore dangers as far as cape Frehel, to avoid being carried by the tides towards the Minquiers and other off-lying dangers. In fine weather, the Minquiers light-buoys, together with the lights of Chausey, Granville, Pierre de Herpin, St. Malo, and cape Frehel, render this navigation as easy by night as by day. THE COAST. — From pointe du Roc, Granville, cape de Carteret, which is the western extreme of the first high land on the coast northward of Granville, bears N. j- E. 33 miles, the ->vhole of the coast line between the two points being low and receding slightly eastward. The off-lying reefs and shoals between the coast and the Channel islands are also very numerous, causing the navigation between Granville and Cape de la Hague by this route, known as the Cotentin channel, to be both intricate and dangerous, the latter especially if surprised by foggy weather, though it is well lighted and buoyed. Coutances cathedral, about 6 miles inland and 14 miles N.E. from pointe du Roc, may be known by its two spires or turrets ; it is lofty and a useful land-mark. The church steeple of Agon, one mile inland, is a large square tower covered with tiles, and the little church steeple of Pirou 8 miles further northward very much resembles it. From Coutances towards Granville, the interior of the country presents a moderately high but regular outline which ter minates at Champeaux point, the bluff and nearly perpendicular headland 5f miles southward of Granville. From Coutances north ward the character of the country alters, the interior being high though somewhat irregular, and between St. Germain and Barneville, 2 miles eastward of cape de Carteret, the inequalities become very marked and conspicuous. The entrance to Regneville is 10 miles N.N.E. \ E. from Granville lighthouse. The coast between it and St. Germain trends N. by E. for 13 miles, and the shore is low, sandy, and bordered with downs. Among the most remarkable objects is Mont Huchon, about 2 miles northward of Coutances cathedral and 6 miles inland eastward of the entrance to Regneville harbour, and of the western part of the line of hills immediately northward of the harbour, on which stand the village and church of Agon. This part of the hills ends abruptly with steep slopes towards the sea, and, when seen from the north westward at a distance, presents the appearance of a high cape facing westward. CATHEUE BANKS, including Catheue reef and Shamrock knoll, extend North and South 6 miles and lie nearly parallel with the line of coast ; they are chiefly composed of sand. Two patches near their middle dry at very low tides, at which time there are 6 feet at their southern end and 2 fathoms at their northern end. These banks are almost connected with the shore on their eastern side and, southward, with the shoal extending from pointe du Roc, from which point, their northern extreme is distant 11 miles ; they are only separated from the Ronquet reef off Regneville by a bed of sand which has from 2 to 12 feet over it at low water, at which time there is no /navigable passage between the banks and the shore. Catheue reef. — Bell-buoy.— This dangerous ledge is about a mile long W.S.W. and E.N.E. and 2\ cables wide, lying between the northern end of the Catheue banks proper and the Shamrock knoll. It has several rocky heads, of which two uncover at the lowest tides, when the rest have from 3 to 6 feet over them. The highest head uncovers 2\ feet near the middle of the reef, and is marked by a red bell-buoy moored 100 yards south-eastward of it. This head lies W.S.W. 2| miles from the westernmost head of the Ronquet reef ; N. f W. 8^ miles from Granville lighthouse ; and, N.E. by E. 7^ miles from Chausey lighthouse. The marks for it are, Mont St. Michel thrice its width open westward of Champeaux point ; Chausey lighthouse on with the southern side of the Etat rock ; and, Coutances cathedral in line with Agon point E. | N. Champeaux point just open of pointe du Roc, South a little easterly, leads eastward of Catheue banks and reef ; and, Agon church steeple on with the southern slope of Mont Huchon, East, leads a safe distance northward of that reef and of the Shamrock knoll. REGNEVILLE is at the mouth of the little river Sienne, into which the river Soulles flows 4 miles in the interior ; the harbour is so choked with sand as to be practically dry at high water, neaps, and to admit coasters only of about 8 or 9 feet draght at high water, springs. The bottom being chiefly sand and shells, is bad holding ground ; the anchors should therefore be buried to avoid driving with strong winds between W.N.W. and S.W., to which the entrance is exposed. The entrance is between the Bee d'Agon, or Agon point, and the point on which the guard-house stands, which, on with Mont Martin windmill, is the mark for the south-western extreme of the Ronquet group ; several sand-banks lie in the fairway, and the action of the tides causes Agon point to grow constantly southward, the lighthouse originally built near the extreme being now more than 3 cables from it. Two channels, marked by beacons and buoys, lead to the entrance, but both are very subject to change and neither should be attempted without a local pilot. The deepest channel borders the southern side of the Ronquet group and the Moulieres d'Agon ; the leading mark for it is, the fort 3 cables north-westward of the extreme of Agon point seen between the steeples of Coutances and Grimouville about E. by N. The other channel, named the Coliere, is not quite so deep but has the advantage of leading directly into the harbour and avoiding the turn south-eastward in rounding Agon point. The Caillou rock, which uncovers 17 feet, lies on the eastern side of this channel ; the leading mark is, Grimouville church steeple a little open eastward of the Custom-house, the last large house on the shore at the northern part of Regneville village.
