OUEN BAY. 231 La Moye white semaphore house just open westward of Rocco tower S. -L E. leads westward ; Tour de Rozel just shut in with Belle Hougue point S.E. \ E. easterly leads southward ; and, the Corbiere rock lighthouse just in sight outside the Pinnacle S. by W. J W. leads eastward of the Bane Desormes. GROSNEZ POINT is the high precipitous bluff at the north western extreme of (he island ; from it, St. Martin's point, Guern sey, the nearest point of that island, bears N.N.W. § W. 14| miles. On the summit of the point are the ruins of an old fort. From Grosnez point, the land trends eastwards towards Plemont point and the northern side of Jersey, and southward towards St. Ouen bay ; in this direction, the coast continues high and rugged nearly as far as l'Etac point, southward of which the high land recedes from the shore. ST. OUEN BAY is the indentation on the western coast of Jersey between l'Etac point and the Corbiere. As already described, its shores are low and sandy, but quickly rising to the level of the plateau of the interior. Southward of St. Peter's barracks, stand ing conspicuously on the high land, is the Quenvais, an extensive district covered with sand and forming a remarkable feature on this coast. Anchorage. — St. Ouen bay affords good shelter in easterly winds, but no vessel should anchor in it with the wind from the westward. The greater part of the bay being rocky and foul, the anchorage is limited to a space about half a mile square near the southern part, between the Great bank and Rocco tower ; here a vessel is well sheltered from the tide, and may lie in about 7 fathoms, sandy bottom, with St. Ouen mill a little open northward of the square fort on the beach, between Nos. 2 and 3 towers, bearing E.N.E. The anchorage is easy of access and may be safely entered by large vessels without pilots. An extensive reef, dry at low water, stretches off 7 cables west ward of the Rocco tower, and from thence extends alongshore southward in the direction of the Corbiere rock, which it unites with Corbiere point ; the whole of this reef is covered before high water except a small rocky mass near the middle, of which the Flat and Sharp rocks are the highest heads. Between the Rocco tower and l'Etac, there is a fine beach of white sand, but, at low water, it is See chart, No. 62 c. I' S 0 11886

232 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. fringed with rocks throughout, and off l'Etac point it dries out 1\ cables ; the greater part covers before half flood and no part is visible at high water. Rigdon bank, of which the outer edge is nearly 2 miles west ward of l'Etac point, consists of rocky ridges, the interstices being filled up with sand and gravel ; it is about a mile long, E.N.E. and W.S.W., and 2 cables wide. The general depth is from 3 to 5 fathoms but two rocks have only 11 feet over them ; of these, one is near the middle, the other at the north-eastern extreme. The bank is very steep-to on the outside, and between it and the Etac reef is the Swashway channel, about 3 cables wide, with a general depth of 6 fathoms ; this channel is frequently used by vessels of from 200 to 300 tons. Plemont and Grosnez points in line E. \ S. lead northward of Rigdon bank. La Moye white Semaphore house midway between Flat and Sharp rocks S.S.E., or St. Peter's spire open southward of No. 2 martello tower S.E. by E., leads south-westward ; and, St. Peter's spire open eastward of No. 1 martello tower S.E. leads north-eastward of it. The best leading mark through the Swashway between Rigdon bank and the Etac reef is, the highest heads of the Pierres de Lecq or Paternoster rocks about half a point open of Grosnez bluff N.E. by E. \ E. West rock, sometimes called Grey bank, is 1^ miles westward of Rigdon bank ; it is a mass of rock, very steep on the outside, 1^ cables long N.E and S.W., and more than a cable wide, on which are from 7 to 10 fathoms except near the middle where there are only 6 fathoms. From this spot, St. Peter's spire a little open northward of the small square fort on the beach bears S.E. by E. \ E. easterly ; and, the highest, or Great rock, of the Pierres de Lecq is open 8° of Grosnez bluff, which bluff and the Corbiere rock subtend an angle of 72°. The shoal part is well marked near low water by a strong ripple. The channel between West rock and Rigdon bank is more than a mile wide, quite clear, and has from 12 to 17 fathoms water. Great bank extends N.N.W. \ W. \\ miles from the Corbiere rock, and is 3 cables wide. It consists entirely of sand and has from See chart, No. 62 c.

The Jument, a whitewashed rock 31j cables eastward of the Corbiere, touching the inner side of the Corbiere S.E. \ S. leads westward ; and, the Jument on with the high-water rock midway between Corbiere rock and point, S.S.E. \ E. leads eastward. St. Ouen mill a little open northward of the square fort E.N.E. leads over the bank, midway between the two shoal ridges, in 9 fathoms water. Corbiere point, at the south-western end of Jersey, is a low bluff with a flagstaff on the summit and two small houses at its side. Just within the point the land rises at a steep slope and unites with the high table land of La Moye. CORBIERE ROCK, 2 cables westward of the point and connected with it by a reef which dries after the last quarter ebb, is 70 feet above hisrh water and very remarkable. It stands prominently out from the coast-line and is the principal landmark for vessels approaching from the westward. On it is a lighthouse, and a signal station which is in telegraphic communication with St. Helier ; it may be seen in clear weather 10 or 12 miles distant. From it, the N.W. light-buoy of the Minquiers shoals bears about S.S.W. \ W. llf miles ; and, Hanois lighthouse N.N.W. | W. 23^ miles. LIGHT. — From a circular stone lighthouse 62 feet high, on the Corbiere rock, is exhibited, at 119 feet above high water, a fixed white light visible 17 miles round seaward between S. 15° E. and N. 15° W. Between S. 15° E. and the land, the light shows red; also between N. 15° W. and N. 48° W. over the Vracheres and the adjacent dangers ; but between N. 48° W. and the shore, it shows ivhite. Fog signal. — During fogs a bell is sounded three times in quick succession at intervals of ten seconds. An explosive signal making- See chart, No. 62 c. P 2 S O 11886

Caution. — Mariners must be very careful when navigating within the limits of either sector of red light. The principal dangers off and near the Corbiere are the Green rock, the Boiteaux, Boue, Frouquie, and Noirmontaise rocks. Green rock, the outer danger, has 11 feet water ; it bears N.W by W. \ W. 6f cables from Corbiere lighthouse and 2 cables from the Boiteaux rocks on the same line of bearing. The marks for it are, St. Ouen mill just eastward of No. 3 martello tower N.E. by E. ; and, the Jument rock on with La Moye Point S.E. by E. Another rock, with only 8 feet water, lies E.N.E one cable from the Green rock. The Boiteaux are two rocks only 60 yards apart between the Green rock and the Corbiere ; they uncover 9 feet distant 4f cables from the Corbiere. From the southern Boiteaux, St. Ouen church is open southward of the Magazine on the beach of St. Ouen bay N.E. by E. ; and, La Moye white Semaphore house is on with the northern side of the peak of the Corbiere rock S.E. by E. | E. The Boue rock bears N.W. 3| cables from Corbiere lighthouse and uncovers 20 feet, or rather before half ebb ; it is at the inner part of the sunken reef in-shore of the Boiteaux. The Frouquie is at the outer edge of the reef extending from Rocco tower and fort to the Corbiere, from which latter it bears N. -5 W. 5 cables ; and, from the Boue rock N.E. 3 cables. The Frouquie covers 6 feet at high water, springs. Noirmontaise reef lies 2\ cables westward of the Corbiere, and dries 4 feet at low water. Another reef, one cable westward of the Corbiere, has 4 feet only over its shoalest part ; and, a large rock S. by E. one cable from the Corbiere uncovers after the first quarter ebb. Clearing marks.— St. Ouen windmill open northward of No. 3 martello tower leads outside and northward of the Green rock and of all other rocks north-westward of the Corbiere ; and, La Moye white Semaphore house on with the Jument rock leads 3 cables southward of the Green rock and half a cable southward of the Noirmontaise reef. See chart, No. 62 c.

Chap. VI.] DANGERS. — FROUQUIE PASS.— LA MOYE POINT. 235 The Frouquie pass is between the Frouquie and Boue rocks. The clearing marks for the outer and inner parts of the Great bank, see page 233, are the best leading marks by which to enter this pass from the northward ; for, should both the Boue and Frouquie rocks be covered, a vessel cannot go too near the former so long as the Jument is in sight inside the Corbiere, nor can the Frouquie be touched without opening the Jument eastward of the high rock between Corbiere point and rock. There is a small rock 1^ cables westward of the Frouquie with only one foot water ; from it, the Jument rock and a beacon pole on the western side of the high rock between Corbiere point and rock are in line. With this exception, there is a clear 2i-fathoms passage more than a cable wide ; no vessel should, however, attempt to run through until half tide, that is to say, until the Boue rock is nearly awash ; it is then quite safe for vessels under 15 feet draught. At or above half tide, therefore, enter the pass midway between the Frouquie and Boue rocks, with the Jument midway between the Corbiere rock and the large rock off Corbiere point ; and, when St. Ouen church tower is on with the high rocky mass south-westward of Rocco tower N.E. \ E. easterly, steer for the Corbiere rock until within one cable of it, when it must be rounded at a distance of 150 yards only ; and, run out to southward w-hen the Pinnacle rock is nearly on with the outer part of the Corbiere. There is a narrow deep-water channel between the Frouquie and the one-foot vjatch, also between the Green rock and the Boiteaux and between the Noirmontaise and Boue rocks, close to the Corbiere and leading to the Frouquie pass, but the space between the Boiteaux and Boue rocks, and from the latter to within one cable of the Corbiere, is so thickly studded with sunken rocks as to be very dangerous even for boats, at low water, and should be avoided. Jument rock, very useful as a sea-mark, has a large white patch painted on it ; from it, Corbiere lighthouse bears N.W. \ W. 3^ cables ; and, it is one cable from the high bluff next eastward of Corbiere point, with which bluff it is connected by a reef dry at low water. About 100 yards outside the Jument is a dangerous rock which dries only at the last quarter ebb ; it should not be approached therefore nearer than 3 cables. LA MOYE POINT is a high cliffy bluff one mile eastward of See chart, No. 62 c.

The quarries at La Moye, showing at a distance as a white mark in the bluff, are also useful in clearing the Minquiers reefs. La Moye point is safe of approach from the westward, but I-} cables off it is a rock with only 6 feet water ; close eastward of this rock and probably connected with it are the Kaines, a dangerous rocky group of which the highest covers only at the last quarter flood. The outer sunken rock of the Kaines lies 2-} cables from the shore. Corbiere lighthouse kept open southward of the Jument until Tabor chapel, St. Brelade bay, opens out eastward of Grosse Tete, leads clear of all these clangers. ST. BRELADE BAY, near the south-western end of Jersey, between La Moye and Le Fret points, is much contracted by the extensive reef fringing its eastern shore, and the anchorage is further cut up by the Fournier and Fourche rocks. There is always less sea on the western than on the eastern side of the bay, but it is very inferior to St. Aubin bay as an anchorage and more exposed to southerly gales ; nevertheless, small vessels, and even large open boats, anchored within it off port Bouilly, have been known to ride out fresh gales from this the most exposed quarter, the holding ground being remarkably good. Approaching St. Brelade bay from the westward, the most remark able objects seen are, Grosse Tete, the high square rock under the rugged land of La Moye on the western side of the bay ; and, Noirmont tower standing prominently out at the end of the low point, of that name to the eastward. On opening out the eastern side of the bay clear of Grosse Tete, the white sandy beach appears, and two martello towers, one on each side of Grouin point at the head of the bay ; beyond are villa residences and scattered groups of houses ; whilst, above all, on the high land near the middle of the bay, stands Tabor chapel, a plain white building with "slate roof forming the principal landmark in it. Near the middle of the bay are the Fournier and Fourche rocks, about 2^ cables W.N.W. and E.S.E. from each other. The best anchorage is about a cable north-eastward of the Fournier ; the ground is quite clean up to the base of this rock, which is of very See charts, Nos. 62 b and e.

Chap. VI.] ST. BRELADE BAY. — DIRECTIONS. 237 small extent. The Fournier dries 9 feet and the Fourche 10 feet at low water, springs. The other but less important rocks of the bay are, the Fournier du Havre, which dries 17 feet 2§ cables north-eastward of the Fournier ; the Plat Houmet, which dries 12 feet in the bight nearer the shore ; and, the Rousse rock, about 25 feet above high water level, with the Rousse-Frouquie just northward of it, on the eastern side and outer part of the bay. St. Brelade bank is an uneven bed of rocks, commencing 5 cables South of La Moye point and extending eastward about 4£ cables ; the least water, 29 feet, is near the eastern end of the bank. Le Fret bank, 3 cables off Le Fret point, is 1| cables in extent North and South, with from 25 to 29 feet water. Within 2^ cables north-westward of the bank are several rocks, having a least depth of 14 feet on them, and at 2 cables south-eastward of the bank is a patch with only 20 feet ; the marks for the 14-feet patch are, Noirmont tower E. | S. ; and, the western martello tower in St. Brelade bay on with Rousse-Frouquie N.N.E. Corbiere lighthouse on with La Moye point leads in-shore of Le Fret bank and of all these rocky patches ; and, Corbiere lighthouse a little southward of the Jument leads southward of them but over St. Brelade bank. Directions. — A vessel from the north-westward bound to St. Brelade or St. Aubin bay, on nearing the shore of Jersey, should keep Plemont point open of Grosnez point until Corbiere lighthouse bears eastward of S. by E. E. in order to clear the Rigdon shoal. When St. Peter's spire opens southward of No. 2 martello tower she will be southward of the shoal, and from thence should steer to round the Corbiere about a mile distant, avoiding the Green rock and other off- lying reefs by keeping St. Ouen windmill open northward of No. 3 martello tower in St. Ouen bay until La Moye white Semaphore house is on with Corbiere lighthouse.* When the white house opens south ward of the Jument rock E. by S. \ S., or when the outer part of the high table land within Noirmont point is open of Le Fret point, a vessel is clear of the Noirmontaise reef and of all dangers south-west- See charts, Nos. 62 b and c. To preserve a safe distance from all dangers in rounding the Corbiere, Jersey pilots keep the top of the high land of Jersey, eastward of the lighthouse, always showing above the top of the lighthouse.

The danger is increased by Portelet ledge, an isolated mass of rock S.W. by S. 2^ cables from Janvrin tower ; from the shoalest spot of 2 feet on this ledge, La Moye white Semaphore house over a remarkable sharp-peaked rock semi-detached from Le Fret point bears N.W. W. ; and, Noirmont tower appears northward of the high part of Pierre au Poisson, which lies midway between that tower and the ledge. In case of necessity, a vessel may anchor outside and eastward of Portelet ledge in 6 fathoms, with Corbiere lighthouse nearly on with La Moye point ; Janvrin tower N. by E. I E. ; and, Elizabeth castle, St. Helier, just open southward of Noirmont tower. ST. AUBIN BAY.— The whole of the anchorage in this fine bay, though surrounded by rocks, is free from foul ground and sheltered from all winds but those from S.S.E. round by South to See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

Chap. VI.] PORTELET BAY. — ST. AUBIN BAY, HARBOUR. 239 W.N.W., and partially so even from them. South-westerly gales send in a heavy rolling sea between half flood and high water, but as the water falls the sea subsides, the rocks in the offing greatly contributing to break its force. The town and harbour of St. Helier occupy the north-eastern side of the bay, and the little town of St. Aubin, with its castle on a rock nearly 3 cables from the shore, is on the western side, opposite St. Helier ; their distance apart being about 2\ miles. Both towns have stone pier harbours, St. Helier by far the larger and more important, where vessels lie aground at low water on soft muddy sand ; the tide, at low water, springs, receding 5 cables from St. Aubin harbour, and 100 yards outside the entrance of St. Helier new harbour. A strong mole or breakwater projects from the northern side of St. Aubin castle, sheltering a pier within, where vessels frequently refit and unload, grounding, however, at low water. Elizabeth castle is built on a craggy rock on the eastern side of the bay fronting the harbours of St. Helier, and about three quarters of a mile south-westward of the town ; moles or breakwaters extend both north-eastward and southward from it ; the top of its high central tower or keep is 105 feet above high water level. On the site of this castle formerly stood an Augustine monastery built in honour of St. Helier, a recluse, whose hermitage, on the summit of a high rock, 1^ cables southward of the castle, still exists. Elizabeth and St. Aubin castles are insulated every tide, but with their moles afford shelter respectively to the two harbours, by breaking the swell which rolls into St. Aubin bay during south westerly gales. ST. AUBIN HARBOUR.— Several rocks lie scattered south ward and westward of St. Aubin castle, most of which uncover at low water. The two largest and most conspicuous are the Grosse and the Platte, very close together and 1| cables from the castle ; the Grosse is the highest and shows about the first quarter ebb ; both rocks are marked by beacon poles. Another group of rocks lies 2 cables southward of the Grosse, the north-eastern head drying 7 feet at low water. Haule house open eastward of St. Aubin castle breakwater leads eastward of these rocks ; and, eastward of this line, the bottom is all fine sand. Depths. — At half flood, there are 8 feet water inside St. Aubin See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

240 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. castle pier, at which time the water begins to enter the harbour ; in the entrance the depth is about 17 feet at high water, springs, and 8^ feet at neaps. The passage westward of St. Aubin castle is not passable even for boats until half flood. The population of the little town of St. Aubin is about 1,000. There is direct communication between it and St. Helier by railway. The chief import is coal and the only export red gravel. No stock of coal is kept on hand for shipping, the port of St. Helier being so near at hand. From 40 to 50 small vessels of an aggregate tonnage of 3,700 tons enter the port annually. Water of first rate quality may be procured from pumps on the quay of St. Aubin harbour. ST. HELIER, the chief town of Jersey, is built on low land open southward but overlooked and sheltered northward by a high semicircular plateau completely commanding it. The town is well built, and, as previously stated, contains about 28,000 in habitants. It has a college and several churches, whose spires, together with Fort Regent on the eastern side of the town, are the most prominent objects from the sea. A large general hospital is available for seamen in case of accident or illness. The English quarantine laws are in force, and vessels from the Mediterranean, Brazils, or from infected ports hoist the quarantine flag and are not permitted to enter the port until pratique has been granted by the Customs authorities. Communication. — Steamers run daily between Jersey, South ampton, and Weymouth all the year round, and frequently to London, Plymouth, Bristol, and other English ports ; and, during the summer, daily to Granville, St. Malo, St. Brieuc, port Bail, and de Carteret, in France ; and bi-weekly to Granville, St. Malo, and Brieuc, during the remainder of the year, the principal part of the Jersey trade being carried on by steamers. Upwards of 2,400 vessels entered the port of St. Helier in the year 1894, their tonnage being about 320,000 tons. St. Helier has a well-supplied market, where fresh meat and poultry may be purchased at about the same prices as in London. Fish is scarce, vegetables and fruit abundant and cheap. The principal imports are dead meat and bullocks for slaughter, coal, wheat, flour, timber, cement, artificial manures, &c. The exports are Jersey cows, granite, red gravel, fruit, new potatoes, &c. The agricultural exports alone realized close upon 5O0,00OZ. in 1891. See chart, No. 62 b.

Chap. VI.] ST. HELIER. — DEPTHS. 241 St. Helier harbours * are on the north-eastern side of St. Aubin bay. The Inner harbour is completely enclosed by the Outer harbour constructed between the years 1840-50 at a cost of 170,000?., from designs by Mr. J. Walker, C.E. Both are alike in form, the Outer harbour being in fact a repetition of the Inner on an extended scale ; they are nearly rectangular, narrow in proportion to their length, with the entrances near their south western corners. Depths, &C— The Inner harbour is about 1,900 feet long by 300 feet wide ; it dries 11 feet at the entrance and 25 feet at its northern end, and has 8 feet water at its entrance at half tide. The Outer harbour, enclosed by the Victoria and Albert piers, is 2,600 feet long by 500 feet wide ; at present, it dries 3 feet between the pier-heads and 17 feet at its northern end ; it has 16 feet in its entrance at half tide, 31^ feet at high water, springs, and about 23 feet at neaps ; the ground rises gradually within the pier-heads for a distance of about 300 feet where there are 3 feet less water ; the bottom is fine sand and mud throughout. New Works. — The new North Quay is completed, giving about 1,400 feet additional quay frontage, with deeper water alongside than at the other quays. A landing stage has been erected within the Victoria pier-head, and the Albert pier-head is in course of reconstruction, its foundations being carried down to the rock. When this is completed, dredging to the depth of 5 "feet below the low water level is intended in order to give access to mail and passenger steamers at all times of tide. The dredging opera tions will include a channel from the Little road to the new North Quay and part of the Outer harbour. Dredging and other works were commenced as early as October, 1895 ; and a notice issued by the harbour authorities cautioning all masters and pilots to keep clear of dredgers, scaffolding, &c. Coal can always be obtained, though the stock on hand is usually not large, from 300 to 400 tons ; it is placed on board vessels along side the quays where the available depth at high water, neaps, is about 18 feet ; but, it must be borne in mind that, although from the great rise of tide the harbour is accessible at springs to vessels See chart, No. 62 *. * The works commenced in 1872 to enclose the two present harbours, and suspended in 1878, were resumed in 1887 so far as the Hermitage breakwater is concerned, but again discontinued in 1890. The head of the breakwater now reaches within about 40U feet of Sir John Coode's original plan. — Harbour Master St. HoUer, 18i>5.

Water mains are laid along the piers, and vessels are supplied, at one shilling per ton. Storm signals. — St. Helier is a storm signal station A Life-Boat is stationed at St. Helier. LIGHTS. — The following fixed lights are exhibited for the guidance of vessels bound to St. Helier : — A ivhite light, from a gas lamp close to the edge of the quay on the Victoria pier. A small white light from the end of the Hermitage breakwater. Chap. VI.] 243 ST. HELIER. — LIGHTS. — DANGERS OFF. lead on the same line as the day leading mark, which leads over the Passage rock, see page 252 ; the lights therefore must not be brought in line until eastward of St. Brelade bay. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at St. Helier, at 6h. 29m. ; equinoctial springs rise in the entrance, which is 3 feet above the zero of soundings, 39 feet, ordinary springs 31^ feet, neaps 23 feet. The flood stream runs 3 knots and the ebb 2 knots in the entrance of the harbour. For a full description of the tidal streams off St. Helier harbour and in St. Aubin bay, see pages 298-301.* The Dog's Nest rock. — Beacon. — This important mark either for entering St. Aubin bay or St. Helier from the westward, is near the outer extreme of the rocky ridge extending from point de Pas, which forms the eastern boundary of St. Helier Little road. It is nearly awash at high water, and its apex is marked by three white spots and is surmounted by a beacon consisting of an iron pole and ball. The principal rocks fronting the harbour and around the Little road of St. Helier, besides the Dog's Nest rock, are, the Cloches rocks, the Oyster rocks, Grune Moulet, the Platte, and the Sharp rock. Cloches rocks. — Buoy. — The Cloches are two sunken rocks immediately off the entrance to the Little road. The western Cloche has 8 feet water and is marked, close to, on its north-western side, by a black buoy with a white top, as a guide for vessels passing between it and the Oyster rock. The western Cloche is on the western side of the southern fairway, with Nicolle tower a little open southward of the Dog's Nest beacon E. J S. ; and, the Oyster rock beacon on with the north-eastern extreme of Elizabeth castle N. by E. | E. Another rock with 8 feet water lies N.N.W. 1\ cables, and a third, the southern rock of the Oyster rock patch, with 7 feet, N.N.E. | E. 1^ cables from the western Cloche ; from this last rock, Elizabeth castle flagstaff is on with the Oyster rock beacon, the rock being distant from the latter exactly one cable, and connected with it by a chain of sunken rocks ; there are, however, 3 fathoms with clean ground close southward of it. See chart, No. 62 *. * In the island of Jersey and its vicinity, a rough way of ascertaining the height of the tide for any day, from the Admiralty tide tables, is as follows : — Double the height given for Brest, and from it subtract 2 feet. It should be borne in mind that the height thus found may vary considerably, north-easterly winds decreasing the height by 2 or 3 feet and westerly winds raising it by as much.

244 [Chap. VI CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. The eastern Cloche rock is on the eastern side of the fairway and has only 2 feet water ; from it, the western Cloche bears W. by N. § N. l}f cables. There are 4 fathoms between it and the rocks extending from the direction of the Dog's Nest to within 120 yards of this rock. Oyster rocks and Grune Moulet.— Beacons. — These rocks occupy positions on either side of the entrance to the Little road. They bear S.E. by E. } E. and N.W. by W. { W. 2±- cables from each other, and are each marked by a beacon consisting of a pole sur mounted by a ball. The Oyster rock uncovers 13 feet and lies S.W. \ W. 1-| cables from the Hermitage breakwater end. The Oyster rock beacon is marked in 23 divisions of a foot each. When the rocks are awash, there are 10 feet water between the Victoria and Albert piers ; and, after the rocks are covered, the depth of water in feet between the piers may always be known by deduct ing thp number of divisions seen above water from 33. The Grune Moulet dries 11 feet ; its beacon is marked in 10 divisions of 2 feet each. Platte rock is within the entrance to the Little road E. by N. northerly exactly one cable from the Oyster rock beacon. It dries one foot, and is less than a cable from the present head of the Hermitage breakwater which is intended to be eventually extended to this rock. There is a small pole beacon on the Platte rock which, however, is covered and not visible at high water, springs. There is no safe channel between the Oyster and Platte rocks. Sharp rock dries 3 feet S.E. by E. § E. \\ cables from the Platte. The channel into the Little road lies between the Platte and Sharp rocks, and has 22 feet water at the lowest tides. In passing between these rocks, which is the narrowest part of the channel, the Platte may be cleared on its eastern side by keeping the spire of St. Mark's church open eastward of the northern white patch on the Albert pier ; and, Sharp rock may be cleared on its western side by keeping the eastern end of Almorah terrace open westward of the Albert pier. Anchorage.— Little road lies eastward of the Hermitage breakwater and is used chiefly by vessels waiting tide to enter the harbour, or during neaps in fine weather with off-shore winds. In entering, the Oyster and Platte rocks are left on the port hand, and the Grune Moulet and Sharp rocks on the starboard hand ; the depth See chart, No. 62 b.

Chap. VI.] ANCHORAGE. — DANGERS OFF ST. AUBIN BAY. 245 is from 17 to 6 feet at low water, springs, but the anchorage is so contracted by rocks that vessels over 8 feet draught, if remaining beyond a tide, should moor. At low water, the Little road is com pletely sheltered eastward by the new pier building and by the rocky barrier, entirely dry, extending from point de Pas to the Dog's Nest rock, and westward by the Hermitage breakwater and the rocks extending to, and one cable beyond, the Oyster rock beacon. The best anchorage is north-westward of the Grande Mangeuse rock, in 10 feet water, with Fort Regent signal-post over the middle of the harbour entrance ; and, the south-western side of Close rock N.W. by W. W. ; or, nearer the Hermitage breakwater in 16 feet, with Fort Regent signal-post a little open south-eastward of Victoria pier lighthouse. The available anchorage space is only 1-1- cables wide and 2 cables long, N.E. and S.W., and is surrounded by dangerous rocks ; see also directions, page 256. DANGERS Off St. AUBIN BAY.— The principal dangers to be avoided in approaching St. Aubin bay, in addition to the St. Brelade and Le Fret banks, described at page 237, are : on the western side, the Vracheres, the Hubaut with its surrounding rocks, the Grunes, the Grunes Vaudin, the Sillette rocks, the Fours, the Grimes aux Dardes, and Danger rock ; the Rouaudiere near the middle ; and, on the eastern side, the Grunes St. Michel, the Hin guette, Tetards, and Demie de Pas ; the Diamond rock near the centre of the bay, in line between the Noirmont tower and the outer Hermitage rocks ; the Pignonet, Grunes du Port, and Junees along the western shore ; the Baleine and other sunken rocks near the eastern shore off Elizabeth castle ; and, the Cloches, already described, off the entrance to St. Helier Little road. Some of the passages between these rocks are extremely narrow, and all are dangerous both from the rapidity of the tides and from the generally discoloured state of the sea preventing the rocks being seen, even when close to them. A stranger should not attempt to navigate these channels without a competent pilot. The Vracheres, a rocky bank of small extent, is the outer or south-western danger off St. Aubin bay. The Frouquie, its highest head with only 5 feet water, is at the south-eastern extreme of the bank, with Prince's tower touching the western corner of Fort Regent E. by N. \ N. ; and, the western martello tower in St. Brelade bay on with the western head of Rousse-Frouquie N.N.E. See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

[Chap. VI. 246 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. The Vraicquieres, Hubaut, Grande and Petite Grune, and Passage rocks, all lie between the Vracheres and point Le Fret ; the narrow channels separating these rocky banks should never be attempted. The Vraicquieres, North i\ cables from the shoalest head of the Vracheres, has 17 feet, least water. From the Hubaut, which dries 2 feet, the western martello tower of St. Brelade bay on with the western side of the Rousse rock bears N. by E. | E. ; and, the eastern end of Almorah terrace touching the inside part of Noirmont tower E. by N. § N. From the Grande Grune, which dries 6 feet, Prince's tower is on with Elizabeth castle hospital, a small red-tiled building between the highest part of the castle and its north-eastern angle ; and, the western martello tower in St. Brelade bay is a little open of the high-water extreme of Le Fret point. The Petite Grune has 10 feet on its shoalest part, from which St. Mark's spire just shut in with Noirmont point bears E. by N. northerly ; and, the western martello tower in St. Brelade bay appears midway between Rousse rock and Le Fret point. The passage between the Petite Grune and Le Fret bank is 2tj cables wide. The Passage rock, of 14 feet, bears W. by N. § N. 5 cables from the shoalest spot on the Petite Grune, and, from it, the Dog's Nest rock beacon is on with the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette ; this is also a leading mark for the western channel, but leads, as described, over the Passage rock and very close inside all these dangers. Their eastern boundary is marked by Tabor chapel on with the high-water extreme of Le Fret point. Grunes Vaudin are an extensive cluster of rocks more than a mile S.S.W. of Noirmont point and a mile eastward of the Vracheres. The two highest rocks, the Grand Vaudin and the S.W. rock, dry 5 feet near the middle of the bank, about N.E. and S.W. 2 cables from each other ; many other heads have only from one to 3 or 4 feet over them. From the S.W. rock, the gateway of St. Brelade church is just in sight eastward of the Rousse rock ; and, St. Mark's spire is a little open eastward of the south-eastern part of Elizabeth castle N.E. by E. E. From the S.W. rock a chain of dangerous sunken rocks extends 2\ cables W.N.W., and also 5 cables in a north-easterly direction ; the eastern part called the Poches-a-suie, See charts, Nos. 62 b and r.

Chap. VI.] DANGERS OFF ST. AUBIN BAY. 247 is nearly detached from the Vaudin bank, and has on it as little as 4 feet. The Sillette.— Beacon.— This reef lies north-eastward of the Grunes Vaudin and is separated from the Poches-a-Suie by a 7-fathoms channel If cables wide. It is a small reef, less than 2 cables wide, but the rocks generally are higher than any others in the neighbour hood ; its highest head, close to the eastern side of the reef, dries 12 feet, and is marked by a beacon pole 23 feet high, from which, the spire of St. Mark's church touches the south-eastern angle of Elizabeth castle ; and, Icho tower, off St. Clement's bay, on with the northern side of the Frouquie rock bears E. by S. f S. There is a sunken 4-feet rock about a cable north-westward of the Sillette reef, with 6 fathoms water between. Grand and Petit Four. — These rocks lie between the Sillette and the shore. The Grand Four uncovers 3 feet ; from it, Noirmont tower bears N.N.E. E. ; and, Nicolle tower is its apparent breadth open southward of the white patch on the Dog's Nest rock. The inner head of the Grand Four has 6 feet water and bears N. § W. one cable from the highest rock just described. The Petit Four is a reef of sunken rocks 1\ cables eastward of the Grand Four, and nearly 3 cables in extent East and West. The highest rock is near the middle of the south-western part of the bank, it dries only one foot ; another rock dries 6 inches south eastward of this one-foot rock ; and, a third, bearing E. by N. 14 cables from it, is just awash at low water, springs ; the latter is close to the eastern edge of the reef, and, from it, Fort Regent flagstaff is open northward of False Hermitage rock ; and, Mont Plaisir house touching Pointe de But bears N. f E. Grunes aux Dardes is a rocky bank, of which the shoalest part is a cable wide, about 2 cables eastward of the Sillette beacon. From its highest head, which dries 5 feet near the northern part of the bank, St. Mark's church midway between the Hermitage and Close rocks bears N.E. by E. J E. ; and, Janvrin tower on with the south-western high-water extreme of ile Percee N.N.W. £ W. westerly. Another rock dries 4 feet close to this on a N.N.E. bearing, and a third dries 3 feet half a cable S.S.W. from it. A rock awash at See chart, No. 62 *. Q S 0 11886
