VI. 248 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. low water, bearing S.S.E. one cable, marks the limit of the bank in that direction ; and, 1£ cables eastward of the highest rock is the Frouquie, a sunken rock entirely detached, on which are only 5 feet water. Danger rock, with 5 feet water, is the eastern rock of some sunken rocks southward of the Grunes aux Dardes, and 4£ cables distant from the highest head of that reef ; from it, the eastern end of Almorah terrace is on with the northern side of the Hermitage ; and, Janvrin tower open of the south-western high- water mark of ile Percee bears N.N.W. \ W. Rouaudiere rock. — Buoy. — The Rouaudiere rock dries 4 feet and is small and steep-to, except on its south-eastern side where a sunken ridge extends half a cable. A red buoy with staff and black ball is moored in 5 fathoms, 100 yards westward of the rock. This rock is exactly in the fairway off the middle of St. Aubin bay and 4£ cables S. \ W. from the Diamond rock ; from it, Haule house open westward of St. Aubin castle bears N. by W. westerly ; St. Saviour's church is on with the north-western side of False Hermitage ; and Icho tower touching the southern side of Tas de Pois or White rock bears S.E. by E. \ E. easterly. Grunes St. Michel are two small reefs nearly North and South of each other and little more than half a cable apart ; the southern reef is about a cable in extent East and West, and the least water, 3 feet, is at the western end. The highest head of the northern group of rocks dries 5 feet ; from it, the Rouaudiere buoy bears N.W. by N. h-\ cables, and St. Mark's spire is on with the northern white patch on Albert pier N.E. easterly. Hinguette reef, 2 cables south-eastward of the Grunes St. Michel, is 2\ cables long N.E. by N. and S.W. by S., and most of its rocks dry at low water, springs ; the highest, near the northern end, dries 11 feet ; another, 150 yards within the south-western end, dries 5 feet. From the 11-feet rock, the western end of Victoria college is on with the Dog's Nest beacon N.E. \ E. easterly ; and, La Moye white Semaphore house is open south-westward of Noir mont tower. From this rock, the reef extends about 120 yards eastward, and 2| cables S.S.W. See chart, No. 62 b.

Chap. VI.] DANGERS OFF AND IN ST. AUBIN BAY. 249 The Tetards are 3 cables southward of the Hinguette reef, they have only 2 feet over their outer head, from which, Seymour .tower touching the northern side of the Frouquie bears E. f S. ; and, the western end of Almorah terrace open eastward of the Dog's Nest rock N.N.E. £ E. Nine-Feet rock, nearly midway between the Tetards and Tas de Pois, is the shallowest of several rocky heads in this passage ; from it, Icho tower is the apparent breadth of the Frouquie open northward of that rock ; Fort Regent signal post is on with the eastern side of the Crabiere rock ; and, No. 2 martello tower, St. Aubin bay, just open eastward of Gros du Chateau rock bears N. | W. westerly. DANGERS in St. AUBIN BAY.— The Rouaudiere rock, as already described, lies in the fairway off the middle of St. Aubin bay. The main channel to St. Helier Little road from the westward is between the Rouaudiere and Grunes St. Michel ; it is nearly 4 cables wide at this part, has an even bottom, and a depth of 6 fathoms. Diamond rock, near the middle of St. Aubin bay, has 8 feet water over it. From it, Fort Regent flagstaff touching the northern side of Close rock bears E. by N. ; and, Haule house midway between St. Aubin castle tower and the end of the breakwater extending from it N. by W. \ W. Pignonet, Grunes du Port, and Junees are the principal dangers off the western shore of St. Aubin bay. Pignonet rock. — Beacon. — The Pignonet uncovers 10 feet with Le Fret and Noirmont points in line, distant 2^ cables from the latter. It is marked by a beacon pole and ball, from which Haule house touching St. Aubin harbour pier-head bears N. \ E. easterly ; and St. Saviour's church just open northward of St. Mark's spire E. by N. \ N. northerly. There are many rocks between the Pignonet and Noirmont point, of which the most dangerous is southward of a line connecting the two. This rock is the same height as the Pignonet and lies with tne outer apex of Le Fret bluff on with Noirmont tower, \\ cables from the latter. See chart, No. 62 S 0 11886 Q 2

[Chap. VI. 250 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. Grunes du Port is a rocky group nearly a cable long North and South. The southern rock has 3 feet water and the northern head dries 6 feet ; from this latter rock, pointe de But bears N. by W. \ W. westerly ; and, Fort Regent flagstaff is on with Elizabeth castle flagstaff. The Junees are a sunken rocky group 2 cables N.N.E. from the Grunes du port. From the southern rock, which has 2 feet water, Lower Blanc Pignon house just shut in with the detached eastern bastion of St. Aubin castle bears N. \ E. ; and, Fort ■ Regent signal-post is on with the north-eastern extreme of Elizabeth castle. Baleine rock with 2 feet water, the most important danger within the bay on its eastern side, is between Gros du Chateau and the Diamond rock. From it, Gros du Chateau rock bears E. by N. 2§ cables ; the lighthouse on Victoria pier is touching the northern side of Close rock ; and, the eastern end of Almorah terrace is open northward of the high rock next to the Gros du Chateau on its north-eastern side. Outer rock, off Hermitage reef, has 7 feet water, and several similar small patches are in its vicinity ; from it, the outer extreme of Motte islet on with the Oyster rock beacon bears S.E. by E.|E. ; and the eastern end of Victoria terrace is nearly touching the northern extreme of Elizabeth castle. ANCHORAGE. — There is sufficient room for several vessels to lie at single anchor in St. Aubin bay ; but, if moored, the hawse should be open to the South-west at any time between September and March when the prevailing winds are from that quarter. The best berth is within the Diamond rock, in about 20 feet water, lowest springs, with St. Saviour's church tower just open northward of St. Mark's spire and on with the high rock between Gros du Chateau and the Vrachere, or, Fort Regent signal-post, seen over Elizabeth castle, on with Gros du Chateau E. -| N. ; and, Haule house on with the northern extreme of St. Aubin castle breakwater N. by W. § W. This spot is N.N.E. nearly 2 cables from the Diamond rock. Vessels wishing to lie as near as possible to St. Helier, may anchor outside the Diamond rock in 5 fathoms, with Haule house on the See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

Chap. VI.] ST. AUBIN BAY.— ANCHORAGE.— PASSAGES INTO. 251 same bearing, and with St. Mark's spire touching the south-eastern Hermitage rock. This last position should only be used in fine weather, but at the anchorage within the Diamond rock, vessels of 18 feet draught may ride out a heavy southerly gale in safety, being out of the strength of the tidal stream, and the swell and sea being broken by the outlying rocks, especially when the water is below the level of half tide. During neap tides, vessels of 22 feet draught may safely anchor inside the Diamond rock, but for deeper vessels there is no safe anchorage on any part of the southern coast of Jersey in very bad weather. PASSAGES into ST. AUBIN BAY.— Nine passages lead into St. Aubin bay, viz. : the North-west, Western, South-west Sillette, Danger rock, Middle, Hinguette, South, and Eastern In westerly gales, the best time to pass through any of these channels is between first quarter flood and high water. The first of the ebb or west-going stream throws up a very dangerous overfall off Noirmont point, and when that stream has fairly made, overfalls which continue with more or less intensity according to the height of the ocean swell and strength of the wind, extend across all the channels until the stream slacks. NORTH-WEST PASSAGE is only If cables wide at the narrowest part between Le Fret point and the rocky bank of that name, which, however, in the shallowest spot near it has 14 feet water ; the channel is safe and has nothing less than \ fathoms in any part. Beingthe ordinary steam -packetroute between Southampton, Guernsey, and St. Helier, it is more used than any of the other channels. Directions. — Having rounded the Corbiere, see page 237, and having passed between La Moye point and St. Brelade bank by shutting in Motte islet with Noirmont point ; and, having Noirmont tower bearing S.E. by E. f E., run direct for the tower until Corbiere lighthouse is on with La Moye point N.W. f W., which mark leads midway through the narrowest part of the channel off Le Fret point in 8 fathoms. Continue on the same line until the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette is on with the Dog's Nest rock beacon E. | S. ; this mark leads nearly midway between Noirmont See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

[Chap. VI. 252 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. point and the Grand aud Petit Four reefs, more than one cable northward of the Rouaudiere rock, exactly midway between the Cloches and the 7-feet rock a cable outside the Oyster rock beacon, and up to the leading mark for entering the Little road ; see pages 244 and 256. WESTERN PASSAGE, between the Hubaut reefs and St. Brelade bank, is about 2f cables wide at its narrowest part, between the Petite Grune and Le Fret bank where there are from 7 to 9 fathoms water, but the Passage rock with only 14 feet lies in the fairway of the entrance. It is, however, the most direct route to St. Aubin bay and St. Helier harbour from the westward, one leading mark only being required, but as the marks are not easily made out in hazy weather, the North-west passage is probably the best and safest. Directions. — The leading mark is, the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette and the Dog's Nest beacon in line E. \ S. ; this almost touches the northern side of the Passage rock, and passes only 100 yards northward of the Petite Grune, therefore in entering the channel from the westward, to clear those reefs, keep the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette open northward of the Dog's Nest beacon until Tabor chapel is on with Le Fret point, after which the white patch and beacon may be brought in line, and, as already described, they lead up to the entrance of the Little road. Should the white patch at Greve d'Azette be obscured, Noirmont tower on with De Pas tower E. \ S. will do equally well, but, to clear the 20-feet rock eastward of Le Fret bank, the Hermitage rock should be opened clear of Noirmont point before shutting in Tabor chapel with Le Fret point ; and, if all objects eastward and near the town are invisible whilst the land about Noirmont and La Moye are tolerably clear, which is often the case in fine weather, Noirmont point may be approached to the distance of a cable ; but, in passing eastward of it, do not shut in La Moye white Semaphore house with Le Fret point until St. Aubin castle opens out ; this clears the dangerous rock between, and outside the line of, Noirmont tower and Pignonet beacon. After passing Pignonet beacon, bring Noirmont tower a little open northward of it, and when about 2^ cables eastward of the beacon, anchor until the weather clears. See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

Chap. VI.] 253 ST. AUBIN BAY.— PASSAGES INTO. SOUTH-WEST PASSAGE is between the Vracheres and the Grunes Vaudin, eastward of the Grande Grune, and westward of the Grand Four. The narrowest part of the channel is between the 6-feet sunken rock at the northern part of the Grand Four, and another rock with 20 feet over it ; these rocks bear from each other W. by N. and E. by S. and are 2 cables apart. Directions. — Saumarez house, or the Firs, a yellow building about half way up the slope of the hill north-eastward of St. Matthew's church, on with Noirmont tower N.E. leads midway between the Frouquie of the Vrachere and the Grunes Vaudin ; enter the channel therefore on this line and run on it until the white patch in the sea wall at Greve d'Azette is on with the Dog's Nest beacon, when proceed as before directed. As the leading mark given leads very close past the western side of the Grand Four, it is recommended that on the flood vessels should run in on it only until Tabor chapel is on with the upper part of the slope of Le Fret bluff, and then use that as the leading mark until the eastern leading mark comes on. Tabor chapel is here given as the most conspicuous mark, but this leading line approaches the Grande Grune rather nearer than is desirable ; for the middle of the channel, Tabor chapel should be shut in altogether, and the Pic-nic hotel, a house with a white gable on the low land westward of the chapel, should be brought in line with the extreme of point Le Fret. As -there are overfalls and strong eddies from the rocks in this channel on both ebb and flood, it should be avoided except in tins weather. SILLETTE PASSAGE, between the Sillette rocks and the Grunes aux Dardes, is less than 2 cables wide, with an average depth of 6 fathoms ; but, a rocky patch of 26 feet lies in the fairway, so that no more than this depth can be depended on. Directions.— The Sillette passage should only be attempted by a sailing vessel with a fresh leading wind, as both tidal streams set right across it. The leading mark is, No. 3 white martello tower in St. Aubyn bay on with the eastern side of Grosse rock, on which there is a beacon, N. by E. \ E. This leads 1£ cables eastward of the Poches-a-Suie rocks on which there are only 4 feet water, midway See chart, No. 62 b.

[Chap. VI. 254 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. between the Sillette and Grimes aux Dardes, one cable eastward of the Petit Four, H cables eastward of the Pignonet beacon, half a cable westward of the Grunes du Port, and very close inside the western head of the Junees. MIDDLE PASSAGE. — In entering by this passage, Danger rock and the Grunes aux Dardes are left on the port hand, and the Tetards, Hinguette reef, and Grunes St. Michel on the starboard hand. The narrowest part would be b\ cables wide but for two sunken rocks, with only 14 and 15 feet over them, southward of the Grunes St. Michel and distant from it nearly half a mile, thus dividing the channel into two. The westernmost of these two rocks has 15 feet water, and is near the middle of the channel at its entrance ; it bears from Danger rock E. by S. § S. i-\ cables. The best channel is between Danger rock and this 15-feet rock ; here the ground is clean and the soundings regular in about 7 fathoms. The eastern side of the Middle passage is rocky and the depths irregular. Directions. — Mont Plaisir house on with St. Aubin castle tower N. \ W. leads through the Middle passage, passing 1^ cables west ward of the 15-feet rock, 2\ cables eastward of Danger rock, and rather less from the Frouquie of the Grunes aux Dardes on which there are 5 feet water, 1| cables westward of the Rouaudiere buoy, \\ cables eastward of the Grunes du Port, and eastward of, but very close to the Junees sunken rocks. To clear the Diamond rock when anchoring in St. Aubin bay, haul to the eastward when the eastern end of Almorah terrace comes on with the Vrachere, which rock is marked by a beacon and is the innermost high rock northward of Elizabeth castle ; and anchor as convenient when Haule house opens eastward of St. Aubin castle tower. DANGER ROCK PASSAGE is between the Grunes aux Dardes and Danger rock and is at this part 3 cables wide with 5-j fathoms water near the middle, but two rocky patches of 16 and 17 feet lie close south-eastward of the leading line. This passage, like the Sillette, is dangerous at times for sailing vessels, and should not be taken without a pilot. Steam-vessels, however, whose captains are acquainted with the pilotage, use it as the most direct passage to the Little road from the south-westward. See chart, No. 62 b.

Chap. VI.] ST. AUBIN BAY.— PASSAGES INTO. 255 Directions. — Bring St. Mark's spire on with the south-eastern rock off the Hermitage N.E. § E. ; this mark leads nearly 1^ cables southward of the southernmost rock of the Grunes aux Dardes, awash at low water, and rather farther from Danger rock ; it also passes more than 1| cables clear of the outer 7-feet rock of the Rouaudiere, and may be followed until the Dog's Nest beacon is on with the white patch on the sea wall in Greve d'Azette. HINGUETTE PASSAGE, between the Hinguette reef and the Tetards, is 3^ cables wide, has 7 or 8 fathoms water, and is a good and safe passage at slack water, but at other times requires careful allowance for the tide, which sets right across it. Directions. — Enter this passage with St. Mark's spire on with the Dog's Nest beacon N.E. by N. and run through between the Hin guette reef and the Tetards ; when St. Matthew's church comes on with the Gros du Chateau rock N. J W., the vessel is between the Cloches rocks at the entrance of the Little road. SOUTH PASSAGE is between the Tetards, with only 2 feet water, and some rocky patches to the eastward on which the shoalest spot has 14 feet. The channel is 2 cables wide, has 8 fathoms water, but is not so safe as the Hinguette or as the Eastern passage. Directions. — St. Matthew's church tower, a dull greyish- white building, seen between the heads of the Gros du Chateau rock N. -\ W. leads through about mid-channel, and between the Cloches up to the entrance of the Little road ; but, if proceeding to the anchorage in St. Aubin bay, when St. Peter's spire is on with Lower Blanc Pignon house N. by W. § W. steer with that as the leading mark up to the anchorage. Near low water, St. Peter's spire may be lost sight of before arriving at the anchorage, in which case care must be taken to note some other object in the line of direction. EASTERN PASSAGE.— The narrowest part of this passage is between a rock with 11 feet water and Demie de Pas, which dries 20 feet and on which is a beacon pole. The 11-feet rock bears W. by N. | N. 3 cables from Demie de Pas beacon, and, from it, the 9-feet rock, see page 249, bears N. by W. ]- W. one cable. The ground outside Demie de Pas is clean up to the foot of the rock, which is not more than 40 yards from the beacon. See chart, No. 62 *.

256 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. Directions.— Approaching from the eastward, run in with La Moye white Semaphore house open of Le Fret bluff until the Frouquie rock is abaft the beam ; then haul up to pass within a cable of Demie de Pas beacon, and when it bears S.E. by E. E. steer about N.W. by N. until St. Matthew church tower is between the heads of Gros du Chateau rock, the leading mark for the South passage ; this leads up to the entrance of the Little road ; or, St. Peter's spire on with Lower Blanc Pignon house, leads up to the anchorage in St. Aubin bay. ST. HELIER LITTLE ROAD.— DIRECTIONS.— From St. Aubin bay, or from the Westward.— When bound from St Aubin bay into the Little road, it is best to weigh at about half flood, at which time the depths at St. Helier are as stated at page 241. The channel is between the western Cloche rock with 8 feet water and the outer Oyster rock with 7 feet ; it is lj cables wide and has from 4^ to 5 fathoms water. Steer between the Oyster rock and the buoy marking the western Cloche rock, with the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette and the Dog's Nest beacon in line, until St. Mark's spire is on with the white patch at the Albert pier-head N.E., which mark leads into the Little road ; but, after passing the Platte rock, edge to the northward until St. Mark's spire is on with the northern white patch on the Albert pier, which, as already described, leads either to the anchorage in the Little road or up to the entrance of the harbour ; see also page 244. From the Southward. — Pass between the Cloches rocks with St. Mark's spire on with Victoria pier lighthouse N.E. or with the elbow and inner lights on Albert pier (green and red) in line ; and, when nearing the Oyster rocks, proceed by the marks just given for the Little road or for the harbour entrance, as may be required. From St. Aubin bay over the bridge to the Little road or St. Helier harbour. — This passage is only fit for small craft at high water ; in taking it, steer to pass half a cable northward of the Vrachere rock, or run in with St. Mark's spire on with the northern side of the hospital until De Pas tower opens northward of the northern white patch on the Albert pier, with which mark run over the Bridge (this part has only one foot water at half tide), and either enter the harbour or haul out into the Little road. See charts, Nos. 62 b and c,

Chap. VI.] ST. HELIER LITTLE ROAD. — DIRECTIONS. 257 By night. — Bring the Victoria pier white light to bear N.E., and steer for it until* the green light and inner red light on Albert pier are in line bearing N.E. \ N. ; which mark, if visible so far, leads between the Hinguette rock and Grunes St. Michel up to the anchorage in the Little road, or to the entrance of the harbour, care being taken to observe the precautions named at page 245. If from the westward, see leading lights, page 242. CAUTION. — In entering the harbour, allowance must be made for the tide, which, at or near springs, runs in and out with consider able strength. The most dangerous time for a vessel to enter is at about half flood ; at that time, vessels are frequently forced over against the sank-bank fronting the South pier of the old harbour before they have time to turn their heads up the harbour. GENERAL DIRECTIONS.— In beating along the southern coast of Jersey, it should always be borne in mind that the available space between the outer shoals off Noirmont point and the Minquiers ledge is but 8 miles, and between the Violet bank and the Minquiers only 6^ miles. Small vessels working up towards the narrows of the western channels, when eastward of the Kaines, may stand into St. Brelade bay until the Jument rock is on with La Moye point ; and southward, until the southern extreme of Elizabeth castle is on with Noirmont point. When in the narrows of the western channel, before half flood or after half ebb, backing and filling is recom mended with a beating wind ; with the east-going stream, the vessel's head should be off-shore, and with the west-going stream, in-shore. Between half flood and high water, a vessel may act according to her draught, for, at half tide, there are at least 13 feet over all the rocks in the offing of St. Aubin bay, with the exception of the Pignonet, Hinguette, and Sillette, on which there are then only 9, 8, and 7 feet respectively. If bound to the Little road or to St. Helier harbour, it may be useful to know that St. Mark's spire touching the southern side of Close rock leads 60 yards northward of the Rouaudiere ; and, the same spire on with the False Hermitage leads well southward of it. A vessel from the north-westward running for shelter in St. Aubin bay during a gale from that quarter, should keep \\ miles outside the Corbiere to avoid the breaking sea near it, especially between half ebb and low water ; and, when the land of Noirmont is well open, steer for its point until Grosnez point conies on with the See charts, Nos. 62 b and c.

258 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. [Chap. VI. Corbiere, when haul up for La Moye and bring the marks for the North-west passage on, see page 251, where much less sea will be found than in either of the other channels. In heavy westerly gales, the whole space between the outlying rocks off Noirmont point is a confused mass of breakers ; clouds of driving spray create an impenetrable mist, obscuring all marks near the level of the sea, and the beacons marking rocks are all out of sight ; but, even under such circumstances, the North-west passage may be safely taken by those acquainted with it as both Le Fret and Noirmont points are safe of approach for large vessels to the distance of one cable. On arriving abreast of Noirmont point, attend to the directions given at page 252 ; or, do not shut in La Moye white Semaphore house with Le Fret point until No. 3 white martello tower in St. Aubin bay opens eastward of St. Aubin castle, to clear the Pignonet rocks, as the first of the flood sets right over these rocks into St. Aubin bay. It may be useful to repeat that when Haule house comes on with the western end of the wall extending westward from St. Aubin castle the vessel is midway between the Grunes du Port and the Diamond rock ; and, that St. Saviour's church tower just open northward of St. Mark's spire and on with the high rock between Gros du Chateau and the Vrachere rock beacon E. by N. \ N. leads up to the anchorage in St. Aubin bay, well clear of the Diamond rock. Approaching from the westward, the Frouquie rock, off Le Croc point, on with Seymour tower E. § S. leads outside all the shoals off Noirmont point and St. Aubin bay until near the Tetards, when the tower should be brought nearly on with the Rousse rock, just northward of the Icho tower. From the eastward, La Moye white Semaphore house open of Le Fret bluff N.W. \ W. leads outside all the rocks off St. Clement's bay, and of the Frouquie and Demie de Fas, up to the entrance of the Eastern passage. The COAST eastward of St. Helier is low and sandy to La Roque point, the south-eastern extreme of Jersey, distant 5^ miles E. by S. \ S. from Noirmont point ; and also northward of La Roque point as far as Mont Orgueil bluff, which bears from La Roque point N.N.E. \ E. 2 miles, the bight between them being named Grouville bay, off which, at one mile S.E. \ E. from Mont Orgueil castle, is good anchorage for vessels of the largest size. The southern part of See charts, Nos. 62 a and b.

Chap. VI.] COAST.— VIOLET BANK.— TIDAL STREAM. 259 this coast is inaccessible to shipping, it being fringed by extensive reefs which dry in some parts around La Roque point 2 miles from the shore at low water, springs. The outer edge of these reefs on the southern side is generally steep to and, fortunately, well marked by a number of large rocks, which, although sometimes nearly awash at high water, are never entirely covered, and also by two stone towers, viz., the Icho tower, about 3 miles south-eastward of the Little road of St. Helier ; and, Seymour tower, off La Roque point, If miles farther eastward and near the middle of the Violet bank. VIOLET BANK is the general name applied to the south-eastern part of the great reefs eastward of St. Helier. The part which dries at low water, springs, extends" rather more than 2 miles from La Roque point, and consists of gravel, shingle, and sand, interspersed with numerous ledges of sharp-pointed rocks ; beyond this to the eastward, the bank extends 1^ miles beyond the Conchiere rock with many sunken reefs, included in the description of the Violet channel. The greater part of the bank covers at half flood, at which time there is a foot of water over the inner part of the ridge of sand and shingle extending from La Roque point to Seymour tower ; this, the lowest part of the ridge, is near La Roque point and is the most favourable spot for the passage of boats. At high water, the drying part of the bank is entirely covered and is then only marked by the Conchiere rock at its southern extreme, by Seymour tower near the middle, by Karame rock, at this time awash, on the South-east, and by Little Seymour rock, also awash but marked by a pole and basket beacon, near its eastern side. Tidal Stream. — From half flood to half ebb, the stream runs with a velocity of 6 knots, at springs, over the Violet bank and through the Violet channel in a north-easterly direction, turning northward through GoreyT roads where its strength is about 4| knots. As before remarked, the reef eastward of St. Helier, as well as the southern edge of the Violet bank, is well marked by conspicuous rocks, which, together with the principal sunken dangers along this line, will now be described. Tas de PoiS, or White rock, bears S. by E. f E. 7\ cables from the Dog's Nest beacon, see page 243. Although only 5 feet above See charts, Nos. 62 a and b.

260 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. [Chap. VI. high water, springs, it is very remarkable from its upper part being well whitewashed all round, and from there being another rock, rather larger and black, 1^ cables eastward of it. Dangerous rocks, which never show, extend If cables westward of it ; and 2\ cables north-westward is a rocky group, of which the Trois Grunes, the highest heads, uncover 20 feet. A chain of rather high rocks extends from the White rock to the shore. Demie de Pas. — Beacon. — This is the westernmost rock of a cluster bearing S. \ W. 4 cables from the White rock, and W. by N. § N. 5i cables from the Frouquie ; it dries 20 feet, is steep-to outside, and is marked by a pole beacon. The Frouquie, S.E. \ S. 1\ cables from White rock, is 3 feet lower than that rock, and therefore nearly awash at high water, springs. A dangerous reef extends W.S.W. 2\ cables from the Frouquie, and a chain of high rocks connects it with point Le Croc, of which the inner and highest is Motto islet, about 22 feet above the level of the highest tides ; La Sambue, another rock in the same chain being only 2 feet lower. This line of rocks marks the limit of the Greve d'Azette, the first bay eastward of St. Helier. La Moye white Semaphore house open of Le Fret point N.W. \ W. leads 2 cables south-westward of the Demie de Pas and of the rocks extending from the Frouquie. The coast between Motto islet and La Roque point recedes slightly and forms St. Clement's bay. Between the Frouquie and Icho tower, no rocks are visible at high water to mark the outer edge of the reef fronting this bay, but, at half tide and less, it is well marked by the Rouget rock, which is close to the edge of deep water and bears S.E. easterly 6^ cables from the Frouquie ; also, by the Jinquet which dries 25 feet 5 cables E. by S. § S. from the Rouget ; and, 3 cables eastward of the Jinquet rock is the Grande Frouquie, which bears W. by S. | S. 3 cables from the Icho tower and is 7 or 8 feet above the level of the highest tides. ICHO and SEYMOUR TOWERS are built of stone, are each about 45 feet above the level of high water, bear from each other E. \ N. and W. \ S. and are 1| miles apart. Icho tower is surrounded by high rocks, and in this respect differs from Seymour tower, which at high water rises abruptly from the sea and is completely isolated. See charts, Nos. 62 a and b.

Chap. VI.] ICHO AND SEYMOUR TOWERS.— VIOLET CHANNEL. 261 Echiquelez rock is one of the principal sea-marks near Icho tower, from which it bears S. by E. \ E. 4| cables. Its summit is 5 feet above the highest tides ; it is steep-to on the outside westward, but S.S.E. \ E. 1| cables from it is a half -tide rock ; and, north westward, in line between it and the Jinquet, are several dangerous rocks, of which the farthest dries 5 feet and lies 1\ cables S.S.W. from the Grande Frouquie. Between Echiquelez rock and the Conchiere, the edge of the reef curves outwards 2\ cables beyond a straight line connecting those rocks. Icho bank is a dangerous, rocky, irregular, off-lying ridge about 4| cables long N.N.W. and S.S.E., and H cables wide ; the least water, 2\ fathoms, is at the northern extreme, and bears S.W. £ W. 2j miles from the Icho tower. From this shoal spot, Platte Roque martello tower just open northward of Icho tower bears N.E. E. ; and, St. Peter's spire open eastward of Lower Blanc Pignon house N. by W. § W. On other parts of the bank there are from 3 to 5 fathoms water. The channel between this bank and the rocks fronting Icho tower is nearly 2 miles wide and clear of danger. The Conchiere rock, 2 miles from La Roque point and at the southern extreme of the Violet bank, dries 41 feet and is therefore never covered, although sometimes awash. From it, Mont Orgueil castle and Seymour tower are exactly in line N. \ E., the latter distant ~L\ miles. A reef extends 1^ cables southward from the Conchiere ; therefore that rock should not be approached nearer than 3 cables. A good clearing mark for the line of reef just described between the Frouquie and Conchiere rocks is, Corbiere lighthouse touching La Moye point until the Grande Anquette beacon turret is well open southward of the Conchiere rock. VIOLET CHANNEL.— The sunken part of the Violet bank commencing at the Conchiere rock, extends eastward 1^ miles with dangerous reefs on its edge in the direction of the Echiquelez and Conchiere rocks in line. Northward of these reefs for rather more than a mile, the entire space is shoal water with rocks innumerable ; so that, at low water, it is difficult for a stranger to find his way through them even in a boat. The southern edge of the bank is See charts, Nos. 62 a and b.

262 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. well marked at the last quarter ebb by a long string of rocks called the Route en Ville ; its eastern extreme is bounded by the Petit Four, a rock with 2 feet water ; and, the bank may be said to extend northward as far as the Cochon, Noire, and Grande Haisse rocks. The navigable part of the Violet channel is between this sunken part of the Violet bank and the Plateau de la Frouquie, the rocky bank to the southward, on the northern edge of which are the Goubiniere, Rousse Platte, and other dangerous rocks ; and the Anquette rocks to the eastward. The narrowest part is between the Petit Four and the sunken rocks westward and north-westward of the Petite Anquette, where it is about 5 cables wide, but it is only a cable wider between the Plateau de la Frouquie and the Route en Ville rocks ; the general depth is from 5 to 6 fathoms. Anquette Channel leads out eastward between the Grande and Petite Anquette rocks from the middle of the Violet channel. The general depth of water is about the same as in the Violet channel, but, from the absence of good leading marks, the passage is more difficult. Near the point of separation of the Anquette and Violet channels, with Prince's tower and Little Seymour beacon in line, and with the Grand Anquette beacon turret bearing East, southerly, is a rock with 23 feet water and another near it with 25 feet. Though nothing less than these depths has been found, caution is necessary with large ships passing through this part of the channel at low water. Vessels of 15 feet draught or upwards should wait until the flood tide has fairly made, and, with any swell on, should not pass through until the first quarter flood. DANGERS in the VIOLET CHANNEL— The Conchiere rock, see preceding page, is the principal mark at the western entrance of the Violet channel. Taxe rock, 6-} cables eastward of the Conchiere, dries 10 feet at low water ; from it, the Conchiere and Echiquelez rocks are exactly in line bearing N.W. by W. f W. Route en Ville rocks.— At 2\ cables south-eastward of Taxe rock, with Echiquelez rock open southward of the Conchiere, is the highest rock of the Route en Ville, which dries 11 feet ; West rock dries 6 feet at 100 yards W. \ S. from it ; and, another rock, a cable See charts, Nos. 62 a and b.

Chap. VI.] ANQUETTE CHANNEL.— PLATEAU DE LA FROUQUIE. 263 eastward of the highest head, dries 10 feet. From these rocks east ward, and close to deep water, the Route en Ville chain extends for about 5 cables with an outward curve to the East Grune, its eastern rock, on which are 5 feet water ; most of the rocks are nearly awash at low water. St. Martin's spire on with Gorey tower leads over a 2-feet rock half a cable within or westward of their eastern end. To clear these rocks on their southern side, keep Icho tower open southward of the Conchiere rock until Prince's tower is on with Seymour tower ; after which, keep Echiquelez rock open southward of the Conchiere until Prince's tower is on with No. 5 martello tower in Grouville bay. Petit Four, with 2 feet water, is at the eastern extreme of the Violet bank ; from it, Karame rock just shut in with the outer part of the high table land above Noirmont point bears N.W. by W. W. ; Coupe turret seen over the end of the bluff just within the break water house at Verclut point, N. | W. ; and, Grande Anquette beacon turret on with the northern side of Petite Anquette rock, S.E. by E. £ E. On the southern side of the Violet channel the following are the principal rocks : — PLATEAU DE LA FROUQUIE.— The Goubiniere dries 20 feet at low water ; it is at the western end of the Plateau de la Frouquie, very little eastward of Orgueil castle, Seymour tower, and Conchiere rock in line, and distant from the latter nearly 1^ miles. From the rock, La Moye white Semaphore house is over the outer part of Le Fret point. There are several rocks northward of the Goubiniere ; the Canger rock is the most northern, it dries 16 feet, and is one cable distant from the Goubiniere. Orgueil castle open westward of Seymour tower and of the Con chiere rock clears the Goubiniere and all dangers on the western side of the Plateau de la Frouquie. Frouquier Aubert rock is at the south-western edge of the Plateau de la Frouquie, 1J miles south-eastward of the Goubiniere ; it uncovers 26 feet at low water and does not cover at neaps. From it St. Peter's spire is on with the white patch on South hill ; and, See charts, Nos. 62 a and o. s S O 11886

[Chap. VI. 264 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. St. Martin's spire is well open eastward of Seymour tower N. £ W. westerly. Rousse Platte rock is at the eastern side of the Plateau de la Frouquie, and E. h S. rather more than a mile from the Goubiniere ; it is a large flat rock about 100 yards in diameter and dries 14 feet. Between this rock and the Goubiniere are several rocks, of which one dries 15 feet, another dries only 4 feet but is the most dangerous, as it stands prominently out in the channel, which, between it and the Route en Ville reefs, is only 6 cables wide. Pierre des EnfantS, 2\ cables S. by E. £ E. from the Rousse Platte, is 7 feet higher than that rock, and is therefore a very useful mark when the Rousse Platte is covered. ANQUETTE ROCKS.— Petite Anquette lies 2\ miles E. by S. from the Conchiere rock, and, with the Seal rocks and Maraine reef, forms the eastern boundary of the Violet channel. The Petite Anquette uncovers 20 feet ; from it, Bergerie house on the heights above Noirmont point, on with the northern side of Motte islet bears N.W. by W. \ W. ; and, Archirondel red tower in St. Catherine's bay its apparent breadth open eastward of Rozel manor-house, N.N.W. Seal rocks form part of the extensive reef northward of the Petite Anquette, on which one of the most dangerous ridges is known as the Seals. The western Seal dries 4 feet N.N.W. \ W. Z\ cables from the Petite Anquette. A rock with only 12 feet water lies If cables westward of the western Seal ; and, the Maraine reef, with as little as 3 feet water, lies N.N.E. more than 6 cables from the Petite Anquette. Grune Le Feuvre has only 6 feet water at its shoalest spot, which bears N.E. by N. 1£ miles from the Petite Anquette. Grande Anquette rock.— Beacon turret.— This rock lies S.E. by E. \ E. easterly 1\ cables from the Petite Anquette, and is Z\ miles eastward of the Conchiere rock ; it covers about 8 feet above half tide, but is marked by a stone beacon turret painted in horizontal red and white bands, 20 feet above high water, and surmounted by a staff and ball. From the beacon, Rousse Platte rock bears W. by S. 2\ miles ; Grande Arconie, which dries 9 feet, See charts, Nos. 62 a and *.

Chap. VI.] ANQUETTE AND ARCONIE ROCKS. 265 S.S.E. £ E. one mile ; and, Porpoise rock, which dries 4 feet, S.W. by W. 8^ cables. Anquette patches form a small rocky bank, with from 16 to 20 feet on its eastern end, N.E. N. one mile from the Grande Anquette ; from the eastern shoalest spot of 16 feet, Seymour tower on with Motto islet bears W. by N. | N. ; and, Rozel mill (see page 283) twice its apparent breadth open westward of St. Catherine's white martello tower N.W. by N. Another bank of rock and gravel lies E. by S. \ S. 2 miles from the Grande Anquette, and N.W. northerly 3| miles from the Bœuf beacon turret ; from its shoalest part of 15 feet, Rozel mill is a little open eastward of St. Catherine's martello tower ; and, Grande Anquette beacon turret and the Conchiere rock in line bear W. by N. \ N. northerly. PLATEAU DE L' ARCONIE. — Some dangerous sunken rocks with as little as 3 feet lie from 1^ to 3-\ cables E.S.E. from the Anquette beacon turret ; and, the space southward of it for the distance of 1^ miles is occupied by a vast shoal called by the French the Plateau de l'Arconie ; some of the rocks on this shoal begin to uncover soon after the last quarter ebb, at springs ; others are only awash at low water, springs, and by far the greater part never uncover. Grande Arconie rock, which dries 9 feet, is at the eastern side of the plateau ; the Porpoise rock, drying 4 feet, marks its western boundary ; the Grand Four rock, drying 7 feet, and with several small rocks drying 2 feet in its vicinity, lies just within its south western extreme ; and, Grune la Hauche dries 6 feet one mile S.E. by E. £ E. from the Grand Four, and 7{T cables S. by W. f W. from the Grande Arconie. The channel between Plateau de la Frouquie and Plateau de l'Arconie is 1\ miles wide and has 5^ fathoms water, but its free navigation is impeded by a string of rocks extending across at unequal distances from each other between the Pierre des Enfants and the Grand Four ; of these, some are awash, others have 5 or 6 feet over them at low water, springs. The great strength of the stream at this part of the channel and the absence of good marks render its navigation extremely perilous See chart, No. 62 a. R 2 S 0 11886

[Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. 266 near low water ; no vessel should attempt to pass through, therefore, until after the first quarter flood. Coupe mound open eastward of Verclut point N. by W. leads through the best part of the channel. The Southern Anquettes commence near the south-western extreme of the Plateau de l'Arconie, and extend 5 miles south eastward in an almost continuous line. They consist of a number of narrow ridges of fine gravel, having generally a depth of from 3 to 4 fathoms, except on one detached bank near the south-eastern end, where there are only 2 fathoms. The markB for this spot are, La Moye white Semaphore house just open northward of Frouquier Aubert ; Grande Anquette beacon turret a little within Verclut point N. by W. | W. westerly ; Bœuf beacon turret N.E. by E. | E. 3 miles ; and, Basse le Marie S. by E. £ E. 3 miles. There are good 7-fathoms channels on either side of this bank. La Moye white Semaphore house just open of Le Fret point N.W. £ W. leads south-westward of the southern Anquettes, of the Plateau de la Frouquie, and of all the rocks bordering the southern shore of Jersey, up to the leading mark for the Eastern passage into St. Aubin bay ; and, this line passes 1£ miles northward of the Icho bank. Directions. — Violet channel. — If bound eastward from St. Helier through the Violet channel, having cleared the dangers outside the Little road, keep La Moye white Semaphore house open of Le Fret point N.W. W. until Orgueil castle, seen over the low land of La Roque point, comes on with Icho tower N.E. N. ; at which position, about 5 cables from the outer edge of the reef, the Grande Anquette beacon turret will be a little open southward of the Conchiere rock E. by S. \ S. From hence, steer E.S.E., parallel with the outer edge of the reef, the depth being from 5 to 7 fathoms. The Conchiere rock should be passed at about 4 cables, and, when eastward of it, bring the Echiquelez rock on with Noirmont tower N.W. by W. for a leading mark until Prince's tower is on with Seymour tower ; if the distance from the Conchiere and Route en Ville rocks has been correctly preserved in passing them, the Rousse Platte should now bear about S.W. 3^ cables, and the Grande Anquette beacon turret E. \ N. Now steer about N.E. \ N. to pass through the deepest part of the channel or, to pass through the middle of it, steer E. \ N. for the Grande See charts, Nos. 2,669 b, and 62 a and *.

Chap. VI.] VIOLET CHANNEL, DIRECTIONS.— GROUVILLE BAY. 267 Anquette beacon turret until Coupe mound is just open eastward of Verclut point N. by W., with which mark run towards the Petit Four ; and, when northward of a line drawn from the Conchiere to the Grande Anquette, edge to the eastward to bring Coupe turret open of Verclut point, which mark leads 2| cables eastward of the Petit Four, one cable eastward of Giffard rock, and through Gorey outer road. For mid-channel through the latter, however, the vessel should again edge away to the westward when Gorey lighthouses are in line, N.W., until Coupe mound is just open of Verclut point as before. The narrowest part of the channel being between the Petit Four and Petite Anquette, it may be useful to know that Coupe turret and the breakwater house at Verclut, exactly in line, leads a cable outside the Petit Four ; at this position, Rozel mill is touching the northern side of Mont Orgueil castle ; and, St. Catherine's white martello tower is on with Archirondel red tower. When abreast of the Petit Four, Karame rock just shut in with the high land above Noirmont point bears N.W. by W. f W. ; and, the Grande Anquette beacon turret open northward of Petite Anquette S.E. by E. i E. Small vessels may haul out eastward of the Bane du Chateau when Echiquelez rock is open northward of Karame rock, but vessels of very deep draught should not do so until Icho and Seymour towers are in line, in order to avoid the Stony banks 6 cables north westward of Grune le Feuvre, on which there are as little as 25 feet at low water. GROUVILLE BAY, which derives its name from a hamlet near St. Clement's church, is on the eastern side of Jersey between La Roque point and Mont Orgueil. Its outer southern boundary commences on the north-eastern side of the Violet bank and is very rocky ; numerous masses of rock lie scattered along the low-water line to the northward, which line is nearly a mile from the shore in the southern part of the bay ; there are also many rocks within as well as outside this line. Grouville bay, at low water, is very picturesque with its vast expanse of fine white sand rising with a gentle slope towards the shore, bounded on the South by Seymour tower and the rugged rocks of the Violet bank, and on the North by Mont Orgueil and its venerable castle. See chart, No. 62 a.

[Chap. VI. 268 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. Horn rock.— Beacon.— The Horn rock, S.S.E 1J miles from Mont Orgueil castle and one mile southward of the Equerriere beacon, in the centre of the bay, is the outer rock of the Frouquies de la Greve, dries 16 feet, and is marked by a beacon consisting of a staff and horizontal cross. Little Seymour rock.— Beacon.— Amongst other rocks on the southern side of the bay is Little Seymour rock, awash at high water and marked by a pole-and-basket beacon, from which a long string of rocks extends eastward, forming the low-water boundary of the bay. The most important of these rocks are : the Cochon at the outer edge, which dries 7 feet ; the Grande Haisse, which dries 22 feet ; and the Noire, which dries 14 feet, at 9| cables S. by E. from the Horn rock, and nearly a mile outside Little Seymour beacon. The Giffard, a most dangerous mid-channel rock in approaching Grouville bay from the southward, lies about 4 cables north-eastward of the Noire, and has only one foot over it at low water. From it, Little Seymour beacon, open northward of Gros Etac rock, bears W. by S. | S. southerly nearly 1^ miles ; Rozel mill a little open west ward of Crete guard-house N.N.W. ; Horn rock beacon N.W. | N. 7^ cables ; and a depth of 12 feet water on the South Ridge sand of the Bane du Chateau N.E. by E. \ E. 4 cables. Road rock, 4 cables N. by W. I W. from Horn rock beacon, and 1| cables outside the Grune du Port, has 9 feet water ; from it, St. Catherine's white martello tower is just shut in with Crete point ; and No. 5 martello tower on with the extreme end of the high table land southward of Grouville bears W. | S. A 14-feet patch lies S.S.E \ E. one cable from the Road rock. A small rock, with 26 feet water, and 30 to 34 feet round it, lies 2\ cables from Road rock in the direction of Verclut point ; half way between this and the Dasher rock, and about 1\ cables distant from each, is the Inner Road rock with 16 feet water. From this rock, St. Catherine's tower is just shut in with Crete point, and Gorey pier lighthouse is open northward of the Ecureuil beacon, the latter being 2^ cables distant. GOREY TOWN AND HARBOUR, at the northern end of Grouville bay, are immediately under Mont Orgueil castle. The little town contains about 1,000 inhabitants ; it is considered to be See chart, No. 62 a.

Chap. VI.] 269 GOREY, TOWN AND HARBOUR. particularly salubrious, and has railway communication with St. Helier, and by steamer with the coast of Normandy. It has a fair trade in vegetables, fruit, coal, cattle, timber, &c. Supplies of all kinds can be obtained, including coal in limited quantities, but vessels requiring coal, unless it can be shipped during tide time, 4 or 5 hours, have to lie aground in their berths. Hospital accommodation is avail able in case of sickness or accident. Depths. — The harbour is formed by a stone pier built out from the south-western part of Orgueil head. The outer berth alongside the pier has a depth of only 9 feet at half tide, about 23 feet at high water, springs, and 14 or 15 feet at neaps ; at low water, springs, the sand dries one cable outside the pier-head. Two small warping buoys are moored at the entrance to assist vessels arriving or leaving, the outer buoy about a cable south-west ward of the pier-head, the other about 80 yards westward of the pier. About 135 yards westward from the pier-head is a space paved with flat stones for depositing oysters ; it is, however, much broken up and no longer used for that purpose. With this exception, the bottom of Gorey harbour, consisting of mud and sand, affords good grounding berths. Vessels of 300 tons may occasionally be seen here, and about 300 vessels of all sizes enter the port annually, though the bottom dries at low water from 10 to 15 feet ; as it is the headquarters of the oyster fishery, a number of sloops of from 30 to 50 tons belong to the place- Sharp vessels not provided with legs should always get a pier berth and list inwards, assisted by mast-head tackles to the shore, to prevent falling over at low water. During severe gales, a vessel strains less in taking the ground, is better sheltered, and experiences less 'scend in this harbour than in any other in the Channel islands. Mooring buoy. — A Government mooring buoy is placed in 11 feet, with Gorey slip just open of the pier-head, and Horn rock and Ecureuil beacons in line, distant only one cable from the latter. The ground chain of these moorings lies North and South ; there are 38 fathoms on each arm, and the anchors are of 24 and 30 cwt. A cable within the buoy there are 7 feet, and 3J fathoms at the same distance outside, but close to their north-eastern side is a rock with only 7 feet at the lowest tides. LIGHTS. — From Gorey pier-head a, fixed white light is exhibited at 16 feet above high water. See chart, No. 62 a.

270 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. [Chap. VI. On the slope of the hill, from a red lantern in the face of the wall below Gorey church tower, at 535 yards N.W. from the pier-head lighthouse, and 80 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed red light, visible 8 miles. The two lights in line N.W. lead northward of the Frouquies de Greve, and of the Road, Fisherman, and Azicot rocks, and southward of the Ecureuil rock, in passing which latter, the red light should on no account be opened northward of the ivhite light. Storm Signals. — There is a storm signal station at Gorey. DANGERS. — Beacons. — The principal dangers in the immediate neighbourhood of the port of Gorey are the following : — The Equerriere is the largest and most conspicuous rock off Gorey harbour; it bears E. by S. \ S. 4J cables from the pier-head, dries 35 feet, and is marked by a pole and fish-tail beacon. Another rock, drying 14 feet, lies about 135 yards S.E. \ S. from it. Dasher rock, with 2 feet water and from 18 to 20 feet close-to, lies S. by W. about one cable from the Equerriere rock. The Ecureuil, \\ cables S.W. of the Equerriere, dries 14 feet, and is marked by a pole-and-basket beacon. Fisherman rock, with 8 feet water, lies S. \ W. 2^ cables from the Dasher rock. Other rocks which abound here, though smaller, are very dangerous, such as the Azicot rock, 2 cables outside Gorey pier-head, which dries 5 feet and is marked by a spar buoy ; the Guillimots, a group of rocks S. by W. 2\ cables from the Azicot, of which group the outer rock dries 6 feet and is marked by a spar buoy ; the Burons, a rocky group 2 cables south-eastward from the Guillimots, of which the highest rock lies to the N.E. and is also marked by a spar buoy ; and the Grune du Port, with 5 feet water 3^ cables outside the Burons, on a line connecting Gorey pier-head and Horn rock beacon, but 3| cables inside the latter. The Tres Grunes lie 2 cables outside and eastward of the Equerriere rock, and are awash at low water. Little Seymour beacon on with Seymour tower S. by W. £ W. leads 150 yards eastward, but passes over a 25-feet rock just outside them, which See chart, No. 62 a.

Chap. VI.] GOREY.— DIRECTIONS.— BANC DU CHATEAU. 271 rock is the extreme end of the ledge, the water being deep close up to it. To clear this outer rock when passing the Tres Grunes in a large vessel, Little Seymour beacon should be kept perceptibly open west ward of Seymour tower. Northward about 1£ cables from the Tres Grunes is the Pacquet rock with 2 feet water ; within and north-westward of which, at about the same distance, are the Arches rocks, a small group which dry 14 and 15 feet, the south-eastern rock being marked by a spar buoy. Northward of these again, and within 3 or 4 cables of Mont Orgueil, are the Grand Houmet, Le Mont, Seven Grunes to be pre sently described, and many other rocks, the ground here being very foul. Directions. — To enter the Inner road or Gorey harbour, three channels are available according to state of tide. For the southern channel, the leading mark by day is the red lantern of the high light on with the pier-head N.W., and by night, the two lights in line. For the middle channel, the northern end of the white house at the top of Hard way on with the pier-head N.W. by W. f W. leads between the Equerriere and Ecureuil rocks up to the Government mooring buoy in the Inner road. For the northern channel, the leading mark is the chimneys of Fort William on with the pier-head W. \ S. southerly ; as this leads close past the Arches rocks, it will be well to open the chimneys a little southward of the pier-head before the Equerriere and Ecureuil beacons are in line. If entering the harbour, having approached it by either of these channels, run up to the entrance, passing on either side of the Azicot spar buoy, but leaving both the warping buoys near the pier-head on the port hand in rounding it, and be careful not to approach the pier too closely, as the tide sets round it to the eastward with great strength after half flood, at springs. When the Horn rock is awash, there are 10 feet water just off the end of Gorey pier and 5 feet at the outer berth alongside it. BANC du CHATEAU. — This extensive bank of sand, gravel, and shells, lies off Grouville bay nearly parallel with the low water line of the shore and distant from it rather more than a mile, except at its northern end which approaches Mont Orgueil within 1\ cables ; it forms a great natural protection to the anchorage in Gorey roads. Set chart, No. 62 a.

272 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. Within the 5-fathoms line, the bank is rather more than 2 miles long by 4 cables wide ; the main body has a general depth of 2\ to 3 fathoms, gravel bottom ; from this base rise numerous narrow sandy ridges extending across the bank in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction. Near the middle, for about a mile, these ridges are so close together as to form almost one continuous bank, and have accordingly been named the Middle bank. At very low tides, parts of these ridges occasionally dry. The North ridge is nearly 4 cables within the northern end of the Bane du Chateau, and has from 10 to 12 feet water ; just south ward of it is a smaller ridge with as little as 4 feet. The South ridge, with from 12 to 16 feet water, forms the south-western and southern edge of the bank close to deep water. The Bane du Chateau is much affected by the weather and by the action of the tidal streams ; the upper part, within a limited space, is continually shifting, and during westerly winds the ridges of the sand-banks are so sharp that, when awash, a boat may easily knock them down in passing over. At such times the banks are about 4 feet higher than with westerly winds. Clearing marks. — Grouville mill, which stands on the high land south-westward of Grouville church but has no sweeps, on with the southern side of Mont Orgueil bluff W.S.W., clears the 5-fathoms line at the northern end of the bank. Icho tower and Little Seymour beacon in line W. by S. \ S. lead close past its southern end. Coupe turret on with the breakwater house under Verclut bluff N. by W. clears the north-western corner and leads down its western side nearly in mid-channel ; and, Coupe turret on with St. Catherine's breakwater lighthouse N.N.W. 4 W. leads east ward of the bank as well as of a rocky 5-fathoms patch outside, but westward of the West Tongue sands. Tongue sands are two small shoal banks nearly 1 and 2 miles respectively eastward of the South ridge of the Bane du Chateau, but separated from it and from each other by good clear channels. They are of the same character as the Bane du Chateau, having sharp ridges of fine sand. The least water on the eastern bank is 36 feet, and on the western bank 23 feet. Set chart, No. 62 a.

Chap. VI.] GROUVILLE BAY.— ANCHORAGE.— DIRECTIONS. 273 From the 23-f eet ridge,|Coupe turret open eastward of St. Catherine's lighthouse bears N.N.W. § W. ; and, Icho tower is a little open northward of Little Seymour beacon. Anchorage. — Between the western side of the Bane du Chateau and the 5-fathoms line fronting Grouville bay is the Outer road, a safe anchorage and large enough to accommodate several vessels of deep draught, it being a mile long North and South by 4| cables wide. The eastern limit is marked by Coupe turret being on with the breakwater house at Verclut bluff, and its western limit by St. Catherine and Archirondel towers in line. At its northern extreme, Gorey pier-head is open southward of the Equerriere beacon ; and, at its southern end, No. 4 martello tower and the Horn rock beacon are in line W. \ N. The space included within these lines has a depth of from 6 to 8 fathoms with an even bottom of gravel and shells, and the best line on which to anchor is with Grouville spire on with Fort Henry. The Inner road is within the 5-fathoms line of Grouville bay, between the Road and Inner road rocks, and between the Equerriere beacon and the Burons rocks. In-shore of this space is the Government mooring buoy, as already described. The best line on which to anchor in the Inner road is, with Prince's tower open northward of Fort William the apparent breadth of the latter. The anchorage in Gorey roads is the only place in the Channel islands, or on the French coast from St. Malo to Cherbourg, where a squadron of heavy ships might find good shelter in a westerly or north-westerly gale ; and, with proper charts and sailing directions, the approach is sufficiently easy for any seaman, in clear weather, to take his ship in without the aid of a pilot. DIRECTIONS.— Grouville bay.— The approach to Grouville bay from the direction of the Violet channel has been already given, see page 266. When running for this bay from the northward, and having cleared the Pierres de Lecq, the Drouilles, and other dangers near the northern end of Jersey by the directions hereafter given, see pages 288-289 ; avoid the foul ground off Nez du Guet and Coupe point by giving each a berth of at least 3 cables in rounding them. Belle Hougue bluff open northward of Tour de Rozel point N.W. \ W. leads outside the dangers off Coupe point and See ohart. No. 62 a.

274 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. 6 cables northward of the Pillon rock off Verclut breakwater ; La Roque No. 1 martello tower on with the Equerriere beacon S.W. \ S, southerly, or Seymour tower and Little Seymour beacon in line, leads eastward of them but over the Fara ledge of 21 feet. The North channel into Gorey road is between Fara ledge and the northern end of the Bane du Chateau, and is there only 2\ cables wide between the 5-fathom lines, with a depth of 6 fathoms in mid-channel, but it has a depth of 4 fathoms for a width of 4 cables and is therefore perfectly safe for large ships. Entering this channel from the northward, keep Belle Hougue bluff open of Tour de Rozel point until Little Seymour beacon is just open westward of Seymour tower, which mark leads inside the Bane du Chateau up to the anchorage. At any time after the first quarter flood, the deepest ships may enter the North channel either with the mark just given or with No. 1 martello tower at La Roque point on with the Equerriere beacon, passing over the Fara ledge ; the former has the great advantage for long ships of making much less abrupt the turn to the leading mark through the Outer road, Coupe mound open of Verclut bluff. To anchor as near the shore as possible, Coupe turret may be shut in a little over Verclut point ; but, Little Seymour beacon should be kept perceptibly open westward of Seymour tower until Fort William is open southward of the Equerriere beacon in order to clear the Tres Grunes, or until the best anchoring lines, already given, are approached, when anchor as convenient. The South Channel is between the shore reefs on the western side, and the southern end of the Bane du Chateau and reefs north ward of the Anquettes on the eastern side, and, as the narrows are reached, between the Giffard rock and the South ridge of the Bane du Chateau, where it is only 3^ cables wide. The water is deep throughout, there being not less than 8 fathoms in mid-channel at the lowest tides. Approaching this channel from the northward, to clear a rocky bank of 32 feet outside the Bane du Chateau, keep Coupe turret outside St. Catherine's lighthouse until Prince's tower comes on with Gorey pier-head, after which the turret may be brought inside the lighthouse as far as the outer arches of the breakwater ; and, when See chart, No. 62 a.

Chap. VI.] GROUVILLE BAY.— DIRECTIONS. 275 Icho tower opens southward of Little Seymour beacon, haul in round the southern end of the bank. Rozel mill over Crete bluff clears the inside part of the South ridge ; but the leading mark which clears the Giffard rock by 1£ cables is, Gorey spire on with the white patch on Gorey pier-head N.W. \ N. until Coupe mound opens of Verclut bluff, with which mark run up to the anchorage in the Outer road, anchoring as before directed. A large vessel working into the Outer road through the South channel should not open Icho tower southward of Seymour tower until Coupe turret is westward of the middle of St. Catherine's breakwater, in order to clear the Stony banks, of 25 feet least water, northward of the Petite Anquette. From Grouville bay to the South-eastward.— Bring Gorey spire open a little westward of the white patch at Gorey pier head N.W. \ N., and run out until Icho tower is midway between Seymour tower and Little Seymour beacon about W. \ S. ; haul out to the eastward on this line until Coupe turret opens eastward of St. Catherine's lighthouse, which mark leads clear of all danger off the Anquettes. To the Southward through the Bœuf channel.— After clearing the Anquettes as described, bring Coupe turret on with St. Catherine's lighthouse N.N.W. \ W., and, with this mark on, steer to the southward. As the line of Icho and Noirmont towers in one is approached, Coupe turret may be brought a little westward of the lighthouse ; and, when southward of this line and clear of the Grande Arconie, Coupe turret should be brought westward of the lighthouse at least one third the distance to Verclut point, to clear the western side of the Basse Occidentale des Bœufs ; from whence, if bound for Granville, the same mark on astern and a S.S.E. course lead past the Basse le Marie bell-buoy and up to the leading marks for the Cotentin channel, see pages 214-218 ; or, if bound westward, a S.S.W. course leads to the channels between the Southern Anquettes, see page 266, which banks may be always known and avoided by the tide ripples over them, and when La Moye white Semaphore house opens of Le Fret point N.W. \ W., the gravel banks are passed and a vessel may haul to the westward. In passing through this channel, it should be remembered that See charts, Nos. 62 a, and 2,669 b.

[Chap. VI. 276 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. Coupe turret touching the outer part of St. Catherine's lighthouse leads over the Anquette north-eastern patch, and also over the Basse Occidentale des Bœufs. A small vessel bound southward from Gorey on the flood, may pass inside Grune Le Feuvre and the Anquette north-eastern patch by bringing St. Martin's spire open northward of the white patch on the northern side of Mont Orgueil castle, at least the width of the patch, N.W. by N. At or before half flood, a small vessel may also pass between the plateau de la Frouquie and the plateau de l'Arconie by keeping Coupe turret on with the breakwater house at Verclut point N. by W. until La Moye white Semaphore house is on with Le Fret point N.W. W., when she may haul to the westward. Approaching the Bœuf channel from the southward, if the marks on Jersey are indistinct, Mont Huchon, on the French coast, on with the sandy point of Blainville river entrance E. by S. \ S., or Coutances cathedral on with the southern end of Blainville village and well open southward of Blainville church S.E. by E. | E., lead up until they can be made out. It is, however, generally difficult and often impossible to distin guish the marks for this channel owing to their distance ; a vessel of deep draught should therefore only attempt it in charge of an experienced pilot and during the upper half of the tide ; nor should square-rigged vessels ever attempt to work through except under such conditions. From Grouville bay through the Violet channel.— Run out as before with Gorey spire open westward of the white patch on the pier-head N.W. \ N. until the northern side of Gros Etac rock is on with Little Seymour beacon W. by S. | S. The vessel is then abreast of the Giffard rock, and Coupe turret a little open of Verclut point becomes the leading mark with which to enter the Violet channel ; and, when approaching the narrows, be particular that Coupe turret is only just open eastward of the break water house at Verclut point. As a check, it is useful to know that if any part of St. Catherine's white martello tower shows eastward of Archirondel red tower you are quite far enough to the eastward. Another good mark for the middle of the channel, when abreast of the Petit Four, is Rozel mill touching the northern side of Mont Orgueil castle N. by W. § W. See chart, No. 62 a.

Chap. VI.] DIRECTIONS.— ANNE PORT AND ST. CATHERINE BAYS. 277 When abreast of the Petit Four, Karame rock is just shut in with the high land above Noirmont point ; and Grande Anquette beacomturret is open northward of the Petite Anquette. From this position, haul to the southward to bring Coupe mound open of Verclut point and use it for the leading mark ; or, if the Rousse Platte rock is uncovered, steer direct for it on a S.W. bearing until Grande Anquette beacon turret bears E. \ N. In either case, steer westward with the Anquette beacon turret on that bearing until Icho tower is on with the Conchiere rock, when the vessel is clear of the Route en Ville reefs and may steer to pass 3 or 4 cables southward of the Conchiere rock. ANNE PORT BAY, between Grouville and St. Catherine bays, is small, and outlying rocks render the approach to it dangerous ; there is, however, good anchorage off it, occasionally used by fishing boats and other small craft in fine weather. The principal dangers are, on the southern side, the Seven Grunes, and, on the northern side, the Cloches rocks. Between these reefs is the anchorage ; it is 2\ cables in extent North and South, has an even depth of \\ or 5 fathoms, and is sheltered from the tide. The Seven Grunes, form a long straggling reef extending 2>\ cables eastward from the Grosse Moie ; the highest rock, near the middle of the reef, uncovers 7 feet, and the outer Grune, called Le Mont, has 5 feet water over it. The Cloches rocks extend in an E. by S. direction 5^ cables from Crete point to a rock with only one foot water ; they are the southern rocks of the Fara or St. Catherine's bank and several heads in-shore of the one-foot rock dry from one to 5 feet. ST. CATHERINE'S BAY, on the eastern shore of Jersey northward of Mont Orgueil castle, though much encumbered by rocks, affords excellent anchorage for small craft in 2 or 3 fathoms water, with a bottom of muddy sand covered with very long grass and seaweed ; it is difficult, however, for a sailing vessel to enter or leave except with a leading wind. The bay is completely sheltered from northerly, westerly, and south-westerly winds ; but, south easterly and easterly winds blow right in and, near high water, cause a short turbulent chopping sea ; as the tide falls, however, the sea subsides. Sea ohart. No. 61 a.

278 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. A harbour of refuge was begun in this bay in the year 1847. The northern pier or breakwater was completed in 1855, and extends 826 yards S.E. from Verclut point, the northern extreme of the bay, and over the rocky bed formerly called the Pierre Mouillee ; it has a depth of 5 fathoms at its outer end at low water, and on the pier-head stands the lighthouse. The pier has a lofty parapet, and, alongside it, a steam-vessel of large size might coal, water, and land or embark troops, with any wind from N.N.E. round by West to S.W. The southern breakwater was designed to extend in an easterly direction from the point near Archirondel tower across the Fara reef. Of this, however, only about 200 yards has been built, and the work discontinued. Should the southern pier ever be completed and a harbour formed it might prove useful in bringing Jersey into closer commercial relations with France ; but, from the great strength of the tides across the entrance of the bay, and from the dangerous rocks near, it is now difficult of access to sailing vessels in bad weather, and only fit for ordinary use by steam-vessels. LIGHT. — A white octagonal iron lighthouse, 30 feet high from base to vane, stands on the outer extreme of the parapet wall of Verclut breakwater. It exhibits a. fixed white light of the fifth order at 60 feet above the level of high water, visible in clear weather from 10 to 12 miles. DANGERS off and in ST. CATHERINE'S BAY —The approach to St. Catherine's bay from the South-east is completely barred by St. Catherine or Fara bank, a large bed of rocks about half a mile square, of which the outer part extends 8 cables eastward of Archirondel tower. The rocks begin to uncover about the last quarter ebb, many show at low water but by far the greater number never dry. Beacon. — On the southern edge of the bank are the Cloches, already described ; on the eastern side, the Fara rock, about 100 yards wide, which dries 9 feet and, with a pole beacon in its centre, is the most conspicuous rock ; also, on the eastern side, the Grune du Nord which dries one foot ; and within, on the North-west and North, the Basses de Fara, and the Etot rock which dries 10 feet. See chart, No. 62 a.

Chap. VI.] ST. CATHERINE'S BAY.— DANGERS.— ANCHORAGE. 279 Fara ledge, about 3 cables south-eastward of the Fara beacon, is a rocky bank about a cable in length E.S.E. and W.N.W., rather more than half that width, and about the same distance detached from a depth of 2 feet on the edge of St. Catherine's bank. The least known depth is 21 feet near its eastern end, but there may be a foot or two less. No. 2 martello tower in Grouville bay and the Equerriere beacon in line S.W. -} S. just clears the south-eastern side ; and, Little Seymour beacon on with Seymour tower leads over its western end in 23 feet. This latter mark also leads over the outer part of St. Catherine's bank, northward of the Fara ledge, in 28 feet but close to a 17-feet patch ; Coupe turret on with St. Catherine's lighthouse N.N.W. £ W., or a little open eastward of it, leads outside the Fara ledge and reef up to the lighthouse, leaving the Eureka and Pillon rocks on the starboard hand. Eureka rock, with 12 feet water, lies 2\ cables from the light house, with the northern side of the breakwater slightly open, and No. 4 martello tower just shut in with Mont Orgueil point. The Pillon rock has only 4 feet water ; it bears due North 1J cables from the Eureka rock, and is 2 cables from the breakwater end. From the rock, St. Martin's spire is on with the lighthouse ; and, No. 3 martello tower is just shut in with Mont Orgueil point. Within St. Catherine's bay, in line between the lighthouse and Archirondel tower and nearly 2 cables from the lighthouse, is a rock with only 8 feet water ; Le Graveur, another rock with only 7 feet, lies northward of a line drawn from the lighthouse to St. Catherine's martello tower, with Coupe turret just showing over Verclut point. Caution. — During spring +ides, the stream sets with great velocity over St. Catherine's bank into the bay and also round the end of the breakwater, for which due allowance must be made in entering or leaving the bay. Anchorage. — There is barely room for one large ship to anchor in St. Catherine's bay. The best berth is in 5 fathoms water about a cable distant from the breakwater and 1^ cables westward from the lighthouse. Small vessels may anchor farther up the bay in 2 fathoms, with St. Martin's spire on with the southern extreme of the bluff north ward of St. Catherine's martello tower W. by N.| N. ; and, Seymour See chart, No. 62 a. S S 0 11886

[Chap. VI. 280 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. tower on with Grosse Moie S. | W. One cable in-shore of this, there is only one fathom, and the same distance off-shore 3| fathoms. The bottom is a mixture of fine sand and mud throughout. Directions.— From Grouville to St. Catherine's bay- Run out from Gorey Inner road with Prince's tower open north ward of Fort William until Little Seymour beacon is just westward of Seymour tower, which mark clears the Tres Grunes and foul ground outside them ; having passed these, bring Little Seymour beacon and Seymour tower exactly in line to pass over Fara ledge, in 23 feet ; or, No. 2 tower a little open south-eastward of Equerriere beacon to pass outside Fara ledge. With Coupe turret on with St. Catherine's lighthouse, a vessel is clear of all the rocks of St. Catherine's bank, and may steer for the lighthouse, hauling into the bay, when a cable distant from it, with St. Martin's spire nearly shut in over the bluff northward of St. Catherine's martello tower for a leading mark, and anchoring as convenient by the marks just given. There is another passage into this bay from the southward between the Cloches and Crete point which, though much encumbered by rocks nearly awash at low water, may be useful occasionally to small craft with pilots. A very useful mark for this small channel during the lower part of the tide is, St. Catherine's martello tower on with the eastern side of Little Fara rock to clear Le Mont, the outer rock of the Seven Grunes ; and, having passed that danger, open the tower a little inside the Little Fara before passing Crete point, to clear the rocks along the inner part of St. Catherine's bank. A vessel may pass close inside the Little Fara in 9 feet at low water, ordinary springs. Coupe point is a bluff about 180 feet high, and so named from its being connected with the neighbouring land by a narrow neck of little more than half that height. On the summit of the bluff is a ruined guard-house surmounted by a stone sentry box or turret, a conspicious and very useful mark, known as Coupe turret, to which frequent reference is made. An extensive range of farm buildings stands near the edge of the plateau southward of and overlooking the Coupe ; two high rocks lie half a cable outside the bluff, from which a dangerous reef extends 2 cables eastward. See chart, No. 62 b.

Chap. VI.] DIRECTIONS.— PLIQUET BAY.— ANCHORAGE. 281 FLIQUET BAY is between Verclut and Coupe points, and affords good shelter from south-westerly winds, but is quite exposed to those from South round by East and North to W.N.W. As Gorey road affords indifferent shelter with southerly winds, vessels bound to Gorey harbour, during strong winds from that quarter and not able to save their tide in, may anchor under shelter of the breakwater until two hours flood, when they will still have sufficient southerly tide to enable them to reach the road by the time there is water enough to enter the harbour. No vessel, however, should anchor in this bay with the intention of remaining longer than a tide, for a shift of wind to S.E. or N.E. would place her in a dangerous position. The bottom is hard sand, free from any foul ground except the Brayes, a small group of rocks which dry and extend If cables from Coupe point ; and, the Coupe rock, with 10 feet water, S.E. by E. | E. 4^ cables from Coupe turret, and North a little westerly 5f cables from St. Catherine's lighthouse. The white patch in the centre of the northern side of the breakwater on with Mont Orgueil castle leads outside the Coupe rock. Telegraph cable. — The telegraph cable between Jersey and France is laid in a S.E. by E. E. direction from Fliquet bay to Pirou on the French coast, see page 194. The shore end in Jersey is at the white martello tower in Fliquet bayr, on which is painted in black letters the word Telegraph, surmounted by a green disc. To prevent damage to the cable, or loss of anchors, grapnels, or dredges, by the fishermen, the following directions are given : — The course of the cable is distinctly indicated by the two towers, which are a sufficient guide during the day for clearing it. Fishing-boats without a compass may avoid it on the South by not opening the Tour de Rozel northward of Coupe point ; and, on the North, by not shutting in the guard-house in Bouley bay with the Tour de Rozel. Anchorage. — From the northward, Seymour house, on the hill northward of Gorey, on with or a little eastward of the breakwater house under Verclut point S.S.W. leads between the Brayes and Coupe rock ; and, from the eastward, Rozel mill or with Fliquet telegraph tower, W. by N. J N., leads between the Pillon and Coupe rocks. The best anchorage, with southerly or south-westerly winds, is in about 6 fathoms midway between the breakwater and the Coupe rock, with Nez du Guet and Coupe point in line N.W. ; and, See charts, Nos. 62 a and b.
