Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Alderney harbour at 6 h. 46 m. ; mean springs rise 17^ feet ; neaps, 12| feet ; neaps range 8 feet.- See plan, No. 2,845.

372 [Chap. VIII. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — ALDERNEY. Braye Harbour, within Alderney harbour, is formed by a, sheltering pier projecting in an easterly direction .from the western side of Braye bay ; it dries at low water, neaps, and is very inferior to the little harbour of Craby. The best time to enter Braye harbour is on a rising tide between half flood and high water ; at low water, ordinary springs, there are from 6 to 8 feet water between the iron beacons placed one on either side of the entrance on the two rocky masses just outside the pier head. The western beacon has a circular eye on the top ; the eastern one, a cross. No leading mark is required, but the pier-head should be rounded as closely as possible. Craby harbour, also within Alderney harbour, was constructed by the Government in 1850, in the creek between Braye harbour and Grosnez point. In addition to the shelter of the breakwater, this harbour is protected by two small piers having an entrance between the pier-heads 40 feet wide and open to the North-east. This harbour is 100 yards long from West to East, and 90 yards wide ; it affords 230 yards of quay frontage, sufficient to berth four colliers of about 150 tons burthen ; it dries out to the pier-heads at low water, springs, and at half tide there are 9 feet between the pier-heads. DIRECTIONS.— From the north-eastward, in hazy weather, it is prudent to obtain a bearing of cape de la Hague, when a vessel may stand boldly for the north-eastern end of the island ; but, to avoid the outlying rocks, should the weather be so thick that land cannot be discerned at the distance of 2 miles, neither the cape nor the island should be approached within that distance. When nearing either the cape or the island, the tides must be care fully considered, especially during the south-western stream, as it sets strongly over the Blanchard and Brinchetaie ledge ; and, it may be useful to note that on nearing the eastern end of Alderney, the great Coque Lihou rock open south-eastward of the island keeps a vessel in the stream of the Race, and the Casquets light open north ward of Burhou island keeps her in the Swinge or Channel stream. See also page 388 for approaching the harbour entrance when coming from the south-westward round the eastern end of the island. In clear weather, a vessel may stand direct for the island. The leading mark into the harbour can then be seen 5 or 6 miles distant ; it is, the tower of St. Anne's church on with the pier-head -Seel plan, No. 2,845.

373 Chap. VIIL] HARBOUR. — DIRECTIONS.— CAUTION. of Braye harbour -S.W. £ W. ; and, to clear the outer end of the submerged portion of the breakwater, vessels from the northward or westward rounding the breakwater must be careful to keep the beacon on King's battery wall well open eastward of the Hornet des Pies beacon until the leading mark for the harbour comes on. CAUTION. — It is- necessary to repeat, and the special attention of the mariner is drawn to the fact, that the present visible end of the breakwater terminates so abruptly as to resemble the original finished end. Vessels unaware of the destruction of the outer end of the breakwater, and rounding it without paying strict attention to the marks and directions given, run the risk of almost certain destruction on the submerged portion, which extends 642 yards beyond the present visible end. The strength of the west-going stream, especially at springs, also sets directly on the submerged end for about 9 hours out of 12, which is an additional reason for the closest attention being given to the leading marks. It need scarcely be added that a vessel should be always ready for anchoring promptly in case of necessity. .See also Tidal streams, page 383. When the eastern stream is running, the submerged end of the breakwater may be safely passed by keeping the beacon on King's battery wall on with the beacon on Hornet des Pies. By night, on account of the strength of the tides in this neigh bourhood, no vessel should enter unless in charge of a pilot or of some person with good local knowledge. The leading mark is, the harbour red lights in line bearing S.W. f W. ; run in on this line, making careful allowance for the set of the tidal stream across the entrance. From the northward and westward, do not bring the Casquets light northward of West until the harbour lights are in line. and, on approaching the harbour, be very particular to have them exactly in line before shutting in the Casquets light with Burhou island, when a vessel will be close up to the submerged end of the breakwater. Near high or low water, springs, the stream sets across the entrance of the harbour with great velocity, and great caution is then necessary in entering. To ensure avoiding the rocky patches outside the Aiguillons on the one side, and the toe of the breakwater on the other, the bearing of the upper light should on no account be altered more than a quarter of a point on either side, and the lower light never lost sight of. Seetpla.n, No. 2,845 ; and chart, No. 60.

374 [Chap. VIII. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — ALDERNEY. If not desirous of using the Government moorings, anchor in about 5 fathoms, with the high light open northward of the low one. DANGERS N.W. and NORTH of ALDERNEY.— The outer dangers along this shore have been included in the description of the Swinge channel, see page 364, &c. ; those nearer the shore are the following : — The Etacs, the most remarkable of all the rocks near the western end of the island, with their off-lying shoals, form the southern boundary of the Swinge channel. They consist of a group of four ; the highest is 128 feet above high water ; the centre of the group is 2 cables from the shore off the western end of Alderney. The Boues des Etacs extend W.N.W. If cables from the outer Etac ; their north-western head has only one foot water. The eastern end of the outer Noire Pute on with the western end of the Coupe leads 100 yards westward of them ; and, the northern or low part of Tourgis fort on with the southern part of Clonque fort leads the same distance northward. The Clonques are three high rocks attached to the western shore of Alderney by a rocky ridge uncovered at low water ; on this ridge, there has been constructed a roadway to communicate with Clonque fort, which fort stands on the two rocks nearest the land. A wooden beacon stands in the rear of the fort, on the south-eastern head of the Clonque. Platte Boue, Founiais, and Ozard rock, are off the Clonques on about a W. \ S. line of bearing from the fort ; the Platte Boue is close to the main reef ; the Founiais, which dries 6 feet, nearly 2 cables from the fort ; and, Ozard rock, on which there are 4 feet water, nearly 3 cables from it. Ozard rock is very small ; from it, the western end of the highest Noire Pute just open eastward and clear of the inner rock of the Etacs bears S. f E. easterly ; and, Tourgis beacon is on with the northern tangent of Clonque fort. Queruelles rocks. — The outer edge of this reef bears N.N.W. \ W. 2\ cables from Clonque fort, and is 1^ cables southward of the Barsier reef, already described, with from 4 to 8 fathoms water between them. The Queruelles dry 8 feet at low water, springs. See chart, No. 60.

Chap. VIII.] DANGERS N.W., NORTH, AND N.E. OF ALDERNEY. 375 Caution. — There is no safe passage inside the Queruelles and Barsier reefs, even for boats, and the first of the flood sets right on them ; at this time, therefore, a wide berth should be given them in passing. The Grosse rock, large and prominent, 14 feet above high water, springs, and steep-to, may be approached within half a cable. It lies E. \ S. 4 cables from the Corbet ; and, North 2 cables from Tourgis point. The Jumelles are two small ridges of rock which uncover at half tide East 1\ cables from the Corbet, and 3 cables from the shore of Plate Saline bay. Braye rocks are a group of four heads, ot which the outermost seldom covers though awash at high water, springs ; the three others, named the Follets, show at half tide. The outer Braye lies N.E. \ E. 2| cables from the outer angle of Grosnez fort and a cable from the breakwater. A rock with only 3| feet water lies E.N.E. 65 yards from the outer Braye. DANGERS N.E. OF ALDERNEY.— The principal dangers on the north-eastern side of Alderney besides the sunken rocks north-eastward of the Aiguillons, included in the description of Alderney harbour, see page 371, are the Grois, the Platte, the Ledge, and the Sauquet. Grois ledge is an extensive and dangerous reef off Etoc point ; it extends 2\ cables between the bearings N. by E. and N.E. from the tower of the Chateau de l'Etoc on that point, which fort should not be approached on these bearings within 5 cables. The Outer Grois, a peaked rock, and the highest of the reef, is awash at high water, springs, and bears N. by E. \ E. 2\ cables from the flagstaff of the fort. Several heads show at half tide, and many more at low water. The stream rushes over this reef with great velocity. The depth is 13 feet at l-\ cables W.N.W. of the Outer Grois ; and the Boues briees, awash at low water, are 1\ cables eastward of that rock. The Ortac rock and Noir Houmet in line and well open of the breakwater W. N. leads 100 yards northward of these ledges ; and Bon-Ami, the high rock on the eastern side of Corblets bay, on with the look-out tower above the Mannez quarries S. | E. leads 100 yards eastward of the Boues briees. See chart, No. 60. SO 11886 2 A

[Chap. VIII. 376 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — ALDERNEY. Platte rock, S.E. by E. 3£ cables from the Outer Grois, un covers 5 feet. From it, the Ortac is just open northward of Etoc point ; and, the summit of Bon-Ami rock bears S.W. -J S. 1J cables. The ground between the Platte and the outer extreme of the Grois reefs is foul and should not be approached by any vessel. The Ledge, or Fosse de la Bande, is a reef of considerable extent, with 13 feet water. It bears E. § S. 6^ cables from the Outer Grois rock, with that rock and the Ortac in line ; and, the brick kilns, eastward of St. Anne, on with the north-western tangent of Corblets fort S.W. by W. westerly. The long western mark to clear the dangers off the north-eastern shore of Alderney is, the Casquet towers open northward of Burhou island W. § N. Sauquet rock, 2 cables southward of the Ledge and H cables north-eastward of Homeaux Florains reef, on which is a small fort, uncovers 3 feet at low water, springs, with the tower of the Chateau de l'Etoc on with the Ortac rock. Great Nannel on with the Outer Grois rock W. by N. | N. leads just northward of it ; and the north eastern point of Burhou island in line with the Outer Grois leads between the Ledge and the Sauquet. Tidal Stream. — The south-western stream running down towards Alderney divides in the vicinity of the Sauquet rock, one part running through the Race of Alderney, the other through the Swinge; its tendency is to throw vessels near the Sauquet rock right on it. A berth should therefore be given it of 3 or 4 cables. DANGERS E. and S.E. of ALDERNEY— The principal dangers off the eastern side of the island are the Brinchetaie ledge, the Boufresses, and the Blanchard ; and, south-eastward of port Longy, the Race and Inner Race rocks and other rocky patches. The Brinchetaie is a dangerous group of rocks forming a ledge extending south-eastward from Houmet Herbe, off the eastern point of Alderney. The outer tidal rock is 3 cables from the shore and uncovers 11 feet ; the inner rock uncovers 16 feet. Several shoals, awash at low water, equinoctial springs, extend south-eastward of these rocks nearly 4 cables from the shore. Raz island flagstaff on with the southern extreme of Essex castle ; or, the high Noire Pute, &<"chart. No. 60.

Chap. VIII.] DANGERS EAST AND S.E. OF ALDERNEY. 377 inner Coque Lihou, and southern side of the Etac de la Quoire in line bearing W. by S. southerly, lead southward of the Brinchetaie ; and, the outer tangent of Quenard fort on with the inner tangent of Homeaux Florains fort leads eastward. Boufresses reef is nearly 4 cables westward of the Brinchetaie and closer in-shore, its outer end being If cables eastward of Raz island fort ; it uncovers to a considerable extent at low water. Raz island flagstaff on with the middle of Essex castle leads southward. Blanchard bank and rock. — Blanchard bank is composed of rock, gravel, granite stones, and shells. At its western extreme. which bears E. by S. 6 cables from Houmet Herbe fort, there is a mass of rock with only 2| fathoms water ; from thence, the bank extends If cables in the same direction to the Blanchard rock, with only 12 feet water, which lies at the eastern edge of the bank 1\ cables from Houmet Herbe. Between its western end and the rocks nearer the shore off the eastern end of the island, there are from 9 to 12 fathoms water. The Blanchard is very dangerous, especially at its eastern extreme, which rises quite suddenly from depths of 20 and 25 fathoms, causing, during springs, eddies and a heavy sea on a weather tide. .- Race and Inner Race rocks. — Three unconnected rocky patches lie south-eastward of Longy bay, stretching off from the tails of the Brinchetaie and Blanchard at the several distances of 4£ cables. 9 cables, and 1 \ miles from the latter. On the Race and Inner Race rocks, the two outermost, there are only 18 feet water, and 4^ fathoms on the patch nearest the Blanchard, which bears no special name. From the Race rock, the old telegraph tower is thrice its own length open southward of the Etac de la Quoire ; and, Doyle's column, Guernsey, is nearly on with the Grande Amfroque, a very distant mark only to be distinguished in the clearest weather. From the Inner Race rock, St. Anne's mill is twice its own length open southward of the Rousset rock ; and, from the northern patch, St. Anne's mill is on with the southern angle of Essex fort. Clearing marks. — To pass southward of the Brinchetaie, Boufresses, and Blanchard rock, and northward of the Race and Inner Race rocks and of the 4|-fathoms rocky patch, keep the high Noire Pute, inner Coque Lihou, and southern base of the Etac de la See chart, No. 60, S 0 11886 2 A2

[Chap. VIII. 378 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — ALDERNEY. Quoire in line W. by S. southerly. To pass northward of the Blanchard, the mark is, Outer Grois rock on with the Great Nannel W. by N. | N. ; or, if near high water when the Outer Grois is not easily distinguished, the north-eastern extreme of Chateau de l'Etoc just open northward of the Homeaux Florains. Doyle's column just open northward of the northernmost bluff land on Herm S.W. by W. W. leads well southward of all these rocks, as does also cape de la Hague lighthouse kept bearing northward of East, or Casquets lighthouse in sight southward of Alderney. SOUTH COAST OF ALDERNEY. — Longy bay, or Baie du Catel, is on the south-eastern side of Alderney ; it has only about 12 feet in it at high water, springs, and dries at low water, neaps ; it affords but little shelter and is seldom used. The entrance is between Raz island, on which there is a fort, and the Queslingue rock. The distance between these points is less than 2 cables, and this small space is divided into two entrances of equal width by a rock in the centre, which dries 2 feet ; moreover, both tidal streams set with great strength across the entrance, therefore no stranger should attempt to enter unless compelled to do so, when the following directions should be observed. Directions. — The most favourable winds for entering Longy bay are those between N.W. and S.W., and the best time is between 2 and 5 hours ebb ; a vessel may then run aground, and on the succeed ing tide she may be hauled up under Essex nunnery on the sandy beach at the western side of the bay. The leading mark in with these winds is, the Nunnery just shut in by the land westward of Queslingue rock N. £ E. until near the rock ; then, by rounding its rocky point within half a cable, the fairway sunken rock in the entrance is avoided. Anchorage. — Off Longy bay, anchorage at 1^ cables off-shore, affording shelter from northerly and north-westerly winds, may be found in 9 fathoms, sand, gravel, and shells, with the whole of Fort Albert just shut in with, and seen over, the western point of Longy bay N. by W. | W,; and, the Grande Folie rocky peak just open eastward of Raz island fort N.E. f N. A better anchorage, farther westward and more out of the tide, is in 7 or 8 fathoms off Tchue bay, 1| cables westward of the Rousset rock, with the western side of Raz fort touching the eastern side of Queslingue rock. See chart, No. 60,

Chap. VIII.] SOUTH COAST.— ANCHORAGES— DASGERS, 379 The Roque Pendante is a remarkable overhanging rock on the summit of the bluff within the Rousset rock and south- westward of Essex castle ; it may be seen from a distance of 9 or 10 miles on an easterly or westerly bearing, but on altering the bearing on either side it soon shuts in with the land and can only be distinguished from a very short distance.* Queslingue and Rousset rocks are high and peaked ; they are within 2 cables East and West of each other and close to the shore. The Etac de la Quoire is about 100 yards off-shore near the middle of the southern coast of the island, and is connected with it at low water. It is a conical rock, about 60 yards in diameter and 106 feet above high water, or 10 feet lower than the great Coque Lihou. Bonit rock bears S. by W. \ W. 4 cables from the Etac de la Quoire. This dangerous rock is of small extent and uncovers only at low water, springs, having from 10 to 14 fathoms close to. The marks for it are, the Grande Folie seen between the Rousset and Queslingue rocks N.E. \ E. ; and, the Etac de la Quoire on with a beacon on the adjoining shore N. by E. \ E., the latter mark leading rather on the eastern side of the rock. The Bonit may be avoided by not approaching Alderney nearer than a mile, by keeping the Casquets in sight southward of the island, or by keeping the inner Noire Pute open southward of the outer Coque Lihou. Noire Roque, which is 15 feet above high water, bears N.W. northerly 3^ cables from the Bonit and is 2 cables from the nearest shore ; it is exactly in line between the Etac de la Quoire and the great Coque Lihou ; it is steep-to all round, but has a 4-feet patch only a cable distant north-eastward, between it and the land. Alderney South banks extend from the Bonit rock in a south-westerly direction more than 1^ miles ; the general depth on the main bank is 15 fathoms, gravel, from which as a base there arise seven small sand-banks, one with as little as 6 fathoms water. These small banks have sharp ridges which lie in a N.E. and S.W. direction ; the largest is only 2 cables long. The shallow 6pots commence 5^ cables S.S.W. \ W. from the Bonit. A vessel from the eastward may pass inside them by keeping the Coupe rock a little open southward of the outer Coque Lihou, until the Grande Set chart, No. 60.

[Chap. VIII. 380 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— ALDERNEY. Folie opens westward of Queslingue rock ; and, outside them from the westward, by keeping the Verte-tete rock open westward of the outer Noire Pute N. by W. £ W. until Grande Folie is on with Raz island fort N.E. i N. By night, Casquets light bearing N.W. \ N. leads 5 cables south westward of the Pierre au Vraic, and oae mile clear of Alderney South banks. Cape de la Hague light kept bearing northward of East also leads southward of these banks, and as some of the heaviest overfalls in the Race are caused by them they must be carefully avoided in bad weather. Coque LihOU rocks are off the south-western end of Alderney, nearly a mile westward of the Etac de la Quoire, and 2\ cables from the shore. They consist of a group of three. The great Coque Lihou, the middle and easternmost, is much larger and higher than either of the others, being 116 feet above high water ; it bears S.S.E. \ E. easterly 6 cables from Alderney old telegraph tower. A bank of sand, extending 2| cables eastward from the great Coque Lihou, has on it as little as 1^ fathoms. It makes a convenient anchorage for fishing-boats and small craft in fine weather. There is a 5-fathoms channel inside the Coque Lihou rocks close to the Alderney shore ; it is only a cable wide and therefore not to be attempted by a stranger. Rocks awash at low water extend from the Coque Lihou rocks more than half way across to the Alderney shore ; and, a continuous sunken chain unites them to the Joyeux rocks, a scattered group extending W.N.W. about 5 cables from the Coque Lihou rocks and north-eastward from the Noires Putes. The Noires Putes are a group of rocks, four in number, three of which are always uncovered ; the two outer rocks are much larger and higher than the others ; these lie East and West from each other and are rather more than a cable apart. The western rock is flat-topped, and 55 feet above high water ; the eastern rock has a peak near its eastern end 76 feet high ; it bears S.W. by S. 1\ cables from the old telegraph tower. The inner Noire Pute is 24 feet above high water. The group is quite steep-to on the outside. The Aiguillons, Coupe, and Orbouee, three rocks respectively 18, 22, and 6 feet above high water, lie between the Noires Putes and the Etacs, in a W.S.W. direction from each other, the outer rock 5 cables distant from the south-western extreme of Alderney ; they See chart, No. 60.

Chap. VIII.] DANGERS.— WEST BAY.— TIDAL STREAMS. 381 form the southern boundary of the Fossee Malieres or West bay anchorage. The Coupe, the middle of the three, is sometimes called the Cocked hat, which it somewhat resembles in appearance ; it is one of the marks for the Pierre au Vraic. The Orbouee, the outer rock of the group, is awash at high water, equinoctial spring tides ; it is connected with the Coupe under water, is steep-to on the southern and western sides, but has a rock with only 2 fathoms water one cable N.W. by N. from it. Orbouee bank, extending S. by W. about 5 cables from the Orbouee rock, consists of gravel, sand, and broken shells ; its general depths are from 6 to 9 fathoms, but near its outer end there are only 3f fathoms. This part rises from the main bank in a narrow ridge of fine sand, very difficult to pick up, and thrown up apparently by the turning of the stream. From the shoalest spot, the Great Nannel is a little open westward of the outer rock of the Etacs ; and the Etac de la Quoire is on with the northern part of the outer Noire Pute. The bank may be cleared by keeping the Pierre de But open westward of the Etacs N. by E. \ E. until the Etac de la Quoire opens south-eastward of the Noire Putes. Anchorage. — West bay.— The best anchorage at the western end of Alderney is in the Fossee Malieres or West bay, in 9 or 10 fathoms, gravel, with the Great Nannel or with the Refuge on Burhou island touching the outer end of the Western Etac ; and, great Coque Lihou open clear inside the Aiguillons E.S.E., or the highest Noire Pute appearing midway between the Coupe and the Aiguillons. Here a vessel will lie out of the tide. There is also indifferent anchorage 2 or 3 cables S.S.W. from the Orbouee rock in 7 fathoms, but it is exposed to the full strength of the flood stream. TIDAL STREAMS.— The tidal streams round Alderney are subject to changes and variations very similar in character to those round Guernsey and Jersey, but with local peculiarities, arising principally from the more prominent position of Alderney on the edge of the true Channel stream, and also, in a great degree, from the different form of the island itself as compared with the others. At Alderney, as well as round Guernsey, the direction of the tidal stream revolves from East round by North to West and South, See chart, No. 60.

[Chap. VIII. 382 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — ALDERNEY. running from every point of the compass during one whole tide of ebb and flood. As at Guernsey, the stream attains its greatest strength about high and low water by the shore, but, as might be expected from the situation of Alderney, its direction at this time is different, coinciding more nearly with the Channel stream. Thus the strength of the stream, flood and ebb, on the northern side of Alderney and the Casquets, runs about E. \ N. and W. \ S. ; whilst round the Guernsey group, at the same time, its general direction is about E.N.E. and W.S.W. This change in direction may be considered as taking place on a line passing close northward of the Casquets, past the Nannels, northward of Alderney and of cape de la Hague. A glance at the chart best illustrates how the east-going stream, after passing through the Race, Swinge, and Ortac channels, is deflected a little to the southward of East in uniting with the Channel flood stream ; also how, on the west-going stream, the Channel ebb stream running in a westerly direction past cape de la Hague, Alderney, and the Casquets, is deflected through the channels between these places in a more southerly direction. This description, however, only applies to the periods of high and low water ; in its transition from one to the other direction, peculiarities occur requiring a more particular description. The eastern stream begins to make through the Race and Swinge channels at about the time of half flood by the shore, and it attains its greatest strength, 7 to 8 knots, about the time of high water. An hour after high water, the stream, in the course of its rotatory change of direction, is setting about N.E. by E. and begins to abate in strength, still veering in direction and slacking in strength ; at 3 hours after high water, it sets faintly to the N.W., causing a short slack in the Swinge, and also on the north-western side of Burhou, after which the western stream comes down and rushes through these channels with a velocity nearly as great as the eastern stream. After low water by the shore, the stream begins to veer to the south ward and abate in strength ; an hour and a half after low water, the stream is setting from the northward on Alderney and Burhou, causing extensive slacks or eddies southward of these islands ; and, near half flood, the offing stream, now very weak, sets south-east ward, causing a dead slack for a short time in all the channels between Alderney and the Casquets, followed by the commencement of the eastern stream. Sen chart, No. 60.

Chap. VIII.] 383 TIDAL STREAMS. Having thus described the general course of the main tidal stream round Alderney, it is necessary to describe some of the most im portant eddies caused by the peculiar turning of the streams and the obstruction offered by islands and rocks. Alderney, the Casquets, and intermediate rocks, all narrow in proportion to their length and each lying on a line of direction nearly East and West, are in the line of both tidal streams when at their strength ; therefore, at these times, the resistance they offer to the free course of the stream is small and the eddies under them insignificant ; but, as the stream in its rotatory change of direction moves out of this line, extensive eddies or in-shore streams are formed under the lee of Alderney, alternately on its northern and southern shores. On the northern shore of Alderney, the in-shore eddy stream commences at the Sauquet rock and extends westward as far as the Corbet rock, and within that rock southward of the main channel of the Swinge as far as the western end of the island, running 9 hours westward and only 3 hours eastward, the western stream commencing an hour before high water and the eastern stream at 2 hours flood. Along the southern side of the island, between Orbouee rock and Raz island, there are 9 hours of eastern and but 3 hours of western in-shore eddy stream ; the eastern stream commences one hour before low water, and runs along the land towards Longy and beyond it during the whole flood and until 2 hours ebb. In the neighbour hood of Longy, meeting with the south-western stream of the Race, it suddenly veers and unites with it ; the western in-shore eddy stream commences at 2 hours ebb and sets towards the Orbouee for 3 hours, or until 5 hours ebb, at which time it joins the south-western stream from the Swinge. The general courses and action of these two great eddies or in shore streams are exactly the reverse of each other. They may be easily understood by reference to a chart of Alderney and by careful perusal of the foregoing remarks ; but, as the northern eddy sets across the entrance of Alderney harbour, at times with great velocity, and then constitutes the principal danger in entering that harbour, a more particular description of its action will now be given. Alderney harbour entrance. — The direction of the eastern stream half an hour before high water, about which time it attains its greatest strength, is about East ; this being the line of direction of See chart, No. 60.

384 [Chap. VIII. CHANNEL ISLANDS.— ALDERNEY. Alderney, it runs full on the western point of the island by which the stream is now fairly divided, one part rushing through the Race along the southern side of the island between 7 and 8 knots, the other through the Swinge at about the same rate, leaving a small eddy previously noticed under the eastern end of the island near the Sauquet rock. At high water by the shore, the turning of the offing stream from an easterly to a northerly direction relieves the pressure of the Swinge stream from the end of the breakwater ; and, at this time, during a spring tide, the Swinge stream is running eastward at the rate of 3 knots 120 yards outside the breakwater, the intermediate space being occupied by the stream setting westward round the breakwater, also at the rate of 3 knots. This latter is the in-shore stream or eddy ; it commences in the eddy near the Sauquet rock, and begins to set westward, as before stated, an hour before high water. At this time, the western stream sets round the end of the breakwater, in volume a mere thread, but it gradually increases in magnitude as the turning of the offing stream removes the pressure of the Swinge stream from the breakwater. The most dangerous time in dealing with this stream and eddy is at about high water, when they set past each other, separated by only a few feet, at the rate just given ; great caution must therefore be used in taking a long vessel into harbour at this time. The break water obstructing the course of the western stream is the cause of the danger, and the stream is, of course, strongest near the outer end of that structure ; therefore, at high water, it is advisable to: enter the harbour a little southward of the mid-channel course rather than risk a too near approach to the breakwater end. An hour after high water, the inner edge of the east-going Swinge stream is removed to the distance of 2 cables from the breakwater end, and both streams beginning to abate in strength, the danger gradually disappears.* At 2 hours ebb, the Swinge stream, now slacking fast and veering westward, sets on the Nannels ; the western stream running past the end of the breakwater at the rate of 3 knots, meeting the eastern stream in the Swinge a little outside the Corbet rock, unites with it and both set towards the Nannels. Within the Corbet rock, the See chart, No. 60. * The destruction of the outer end of the breakwater in some degree modifies the conditions affecting this stream and eddy. To the mariner it should give rise to additional caution, in order to avoid being caught by the eddy on the port bow and set on to the submerged portion of the breakwater.

Chap. VIII.] TIDAL STREAMS.— BANC DE LA SCHOLE. 385 western stream sets down in-shore as far as the western end of the island. At half ebb by the shore, the offing stream is setting faintly north westward and there is slack water in the Swinge, but only for a few minutes, after which the westerly stream makes through the Swinge and immediately commences to run past the breakwater end with renewed strength until low water by the shore, gradually slacking as the offing stream veers from W. \ S. to the southward. Whilst the direction of the stream is veering through the latter section of its course, there is slack water at the entrance of Alderney harbour ; after a short interval, at 2 hours after low water, the stream sets across the end of the breakwater in an E.S.E. direction. BANC DE LA SCHOLE, 7 miles S.S.W. from Alderney, lies nearly in the direct line between the Great Russell channel and the Race of Alderney. Like most other banks between the Channel islands, it consists of a mixture of fine gravel, sand, and shells ; it iB very steep-to on the southern and western sides but shoals gradually on the north-eastern side. Within the 5-fathoms line, it is 1\ miles long N. by E. and S. by W. and about 3 cables wide near the middle, tapering off to a mere ridge at the ends. The 10-fathoms line includes a space 2\ miles long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and 8 cables wide, whilst the 20-fathoms line includes a length of 5 miles by 1^ miles. The top of the bank is very narrow and consists of small semi-circular ridges of sand convex to the S.W., over which the general depth is 3 fathoms at the lowest spring tides ; near the middle of the bank, however, as little as 2 fathoms has been found, with some spots close by of 2\ fathoms. The soundings taken on this bank at different times tend to show that its higher parts are continually varying in depth ; it is probable, therefore, that, within a limited space, it also shifts its position under the influence of tide, weather, &c. The position of the shoalest spot on the bank did not alter perceptibly, however, from 1861 to 1869 ; the marks for it are : St Martin's point, Guernsey, appearing midway between the Grande Fauconniere rock and the south western end of Herm island, bearing W. by S. f S. southerly ; Alderney old telegraph tower N. by E. \ E. easterly 7f miles ; Casquets lighthouse N. by W. \ W. 10| miles ; and, Serk windmill S.W. \ W. 10 miles. See charts, Nos. 60 and 2,669 a.

Clearing marks. — Doyle's column, Guernsey, on with the Grande Fauconniere rock W. by S. \ S., the Etac de Serk open east ward of the Burons, or cape de la Hague lighthouse N.E. by E., leads south-eastward and southward of the bank. Doyle's column on with or just open northward of the northernmost bluff land on Herm S.W. by W. \ W., the Gouliot pass open westward of Bee du Nez, Serk, or cape de la Hague lighthouse E. by N., leads north westward and northward ; and, the whole of-Burhou shut in behind the Etacs and Noires Putes N. by W. leads along the eastern side of the bank at the distance of about 2 miles. It must, however, be borne in mind that these marks are all distant and can only be made out in fine clear weather. Between low water and half flood, it is advisable to pass eastward of the Bane de la Schole ; but, between half ebb and low water, westward, because in both cases the tide favours the attempt. In bad weather, if the wind and tide are ever so obliquely opposed to each other, the sea breaks very dangerously on all parts of the bank. The RACE of ALDERNEY is the strait between Alderney and cape de la Hague, deriving its name from the violence of the tidal streams through the strait. Here, as in the Swinge and Ortac channels, the stream sets south -westward at half ebb by the shore, and runs in that direction, with the variations presently given, for 6 hours, or until half flood ; and the contrary is the case with the north-eastern stream, for there is but little slack water in the Race. The greatest strength of the south-western stream lasts for about 2\ hours ; it begins 5 hours after high water at Alderney and ends 1\ hours before the following high water. The greatest strength of the north-eastern stream continues about 2 hours ; that is, from one hour before high water at Alderney until one hour after. During equinoctial springs, the velocity of the south-western stream is nearly 7 knots, and of the north-eastern stream nearly 8 knots ; at neaps, 5-j knots. The first 2| hours of the south-western stream in the Race, from half ebb to low water, sets W.S.W. ; and, the last 2 hours, from low water to half flood, S.W. ; and, the contrary for the first and last 3-} hours of the north-eastern stream, which, between half flood and high water, sets very strongly round cape de la Hague. There are therefore 5i hours south-western and 6^ hours north eastern stream, that is, half an hour's difference between the Race streams and those in the Ortac and Swinge channels. See ohart, No. 2,669 m.

VIII.] ALDERNEY RACE. — DANGERS. — DIRECTIONS. 387 In boisterous weather, if the wind and stream are at all obliquely opposed, the sea breaks in all parts of the Race, as if it were over small knolls or patches, which makes it difficult and often dangerous for small vessels to pass through ; at such times, there are heavy overfalls over all the sunken rocks and banks, all of which must of course be carefully avoided. DANGERS in the RACE.— The Race rock, Inner Race rock, and Blanchard, described at page 377, have respectively 18, 18, and 12 feet water. There is a rocky 13-fathoms bank W. \ S. 3 miles from cape de la Hague lighthouse, which throws up a strong overfall, and should be avoided. The fairway of the Race lies between this bank and the Race rock ; the distance between is 3| miles ; the soundings in this, the narrowest part of the Race, are regular, between 22 and 24 fathoms, and the bottom rocky throughout. Middle rock, or Milieu, an isolated head with 7 fathoms water lies S.S.E. i E. 4| miles from Alderney old telegraph tower ; from it, Casquets lighthouse bears N.W. \ W. 9| miles ; and, cape de la Hague lighthouse E. by N. northerly 85 miles. When the tide is running strongly, the position of this rock is marked by a breaker or overfall, and there is at all times a ripple over it. The clearing marks given on the preceding page for the Bane de la Schole also clear the Milieu, and it may be easily avoided by attending to the directions given for passing through the Race. Another patch of 9 fathoms lies 2 miles S.W. by S. from the Middle rock, between it and the Bane de la Schole. DIRECTIONS. — When running through the Race of Alderney from the northward, if bound for the Deroute or Russell channels, it is at all times best to take the fairway of the channel as described, bearing in mind that the north-eastern stream between half flood and high water by the shore sets very strongly round cape de la Hague, off which there project many sunken rocks, see pages 211, 212, &c. Vessels bound for Granville, or other ports on the French shore in the Cotentin channel, round cape de la Hague more closely, clearing its rocks and shoals by the marks given at the pages referred to. The direct course from the Race to the Little Russell channel is about W.S.W. ; and, from the Casquets, about S.S.W. \ W. There fore, if bound from either the Race or Casquets to the Little Russell, Set chart, No. 2,669 a.

Basses du Houffet and du Fliart.— Buoy.— From the Houffet rocks, about one one mile eastward of cape de la Hague, to the western point of St. Martin's bay, the shore is bordered by irregular rocks which uncover at low water, and off it are many shallow patches. The bay may be known by the Herbeuses rocks, which project from the point, and by a fort commanding the approach to a tolerably good anchorage in from 3 to 5 fathoms, E.S.E. and S.E. of the point, where small craft find shelter with the wind from W.N.W. round by West to S.S.E., but where they are greatly exposed if it blows strongly from the north-eastward. TIDAL STREAMS.— The sudden change in the direction of the flood or north-eastern stream after passing cape de la Hague occasions a great eddy north-eastward and eastward of that cape, which extends even beyond Omonville and runs along the coast, following a direction opposed to the flood stream in the offing, for nearly nine hours, that is, from 2\ hours before high water by the shore all through the ebb and until a little after low water. This eddy begins to form off the entrance of St. Martin's bay about half an hour after the north-eastern stream has commenced in Alderney Race, and its strength increases with that stream ; but, as it runs to the N.W., and, when near the Becchue rock, comes into almost direct opposition to the stream flowing East and E.S.E. out of the Race, it causes a cross sea which is violent in proportion to the rate of that stream. The position of the harbour may be easily recognised from a distance by the village of Omonville, situated at the bottom of a valley, the slopes of which are highly cultivated ; by a large fort erected on the south-eastern point of the indentation ; by an old semaphore called the Vigie, on the top of the hill, at the foot of which stands the sort ; and, by a large mass of rock on the summit of the hill bounding the valley on the North. IX.] OMONVILLE. — MERMISTIN ROCK. — COAST. 395 Depths. — The harbour has within it about 28 feet at high water, springs, and 3 feet less at neaps ; it is only 2 cables long East and West, and barely a cable wide between the rocks, southward of the jetty. Chap. IX.] DANGERS.— TIDAL STREAMS.— CHERBOURG. 397 the eastern stream begins 3h. 45m. before high water at Cherbourg and at first sets southward at the rate of one knot,; from 2 to 3 hours before high water at Cherbourg, it runs S.E. with a velocity of from 3^ to 4 knots when its direction again changes to the southward. One hour after high water, it runs S.S.W., but its rate does not exceed a knot, and, as its strength decreases, it assumes a more westerly direction and finally comes to an end about 2 hours after high water at Cherbourg. The direction of the western stream varies only from West to N.W. from the time of its commencement until 4^ hours after high water at Cherbourg ; but, as its speed decreases, it turns successively to all the points between N.W. and West, where it ends 3h. 45m. before high water. Its greatest velocity, about 3^ knots, occurs from 4 to 5 hours after high water at Cherbourg. At 3 or 4 miles northward of the Mermistin and of Querqueville point, the flood stream begins 3 hours before, and ends about 3 hours after, high water at Cherbourg. Generally speaking, at that distance from the shore, eastward of the Mermistin, and also in the middle of the English channel, the changes of the tidal streams take place at the times of half flood and half ebb at Cherbourg, which is about equivalent to high and low water at Dover ; see Table, page 425. QUERQUEVILLE POINT. — Breakwater. — This point, lying 11 miles S.E. § E. from cape de la Hague, is easily distinguished by its heavy fort, lighthouse, and breakwater, which latter shelters the western entrance to Cherbourg road, is of quite recent construc tion and not yet completed ; it extends about 1270 yards E. S. from the inner part of the point, passing close northward of the isolated Fort Chavagnac, leaving an opening between its foot and that of Cherbourg breakwater about 5^ cables wide. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the point north westward of Querqueville fort ; see page 12. A Life-Boat is stationed at Querqueville point. CHERBOURG.* — -Cherbourg is a sea-port town, naval station, extensive arsenal, and fortress of the first class, with a population of about 37,000. The town stands at the mouth of the river Divette, and has a considerable trade ; its principal exports being butter, See chart, No. 1,106. * See Admiralty plan of port de Cherbourg, No. 2,602 ; scale, m = 6 inches.

[Chap. IX. 398 CHERBOURG. eggs, vegetables, and other provisions ; the imports, coals, guano and other manures, wood, &c. A British Consul is resident at Cherbourg, the consulate being near the port du Commerce. Coal and Supplies.— Coals, usually Welsh, are always available for steamers, a coal hulk containing about 400 tons being moored in the roads, alongside of which steamers coal, the price being about 20 francs per ton, but varying considerably ; the stock in hand on shore is usually from 3,000 to 4,000 tons. Vessels in the Commercial port can also coal alongside the quays in about 12 feet water. Supplies of all kinds are plentiful, and ordinary repairs to sailing vessels or steamers can be well executed, there being a dry dock in the Commercial port, see page 404. The dry docks and other appliances of the arsenal are, of course, not under ordinary circumstances available for mercantile purposes. There is no Sailor's home at Cherbourg, but, in case of sickness or accident, sailors are admitted to the Civil or Marine hospital, on the recommendation of Her Majesty's Consul, with guarantee of expenses. The number of merchant vessels entering the port annually is about 600, and their aggregate tonnage 225,000 tons. Steamers run five times weekly to Southampton, and once a week to Guernsey ; transatlantic steamers also call, the Royal Mail from the West Indies fortnightly, and the Hamburgh steamers from New York weekly. The Western railroad brings Paris within 9 hours distance, and connects with Le Mans, Granville, St. Malo, Caen, and by branches with Brest, Havre, Saint Lo, &c. The telegraphic service is very complete from all points served by the railway, and the coast Semaphore service enables messages to be rapidly forwarded to almost all parts ; see page 12. Rade de Cherbourg may be roughly described as including the whole space enclosed by the three breakwaters of Cherbourg, Querqueville, and Ile Pelee. It is sheltered on its northern side by Cherbourg breakwater, on its western side by Querqueville break water, and on its eastern side by ile Pelee breakwater ; its southern limits are the shores of St. Anne and Cherbourg bays. The area of See chart, No. 1,106.

Chap. IX.] COAL AND SUPPLIES. — ROAD.— BREAKWATERS. 399 the sheltered portion, not including St. Anne's bay, with 3 fathoms depth and upwards, is about 1,650 acres ; with 4 fathoms and upwards, 1,350 acres ; with 5 fathoms and upwards, 900 acres. The shelter afforded by the breakwaters is excellent and vessels now ride in safety where formerly they dared not anchor. BREAKWATERS.— Cherbourg breakwater.— Buoys.— This magnificent structure rises from a depth of from 6 to 7 fathoms at low water ; it consists of a foundation of rubble stone deposited a pierre perdue up to the level of low water, equinoctial springs ; this is 4,060 yards in length and its base about 100 yards wide, having a long foreshore to seaward and its harbour side standing at an angle of 45°. Upon this foundation is built a wall of masonry, nearly vertical, 33 feet wide at the base and decreasing to 27 feet at the top, which, with the parapet, rises 23 feet above the level of high water, springs. The breakwater is not straight but consists of two arms of unequal length, each diverging 5° towards the harbour, the western arm being about one-third longer than the eastern. The work was begun in the year 1784, was several times interrupted, but was brought to a successful close in 1853. The chief engineers employed on it were De Cessart, De Lamblardie, Cachin, Fouques-Duparc, Virla, Bonnin, and Reibell, and they have constructed a work of which France may be justly proud. It is defended by Fort Central placed at the point where the arms diverge, by forts at each end, named respectively forts de l'Ouest and de l'Est, and by an inter mediate battery on the western arm. A large black buoy marks the western extreme of the foundation of the breakwater, and a red buoy its eastern extreme.* * The first idea of sheltering Cherbourg bay by an artificial work dates as far back as 1665, but the first real project was in 1775 by M. de la Bretormiere, Capitaine de Vaisseau. In 1781 the proposal of M. de Cessart, engineer, to forma breakwater by sinking frustra of cones filled with stone was adopted, and the first cone was sunk in 1784. After 18 such cones had been sunk this plan was abandoned in 1788, and that of depositing stone a pierre perdue was adopted and followed up with occasional intervals until the breakwater reached above high water, but as in that form it could not witlistand the force of the sea. M. Fouques-Duparc proposed, in 1829, a vertical wall of masonry based upon the rubble foundation rising from the level of low water of equinoctial spring tides. Such a wall was begun in 1832 and carried on to completion at the close of 1853. Since then the forts have been in progress. The whole cost of the breakwater has been 2,671,491?., or at the rate of 220/. a lineal foot, measured from end to end of the foot of the embankment. — Bonnin, Sur I' Achecement de la Digue de Cherbourg. Paris, 1857. Seeplan, No. 2,602.

400 [Chap. IX. CHERBOURG. Querqueville breakwater has been already described, see page 397 ; its construction was only commenced about the year 1889, and it has closed the former deep water entrance westward and southward of Fort Chavagnac, at the same time affording good shelter to St. Anne's bay. lie Pelee breakwater, being constructed in shallow water, was a much more simple work than either of the others ; it was commenced about the same time as Querqueville breakwater. It leaves the shore at Greves point and its direction for nearly 1,000 yards is N. | E. ; it then curves westward during the next 400 yards, and finally runs nearly 800 yards N.W. to its junction with Fort Imperial on ile Pelee, its total length being about 2,200 yards. About 2\ cables from Greves point an opening about 70 yards wide is left for coasters, in which the depth is about 5 feet at low water ; there are also several small openings near Fort Imperial. Pilots. — Cherbourg pilots usually cruise between the western entrance and point Jardeheu in open boats which cannot keep the sea in bad weather ; they have, however, one decked boat fit to cruise in any weather. A life-boat is stationed at the western end of Cherbourg breakwater. LIGHTS. — The approach to Cherbourg is facilitated at night by the following lights : — Querqueville point. — A fixed white light, 59 feet above high water and visible 9 miles, is shown from a white circular tower in Querqueville fort. CHERBOURG BREAKWATER— West end— A group- flashing white light with a period of fifteen seconds, at 62 feet above high water, shown from the western side of Fort de l'Ouest, and visible 13 miles, marks the western end of Cherbourg breakwater. The flashes are shown in the following order : — Flash half a second, eclipse, two and a half seconds ; flash half a second, eclipse two and a half seconds ; flash half a second, eclipse eight and a half seconds. Set plan, No. 2,602.

Chap. IX.] 401 BRE AK WATERS.— PILOTS.— LIGHTS. East end. — A fixed green light, visible 7 miles at 62 feet above high water, is shown from the eastern side of Fort de l'Est, at the eastern end of Cherbourg breakwater. Occasional lights. — Temporary occasional lights are shown from Fort Central and also from the forts at each end of Cherbourg breakwater in addition to those described. He Pelee. — A fixed white light, visible 9 miles, is shown from a circular tower on the north-eastern bastion of Fort Imperial on ile Pelee, at 85 feet above high water. Harbour lights. — A fixed red light, visible 6 miles, is shown at 33 feet above high water, from a white stone tower at the head of the eastern jetty of the port du Commerce, and a, fixed green light, visible 2 miles, 15 feet above high water, from a lamp-post at the head of the western jetty. St. Anne's bay is upwards of a mile wide between Querqueville breakwater and the ramparts of Cherbourg ; its shore, on which are several batteries, is low and almost entirely bordered by rocks which uncover at low water. Of these, the Rochefort, a large rock at the head of the bay, is about 2 cables from high-water mark, and 6 cables S. by W. from Fort Chavagnac ; its summit is 2 feet above the level of the highest tides. The western part of this bay is well sheltered from all but north easterly winds by Querqueville breakwater, but the water is not deep, the 3-fathoms line averaging 4f cables from the shore, with only 3 feet water close to its edge at one part ; so that, taking Fort Chavagnac as a centre, a radius of about 3^ cables from it will include all the available anchorage space, and this is now prohibited altogether as an anchorage, see page 408. Rocky ground, on which there are only 12 feet water, lies E.N.E. 5 cables from the Rochefort rock, with the summit of that rock nearly on with Henneville church tower, and, N.W. £ W. 9 cables from Fort du Hornet, the fort at the north-eastern angle of the dockyard. This 12-feet patch is much in the way of large vessels beating in or out of Cherbourg road, and should be avoided, at springs, from one third ebb to two thirds flood, and at all times of tide during neaps. See plan, No. 2,602.

[Chap. IX. 402 CHERBOURG. Fort Chavagnac stands on a small rocky patch fronting St. Anne's bay, close to the outer end but inside of Querqueville breakwater, with which it will probably be connected, and there is now no passage between them ; the patch is about 150 yards long and from 50 to 60 yards wide. The southern and eastern sides are almost steep-to. Cherbourg bay is bounded on its western side by the Tenarde and other rocks off Fort du Hornet, and on its eastern side by the Flamands rocks, and ile Pelee with its breakwater. The town of Cherbourg and the port du Commerce occupy the head of the bay, and the establishments of the Arsenal or port Militaire the western side, between the town and Fort du Hornet. The shore is low from the front of the town to the Flamands, and is bordered by a sandy strand 2^ cables wide at low water, with shallow flats of less than 3 fathoms extending 3 or 4 cables farther out. The whole of the bay eastward of the Flamands and towards ile Pelee breakwater is very shallow. The low land adjoining the shore of Cherbourg bay soon rises into high hills, between which are the valleys of Roule and Tourlaville. The entrance to the Roule valley is between two hills of unequal height southward of the bassin-a-flot or wet dock, of the port du Commerce ; the eastern hill, Mont Roule, is steep and crowned by Fort Roule at only three quarters of a mile inland, which fort commands all the neighbourhood ; on the top of the western hill is a Semaphore. Tourlaville valley is eastward of Roule valley and only separated from it by the range of hills, of which Mont Roule forms the north-western extreme. The entrance to this valley is wide, but it rapidly narrows farther inland. Tenarde ledge.— Buoy.— The Tenarde is a rocky ledge with three dangerous heads N.E. 2 cables from Fort du Hornet ; it is one cable long W.N.W. and E.S.E. and about 100 yards wide ; there are 14 ft. water on the western, 6 ft. on the middle, and 9 ft. on the eastern head. A red buoy, in 5 fathoms, is moored about 70 yards north eastward of the eastern head, with the eastern extreme of Fort du Hornet bearing S.W. \ S. The eastern head is If cables from Fort du Hornet, with Nacqueville church tower on with the smallest tower of Querqueville church bearing W.N.W. ; and, the top of the group of See plan, No. 2,602.

Chap. IX.] CHERBOURG BAT.— DANGERS.— PORT DU COMMERCE. 403 trees surrounding Fief farm, half a mile south-eastward of Fort Roule, on with the end of the western jetty of the port du Commerce S.£E. The small church tower at Querqueville kept exactly between the tall spire of that church and the tower of Nacqueville church leads 50 yards northward of the dangerous parts of the Tenarde. There are from 19 to 21 ft. water over rocky bottom between the Tenarde and the shore, but a rocky flat, with an 11-ft. patch at its extreme, extends E. J N. 2 cables from the fort. The Roches des Flamands are close to the south-eastern shore of the bay and their highest parts uncover at low water. A strong fort, erected on these rocks, is approached from the shore by a causeway and drawbridge. Shoal ground with from 7 to 18 feet water extends 4 cables north-westward from Fort des Flamands, and northward, this flat extends still farther from the shore, being separated from the eastern end of Cherbourg breakwater by only 3 cables. Eastward of the fort and everywhere near ile Pelee breakwater the water is very shallow, but there is a 6-feet channel leading up to the opening in that breakwater. Port d'Echonage. — On the eastern side of Fort des Flamands is this small harbour, chiefly used by vessels of not more than 300 tons burthen laden with timber for the use of the Dockyard. A canal connects it with the Mare de Tourlaville to the eastward, where building timber is stored, and which is 50 acres in extent. The Port du Commerce consists of an Avant-port, with the channel leading to it, and a Bassin-a-flot, formed by damming and excavating at the mouth of the little river Divette which waters the Roule valley. The entrance lies between two stone jetties parallel with each other and 60 yards apart ; the western jetty is only half the length of the eastern jetty, and both are marked by the lights described at page 401. The bottom of the channel is a mixture of sand, mud, gravel, and shingle. Depths. — The dredged channel through the entrance and Avant port up to the Bassin-a-flot, and also alongside the jetty for the accommodation of the Southampton steamers, has a depth of 25f feet at high water springs, 21 feet at neaps, and 5 feet at low water, springs ; over the sill of the Bassin-a-flot there is one foot less. See plan, No. 2,602.

404 [Chap. IX. CHERBOURG. Vessels of 15 feet draught can ground alongside the quays of the Avant-port at high water, springs ; and of 9 or 10 feet at neaps. Avant-Port.— Just within the inner end of the western pier of the Avant-port is a small slipway, with the custom-house adjoining. At 60 yards southward of this slipway, a pier projects eastward from the western quay, to break the swell which sets in with strong northerly winds. The Avant-port is surrounded on three sides by granite quays, and, within the short pier just described, is 328 yards long in a N.N.E. and S.S.W. direction, 212 yards wide, and dries at low water on the western side, where the bottom is of rock but with a covering of muddy sand, affording good grounding berths to the merchant vessels for whose use this side is appropriated. The eastern side is occupied by Government vessels, and by the jetty before mentioned, built for the Southampton packets. The swell and surf, though much diminished, still sets in through the channel with heavy gales from N.W. to N.E. ; vessels making any staj- in the port should, therefore, enter the Bassin-a-flot as soon as possible. The Bassin-a-flot, or wet dock, is 418 yards long and 128 yards wide, having an area of 12| acres : it communicates with the outer harbour by a double parallel entrance of which the eastern is the widest and deepest, being 52Jj feet wide and having 24| feet water over the sill at high water, springs, a considerable portion of the basin being dredged to a slightly greater depth ; the sill of the western entrance has 6 feet less water over it, and the width is only 42^ feet ; both entrances are closed by gates which usually remain open about an hour and a half, but are shut with a falling tide. There are building slips at the head of the basin, and a dry dock 249^ feet in length over all by 46 feet wide at the entrance, and with 16 feet over the sill at high water, springs. As vessels are not permitted to enter without pilots, and as a pilot can always board a vessel in the Little road, it is unnecessary to give directions for entering the port du Commerce. Port de l'Onglet has its entrance 3 cables north-westward of the piers of the port du Commerce, and the walls of the arsenal form its western side ; it is a little inlet, with from 2 to 5 feet at low water, springs, very useful for boats and small craft which can make fast alongside its quays at all times of tide, but its entrance, See plan, No. 2,602.

Chap. IX.] PORTS DU COMMERCE, DE L'ONGLET AND MILITAIRE. 405 open to the N.E., is sometimes dangerous with strong winds from that quarter. The Port Militaire, or Dockyard, is north-westward of the town of Cherbourg, and occupies a space of about 220 acres of the level ground at the foot of the Equerdreville and Couplets hills. It is especially appropriated for vessels of war, and is a naval dockyard of the first class ; it is surrounded by fortifications, Fort du Hornet being its principal defence towards the sea. The port, properly so called, consists of three extensive basins. The outer tidal basin or Avant-port, of 16 acres, communicates with the roadstead by a short channel opening eastward, in which the least depth is 15 feet ; and, with the Bassin Charles X., of 15 acres, by gates 59 feet wide, having their sill 13^ feet below the level of the lowest tides. Both these basins have been excavated in the solid rock to a depth of about 32 feet below that level. An inner basin named the Bassin Napoleon III., of 20 acres in extent, was opened in August, 1858. It has seven large building slips and one dry dock on its western side, four dry docks at the northern end, and two dry docks at the southern end. There are also four building slips on the southern side of the Avant-port, making in all eleven building slips and seven docks. The two longest docks are 514 and 499 feet in length over all, with 108 and 120 feet width of entrance, and about 26 and 36^ feet over the sills at high water, ordinary springs ; the shortest dock is 257^ feet in length by 78-7 feet width of entrance, and about 17^ feet over the sill. The other docks vary in dimensions, but four of them have 29^ feet water over the sills at high water, ordinary springs. The quays and docks are faced with fine granite from Dielette, Flamanville, and Chausey. The space for steam factory and workshops is small in comparison with the other works. Time Signal. — The time signal is shown from the look-out of Fort l'Onglet, Quay Napoleon, at 35 feet above high-water level. It is made by means of a metal disc about 3 feet in diameter ; the disc is placed in a vertical position five minutes before signal time, and is dropped to a horizontal position at the instant, by electricity, from the Naval Observatory. The time signal is made at lOh. A.M. Paris mean time, equivalent to 21h. 50m. 39s. Greenwich mean time ; and is repeated at lOh. 2m. Paris mean time. When not in use, the disc is inclined at an angle of 45°. See plan, No. 2,602.

[Chap. IX. 406 CHERBOURG. ILE PELEE. — Beacon turrets. — This isle is all that remains of the long point which formerly extended nearly 1^ miles north ward from point de Greves, but was separated from it by the action of the sea, leaving the shallow channel between it and the mainland nearly half a mile wide, which has now been again reduced in width by the construction of the breakwater described at page 400. The isle is a flat of bare rock, nearly covered at high water ; but, at low water, springs, it is about three quarters of a mile long from North to South by half a mile wide, and is in the form of a horseshoe concave towards the East ; its highest point is a heap of stones awash at high water, equinoctial springs. Fort Imperial stands on the western point of the isle ; on its south-western bastion is a flag staff, and the fixed white light already' described is exhibited from the north-eastern bastion ; both bastions are sufficiently high to be seen at a distance of 10 or 12 miles seaward. The north-western and north-eastern extremes of the isle are marked respectively by the Tromet and Happetout beacon turrets. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the south-eastern and highest part of Fort Imperial ; see page 12. DANGERS on ILE PELEE FLAT.— The principal dangers which do not uncover upon the outer part of the rocky flat forming the base of ile Pelee are, the Basse de Happetout, the Roches du Nord-Ouest, and the Truite rock. Basse de Happetout, a small isolated rocky patch with only 13 feet water, is at the north-eastern extreme of the dangers of ile Pelee. It lies E. N. 91 cables from Fort Imperial lighthouse, with the high battery of Fort du Hornet just open northward of the lower battery of Fort Imperial ; and, the small houses adjoining the eastern part of the barrack at the Becquet de Denneville on with the houses of a farm on the height above the limestone quarries called the Becquet cliffs. A little westward of the Happetout is another patch with 3 fathoms water. The rocky flat of ile Pelee extends 2 cables in a northerly direction from the northern side of the isle, and as the sea is always disturbed upon it, and the soundings vary from 9 to 23 feet it is prudent for vessels to avoid approaching its northern edge. The spire of Querqueville church well open northward of Fort Central leads clear of it. See plan, No. 2,602.

Chap. IX.] ILE PELEE. — DANGERS. 407 Roches du Nord-Ouest.— Buoy.— There are 4 fathoms on the western extreme of these rocks at low water, but 70 or 80 yards eastward of this are some rocky heads with from 14 to 11 feet. A black buoy lies westward of the point of the shoal in about 5 fathoms, with Fort Imperial lighthouse bearing S.S.E. 4£ cables, and the Truite buoy S. by W. § W. 2 cables nearly. The flood stream sets strongly towards the point of these rocks, which becomes very dangerous when with westerly winds the stream is at its greatest strength. The Truite rock.— Buoy.— This rock, lying at the western point of -the flat on the eastern side of the Passe de l'Est or eastern channel in Cherbourg road, is about 100 yards long, East and West, and 60 yards wide. A black buoy is moored in about 5 fathoms at 70 yards N. by W. from the western extreme of the shoal, and N.W. 3 cables from Fort Imperial lighthouse. The shoalest spot is near the centre of the rock, where there are only 3 feet water. The marks for the western end in 10 feet, are, the end of the eastern pier of the port du Commerce seen a little southward of the square tower of Sainte Trinite church, Cherbourg ; and, the barracks at Becquet open half their length southward of the outer wall of the low battery and south-western bastion of Fort Imperial. Caution. — Although there is much less sea in the vicinity of the Truite than off the Roches du Nord-Ouest, both buoys are liable to drift from their exposed positions, and more dependence should be placed on the landmarks given than on the buoys being in their places. The Pelee bank is the sand-bank extending westward from Pelee isle and breakwater into the most sheltered part of the Grande Rade. There are 23 feet on its western extreme S.S.W. \ W. 3 cables from Fort Central, and its 5-fathoms limit is 2 cables farther north-westward. It forms the northern and eastern limits of the roadstead for deep ships, but there is excellent shelter for vessels of moderate draught between it and the eastern arm of Cherbourg breakwater. ANCHORAGES. — The principal anchorages for ships of war and large vessels are, the Grande Rade, and that near the break water eastward of the intermediate fort and extending beyond See plan, No. 2,602. 2 C SO 11886

[Chap. IX. 408 CHERBOURG. Fort Central ; and, for smaller vessels, the Petite Rade, and the eastern part of the anchorage near the breakwater. St. Anne's bay, as described at page 401, does not afford good anchorage, and is within the prohibited area. THE GRANDE RADE is bounded on its northern and north eastern sides by the Pelee bank, and its western limit is the meridian of Cherbourg cathedral. This road is specially reserved for large men-of-war ; for which purpose, three rows of mooring buoys, lying nearly parallel with each other, are provided, numbered from 9 to 22. Two more lines of mooring buoys, numbered from 0 to 8, are placed southward of the others ; they are for vessels of less draught of water. In addition, and immediately off the dockyard, are four large mooring buoys used by ships in the adjustment of their compasses. The bottom in the northern part of the road is for the most part composed of schistose rock in a state of decomposition, and the holding-ground is good ; immediately southward of this rock the bottom is of fine muddy sand which is not sufficiently stiff to hold well, but it improves on nearing the shore. Prohibited anchorage. — Vessels not using the Government mooring buoys may not anchor within their lines nor at a less dis tance than 1J cables from any of them. Anchorage beyond the following limits is also forbidden altogether, viz. : — Westward of an imaginary line drawn from the intermediate fort on Cherbourg breakwater to the buoy of the Tenarde reef, and southward of a line from Querqueville lighthouse to a position 2| cables northward of Fort de l'Ouest. Also, eastward of a line drawn from Fort des Flamands through Fort de l'Est, and southward of a line drawn through Tromet and Happetout beacon turrets ; but small vessels may anchor eastward of the Passe de l'Est, i.e., eastward of a line drawn from Happetout beacon turret to Fort des Flamands. Disregard of these regulations subjects the offender to severe penalties. There is excellent anchorage during all northerly winds within the permitted limits, close to the breakwater and on ile Pelee flat in from 4 to 6 fathoms, sand, shells, and a little mud ; it is chiefly used by merchant vessels seeking refuge during northerly gales. The deepest water and best swinging room is in the western part of this anchorage, as also the best holding-ground. See plan, No. 2,602,

Chap. IX.] ANCHORAGES. — CHANNELS INTO CHERBOURG. 409 The Petite Rade has good holding-ground, is southward of all the mooring buoys, and is well sheltered by Fort du Hornet and the dockyard from westerly winds. It is used by gunboats and despatch vessels, and by merchant vessels waiting tide to enter the port du Commerce. Southward of the buoys, the soundings decrease rather rapidly from 3^ and 4 fathoms to 12 feet, within a distance of 2 cables. Vessels entering the port du Commerce may anchor well to the eastward, as at half-flood the in-shore eddy sets westward and assists their entering. CHANNELS into the RADE de CHERBOURG.— Ships of war and vessels of deep draught enter the road by the channels round both ends of Cherbourg breakwater, the western channel being named the Passe de l'Ouest, and the eastern channel the Passe de l'Est. The Passe de l'Ouest is available at all times for the deepest ships ; the Passe de l'Est is only available for such ships between half flood and half ebb. Passe de l'Ouest. — The Passe de l'Ouest is the best channel and is about half a mile wide ; there is no difficulty in entering by it with a leading wind, vessels having only to approach the western end of Cherbourg breakwater on about a S.S.E. bearing, and, on nearing it, to pass midway between it and Querqueville breakwater ; those of deep draught turning in with the flood stream, after passing within the breakwaters and Fort Chavagnac, must be careful to avoid the rocky ground with 12 feet water E.N.E. 5 cables from the Roche fort rock, and also the Tenarde shoal ; it is imprudent to turn through at night unless the weather is clear and moonlight. Passe de l'Est is between the eastern end of Cherbourg break water and the two black buoys, before described, marking the most dangerous spots on the western edge of ile Pelee flat, viz., the Roches du Nord-Ouest and the Truite rock. The narrowest part of the channel is 2^ cables wide between the breakwater and Truite buoys, and has in it from 28 to 32 feet, the deepest water being close to the breakwater ; but, besides being narrow, this channel has the dis advantage of being crossed obliquely by the tidal streams, rendering it dangerous for sailing vessels with light winds and impracticable during calms ; there is, however, no difficulty or danger in a steamer or with a commanding breeze. See plan, No. 2,602. 2 C SO I18S6

410 [Chap. IX. CHERBOURG. Vessels from the eastward intending to run through this channel on the flood, should be careful to give a good berth to the Roches du Nord-Ouest, keeping rather westward of the exact line of the channel until the point of that shoal is passed as the flood stream sets strongly towards it. Octeville church just open eastward of Fort de l'Est S.W. £ W. leads clear of it, should the buoy be gone ; and, on closing the fort, alter course so as to pass between the Truite black buoy and the red buoy off the eastern end of the breakwater. The shallow entrance channel from the eastward through the opening in ile Pelee breakwater has a W. N. and E. S. direction, and carries only from 5 to 7 feet in the best water for at least 7 cables ; it is therefore fit only for coasters or for the smallest class of gun boats, torpedo boats, &c. When within the breakwater, the narrow channel is bounded on the North by the Basse du Chenal, which is almost awash at the lowest tides. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Cherbourg at 8h. 0m. ; ordinary springs rise 20f feet, and neaps 16 feet above the datum or zero of soundings as on plan No. 2,602. Strong westerly winds in the entrance of the English channel cause an increased rise of one or 2 feet even during calm weather in the vicinity of the port ; easterly winds have a contrary effect. During westerly gales, at springs, the sea frequently overflows the quays of the outer harbour of the port du Commerce. The mean duration of the rising tide is 5h. 45m., and of the ebb 6h. 35m. Tidal Streams.— (See also Table, page 425.)— The flood stream begins to be felt in the Grande Rade half an hour after low water by the shore and ceases three quarters of an hour after high water ; its direction is south-easterly and its rate about 2 knots. The greatest speed of the north-western or ebb stream hardly ever exceeds 1^ knots unless the wind is strong from N.E. or East. In the anchorage near Cherbourg breakwater, the eastern stream commences about an hour after low water and ends an hour after high water. The streams are feeble throughout the whole extent of this anchorage. The Petite Rade is in the eddy of the flood stream occasioned by the projection of Hornet point. This eddy extends beyond the northern limit of the Petite Rade, forming a counter stream which See plan, No, 2,602,

Chap. IX.] TIDES. — TIDAL STREAMS. — DIRECTIONS. 411 sweeps along the shore in a W.N.W. direction from about 3 or 4 cables eastward of the entrance to the port du Commerce to the head of the bay, and then northward along the boundary wall of the dockyard. It begins about half flood and continues until high water ; its greatest rate is about 1^ knots, at springs, and its rate decreases towards high water, finally merging in the true ebb stream which follows the same direction, and, at half ebb, when at its greatest strength, ts rate is about 2 knots. About half a mile northward of the Passe de l'Ouest, the flood stream, which runs S.S.E. and S.E., commences about 1^ hours after low water by the shore, and ceases lh. 20m. after high water, its greatest speed being 3 knots. The ebb runs N.W. by N. at nearly the same rate. In the entrance, the flood stream first takes a S.S.W. direction, but, as it gains its greatest strength, which is about 2 knots at springs, it inclines towards S.S.E. The direction of the ebb varies from N.N.W. to N.W., its rate being nearly the same as that of the flood. The flood stream ceases at the western end of the breakwater about an hour after high water. The flood stream begins to be felt in the Passe de l'Est one hour after low water, and ceases one hour after high water. Its direction is E. by S. between the breakwater and Truite buoys, and its greatest speed, at from 4 to 5 hours flood, is 2j knots ; but, a little northward of this position, the stream runs East 3| knots. At the edge of the Roches du Nord-Ouest and along the northern edge of ile Pelee flats, its direction is E.N.E., and its greatest rate 4 knots. The eddies formed by the uneven rocks on the flat produce a violent and dangerous race. The ebb stream is subject to less variation and its rate is rather less than the flood. It runs along the northern edge of ile Pelee, and, from thence, West, until the rocks are uncovered ; but, outside the flat and Cherbourg breakwater, its direction is W.N.W. DIRECTIONS.— Approaching Cherbourg from the Westward.— The western end of Cherbourg breakwater bears S.E. i E. 85 miles from Start point ; S. by E. \ E. 59 miles from the Bill of Portland ; and S. by W. \ W. 59 miles from the entrance to the Needles. When bound to any French port eastward of cape de la Hague from the westward, the best landfall to make is the See chart, No.
