IX. 412 CHERBOURG. coast of England, proceeding exactly as if bound for an eastern English port, as directed in Channel Pilot, part I., until arrived at a proper position to haul over towards the French coast. Thus, when bound for Cherbourg, proceed by the English shore until abreast of the Start, when having ascertained the vessel's position and the weather being clear, a course may be shaped to make the Casquets ; or, bearing in mind the great strength and variety of the tidal streams in the neighbourhood of the Casquets and to avoid all danger of being carried through the Ortac, Swinge, or Race channels, especially should the weather be at all doubtful, it may be better to make Portland and then stand across for the French coast, shaping a course about half a point westward of cape Barfleur. The ship's position may th'-n be accurately fixed by cross bearings of capes de la Hague and Barfleur by day or of their lights by night ; the white side of Mont Roule is also a conspicuous object by day, being visible at a distance of 20 miles in clear weather. Should it be determined to make the Casquets, consider carefully the direction of the wind and tidal streams as well as the state of the weather, which, unless clear, may render the approach to these islets not only difficult but dangerous. On nearing them, great care must be taken to avoid being set southward of them, especially whilst the tide is flowing on their shores, when there would be great risk of being drawn into the Swinge channel and being obliged to cross Alderney Race at the time the sea is most agitated. From a position about 9 miles N.W. of the Casquets, the course to be steered must depend greatly upon wind and tide. With the wind anywhere from W.S.W. round by North to N.N.E., and making due allowance for tide, a course of about E. S. for 14 miles leads 5 miles northward of all danger up to the meridian of the western point of Alderney, when cape de la Hague lighthouse should bear about S.E. | S. 13 miles ; then an E.S.E. course for 11 miles leads to a position from which the lighthouse, well open of the land, bears S.S.W. 65 miles ; and, from thence, a S.E. by S. course for 14jj miles leads to the western entrance into Cherbourg road. These courses keep a vessel a safe distance outside the dangers, and also beyond the influence of the strong tidal streams running through the Ortac and Swinge channels and Alderney Race ; but, with the wind between W.S.W. and S.S.W., and the north-eastern See chart, No. J, "OS, and plan, No. 2,602.

Chap. IX.] 413 DIRECTIONS. stream running through these channels, to prevent being drifted too far northward, an E. by S. J S. course may be shaped from the first position given (N.W. 9 miles from the Casquets) which leads about 2^ or 3 miles from the shore on the meridian of cape de la Hague, and Cherbourg road can then be gained without difficulty ; whereas, with south-westerly winds, if during the eastern stream the meridian of cape de la Hague should be crossed at 6 or 7 miles from the shore, a sailing vessel runs great risk of missing the entrance to Cherbourg road. During the western stream, with a fresh breeze, a heavy sea will be found off the entrances of all these channels. At night. — Approaching the western channel into Cherbourg road ; when eastward of cape de la Hague, keep its light in sight over the land until Querqueville fixed white light bears S.S.W., then stand to the southward for the entrance, and when the fixed white light in Fort Imperial, ile Pelee, is nearly in line with the flashing white light on the western end of Cherbourg breakwater, be guided by the latter in entering the road. The most unfavourable winds for a sailing vessel to approach Cherbourg from the direction of the Casquets, are those from the eastward, and especially a south-easterly wind. With a moderate breeze, however, from these quarters, the sea is generally smooth, and, during the eastern stream, the passage is not difficult ; but, with the western stream, it is for a sailing vessel impossible, and she should then make a long board to the northward and endeavour to hold her own until the stream slacks ; then the shore should be again approached to take advantage of the first of the eastern stream, and long boards made in order to reach the roadstead or a position eastward of its meridian, so as to enter with the latter part of the flood or the beginning of the ebb. On account of the great strength of the tidal streams, calm and fog are chiefly to be feared when making this passage, and, if threatened by either, every effort should be made to get into the middle of the Channel where the streams are much weaker than near the French coast. From the Eastward. — The course and distance from 2 miles southward of the Royal Sovereign light-vessel to cape Barfleur is S.W. by W. | W. 89 miles. Vessels coming from the North Sea or from the northern part of the English channel and bound for Cherbourg with the wind between North and East, after clearing Sec chart, No. 1,598, and plan, No. 2,602.

[Chap. IX. 414 CHERBOURG. Dover strait, generally steer direct for cape Barfleur, but with other winds they should endeavour to confirm their reckoning by the bearings of some headland on the English or French coasts ; thus, with northerly winds Beachy head should be made, and, with southerly winds, cape d'Antifer, or the lighthouse at Fecamp, which latter may be seen at a distance of 20 miles. The most unfavourable winds for making this passage are those between NW. and W.S.W. ; but, as the change of stream in mid Channel is 2 or 3 hours later than near the shore, it is often possible to keep in a favourable stream 8 or 9 hours out of the 12. Approach ing cape Barfleur during the eastern stream, in order to avoid being drawn into the bay of the Seine or into Barfleur race, where the tide runs with great strength, do not stand into less than 22 fathoms water, which depth may be found about 2 miles from the cape ; the same distance and depth should also be preserved with the west going stream, to keep outside the race and the short chopping sea off that cape on a weather tide. Between cape Barfleur and cape Levi, do not stand into less than 26 fathoms as the dangers between these capes extend 2\ miles from the shore ; and a berth of at least 2 miles should be given to cape Levi to clear the foul ground off it. To avoid being embayed between cape Levi and ile Pelee, where a sudden shift of wind might place her in difficulty, and also to avoid the dangers on ile Pelee flat, a large vessel turning to windward between the cape and island should not stand farther southward than to have Querqueville spire on with the northern tangent of Fort Central ; at night, she should tack when Fort de l'Ouest light bears West, or cape Levi light E. by S. Leaving Cherbourg.— Sailing vessels bound westward from Cherbourg do well not to leave the road until the wind is sufficiently settled to carry them clear of the English Channel. They generally stand out through the western channel at the commencement of the ebb, and, if the wind is light, after passing Fort du Hornet, borrow towards Cherbourg breakwater to avoid Querqueville breakwater and the Chavagnac rock, towards which the ebb stream sets. When on the meridian of cape de la Hague, and 6 or 7 miles from it, they steer about W.N.W. until the Casquets bear S.S.E. when a W. by S. course takes them out of the channel. See chart, No. 1,598, and plan, No. 2,602.

Chap. IX.] 415 DIRECTIONS.— COAST.— PORT DU BECQUET. These courses lead out of the influence of the streams running through the Casquet and Swinge channels and Alderney Race, and in the direction of the offing streams, and also sufficiently near the island of TJshant to admit of taking a departure from it if the weather is clear ; if the weather is not favourable, the chief object is to make westing, and TJshant should be given a wide berth ; see page 20.- If bound into the gulf of St. Malo and intending to pass through Alderney Race, vessels should endeavour so to time their leaving Cherbourg as to be at the entrance of the Race towards half ebb by the shore ; that is, at the end of the north-eastern stream in that channel, and they should then steer so as to pass through the centre of it ; see page 387. Bound eastward from the Rade de Cherbourg with a westerly wind, weigh towards half flood ; or, if in the bassin-a-flot of the port du Commerce, quit it as soon as the gates are open and run out by the eastern channel, see page 409. When well clear of this channel, a vessel leaving the road at half flood by the shore will have the beginning of the Channel flood stream, an! if favoured with a fresh breeze, she will carry-that stream for 8 or 9 hours to the eastward. The Coast between ile Pelee and cape Levi, which bears from it East 4 miles, forms a bight where sailing vessels should avoid getting embayed. From ile Pelee breakwater to the middle of this bight, the shore is low and broken into small projections, of which the most remarkable is Heu point in front of Bretteville village. A short distance inland are the calcareous cliffs known as Becquet quarries, one of the most remarkabie objects in the neighbourhood of Cherbourg. Brique point, with a mound on it, and its steep sides covered with verdure, is also conspicuous ; it bears E. f N. 1^ miles from Heu point. One cable W.S.W. of this is Le Castel, another mound of similar form with a guard-house on its summit. The tower of Maupertuis church, about 2 miles eastward of Bretteville church, is a useful landmark for this part of the coast. PORT du BECQUET, 7 cables south-eastward of ile Pelee breakwater and nearly a mile westward of Heu point, is in front of a group of houses close to the shore. It is formed by a pier running parallel with the shore and closed at the western end, the entrance being at the eastern end ; it is a grounding place about 1^ cables See plan, No. 2,602.

CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. IX. 416 long and 55 yards wide, surrounded by quays of dry stone work ; within it there are only from 12 to 15 feet at high water, springs, and the sea is much felt during strong north-easterly winds ; it is used only by fishing-boats, and by small craft loading with stone from the Becquet quarries. A life-boat is stationed here. Leading lights.— There are two leading lights at Port du Becquet shown from iron standards 76 yards apart and bearing from each other N.E. \ N. and S.W. \ S. ; the inner light is red, 29 feet above high water, and visible through an arc of 16° on either side of the centre of the channel, its intensity diminishing towards the extremes. The outer light is white, and 26 feet above high water. They are visible respectively 9 and 7 miles, and, when in line, lead midway between the pier-head and a black beacon turret marking the northern side of the Tounettes, a mass of rocks eastward of the pier between which and it is the entrance, about 55 yards wide. The Grunes de Bretteville is the rocky ground extending 7^ cables from the shore between Heu and Brique points ; near the outer edge there are only 13 feet water, with 4^ fathoms close inside and 6 to 10 fathoms just outside. From the shoal spot, Le Castel bears S.E. by E. } E., and Bretteville church tower S.W. southerly. Cape Levi port is in the bight 6 cables south-westward of the cape ; the shore is not accessible even at high water, except where a small cove has been converted into this little port by means of two stone jetties, affording fair shelter to fishing craft and coasters, but strong northerly and north-westerly winds send in much surf. The harbour is dry until 2 hours fiood, and the depth at high water is only from 9 to 12 feet. A black beacon turret stands on a rock near the entrance ; it should be left on the port hand in entering ; a small red buoy is moored 100 yards off the entrance to assist vessels warping out or in. Anchorage.— At 3 or 4 cables West and W.N.W. from the jetties, there is good holding-ground in 9 fathoms, muddy bottom, where vessels bound eastward against a foul wind may wait in safety for change of tide. This anchorage is protected by Fort Levi, Set chart. No. 1.106.

Chap. IX.] PORT DU BECQUET. — CAPE LEVI.— RACE. 417 which stands on the northern point of the bay, and a good berth is, with the Semaphore seen midway between the fort and cape Levi lighthouse. CAPE LEVI is low, being the northern termination of some low hills detached from the high lands of the interior. On the highest parts of these hills stand two houses, very close to each other, which may be seen from a considerable distance ; the northern house is an old Semaphore station and the other a guard-house. Several rocky patches which uncover extend as far as 4 cables north-eastward from the cape. The outer patch is terminated by the Bieroc, a remarkable rock with a rounded head 5 or 6 feet above the level of high water. LIGHT. — On the extreme of cape Levi stands a square light house, from which at 115 feet above high water is exhibited a fixed white light, varied by a red flash every three minutes, visible 13 miles. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on a mound about 13 feet high, 383 yards south-eastward of the lighthouse ; see page 12. CAPE LEVI RACE is occasioned by the strong tides and uneven rocky ground which extends N. by E. \ E. 2 miles from the cape. This rocky ground is in some places 5 cables wide, is consfderably higher than the general level of the bottom, and, as it lies across the direction of the tidal streams, it causes a heavy sea, especially on a weather tide. It is stated by local pilots that with strong easterly winds on the flood, at springs, this Race is as dangerous and the sea as bad as in Alderney Race. Some patches rising from the rocky bottom in this Race are dangerous even for small vessels at all times of tide ; they are the Bieroc patch, Basse du Cap Levi, Pierre Noire, and Tete Septentrionale or northern head of the Race, The BierOC patch is small and rocky, with only 3 feet water H cables northward of the Bieroc, from which it derives its name. Basse du Cap Levi is a rocky ledge about 2 cables long N.N.W. and S.S.E. and 1\ cables wide ; at its south-eastern point is a dangerous 13^feet patch N.N.W. f W. 5i cables from the Bieroc. See chart, No. 1,106.

CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. .IX 418 Pierre Noire. — Bell-buoy. — The Pierre Noire bears North one mile from the summit of the Bieroc ; it is one of the most dangerous rocks in the race, having only 7 feet over it at the lowest tides. A black bell-buoy is moored outside its north-eastern extreme ; it, however, occasionally breaks adrift. The Tete Septentrionale is at the north-western extreme of the rocky bottom, N. \ W. 1% miles from the Bieroc ; E. by. N. northerly rather more than 6 miles from Fort Central ; and N.W. by W. \ W. 8| miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse. There are 33 feet on this rocky head at low water, but as it rises precipitously from soundings of from 19 to 25 fathoms, it causes great eddies, and the sea breaks on it in bad weather. Tidal streams. — Between cape Levi and the Bieroc, the eastern stream commences at the time of low water at Cherbourg and it extends farther out as the tide rises, commencing at the Tete Septentrionale at 1^ hours flood ; its greatest strength is 5 knots. The flood sets E. by N. \ N., the ebb W. by N. \ N. The western stream commences in-shore half an hour before high water at Cherbourg but does not extend so far out as the Pierre Noire until 2 hours ebb. Vessels of moderate draught in charge of pilots may, if the weather permits, pass through the race between the Basse du Cap Levi and the Pierre Noire, at low water, but large vessels should alwayS pass northward of the Race. The Coast between cape Levi and cape Barfleur, which are distant 8 miles from each other and on the same parallel of latitude, is generally low and sandy, but the adjacent lands rise at a short distance from the shore and are joined to the hills in the interior by slight undulations, of which the highest are Carne ville heath, the woody mound at St. Pierre, the hills bounding Saire valley, and Pernelle hill. ANSE de la MONDREE, immediately eastward of cape Levi, between the Bieroc and Blanche rocks, is about 1^ miles wide and recedes about 7 cables ; there is good anchorage on its western side, in 1\ fathoms, muddy bottom, where vessels turning to windward against westerly winds may wait during the flood ; but, it must be used only in the finest weather, for should a vessel surprised .■yv chart, No. 1,106.

IX.] TIDAL STREAMS.— ANSE D'^ LA MONDREE.— DANGERS. 419 at anchor here by strong winds from N.W. to N.E. be compelled to weigh during the flood, she would be driven amongst the numerous dangers off the coast to the eastward. The best anchorage is with the Bieroc bearing N.W. by N. 3| cables ; and, the Semaphore on cape Levi about W.S.W. With strong northerly winds, no landing can be effected in this bay, nor upon any part of the coast between capes Levi and Barfleur, except in Roubaril cove near the latter. Roubaril cove. — This small cove, half a mile westward of cape Barfleur is sheltered by a little stone jetty, behind which fishing boats lie ; and, in the cove, coasters take refuge in time of need. The local fishermen state that, in case of necessity, a vessel under 12 feet draught might be saved by running into it at high water. The cove is about 100 yards wide and a cable deep, and the rocks bordering its sides are always uncovered. The water flows into it at about half flood. DANGERS Off the COAST.— The coast between capes Levi and Barfleur is studded with dangers, of which some extend 2h miles into the offing ; between them and the shore are the Hedouin and other winding channels, through which coasting vessels with good pilots may pass even at low water. The Sen is a small isolated rock, just awash at the lowest tides, 8 cables from the shore N.N.E. \ E. from Coqueville church. Basses du Sen. — These shoals are numerous separate patches, extending westward, northward, and eastward of the Sen rock. The shoal northward of the rock is 8 cables long and 3^ cables wide ; it has two dangerous rocky heads, of which one has only 4^ feet water ; on the other, which from its position is called the Tete du Milieu, there are 5i feet. North-westward of this shoal are four isolated rocky heads, with from 21 to 31 feet water ; from the Tete du Nord-Ouest, the outer of these heads, Gatteville church tower on with a rock awash at the highest neaps at Neville point bears S.E. \ S. ; and St. Pierre church tower on with a house at Coqueville, which on that bearing appears to stand a little westward of Coqueville church tower, S. by W. i W. See chart, No. 1,106.

420 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. IX. A fifth rocky head with 9 fathoms water lies N. by E. 8 cables from the Tete du Milieu ; it is dangerous only on account of the heavy sea occasioned by the eddies. There are no dangers between the Sen shoals and cape Levi race, and 6 or 7 fathoms water will be found at the outer edges of the rocks and banks which extend as far as 6 cables from the shore. Renier flat. — Beacons. — The Renier is a small rock uncovering 4 feet at one mile from the shore at the northern angle of a triangular rocky flat, of which the base is towards the shore, on which a number of rocky heads uncover at low water. At its south-eastern angle are the Trois-Pierres rocks, which dry 13 feet, marked by an iron beacon surmounted by a ball 17 feet above high water. A white beacon has also been placed on the Cabot rock about 8 cables West from the Trois-Pierres beacon, and another on the rocks extending from Neville point, these beacons being intended to facilitate the navigation of the Hedouin channel, lying between the Renier flat and the shore. Basses du Renier. — Bell-buoy. — These shoals are from one to H miles north-eastward and northward of the Renier rock ; they form three distinct patches, the basse du Sud-Est with 21 feet water, basse du Centre with 15 feet, and basse du Nord-Ouest with 26 feet. A black bell-buoy is moored just westward of the 15-feet spot on the basse du Centre. The basse du Nord-Ouest is the outer danger between cape Levi and cape Barfleur ; it is about 2h miles from the shore and only 2 cables within the 20-fathoms line of soundings bordering the coast. From its shoalest spot of 26 feet, cape Barfleur lighthouse bears S.E. \ S. rather more than 5 miles ; and, cape Levi lighthouse W. by S. | S. 4| miles. One mile E.S.E. from the shoalest part of the basse du Nord-Ouest is a small patch with 8 fathoms water ; and, as it rises precipitously from soundings of from 14 to 19 fathoms, it occasions dangerous eddies and overfalls during strong winds. The eddies caused by both the Renier and Sen shoals raise a heavy sea during a weather tide. See chart, No. 1,106,

Chap. IX.] DANGERS NEAR CAPE BARFLEUR. — DIRECTIONS. 421 The Roquette, a small isolated rocky patch of only 4 feet water, lies N. by E. f E. about I1- miles from the beacon off Neville point ; and, N. W. § N. 3 miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse. There is another patch, with 5 fathoms, S.S.E. 2 cables from the Roquette, ' and many others lie between the Roquette and the Renier. Plateau des Equets is a rocky ridge about one mile south eastward from the Roquette, and N.W. by N. 2 miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse ; it is of a circular form, about 3 cables in diameter, and has four dangerous heads of which the highest rises from its southern part and uncovers nearly 2 feet ; there are from 2 to 5 feet on the other heads. Haut-Fond des Equets, a rocky patch of 28 feet water, with from 10 to 12 fathoms round it, lies If miles from the shore, 5^ cables northward of the plateau des Equets, and about N.N.W. W. 2} miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse. The marks for it are : the tower of St. Pierre church seen between the church tower and redoubt at Retoville ; and, the small tower of Gatteville church on with a powder magazine on the shore near the guard-house at Gatteville. BailC de Saint Pierre is a collection of sand and broken shells, connected with and extending in a south-easterly direction If miles from the plateau des Equets, and terminating at the depth of 25 feet N.N.E. £ E. 5j cables from cape Barfleur lighthouse. The shoalest part of the bank is about 4 cables wide, aud has three patches of from 4 to 6 feet water on which the sea breaks very heavily in bad weather during a weather tide ; this must cause the depth frequently to vary, but the body of the bank remains stationary. Directions. — Vessels of deep draught, and even small craft without pilots, should keep outside the dangers just described, which extend as far as 2h miles from the shore between cape Levi and cape Barfleur ; and the directions given for approaching Cherbourg from the eastward, at page 413, should be attended to. At night, in clear weather, bearings of the lights of Cherbourg, cape Levi, and cape Barfleur, greatly assist the mariner in avoiding these dangers, which See chart, No. 1,106,

422 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. IX. should not be approached within a depth of 26 fathoms ; but, in thick weather, vessels should keep well off-shore, as the lead does not give sufficient warning of their proximity. Tidal Streams.— At 2\ miles from the land between cape Levi and cape Barfleur, the flood or eastern stream commences about the time of half flood by the shore, and ends at half ebb. It attains its greatest speed at high water, and the west-going stream its greatest speed at low water by the shore. From the northern part of cape Levi race to 2 or 3 miles in the offing, the direction of both streams, during their greatest strength at springs, is East and West, and the rate of the flood is from 3^ to 4 knots, the ebb something less. Outside and amongst the Sen and Renier shoals, their direction is E.S.E. and W.N.W., and their rate about the same ; but, as the meridian of cape Barfleur is approached, the flood stream inclines more to the South-east and its strength increases. At 2 miles northward of cape Barfleur, the flood runs S.E. 5 or 6 knots ; the ebb, N.W., with nearly equal velocity ; see also Table, page 425. CAPE BARFLEUR. — Beacon. — Cape Barfleur is the north eastern extreme of the Cotentin peninsula and the western extreme of the Baie de la Seine ; it is a low point, off which in a S.E. by E. direction at about one mile, as also on its north-western side, are some rocks which uncover at low water, and eastward of it are the reefs causing the race presently described. Two towers of unequal height, about 80 feet apart, stand at the extreme of the point aud serve to mark its position by day. A red iron beacon with conical framework top-mark, 18 feet above high water, stands on a rock E. \ S. about 4 cables from the lighthouse. LIGHT. — The highest or southern tower on cape Barfleur is the lighthouse, now officially named the Bartieur-Gatteville lighthouse ; which exhibits at 236 feet above high water a group-flashing white electric light with a period of ten seconds, showing two flashes in quick succession occupying two and a half seconds, followed by an eclipse of seven and a half seconds. The light is visible 22 miles. Fog Signal.— During thick or foggy weather, a siren established in the upper gallery of the lighthouse, worked by compressed air, gives a blast of about three seconds duration every minute, see Fog signals, page 11. See chart, No. 1,106.

Chap. IX.] TIDAL STREAMS. — CAPE BARFLEUR. — RACE. 423 Semaphore. — The northern tower on cape Barfleur is the Semaphore station ; see page 12. When the sun shines on these towers, the lighthouse may be seen 15 or 16 miles distant, and the Semaphore tower at 11 or 12 miles. They are difficult to distinguish when at some distance north eastward of them on account of the high land at their back ; this land, however, has a remarkable break in its formation, which assists to mark their position ;— it is the valley of the little river Saire, called Coupee du Vaast, which lies S.W. by W. 5^ miles from the lighthouse. Pernelle hill is also a remarkable object, the church on its summit attracting particular notice ; it bears S.W. by S. 4| miles from the lighthouse, and when seen from S.S.E., N.N.E., or N.N.W., the hill has the appearance of a promontory sloping gradually towards the sea. BARFLEUR RACE. — This race is occasioned by the impetuous rush of the tidal streams over the rocks forming a submarine extension of cape Barfleur. These rocks are based on the flat joining the land and extending about a mile between East and S.E. from the lighthouse, as far as the line of Pernelle and Monfarville church towers in one. They form three separate reefs ; the first, with from 7 to 25 feet water, extends E. byT N. 5 cables from the lighthouse ; the second, separated from the first by a deep called the Breche-du- Raz, has a rock with only 17 feet water lying E. \ S. about 6^ cables from the lighthouse ; the third, named the Riden de Quenanville, is southward of the others and separated from them by another deep about 4 cables wide. This latter reef, 2 cables wide, extends 5 cables in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction, and its shoalest spot of 7 feet lies with the guard-house on the summit of the eastern point of Roubaril cove touching the southern part of the highest of the houses (light keepers' dwellings), about 1\ cables south -westward of the light house ; and Reville church spire on with the western side of a cluster of houses at the chateau de Monfarville, which chateau stands one mile southward of Barfleur church, and, being of a brown colour, contrasts strongly with the trees surrounding it. Barfleur race is especially dangerous at springs, when the streams run through at the rate of 8 or 9 knots, and, with a fresh wind, and especially with strong north-easterly gales, the sea breaks violently throughout its whole extent. At neaps, the streams are not so strong and the race is quieter. Fishermen, under these circumstances, cross it, passing through the Breche-du-Raz. 426 CHAPTER X. BAIE DE LA SEINE — CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. Variation in 1897. Cape Barfleur ... 16° 40' W. Cape D'Antifer 16° 10' W. BAIE DE LA SEINE is the deep bight comprised between cape Barfleur and cape D'Antifer, which latter bears from the former E. by S. £ S. 55 miles. The coast of the bay recedes from this line about 24 miles towards the mouth of the river Orne ; and its circuit, excluding the shores of the Seine estuary and of the Grand Vay, is about 96 miles.* It is open to all winds from N.W. round by North to N.E., and a heavy sea is thrown into it when they blow with any strength. At springs, the tidal streams, as described at pages 466 and 506, as also in Table, page 507, run at the rate of 3 or 4 knots. All the indentations in the coast, out of the fair line of the tidal streams, are blocked up by sand and by the accumulations deposited by the rivers, and all the harbours, except Havre and Port-en-Bessin, are dry at low water, and, during neaps, there is but little water in any of them even at high water ; a vessel embayed here, therefore, during strong northerly winds is in a dangerous position. The principal headlands and harbours are well lighted, and thus distinctly marked at night ; but, unfortunately, the lights as well as the characteristics of the coast hy day, are frequently obscured by haze and fogs, which are more prevalent here than at other parts and at times prove very embarrassing.
