Chap. X.] BAIE DE LA SEINE.— COAST. — SOUNDINGS. 427 formation with reefs extending some distance from the shore. Seen from the offing the land here appears well wooded, church steeples showing here and there above the trees. As previously mentioned, Pernelle hill and church, 3 miles north-westward of Saire point, is a conspicuous object. From Saire point, the land falls back west ward, forming at 3 miles southward of that point the Rade de la Hougue; the little ports of Barfleur, Reville, St. Vaast, and La Hougue, all lying between cape Barfleur and the Grande Rade de la Hougue. From La Hougue, the shores of the bay are generally low and sandy, with off-lying shoals and sand-banks in the western part ; but, eastward of Maisy point, it is more diversified, and, in the neighbourhood of point Percee, which bears S. by E. f E. 22| miles from cape Barfleur, are high chalk cliffs visible 12 or 15 miles distant. The ports of Carentan and Isigny are in the deep bight of the Grand Vay, westward of point Maisy. From point Percee, point Beuzeval, the southern boundary of the estuary of the Seine, bears S.E. by E. § E. 34 miles, the intervening coast, described here after in detail, consisting partly of cliffs of chalk or of rock and brown clay, and partly of low sand-hills with a moderately high and well cultivated interior. The ports within this space are, Port-en - Bessin, Courseulles, Oyestreham, and Caen, the latter 9 miles above Oyestreham on the river Orne, and the river Dives just westward of Beuzeval hill. From Beuzeval point, the white chalk cliffs of cape de la Heve bear N.E. N. 13 miles, the whole intervening space being occupied by the shallows, banks, and channels of the Seine estuary, on the southern shore of which is the harbour of Trouville, and the port of Honfleur ; whilst, on the northern shore, is the large and important port of Havre. The river Seine is navigable for large vessels as high as Rouen. From cape de la Heve, the chalk cliffs forming the coast line trend almost directly N.E. f N. 11^ miles to cape D'Antifer, the shore being safe of approach within one mile for the whole distance between the two capes but without port or harbour of any description. SOUNDINGS. — The depths in the Baie de la Seine are very regular, varying, in line between cape Barfleur and cape D'Antifer, from 24 fathoms near the former to 18 fathoms near the latter, and from those depths decreasing very gradually towards the off-lying See chart, No. 2,613

[Chap. X. CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. 428 banks in the south-western part of the bay, towards the southern and eastern shores, and towards the extensive flats off the mouth of the Seine. Wreck buoy. — A large red and black buoy is moored in about 20 fathoms in the south-western part of the Baie de la Seine, 10 miles from the nearest land, in lat. 49° 31' 30" N., long. 0° 44' 45" W. (approximately). It marks the position of the wreck of the Cubana, a ship which foundered in the year 1862, and is maintained in position not that the wreck is any longer a danger to navigation, but for the safety of the trawls and nets of fishermen. The buoy should, according to rule, be coloured green, but is nevertheless as described. PORT BARFLEUR.* — The entrance to this little port bears S. | W. 1^ miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse, and its position is clearly indicated by the church, with its square tower and no spire, standing on the northern point of entrance. The port is only 3 cables long and 2 cables wide, is sheltered by the land from South round by West to N.N.E., and protected from the sea during strong easterly winds by the Antiquaires and other rocky beds fronting the entrance, in which are moored four warping buoys to assist vessels entering or leaving. A small stone jetty extends 53 yards in a southerly direction from the northern point of entrance, and a breakwater 220 yards long extends N.N.E. from the southern entrance point ; the head of the northern jetty bears from the outer end of the breakwater about W.N.W. 110 yards. The bottom of the port is generally mud mixed with broken shells, sand, and gravel, and is good for vessels taking the ground, but there are some rocky patches which should be avoided. Vessels not going alongside the quay should moor securely to the large iron rings fixed in the rocks, as there is a good deal of sea with easterly winds when the Antiquaires rocks are covered. Depths.— The port dries throughout at low water, springs. Vessels loading or unloading lie alongside the North quay, which is nearly 300 yards long, and where the bottom is from 4 to 8 feet above the lowest tides and the berths are soft and good ; the bottom over the rest of the port is from 4 to 10 feet above that level. Vessels of 14 feet draught can enter the harbour at springs, but it is only available for those of 6 feet at the lowest neaps. * See plan on chart Rade de la Hougue, No. 2,743.

Chap. X.] 429 PORT BARFLEUR. The port, though now connected with the general railway system, is of no commercial importance. Its trade, carried on by small coasters, is represented by about 100 vessels of an aggregate of 3,150 tons entering annually, and, of these, about half enter in ballast. Granite for building purposes is quarried in the neigh bourhood. The little traffic carried on is in flax, hemp, vegetables, fruit, butter, oysters, and fish. Dangers. — The outer danger in approaching port Barfleur is the Riden des Dents, a rocky shoal on which is a dangerous patch with only 9 feet water about a mile from the shore, and bearing E. by S. S. from Gatteville church tower. The Anglais rocks bear about N.E. by E. j E. 4 cables from the North jetty end, and the Vinberge rock, the highest head, uncovers 7 feet. The Hintar rock, E. by S. £ S. nearly 2 cables from Vinberge rock, and E.N.E. 5 cables from the breakwater end, uncovers 5^ feet ; a large iron ring is fixed on it for the convenience of vessels warping into harbour or anchor ing near it in the road. Buoys and beacons. — On the northern side of the entrance, a red buoy, with conical top-mark, is moored just southward of the Grotte rock, and two other red buoys mark the Anglais and Vinberge rocks ; a red buoy marks the Ronde rock at the entrance, it is only about 50 yards from the breakwater end, and vessels entering must pass between it and the breakwater. On the southern side are, a black buoy with staff and cylinder marking the Hintar rock, two beacons marking respectively the Raie and Grosse-Haie rocks, and a black warping buoy marking the Hoisier rock near the breakwater. There is also a third beacon marking the Fourquie rock, a short distance south-eastward of the entrance. A life-boat is stationed at port Barfleur. LIGHTS. — Two fixed white leading lights, dioptric and of the fifth order, are exhibited from square towers, one, 23 feet above high water, on a point on the southern side of the harbour, If cables within the breakwater end ; the other, at the head of the harbour, 43 feet above high water, and bearing S.W. by W. 309 yards from the former ; both are visible 9 miles, and when in line they lead to the entrance. Two small fixed lights are also shown, one, red, near the head of the breakwater or southern jetty ; the other, green, near the head of the Set plan on chart, No. 2,743 , ako chart, No. 1,106.

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. 430 northern jetty. These two lights in line lead through the southern passage up to the harbour entrance. Fog1 bell. — Barfleur church bell is sounded continuously, during foggy weather, for one hour about the time of high water. Directions. — A veBsel rounding cape Barfleur from the west ward and bound to port Barfleur, after passing the swell at the outer end of Barfleur race, should take care not to go westward of Pernelle and Monfarville church towers in line bearing S.W., unless of very light draught, or unless the tide has risen considerably. The two harbour lighthouses by day, or lights by night, in line bearing S.W. by W., lead through the channel to the port between the western rocks of the Antiquaires reef and the dangers bordering the shore between cape Barfleur and the northern point of the port, leaving on the starboard hand the four red buoys already described, and on the port hand the black buoys and beacons. The channel narrows considerably between the Hintar and Anglais rocks, and, from thence to the entrance, it is only 120 yards wide. At the entrance, it is only about 50 yards wide between the Ronde buoy and the head of the breakwater. Anchorage. — Vessels arriving before high water with off-shore winds, may anchor in Barfleur road, which is a small deep between the Plateau des Antiquaires and the Gaillarde and Anglais rocks. The best anchorage is in about 5 fathoms, good holding-ground, with the lower leading light a little open to the left of the higher light, or with Pernelle and Monfarville church towers in line S.W. ; and, Crabet mill, in ruins and without sails, just open northward of Masse point. This anchorage should be used during off-shore winds only and in fine weather ; should a vessel, however, be surprised in it by strong northerly or easterly winds, she must moor with open hawse to ihe northward, and with the heaviest anchor to the east ward ; the anchorage being of small extent, it will be necessary to shorten in and tauten the cables as the water falls to prevent tailing on the rocks, Tides and tidal Steams.— It is high water, full and change, in port Barfleur at 8h. 59m. ; ordinary springs rise 20£ feet, neaps 16^ feet above the level of the soundings on the plan, which are about 3J feet below the level of low water, ordinary springs, see See plan on chart. No. 2,743 ; also chart, No. 1,106.

Chap. X.] PORT BARFLEUR. — MOULARD ROCK. 431 Soundings, page 4. Ordinary springs range 17 feet, neaps % feet. The tides are very regular, but with strong prevailing south-westerly winds the water rises higher, and, with strong and lasting winds in the opposite direction, remains lower than the general level ; this is also the case in all the harbours of the bay of the Seine. The mean duration of the rising tide is 5h. 50m., and of the falling tide 6h. 35m., but the duration of the rising tide between a neap and the following spring tide exceeds 6 hours and sometimes reaches 6£ hours, whilst between a spring and the following neap it is below the mean. The first part of the flood stream follows the direction of the shore from cape Barfleur, and crosses the road and channel. Its greatest rate does not exceed 3 knots and it decreases suddenly at about half flood, when an eddy commences in the opposite direction but with rather less speed. This eddy is weak about high water, but its rate increases as soon as the tide begins to fall. Moulard point is low and bears S. by E. £ E. 1\ miles from Barfleur church. Rocks which uncover at low water lie off the point, and rocky ground with shoal patches extends about a mile from the shore. The Basse Orientale du Moulard is the outer or eastern patch ; it has 26 feet water, lies E. N. 8 cables from the Moulard rock beacon turret, and, from it, Crabet mill is on with the northern extreme of Filet at Barfleur. Vessels should keep a mile from the shore between Barfleur and this point whilst the Moulard rock is uncovered. Moulard rock. — Beacon turret. — The Moulard is a granite rock on which stands a white beacon turret about 2\ cables eastward of Moulard point ; this rock uncovers 22 feet at the lowest tides, and is a useful mark to all who navigate along this part of the coast ; for, when it is covered and the sea smooth, there is water for large vessels over all the hidden dangers between cape Barfleur and La Hougue. Pointe de Saire is the first prominent point southward of cape Barfleur ; Pernelle hill rises N.W. by W. 3 miles from the point, the church on its summit forming the most remarkable object on this part of the coast. Reville battery is at the extreme of Saire point, and one of the lights used in entering La Hougue road at night is shown from its south-western face ; see page 435. See plan on chart, No. 2,743 ; also chart, No. 1,106.

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. 432 Ridens des Ecraoulettes are sand-banks about a mile from the shore, a little northward of the church towers of Pernelle and Reville in line, with not less than 18 feet on their shoalest parts ; Gatteville church tower and Moulard beacon turret in line N.N.W. \ W., or La Hougue tower on with the highest house of the lazaretto on the western side of Tatihou island W.S.W. southerly leads eastward. Dranguet rocks.— Beacon turret.— About 5 cables southward of the Ecraoulettes are the Dranguet rocks, which also extend in patches a mile lrom the shore. They are dangerous even for small vessels, and there is a high sea over them during a weather tide. The outer rock which uncovers is 5 cables from the shore, and has on it a red beacon turret surmounted by a ball. Barfleur church tower on with the Moulard beacon turret leads eastward of the outer shoal, which is 6 cables outside the beacon turret, and has on it 25 feet water. The Pont de Saire is a sort of rocky causeway extending a mile south-eastward from Saire point nearly to the line of La Hougue tower touching the north-western angle of Fort de 1'Ilet, which latter is just southward of Tatihou island. With an on-shore wind, the sea runs very high on this ridge as long as the tide makes north-eastward, i.e., from half flood to low water by the shore. Basses de Reville and de Pernelle.— Several rocky patches lie outside the Pont de Saire, but they are dangerous only in bad weather. Those farthest out are, the Reville with 27 feet, and the Pernelle with 6 fathoms water. They are 5 cables apart and both lie with Barfleur lighthouse on with Moulard beacon turret N. vj W. westerly, the Reville 1£ miles, and the Pernelle If miles from Saire point ; the western mark for the Pernelle is, Morsaline lighthouse showing southward of Fort de 1'Ilet West a little northerly. THE COAST.— From Saire point, the direction of the coast changes and trends south-westward. St. "Vaast point, on which stands the church of the small town from whence the point takes its name, bears S.W. by W. \ W. If miles from Saire point, and the intermediate coast forms a deep bight, at the head of which the &* chart, No. 2,743.

Chap. X.] DANGERS.— COAST.— ST. VAAST HARBOUR. 433 waters of the little river Saire, after winding round the northern side of Pernelle hill, lose themselves on a low sandy beach. The island of Tatihou, the small Fort de 1'Ilet on the rocks close southward of that island, and the rocks which surround them, partly close the entrance to this bight ; at low water, they join the mainland by a beach of gravel, sand, and rock ; the whole of the bay from St. Vaast point to the outer rocks of the ile de Tatihou and from thence to La Hougue point being dry, or nearly so, at the lowest tides. The iles de Tatihou and de 1'Ilet may be recognized by their old but obsolete and disused fortifications. The former is used as a quarantine station for Cherbourg, the lazaretto being on its western side, and its only occupants being the officers of the quarantine establishment. The latter has no occupant. The narrow rocky peninsula of La Hougue extends one mile S.W. from St. Vaast point. Fort La Hougue occupies its southern and highest part ; near the centre of the fort and on its western side is the remarkable old round tower of La Hougue. Westward and northward of the fort is a sandy bay, one mile in depth and width, but which, at low water, dries completely out to and beyond the extreme point of La Hougue. ST. VAAST. — The town of St. Vaast has a population of about 3,000 ; its small tidal harbour is on the northern side of St. Vaast point, northward of a stone jetty extending E. N. 440 yards from the shore, with an iron lighthouse at its outer end. From South round by West to North it is sheltered by the land and by this jetty ; and, from the high sea and strong winds from the eastward, by Tatihou island. Protecting the harbour from north-easterly winds is a rough stone breakwater about 440 yards in length N.N.W. and S.S.E. The entrance to the harbour is 100 feet wide between the southern end of this breakwater and a small jetty running off in a north-easterly direction from the main jetty to protect the building and repairing slip just within it. The bottom of the harbour is a mixture of sand, gravel, and a little mud, great quantities of rock having been removed and levelled ; the berths are good alongside the quays, but farther off they are hard, the rocks being thinly covered. The quay frontage is very extensive considering the requirements of the port, being no less than 470 yards in length. Depths. — On the western side of the harbour, the bottom dries See chart. No. 2,743.

434 CAPE BiRFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. 6 feet, and, on the eastern side, 4 feet above the level of the lowest tides ; at high water, ordinary springs, there are at the berths from 13 to 15 feet water, and, at the lowest neaps, 7 to 8 feet ; the harbour is, therefore, inaccessible to vessels over 12 or 14 feet draught under any circumstances. The town of St. Vaast has railway communication with Barfleur, and through Valogne, with the general system of the country. It has a fine hospital, considerable oyster and other fisheries, and its chief foreign trade is with England for coal, and with the Baltic for timber. About 800 vessels, including fishing craft and coasters, of an aggregate of 35,000 tons, enter the port annually ; the exports are chiefly fruit and cattle, but are unimportant, vessels usually leaving in ballast. The southern and principal passage to the harbour is between the rocky ridge extending southward from the jetty to La Hougue fort on the western side, and Tatihou island and the rocky ledge which extends 5 cables south-eastward of Fort de 1'Ilet and terminates in the two rocky groups named the Dent and the Gavendest, on the eastern side ; the highest head of the Dent uncovers 7 feet, and of the Gavendest 6 feet at low water. The Plateau du Ouest-Drix spreads out southward of these rocky groups and on it is a shoal spot of 15 feet, 3 cables S. § E. from the Dent. Buoys and Beacon. — The following buoys and beacon mark the southern approach to St. Vaast :— A red buoy 50 yards southward of the Gavendest. A red buoy about 100 yards S. £ W. of the Dent. A black buoy on the Manquet rock off Fort de la Hougue. A black buoy at the edge of the rocks half way between the Manquet buoy and St. Vaast jetty-head. A black beacon on the Creux rock about 330 yards S. by W. from the jetty-head. The red buoys have to be left on the starboard hand, the black buoys and beacon on the port hand in entering from the southward. When round the jetty-head, several mooring buoys are placed to assist vessels warping into harbour, and another black beacon a little eastward and outside of the grounding places in the harbour. LIGHTS.— Besides the harbour lights of St. Vaast, three fixed white lights of the fourth order assist vessels to enter St. Vaast and See chars, No. 2,743.

Chap. X.] ST. VAAST. — LIGHTS. — DIRECTIONS. 435 La Hougue harbours by night, and also La Hougue road ; they are as follows : — -Reville light. — From a square tower on the south western face of Reville battery, at the extreme of Saire point and 36 feet above high water, is exhibited a, fixed, white light, visible 9 miles. When in one with cape Barfleur light N. \ E. it marks the eastern extent of the dangers near Tatihou island. La Hougue light. — A. fixed white light, visible 9 miles, is shown from a white square turret at the southern extreme of La Hougue fort, 36 feet above high water. Morsaline light. — From a square tower on the heights at Morsaline, 282 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed white light, visible 9 miles. A mast, 26 feet high, surmounted by a ball, is placed behind the lantern. Harbour lights. — A small fixed red light, visible 5 miles, is shown from an iron turret on the outer end of St. Vaast jetty. At the entrance, a small fixed red light, visible 2 miles, is shown from the extreme northern end of the small jetty, and immediately opposite at the southern end of the breakwater, is a green fixed light. Fog Signal. — A bell is sounded continuously in foggy weather at the outer end of St. Vaast jetty ; see fog signals, page 11. A life-boat is stationed at St. Vaast. Directions. — When bound into St. Vaast harbour, Morsaline lighthouse on with La Hougue lighthouse W. by N. \ N. leads just southward of the Ouest-Drix flat ; and when the spire of Reville church opens westward of Fort de 1'Ilet, steer for the end of St. Vaast jetty, taking care to give a good berth to the remains of three wrecked vessels lying south-westward of Fort de I'let. Morsaline lighthouse exactly midway between La Hougue light house and round tower leads between the Ouest-Drix patch and the Gavendest ; but, this passage should not be attempted when the sea is heavy, nor by a stranger at night. It is difficult for a sailing vessel to leave St. Vaast harbour with the wind between S.W. and S.E., both flood and ebb running to the northward ; but, even with those winds, small vessels with good See chart, No. 2,743.

436 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. pilots may leave the harbour at high water, springs, and pass out north ward of Tatihou island, keeping about a cable from its northern shore in passing. Tides. — During the whole of the rising tide, the stream runs northward between St. Vaast jetty and Tatihou island, and, with the falling tide, it follows the same direction until the highest part of the beach joining that island to the mainland is uncovered, which is at about half ebb. With both streams, at their greatest strength, a strong eddy forms at the end of the jetty and extends over the whole harbour, and with a fresh wind from North to N.E. there is a confused sea within, though very much reduced since the construction of the breakwater. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station in fort de la Hougue, about 110 yards north-eastward of the round tower ; see page 12. PORT DE LA HOUGUE is merely a grounding place, 4 cables long and one cable wide, westward and under the ramparts of La Hougue fort, which partially shelters it from easterly winds ; the water here is generally smooth, but there is considerable sea when it blows freshly from S.S.W. round by East to N.E. It admits vessels of about 14 feet draught at high water, springs, and of 9 feet draught at neaps, but since the completion of St. vaast harbour it is quite deserted ; it might, however, afford useful shelter in bad weather to a vessel of moderate draught compelled to run ashore. The best grounding place is a cable distant from the fort, between the parallels of La Hougue tower and of the wooden storehouse at the foot of the glacis northward of the fort ; this space is bounded westward by a shallow channel which receives all the water flowing from the land. The bottom abreast of the tower dries 1\ feet, and from thence rises gradually towards the northern part of the bay. The bottom is hard, being a mixture of muddy sand and gravel, and yields but little under vessels when aground. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in port de la Hougue at 8h. 42m. The tide rises abreast of La Hougue tower from 14 to 15 feet at springs, and from 1\ to 8^ feet at the lowest neaps ; in the southern part, it rises 2 or 3 feet higher. Fresh winds from S.W. to West raise the tide a foot or two higher than in calm weather, and winds from N.E. to North have a contrary effect. Set chart No. 2,743.

Chap. X.] PORT DE LA HOUGUE. — ROAD. 437 DANGERS. — The following shoals must be avoided when approaching port de la Hougue, especially if there is any sea on : — The Manquet, a small isolated rock which uncovers 6 feet E.S.E. 4^ cables from La Hougue lighthouse, and which, from its advanced position, is much in the way of vessels navigating between La Hougue and St. Vaast. As already described, a black conical buoy is moored near the eastern edge of this rock. Roche Joly, the top of which uncovers 3 feet, bears W.S.W. 6£ cables from La Hougue lighthouse, and the sea breaks on it at high water in bad weather. Jean de la Dune is a small group of four rocky heads which only uncover at springs ; the highest head, awash at low water, bears S.S.W. 5 W. 7 cables from La Hougue lighthouse. The summits of Jean de la Dune, the Joly, and another rock southward of it, are the 'highest heads of the Verdieres reef, a rocky flat, lying nearly parallel with the shore, and on which there is a heavy sea with onshore winds. Both the Roche Joly and Jean de la Dune are cleared by keeping Pernelle spire a little open eastward of the Du Loup iwhite beacon, standing on the sands in port de la Hougue. RADE de la HOUGUE. — This anchorage is south-eastward of port de la Hougue, and, although the sand-banks in its vicinity are well known to be shifting, it affords good anchorage for vessels of deep draught. It extends westward as far as the spires of Reville and St. Vaast churches in line, and, eastward, as far as the Ouest- Drix flat and the northern part of the Bane de la Rade ; its northern limit is the parallel of the Dent and Gavendest rocks, both marked by red buoys ; and, its southern boundary, the small sand-bank named the Haut-fond de la Grande Rade, on which the least water is 27 feet. The holding-ground is good in almost every part of this anchorage, and vessels are well sheltered by the land from winds between S.S.W. and N.W., which are frequent and dangerous in winter ; but, it is open to winds from N.N.E. to S.S.E., which, even when moderate, send in a troublesome swell, but when blowing with any strength raise a heavy sea. See chart, No. 2,743.

438 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. Quarantine.— Vessels suspected of having contagious diseases on board are sent from all the northern ports of France to ride out their quarantine in this roadstead, and, at times, many such may be seen at anchor in it. The lazaretto and health office being, as before stated, on the western side of Tatihou island. The Grande Rade is a small deep in the southern part of La Hougue road about 6 cables long N.E. aad S.W., and 2 cables wide, where large vessels may anchor in excellent holding-ground. The best position is in the centre of the deep in from 7 to 8 fathoms, with the church towers of Pernelle and St. Vaast in one N. by W. \ W.; and, the Bois de la Ville midway between Quineville church tower and a guard-house on the shore. The Petite Rade is the space included between the Grande Rade and the rocks off La Hougue fort, but good holding-ground does not extend much eastward of the line of Reville light touching the south-eastern angle of Fort de 1'Ilet. Between this limit and the Grande Rade, the bottom is of sand and broken shells, and the holding-ground indifferent ; fresh easterly winds also throw in a heavy sea. Pilots anchor vessels in about 4 fathoms, good holding-ground, in the space which has the following limits : — Quetehou church tower on with La Hougue point ; Morsaline and La Hougue lighthouses in line ; and, Reville lighthouse open a little eastward of Fort de 1'Ilet. From this anchorage, vessels of moderate draught may, if necessary, run aground for refuge in port de la Hougue. If drawing over 9 feet, however, and therefore unable to enter either St. Vaast or port de la Hougue during the lowest neaps, such vessels should anchor in the northern part of La Hougue road, where they are in some degree sheltered from strong north-easterly winds and sea by Tatihou island and the rocks southward of it. Bane de la Rade. — This bank, of which the northern portion bounds the Rade de la Hougue in a south-easterly direction, is, within the 5-fathoms line, 4 miles long North and South, and, abreast of its shoalest part one mile from the northern end, 6 or 7 cables wide. There are from 11 to 15 feet on the shoalest parts ; and the northern end, where there are 18 feet close to the 5-fathoms edge, lies about a cable eastward of Reville spire on with the tower on Tatihou island ; and, with La Hougue lighthouse See chart, No. 2,743.

Chap. X.] RADE DE LA HOUGUE. — TIDAL STREAMS. 439 bearing N.W. | W. westerly. From this point, the Haut-Fond de la Rade, a bank with from 4£ to 5 fathoms, extends in a north-easterly direction about 6 cables, to where cape Barfleur and Reville lighthouses are in line N. J E. ; and, La Hougue lighthouse bears W.N.W. Directions. — The entrance to La Hougue roadstead is between the Plateau du Ouest-Drix and the northern part of the Bane de la Rade, which bear from each other N. £ W. and S. f E. distant 9 cables. Approaching La Hougue road from the northward, the mariner should take care that his vessel is not drifted southward of it by the flood stream, which, from the extreme of Barfleur race to about 3 miles off Saire point, runs southward, following the direction of the coast, at the rate of 3 knots, at springs ; close to Saire point, it changes its direction suddenly to the south-west. Vessels of deep draught should keep outside the off-lying shoal patches by attending to the marks already given for clearing them. When southward of the shoal water off Saire point, and to avoid the dangers eastward of Tatihou island, cape Barfleur lighthouse must be kept open eastward of Reville lighthouse until Morsaline and La Hougue lighthouses are in line, then steer about W.S.W. for the Grande Rade. Running in on this course near low water, cape Barfleur light will be hidden for a few moments by Tatihou tower ; directly it re-appears westward of the tower bearing N. by E. a vessel should anchor. To anchor in the northern part of La Hougue road by day or night, run in with Morsaline lighthouse just open southward of La Hougue lighthouse, in order to pass about a cable southward of the shoal patch on the Ouest-Drix, and anchor as soon as Reville light is hidden by Fort de 1'Ilet, or by the tower on Tatihou should the light be seen above the fort, which may be the case towards high water. Tidal Streams.— In the middle of La Hougue road, the stream of flood, at springs, begins about 4| hours before high water in the port, see page 436, and runs about W.S.W. It attains its greatest rate, 2\ knots, about 2J hours before high water in the harbour, and its mean duration is 5h. 20m. The ebb stream commences about 25 minutes after high water in the port, its mean duration is 7h. 10m., its direction N.E. and E.N.E., and its greatest rate, 2\ knots, occurs about 4h. 20m. after high water. See chart, No. 2,743. 2E SO 11886

440 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. ILES ST. MARCOUF.— -These two islands and the rocks round them which uncover at low water, with the Bastin rock, are nearly midway between port de la Hougue and the entrance to the Grand Vay, their outer edge being upwards of 4 miles from the shore, and they occupy a space about 8 cables long E.N.E. and W.S.W. and 2\ cables wide. They are but little above the level of high water, but the fort, and especially the large case-mated tower on the highest point of ile du Large, the eastern island, may be seen from 9 to 12 miles distant. These islands, distinguished by the names ile du Large and ile de Terre, are separated by a narrow channel, through which the tidal streams run with great rapidity ; a coasting vessel having missed La Hougue road, with a strong north-westerly wind and flood tide, may anchor during the remainder of the flood in a small bight, named Mannette, on the southern shore of ile de Terre, provided she is moored securely and steadied by a hawser to the shore, for the eddies formed by the points of that island occasion a heavy sea. LIGHT. — An occulting ivhite light of the fifth order, eclipsed every four seconds, and visible 9 miles, is exhibited from the fort on ile du Large, the eastern St. Marcouf island, at 56 feet above high water. Telegraph cable. — St. Marcouf fort is in telegraphic communi cation with the mainland. The cable takes a south-westerly direction straight to the shore. Bane de St. Marcouf extends 3 miles in a N.N.W. direction from St. Marcouf ile du Large, and the soundings vary from 4£ to 5| fathoms between it and the southern part of the Bane de la Rade, which lies 7 or 8 cables nearer the land. Both banks consist of large masses of sand and broken shells, the Bane de St. Marcouf having from 7 to 12 feet on its shoalest parts. The tides cross them obliquely, and occasion strong eddies even in calm weather, and with easterly winds or northerly gales the sea breaks violently upon both banks from half ebb to half flood. St. Marcouf bank has off its northern end a narrow ridge of sand, or Haut-Fond, running about If miles in an easterly direction nearly at right angles with the Bane de la Rade, with 4| fathoms at its eastern extreme and from f>\ to 7 fathoms at other parts, and from See chart. No. 2,743,

Chap. X.] ILES ST. MARCOUF.— INSHORE CHANNEL. 441 10 to 8 fathoms on either side close to ; as it lies nearly across the tidal streams, the eddies produced by this narrow bank, at springs, cause a high sea when it blows hard. St, Marcouf light bearing S. by W., or, Cape Barfleur lighthouse open eastward of Moulard beacon turret, lead outside this bank. Bane du Cardonnet extends in a S.E. direction 6| miles within the 5-fathoms line from St. Marcouf ile de Terre to about N. by E. \ E. 3^ miles from Grand Camp church, and forms, at about 4 miles from the shore, a barrier in front of the Grand Vay ; from its south eastern extreme in 6 fathoms, Colleville church tower is on with point Percee S.S.E. | E. The bank consists of sand and broken shells, and its shoalest spots of from 4 to 10 feet extend from West to S.S.E., about a mile from the island ; it slopes gradually towards the South, but its northern side ;<s steep-to, which causes the sea to break heavily on it with strom; winds from the northward or eastward, or when there is much sv/ell on, and especially during the ebb tide. Farther eastward towards the meridian of Maisy church, the depths on the bank vary from 14 to 17 feet, and the water gradually deepens towards its south-eastern extreme. CHANNEL between ILES ST. MARCOUF and the COAST. — The south-eastern entrance to this channel is about on the meridian of the old ruined mill at Criqueville, and it terminates north-westward at La Hougue roadstead ; it has 9 fathoms at its south-eastern entrance, gradually shoaling to 5| or 6 fathoms in the north-west, and for deep draught vessels its navigable width is from 1 to 2 miles. It affords good anchorage in moderate weather and with off-shore winds, except W.S.W. of St. Marcouf islands, where a rocky bottom about 8 cables wide almost crosses the channel from the shore, and also E.S.E. and S.E. of Quineville, where the rocky shoals of St. Floxel, of 4 fathoms, extend If miles from the land. The anchorage in the south-eastern part, off the entrance to the Grand Vay, is known as Capelle road ; see page 444. The dangers to be avoided at low water are, the north-western part of the Cardonnet, which forms a small bank with from 10 to 14 feet water lying in a N.W. and S.E. direction, a mile westward of St. Marcouf ile de Terre ; the rocky shoals of St. Floxel, before mentioned, which extend from the land as far as Pernelle church open 2° eastward of La Hougue tower ; and, the Bavequien rocks, See charts. Nos. 2,743 and 2,073. ■2 c, 2 SO 11886

442 CAPB BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. X. which uncover at low water and border the beach from the parallel of St. Marcouf church as far as the bearing E.N.E. from Quineville church. Local authorities state that a well-found vessel might ride out a heavy gale from the north-eastward in this channel, under shelter of the high parts of the Cardonnet, the St. Marcouf, or the Rade banks, which break the violence of the sea ; it is, however, but precarious shelter, and should only be resorted to as a last resource when a vessel is embayed and finds it impossible to gain an offing, for the sea in such weather is sure to be very heavy in the channel between the banks on the flood, and a breaking sea is caused by the weather tide on the ebb. If a vessel is obliged to bring up in this channel, such an anchorage should be chosen, that in case she parts or is compelled to run ashore, she may do so where there is some chance of safety for the crew. The Magdeleine bank at the entrance of the Grand Vay should be carefully avoided, as it is of hard sand, and a vessel running on it in bad weather would certainly go to pieces. Directions. — The channel between the St. Marcouf and Cardonnet banks and the coast may be taken, even at low water, if the weather is moderate and strict attention be paid to the lead. With a fair wind, point Percee and Huppain wood in line S.E. \ E., leads in the deepest water between the meridian of Maisy church and St. Marcouf ile de Terre. From thence, steer about N.N.W. until Pernelle church tower, bearing about N. \ W., is 3° or 4° open eastward of La Hougue tower ; keep this mark on until Quineville church bears W.S.W., then haul out north-eastward for the Rade de la Hougue. Tidal Streams. — In the channel between the iles St. Marcouf and the shore, the rate of the streams, at springs, is about 3 knots, and their maximum rate is about the time of half flood and half ebb in port de la Hougue, see page 436. The direction of the flood through La Hougue road is W.S.W. ; at the northern end of St. Marcouf bank, S.W. by W. ; round the iles St. Marcouf, S.S.W. ; on the middle of the Cardonnet bank, South ; and, about a mile eastward of the end of that bank, S.E. In mid-channel, however, the flood stream runs nearly parallel with the shore from the Rade de la Hougue as far as the meridian of the iles St. Marcouf, it then turns S.S.W. towards the entrance of the Grand Vay, beyond which it again See charts, Nos. 2,743 and 2,073.

Chap. X.] ILES ST. MARCOUF. — TIDAL STREAMS.— GRAND VAY. 443 follows the direction of the shore. The ebb is rather weaker than the flood and at each position given runs nearly in an opposite direction. At neaps, both streams are feeble except at the entrance of the Grand Vay. GRAND VAY.— The shore is flat and for the most part com posed of sand-hills from port de la Hougue to the entrance of the Grand Vay, which is an indentation of the coast in the south-western part of the Baie de la Seine ; it is about 4 miles wide and 5 miles deep, and at its head are the small tidal harbours of Carentan and Isigny. The entrance to this deep bight is about 5 milos south ward of the iles St. Marcouf ; it is choked with sand and would probably cease to be navigable but for the extensive harbour works and the periodical freshets from the small rivers Taute and Douve on its western shore, and Vire and Aure on its eastern shore, whose channels afford sufficient depth for vessels of moderate draught to reach Isigny and Carentan at high tides. Formerly the tide flowed far into the interior, inundating the low lands bordering the rivers ; to remedy this, dikes were constructed at the mouth of each river with flood gates at the upper ends of the harbours, which close with the rising tide. The church of Ste. Marie du Mont stands con spicuously 2^ miles from the western shore, and the fine church spire at Maisy and the village and church at Grand Camp serve to mark clearly the eastern side of the entrance to the Grand Vay. Magdeleine bank. — The entrance to the Grand Vay is more than half closed by the Magdeleine bank, which uncovers at low water 2J miles from the western shore and is a continuation of the sandy strand, 5 cables wide, bordering the shore from port de la Hougue southward. The highest parts of this bank are scarcely covered at high water, neaps, and it is considered the most dangerous of the Grand Vay banks, for the streams cross it with great rapidity, and raise a heavy sea on a weather tide. The sand also of which it is composed is so hard that a«vessel grounding on it in bad weather would have but little chance. Bell-buoys. — A large red bell-buoy with conical top-mark is moored off the northern edge of the shoal in about 17 feet water at the entrance of the Carentan channel. Another large bell-buoy, red and black with spherical top-mark, is moored in 10 feet water at the entrance to the Isigny channel ; it bears S.E. easterly 2£ miles from the first buoy described. See charte, Nos. 2,743 and 2,073.

[Chap. X. CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. 444 The Bane de la Ravine is an extension of Brevand point, dividing the lower courses of the rivers Taute and Vire. It extends as far northward as the parallel of Maisy point, its summit barely covered at spring tides and the greater part of its surface dry during neaps. The greater part of the space between Maisy point and this bank is occupied by shifting sands ; that named the Feraillon, on the western side of the Isigny channel, is the only one that does not change its surface, being covered with gravel, beneath which there is said to be solid rock. There is little danger in grounding on the sands within the Grand Vay with smooth water during the dry summer season, for the tides then have but little strength ; but, during abundant rains or with equinoctial tides, the ebb stream is very strong and heaps up the sand under vessels aground, causing them to list over and capsize. MAISY POINT, the eastern point of the Grand Vay, is very low, but defended against the heavy sea which sometimes rolls in by the Roches de Grand Camp, a ledge fronting the coast and extending H miles westward and 2| miles eastward of the point. Buoys.— The Roches de Grand Camp are marked by four black buoys moored from 2\ to 5 cables outside their outer edge. GRAND CAMP LIGHT.— From a wooden gibbet 875 yards westward of Grand Camp church is exhibited, at 26 feet above high water, a fixed white light, visible 6 miles. Capelle road. — There is good anchorage off the entrance of the Grand Vay in Capelle road, where, in moderate weather, vessels may remain unil the tide has risen sufficiently to allow of their entering the narrows. This anchorage, about a mile in extent, is bounded westward by the line of Carentan church tower on with the eastern houses of Grand Vay hamlet ; eastward, by the rocky bottom which terminates in the direction of the small fort near the shore on with Maisy spire bearing S. \ W. % and, northward, by the high land of Menil, which rises eastward of Port-en-Bessin, on with point Percee ; the latter mark also leads outside the rocky ledge and dangers off Grand Camp. The best berth is, with the end of Menil cliffs on with, or a little open northward of, point Percee ; and, the small fort open about 3° eastward of Maisy spire. At this anchorage, the flood stream runs S.S.W. and S.W. by S., and it changes about half an hour before See chart. No 2,073.

Chap. X.] MAISY POINT. — CAPELLE ROAD. — CARENTAN. 445 high water. The most favourable time for entering the narrows is about 1| hours before high water, but, with a head wind, it is prudent to weigh in time to arrive abreast of Grouin point, on the eastern shore of the Grand Vay, before the commencement of the ebb. CARENTAN, on the river Taute, about 9 miles from the entrance and on the western side of the Grand Vay where the Vire and Taute canal terminates, has a tidal harbour with a Bassin-a-flot or wet dock at its head. The Bassin-a-flot is entered by a lock 136 feet long, 40 feet wide, and with 13 feet 6 inches over the sill at high water, ordinary springs ; it is nearly 1,600 yards in length and varies from 60 to 120 yards in width, its shores thickly planted with trees until near the town, at the upper end, where are 265 yards of substantial stone quay frontage ; the quays communicating by well paved roads with the railway station about 400 yards distant. From the entrance of the Bassin-a-flot, dikes awash at high water, neaps, at all their outer part, like those of Isigny, the success of which led to the construction of these, extend no less than 7,000 yards, terminating abreast of the little village of Grand Vay. The width between these dikes is, at the entrance, 132 yards, narrowing to 71 yards near the upper end. Depths. — The bottom of the channel is far above the level of low water, and the depth varies considerably, but practically the port is available for vessels of 13 feet draught at springs, but only for those of 7 or 8 feet at neaps. The Carentan channel receives the waters of the Vire and Taute canal as well as of the rivers Taute and Douve, and its depth is only maintained by the extensive modern embankments assisted by the scour of these united streams. Entering from seaward, the channel commences near the western bell-buoy, described at page 443, and is well marked on either side for nearly 3 miles up to the dike-ends by numerous buoys, and the dike-ends and the whole of their submersible parts are marked by beacons at short intervals ; red buoys and beacons being left on the starboard hand in entering, black buoys and beacons on the port hand, as usual. From the changeable character of the channel, both as regards direction and depth, it is dangerous, under any circumstances, to attempt it without pilot. The town of Carentan contains about 3,000 inhabitants and is the See chart, No. 2,073.

[Chap. X. 446 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. centre of a fertile grazing district ; it was formerly a fortress, but its ramparts have been levelled and ditches filled in. It has a handsome church and spire, manufactures of lace and cotton goods, and a trade in cattle, horses, hemp, flax, butter, building materials, &c. Besides its coasting trade, the chief traffic is with Southampton and with Norway and Sweden. It is on the direct Paris and Cherbourg railway, and therefore has ample means of communication with all parts of the country. LIGHTS. — Two fixed leading lights on wooden scaffoldings are exhibited as a guide through the channel of Carentan ; viz., a red light on the sea bank 16 feet, and a white light at Brevand 49 feet, above high water ; the ivhite light is distant 940 yards S. 46° W. from the red light, and is visible 7 miles ; the red light' being visible 9 miles. The lights show through an arc of 32°, their maximum intensity being when in line, which is the leading mark for the channel. ISIGNY, on the eastern side and 6 miles from the entrance of the Grand Vay, also has the benefit of direct railway communication ; it stands on the river Aure which joins the Vire just below the town, both rivers being guided to the point of junction between dikes, and, from thence, in one channel in a N. by E. direction, also between rough stone dikes, their inner ends above the level of the highest tides and their outer parts awash at high water, neaps. The eastern dike extends 3,046 yards, the western dike being more than 600 yards longer and ending abreast of and about If cables from Grouin point. The width between the dikes at the entrance is 102 yards, and it narrows to 92 yards at their inner end ; their whole tidal length is marked at short intervals by beacons, red on the star board hand and black on the port hand in entering. At the town the width between the quays is only 90 feet, except where a gare has been made where vessels can be turned round ; there is an old stone quay 85iyards in length, and also one of recent construction 220 yards in length; there are also two small unloading slips, as well as building and repairing slips. The staple of the town is butter, of which a large quantity is exported annually, also grain, colza oil, and stone. The population is about 3,000, and the trade is represented by the entry of about 130 small vessels annually, of an aggregate of about 9,000 tons. The high road from Paris to Cherbourg passes through Isigny, as does also the railway from Grand Camp to Paris and Cherbourg. See chart, No. 2,073.

Chap. X.] ISIGNY. — TIDAL STREAMS. — COAST. 447 Depths. — As at Carentan, the bottom of the channel is far above the low water level. The harbour is available for vessels of 13 feet draught, at springs, and 7 or 8 feet at neaps ; the berths alongside the quays are good. The depth is reported to have rather increased since the completion of the dikes and embankments, the silting up during the summer, when there is but little water in the Aure, being more than counterbalanced by the scour of the freshets occasioned periodically by heavy rains. Vessels may lighten, if necessary, during neaps, at Grouin or Beuzeville before proceeding up to Isigny. The Passe d'lsigny, between the western end of the Roches de Grand Camp and the Feraillon bank, is the channel leading from the sea to the dike-heads and thence to Isigny. It is well marked by buoys and beacons as far as Grouin point, from whence, as before stated, the submersible dikes between which the channel then lies are also marked by beacons at short intervals up to Isigny. The distance from abreast of the inner black buoy of the Roches de Grand Camp to the dike-ends is nearly 3 miles. LIGHTS. — There are at Isigny two fixed white leading lights, bearing N. by E. and S. by W. from each other, and 656 yards apart. They are respectively 26 and 62 feet above high water, and visible 9 and 12 miles for 18° on each side of the axis of the channel. The lower light is shown from a wooden gibbet at the point of junction of the Aure and Vire rivers, the upper light from a metal mast farther inland ; the two lights in line lead up the channel between the dikes. Tides and tidal Streams. — It is high water, full and change, at Isigny at 9h. 10m. Pilots estimate the depth by deducting 6| feet from the height of tide given in the "Annuaire des Marees a Cherbourg." The flood stream, at springs, loses its strength when the Grand Vay banks are covered. It crosses the Magdeleine bank with some rapidity until 3^ or 4 hours flood, and inclines towards the inner banks, which renders the entrance to the channel some what difficult with a head wind. The beginning of the ebb is weak, but as soon as the banks begin to uncover its rate rapidly increases. At Isigny, both streams run strongly in the river Vire but are scarcely preceptible in the river Aure. The COAST. — From point Maisy, on the eastern side of the entrance to the Grand Vay, to point Percee, the distance is 5| miles, See chart, No. 2,073.

[Chap. X. 448 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. the general trend of the coast being about E. by S. \ S. ; a mile east ward of Grand Camp church, the land suddenly rises and a perpen dicular chalk cliff about 400 feet high commences, which may be seen 12 or 15 miles off. The land above the cliff is level and without any conspicuous object on it except the church of St. Pierre du Mont, which stands in the midst of a clump of high trees. From point Percee, cape Manvieux bears S.E. by E. \ E. 1H miles, the little harbour of Port-en-Bassin lying between them ; and, nearly as far as St. C6me-de-Fresne chapel, 1^ miles eastward of cape Manvieux, the land as seen from the offing appears nearly a level plain upwards of 400 feet above the sea, overtopped only by the church towers and groups of trees surrounding the villages. When nearer the coast, it presents a great variety of aspect ; the chalk cliffs continue to about a mile south-eastward of point Percee, and, from thence as far as the guard-house at Ste. Honorine, the high table-land recedes somewhat from the coast, the shore being low, sandy, and bounded by low sand-hills, in front of which is a beach of muddy sand and shingle about 2 or 3 cables wide at low water. Between Ste. Honorine guard-house and St. C6me-de-Fresne chapel, the shore is again precipitous, consisting of high cliffs of rock and brown clay intersected by narrow valleys, of which some are as deep as the level of high-water mark, but the greater part are only half the depth of the cliffs. Vessels of deep draught may approach to within a mile of the shore between point Percee and cape Manvieux without danger. Eastward of the chapel of St. C6me-de-Fresne, the appearance of the coast changes from cliffs of rock and brown clay to gracefully undulating hills, richly cultivated, and rising with a gentle slope behind the shore as far as the left bank of the river Orne. From cape Manvieux to the Semaphore of St. Aubin-Bernieres near St. Aubin point, a distance of 8^ miles, the coast trends E. by S. | S. ; and, from thence, S.E. t\ E. 7 miles to the mouth of the Orne at Oyestreham. In the vicinity of Courseulles, the entrance to which is If miles westward of the Semaphore of St. Aubin-Bernieres, the coast again consists of low sand-hills, except in front of the village of St. Aubin, where its direction begins to trend more south eastward. The highest reefs of the Plateau de Calvados adjoin the shore along this coast-line eastward of cape Manvieux, rendering a near approach to it dangerous. The different localities may be recognised See charts, Nos. 2,073 and 1,821.

Chap. X.] COAST. — GRAND CAMP. — PORT-EN-BESSIN. 449 from seaward by the clumps of trees surrounding the villages and by the church towers appearing above them. Tailleville hill, south eastward of Courseulles, is remarkable, as is also the hill at Amfre ville on the eastern bank of the Orne, not far from the mouth of that river. Between the low water rocks in front of most of the villages along the coast, there exist small deposits of muddy sand and gravel, called Anneaux, which afford no shelter with northerly winds, but where, at the commencement of the fine season, the villagers fit out large fishing-boats of from 8 to 10 feet draught, when laden. During the winter, these boats remain either at Courseulles or in the Orne. Between St. Aubin point and the river Orne, as far as Lyon, the coast is rather high ; in other parts it consists chiefly of sand-hills. Grand Camp is a little village on the shore between point Maisy and Criqueville and is backed by a low hill ; its position is marked at night by the small fixed white light described at page 444. It has railway communication with Isigny and is an important fishing station ; its people, principally fishermen and sailors, fit out thirty or forty good-sized fishing-boats which lie under the lee of a small breakwater of rough stones, or moored to buoys on a small sandy strand, dry throughout at low water, springs, and protected from the high sea with on-shore winds by the Grand Camp rocks. Some of the pilots for the Grand Vay reside in this village and others at iBigny. A Life-boat is stationed at Grand Camp. Point Percee is the north-eastern point of the high chalk cliffs which border the shore from about a mile eastward of Grand Camp to a mile south-eastward of point Percee. The point projects but little and is remarkable only from the change in the direction of the coast-line. A flat of sand and gravel, divided into several parallel banks, extends about 8 cables E.N.E. from the point ; the eddies occasioned by these banks, which lie across the tidal streams, cause a slight race on a weather tide, but it is not dangerous to decked vessels. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on point Percee. See page 12. PORT-EN-BESSIN is 7 miles eastward of point Percee ; it is at the opening of one of the most considerable of the valleys which See chart, No. 2,073.

[Chap. X. 450 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. intersect the high cliffs of rock and brown clay on this part of the coast. The opening is about 130 yards wide between the cliff of Huppain on the West and of Castel on the East. Within the opening, the valley suddenly widens and forms a circular plain more than a mile in diameter, of which the level is from 15 to 20 feet above high water ; it is almost entirely surrounded by gently sloping hills. Depths, &C. — Fronting the valley is a steep gravel beach, which when the sea is smooth, affords a good grounding place for fishing boats ; and fronting the beach is a break in the rocks which border the shore, forming a natural basin, 140 yards wide and 2 cables long, with sand and gravel bottom, dry at low water but having 21 feet in it at high water, springs, and 18 feet at neaps. Between 1845 and 1860, no less than £1,000,000 was expended in the attempt to trans form this small natural basin into a harbour of refuge. Two massive moles, their bases 550 yards apart, extend from the shore, their ends curving towards each other and leaving an opening about 110 yards wide, with 27 feet water in the entrance at high water, springs, and 24 feet at neaps. The western mole is 500 yards in length, the eastern mole 35 yards less. Several mooring buoys are laid down within this space, but, with northerly winds, in weather when a vessel would require refuge, the sea is so high and the surf so great that it would not only be most dangerous to run for this harbour, but very unsafe for any vessel already in it. The village of Bessin has a population of about 1,200, it is con nected with the city of Bayeux, about 6 miles distant, by road, and, through it, with the general railway system ; it has a large fishery but its coasting and other trade is insignificant ; a few small vessels of about 150 tons arrive annually during the fine season with coal from England and timber from the Baltic, and sail again in ballast. At low water, abundant springs of fresh water issue from apertures in the rocks which dry at that time. A Life-boat is stationed at Port-en-Bessin. LEADING LIGHTS.— A fixed white low light, visible 6 miles, is shown from a wooden gibbet under the western cliff of Port-en- Bessin at 92 feet above high water. An upper fixed light, 131 feet above high water, is exhibited from the window of a dwelling 94 yards from the low light ; the lights in line S.W. southerly lead into the harbour. The high light shows See chart, No. 2,073.

At all other times it shows white, and is visible 14 miles. The lights are visible for 18° on each side of the leading line, and their brilliancy decreases as the distance from that line increases. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Port-en-Bessin at 8h. 57m. ; ordinary springs rise 23 feet, neaps 20 feet, above the level of the soundings, which is about 3 feet below the level of low water, ordinary springs. Tide Signals are made from a mast on the inner end of the eastern mole ; they indicate the depth within that mole. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on the cliff just westward of Port-en-Bessin. See page 12. Arromanches, a pretty little fishing village used as a watering-place by the inhabitants of Bayeux, stands on the sea shore at the entrance of a wide valley three quarters of a mile east ward of cape Manvieux ; and, as it is very conspicuous from seaward, it serves to point out the position of that cape, which otherwise has little to distinguish it but its height, and the steep cliff in which it terminates. The villagers fit out small half-decked fishing vessels which, by means of capstans, they heave up a shingle beach much resembling that at Port-en-Bessin. A rocky shore, which uncovers nearly 5 cables seaward at low water, and forms a point advancing in an easterly direction from cape Manvieux, arrests the sea during northerly winds, and diminishes the violence of the surf on the beach, which is otherwise very exposed. PLATEAU de CALVADOS.— This rocky flat commences just eastward of Arromanches, and extends 13 miles eastward along the coast, as far as Lyon. The parts of the flat which uncover are, the Calvados rock, from which the name of the flat is derived ; the Roches de Ver ; the Essarts de Langrune ; and, the Roches de Lyon. A tradition exists that a forest of chestnut trees, called the forest of Hautefeuille, originally covered the rocks which dry at low water between Bernieres and Lyon, and that its destruction took place about 300 years since ; roots of chestnut trees are said to be found in the tissues of these rocks, and they are so difficult to extract, and the wood so hard, that it blunts the best tools. See charts, No. 2,703 and 1,821.

It is about 5 cables long W.N.W. and E.S.E., and 3 cables wide ; its western part is highest, and uncovers 3 feet above the lowest tides. The chapel on with the spire of Bazanville church, which stands on the top of the hills 2 miles inland, bearing South, leads 3 cables westward. The north-western angle of the Plateau de Calvados bears N.E. by E. one mile from the western edge of the Calvados rock ; it is steep-to, and, from this point, preserves a distance of from 1\ to 2\ miles from the shore as far as Essarts point, the north-eastern extreme of the flat, which lies 3 cables westward of Langrune and Douvres church spires in line bearing S.S.W. \. W. westerly ; with Ver lighthouse bearing West, northerly ; and, Oyestreham Semaphore, at the entrance of the river Orne, S.S.E. \ E. easterly. From Essarts point, which is 2\ miles from the shore, the edge of the flat turns sharply southward, and, approaching the coast within a mile, continues at that distance until it is lost beneath the drying sands westward of the mouth of the river Orne. Essarts point is the most dangerous part of the plateau, having on it only 4 feet water and rising suddenly from a depth of 20 feet ; it occasions a change in the direction of the tidal streams and causes a race, during springs, on a weather tide. There is but little water on all parts of the flat, and, the rocks being uneven, a heavy sea breaks on them with strong northerly winds. Buoys. — A black buoy is moored 5 cables N.N.W. from the north western angle of the Plateau de Calvados and rather more than one mile from the western edge of the Calvados rock. A red bell-buoy is moored in 7 fathoms N.E. by E. one mile from Essarts point, with Langrune and Douvres spires in line ; and, the outer black buoy at the entrance of the Oyestreham channel S.S.E. f E. 5| miles. Caution. — Both these buoys being in so exposed a position, are very liable to drift, and therefore the mariner should be on his guard. Anchorage. — A small anchorage with good holding-ground named the Fosse d'Espagne, lies midway between Arromanches and the Calvados rock, in a small elbow formed by the steep western See charts, Nos. 2,073 and 1 821.

The best position in which to anchor is in about 20 feet water, with Crepon church tower seen between those of Mevaisnes and Asnelles ; and, the tall spire of Bernieres on with the houses of Ver hamlet nearest to Ver lighthouse ; this anchorage is exposed to all but off-shore or moderate easterly winds. The soundings deepen rather suddenly outside the Calvados flat ; but there is no good anchorage ground at less than a mile from its deep western edge, or than 2 miles from its eastern edge. Directions. — Vessels of deep draught may approach to within about a mile of the shore, even at low water, between point Percee and cape Manvieux, but it is imprudent to stand in so near with northerly winds. Coasters keeping close in, with off-shore winds, should be on their guard against the gusts which proceed from the valleys. Good holding-ground may be found at 2 or 3 miles from the shore, in 9 or 10 fathoms, where vessels sometimes anchor to await the turn of tide. The tidal streams follow nearly the direction of the shore, and their greatest strength, at springs, does not exceed 3| knots. In approaching Essarts point of the Calvados flat from the eastward, keep northward of the lines of Ver church tower on with the Bois des Epines bearing W. £ S., until Langrune and Douvres spires are in line S.S.W. W. westerly. The Bois des Epines consists of a few large elms, is very conspicuous, and being used as a landmark, is carefully preserved by the local authorities. It is nearly a quarter of a mile inland, at the foot of the hills between Ver lighthouse and the Chateau de Vaux. In rounding Essarts point from the eastward, keep Lyon church tower open westward of the western house of St. Aubin-d'Arquenay village, bearing about South, until the line of Langrune and Douvres spires in one is crossed. LIGHT. — Pointe de Ver lighthouse stands 800 yards inland on the slope of a small hill 4| miles eastward of cape Manvieux and 10^ miles westward of the entrance to the river Orne ; it is a square tower from which is exhibited at 138 feet abo\e high water a fixed and flashing white light ; the fixed light being varied by a flash every four minutes -, the flash is preceded and followed by a short eclipse which is not total when within 6 miles. The light is dioptric, of the third order, and is visible 18 miles. By day, Ver lighthouse may be easily recognised in approaching it from eastward or westward ; but, from the northward, it is difficult See charts, Nos. 2,073 and 1.821.

[Chap. X. 454 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. to distinguish on account of the high land behind it. The light was established to give warning of approach to the Calvados flat ; but with southerly winds it is very useful to vessels from the westward, bound to Havre, who, after passing cape Barfleur, sight this light, if possible, 9 or 12 miles distant, and, from thence, steer for the lights on cape de la Heve, which are then soon made. By this means they avoid making the land too far northward of Havre and the consequent delay in entering their port. COURSEULLES. — This small tidal harbour, 2\ miles eastward of Ver lighthouse and %\ miles westward of Oyestreham near the entrance of the river Orne, is in fact the channel through which the waters of the river Seulle are conducted, intercepted by a dam which forms the head of the inner harbour or Bassin-a-flot, in which they are retained or discharged at pleasure by means of sluices into the outer harbour, and from thence through the channel to sea. The entrance channel is above the low water level and lies between two wooden jetties running nearly parallel with each other ; the western jetty is 196 yards in length, the eastern jetty not quite so long. The width between them is only 122 feet at their outer end and 90 feet at their inner end. The sand-bank on the western side of the entrance channel is awash at high water, neaps, and prevents access to the western jetty-head, except by the channel itself. It is, however, very steep towards the channel, so that if a vessel grounds upon it in entering, she has no difficulty in hauling off again with a rising tide. A low stone dike extends 325 yards from the eastern jetty-head in the same direction as the jetty ; it serves to confine the stream and thus to maintain the direction and depth of the channel. This dike covers at 12 feet rise ; it is marked by a broom beacon, 82 yards beyond the end, and by two black buoys, one at its end, the other on the dike, about 140 yards from the jetty-head. A red buoy moored 70 yards from the western jetty-head marks the western side of the channel, in which is a white warping buoy for the use of vessels entering or leaving. Depths.— There are from 13 to 14 feet water in the channel outside the jetties at high water, springs, and 4^ feet less at neaps. Within the jetty-heads it is somewhat deeper, though subject to temporary accumulations of sand, but, in ordinary weather, at &t- chart, No. 1,821

At the inner end of the jetties is the outer harbour, a mere widening of the channel between rough stone embankments, with numerous sets of berth ing piles and extensive quays averaging 60 feet in width. The outer harbour is 635 yards long with a maximum width of only 49 yards. At its head is the entrance to the inner harbour or Bassin-a-flot, which is by a single pair of flood-gates, with a depth over the sill of 14 feet at high water, springs, and 9£ feet at neaps ; and, a width of 32 feet. Its length is 320 yards, and width 6H yards ; on its western side, a slip occupies a space of 158?? yards. The depth in the Bassin-a-flot is about 14 feet 6 inches at high water, springs, and is lowered to about 10 feet at low water by the sluices before mentioned. It also has ample quay accommodation of very solid construction. Courseulles has the advantage of direct railway communication with Caen through the little town of Luc, a thriving watering place between Courseulles and Oyestreham, and, from thence, with the general system of France. Its trade, however, with the exception of a rather extensive fishery, is small, its imports being coal and Baltic timber, and its exports nil. The total annual tonnage entering the port, including a few small steamers, is about 28,000 tons. LIGHTS. — West jetty. — A fixed ivhite light, visible 6 miles, is exhibited at 30 feet above high water, from a wooden gibbet on Courseulles western jetty-head ; it is, however, said to be frequently hidden by fog and mist. East jetty. — A fixed green light, 25 feet above high water and visible 4 miles, is shown from an iron standard on the eastern jetty head, when there are not less than 10 feet water in the channel. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Courseulles at 9h. 7m. ; ordinary springs rise 20 feet, neaps 15ij feet above the level of the lowest tides. Tide signals. — The depth of water in the channel commencing at 6^ feet is signalled from a mast and yard erected on the shore near the inner end of the eastern jetty : see pnge 12. Directions. — Tailleville hill and trees, the fine spire at Bernieres, and Ver lighthouse, are all excellent objects by which the position of Courseulles may be determined from a distance. Vessels should remain outside the plateau de Calvados or in the anchorage of the Fosse de Courseulles until half an hour or three quarters of an hour before high water, as they will then be able to steer direct for the entrance channel, and will have nothing to fear from the Marguerite or Germain rocks. If the wind should be off the land, half an hour longer may be required for warping in. For the deepest water, with a heavy sea, vessels may run for the harbour either between the Germain rock, which uncovers 4 feet, and the Essarts de Bernieres ; or, between the Ver rocks and the Germain. Banville church tower on with Courseulles West jetty light S.W. by W. \ W. leads to the harbour entrance by the first ; Beny spire on with the small church tower at Courseulles S. \ E. by the second, this line leading a little westward of the Vallette rock on which the sea breaks. In running for the harbour from the western side, however, it is better to pass eastward of the Vallette rock by bringing Beny spire on with a little mound on which there is a small battery, a cable eastward of the eastern jetty, bearing S. \ E. ; this leads directly towards a small red buoy, moored about 2^ cables south-westward of the Marguerite rock, which rock is awash at low water, and, with another small rock almost awash and 100 yards westward of it, marks the south-western extreme of the shelf of rock separating the Fosse de Courseulles from the Anneau de la Marguerite. Anchorage. — In ordinary weather, small vessels may find safe anchorage either in the Anneau de la Marguerite in about 16 feet, or in the Fosse de Courseulles in from 2\ to 3^ fathoms, good holding-ground. Those unable to enter Courseulles harbour against a strong ebb tide may also, in fine weather, safely ground in the channel and await the next tide. Semaphore. — The Semaphore station of St. Aubin-Bernieres is 1\ miles eastward of Courseulles jetties ; see page 12. ORNE RIVER.— The river Orne has its source near Seez, and from thence it trends in a north-vvesterly direction until it enters the department of Calvados, where it turns to N. by E. in passing Caen ; here it becomes navigable, and, 9 miles below See chart, No. 1,821.

Chap. X.] 457 ORNE RIVER.— CAEN. that town, finds its way into the sea between the sand-hills of Siege and Merville points, nearly 10 miles eastward of Courseulles and more than a mile eastward of Oyestreham church. At low water, the river formally ran by winding channels through the wide expanse of sand which dries 2 miles out from the shore at the entrance. To obtain a greater depth of water, a submersible dike, marked by beacons, was constructed, commencing just inside Merville point and extending 1\ miles in a north-westerly direction outside Siege point to a position about 1^ cables north-eastward of the pier-heads of Oyestreham, and from thence a farther distance of 4^ cables N. by E. | E., thus confining the stream to one channel, which, turning sharply round Siege point, flows between the land and the dike for its whole length north-westward, and then to the sea in front of Oyestreham. This channel, therefore, forms the entrance to Oyestreham and also to the river Orne itself ; but, since the construction of the canal from Oyestreham to Caen, the navigation by the river to that city, except by the small Havre passenger steamers. has been entirely abandoned and needs no further notice, though vessels of 8 or 9 feet draught may still use it. The sand-banks off the entrance are shifting and change their height, shape, and position almost every tide, rendering it most imprudent to venture in without a pilot ; for, to ground on them would almost always involve the loss of the vessel. The parts least subject to change are those near low-water mark ; they are always covered during neaps and only uncover a short time at springs. The banks formed on this part of the shore are named by the pilots baltures, and, with strong northerly winds, there is a heavy sea on them on the flood and breakers on the ebb. The Oiseaux, the high banks on the western side of the entrance, have a decided tendency to extend eastward, thus slowly forcing the entrance channel in that direction. CAEN is 9 miles from the sea by the river, and 1\ miles by the canal ; it is at the confluence of the rivers Orne and Odon. is on the Paris and Cherbourg railway, and is a place of great importance, with an increasing trade, and a population of about 45,000. It may be considered a double port, having its wet dock or Bassin-a-flot entered by the Oyestreham canal, and its natural tidal grounding harbour in the bed of the river Orne, which also has an entrance into the Bassin-a-flot, and some quay frontage but little used ■See chart, No. 1,821. 2 F2 SO 11886

The Bassin-a-flot is rectangular, is entered from the canal by a lock 40 feet wide at the gates, is 622 yards in length by 55 yards in width, and has a general depth of 15 feet. It has good quays, steam cranes, and two careeuing slips for small vessels, but no dry dock. It communicates with an inner basin with 1,350 yards of quays, on which rails are laid, and vessels unload direct into railway trucks. The Canal de Caen is entered from Oyestreham harbour by a lock, at high water, as described on the following page, and is about 1\ miles in length to the lock at Caen. It has a uniform central depth, maintained by dredging, of 16 feet 6 inches ; it is crossed by three swing bridges, and its available width for navigation is limited by the narrowest bridge opening, which is 49 feet 8 inches -wide. The regulations for the navigation of the canal prescribe that vessels leaving Caen for the sea, shall, whenever necessary, moor to allow those arriving to pass freely. Coals may be obtained with facility, though not often required, at from 16s. to 18s. per ton, about 3,000 tons being usually in stock. There is, however, a deficiency of general supplies for shipping, and also of store accommodation, considering the growing trade of the port ; and, facilities for repairs of machinery are very limited. The hospital of the Hotel Dieu is open to sailors in case of illness or accident, a small fee only being required. In the year 1895, 605 vessels of an aggregate of 183,000 tons, of which number nine-tenths were steamers and three-fourths were British, arrived at Caen. This number includes a line of packets from Newhaven which only commenced running this year. The imports are chiefly coal and timber ; the exports, iron ore, colza oil cake, eggs, butter, fruit, &c. Vice-Consul.— A British Vice-Consul is stationed at Caen, OYESTREHAM HARBOUR— This harbour, which forms the entrance to the canal de Caen, consists of a tidal basin with stone quays on either side 1^ cables eastward of Oyestreham battery, communicating directly by means of the canal, already described, with the port of Caen ; and for the passage through this canal, the services of a tug are always obtainable at Oyestreham. The tidal basin is 320 yards long and 100 yards wide, but the bottom is hard See chart. No. 1,821.

At its head is a lock 328 feet long, with 23 feet over the outer sill, and 54 feet wide, by which vessels bound for Caen enter the canal at high water. The tidal basin has for its entrance from seaward, a channel 44 yards wide, between two wooden jetties of unequal length, opening into a wider outer channel between submersible dikes. The western jetty is the longest ; it extends from the tidal basin about 440 yards, and is thence prolonged seaward in a N. by E. \ E. direction a farther distance of 1,100 yards by a submersible dike running nearly parallel with that forming the eastern side of the channel, and described at page 457, the width of the channel at their outer ends being about 250 yards, and at their inner ends only about 200 yards. Both dikes are marked by beacons at their outer ends and by others at intervals to show their position when covered. The eastern jetty is about 300 yards in length. From the outer ends of the submersible dikes to the edge of the sands, the channel has a constant tendency to move eastward, so that, in 1895, the deepest water up to the entrance was in an E.N.E. direction from these dikes. Depths. — The entrance channel is very liable to change both in depth and direction, but vessels of 17 feet draught can generally enter at high water, springs, though at the lowest neaps it is only safely accessible to those of about 9 feet draught. Vessels of 14 or 15 feet draught can proceed through the lock and canal to Caen as already described. Buoyage. —A red spindle buoy is moored in 3^ fathoms, out side the edge of the sands, N.N.E. 1\ miles from the western jetty head. A black buoy also is moored N.E. by E. -\ E. 7 cables from the end of the East dike. Other buoys are placed and moved as may be necessary in consequence of the shifting nature of the sands in the channel leading in to Oyestreham harbour. Pilots. — There are several pilots at Oyestreham ; they may always be found in the neighbourhood of the outer red spindle buoy, and will meet a vessel much farther out if the pilot signal is made. See chart, No. 1,821.
