RADE de CAEN, about 3 miles distant between North and N.N.W. from Oyestreham jetties, affords good anchorage in from 4 to 5Jy fathoms, with off-shore winds, for vessels waiting tide to enter the harbour, but it would be dangerous to be caught there by strong winds from the opposite direction. The eastern limit of the road is the meridian of Oyestreham battery; its northern limit, Bernieres spire on with the houses on St. Aubin point ; and, its southern limit, Bernieres spire on with the small church tower at St. Aubin. Pilots usually place large vessels between these limits in about 5^ fathoms water, with Luc church tower open half a point southward of Beny spire ; here, they can weigh and stand off-shore if the wind should veer to the northward. THE RIVER DIVES.— Depths.— The entrance to this river is about 6^ miles eastward of Oyestreham, the intermediate coast consisting of sand-hills or dunes, several of which are sufficiently high to be recognised 5 or 6 miles distant. A sandy strand, 5 cables wide at low water, borders the shore, and the waters of the Dives run out across it ; but, in front of the entrance, it now dries for about a mile. Attempts have been made, with partial success, • by means of a submersible dike to confine and deepen the channel, which trends N. E. about 5 cables from the entrance and then inclines more easterly as far as the outer edge of the sand. In fine weather and with no swell, the river admits vessels of 11 or 12 feet draught, at springs, and 7 feet at neaps ; the shoalest part of the entrance channel is about 8 feet above the level of the lowest tides, but, with much fresh water in the river, it becomes temporarily deeper. At the outer edge of the sand, the water deepens abruptly, and, with strong winds between North and South, this causes a heavy sea at the entrance on the flood, and breakers as soon as the ebb stream begins to gain strength. The grounding places within the entrance are well sheltered by Cabourg point. Vessels here are safe, but the bottom is hard and unyielding. Those that only remain one tide are placed on the left See chart, No. 1,821.

The little harbour of Dives is by nature much better calculated to make a really good harbour than any of those previously described in the Baie de la Seine. It has also railway connection eastward and with ihe interior, but its trade is entirely unimportant and declining. It is »emarkable as being the port from which William the Conqueror embarked with his army for the conquest of England. Buoys and beacons. — Three wooden beacons with brooms for top-marks, and three buoys, one red and two black, mark the entrance channel ; the two inner beacons are on either side of the channel near the shore, one at the western edge close to the foot of Cabourg point, the other about a cable from it on the eastern edge. The third beacon is also on the eastern side, 3 or 4 cables farther out. The beacons are seldom moved, but the buoys are shifted whenever the course of the channel undergoes any decided alteration. There are, in addition, two beacons surmounted by discs on the shore which act as leading marks by day, as the lights do by night. The lower leading beacon is coloured red, black, and white ; and is close to the tower of the high light. The high leading beacon is on the slope of Beuzeval hill and is black. The lower beacon is moveable, to suit the line of direction to the changes of the channel. LIGHTS. — Two fixed red lights, visible 9 and 8 miles, through an arc of 32°, are established on the eastern side of the mouth of the river Dives ; when in line, they mark the fairway into the channel. The lower light is shown only so long as there is a depth of 3£ feet or more. They bear about N. E. and S. \ W. from each other, are 195 yards apart, and are respectively 148 and 10 feet above high water ; the lower light is shown from a moveable wooden structure by means of which its position may be changed in order to adapt the line of direction to changes in the channel ; the upper light from a stone watch-house. Directions.— Northerly winds are the best for entering the river Dives, but it is necessary to wait for high water, whatever the vessel's draught, except at springs, when, with a smooth sea, small vessels may enter an hour after high water, if there is wind enough to Sri chart, No. 1,821.

With off-shore winds, the entrance should only be attempted by small vessels, and they should be prepared for the heavy gusts coming down from the high land through the valleys. The pilots have no good boats for boarding vessels outside the entrance in bad weather. A vessel, therefore, compelled to enter the river with a strong northerly wind, must contrive to be about 1^ miles from the shore on the meridian of the Balise de Dives at high water. From thence, bring the leading beacons in line, and steer in between the entrance beacons, leaving the two black buoys and outer beacon on the port hand and the red buoy on the starboard hand ; when near the entrance between the two inner beacons, a pilot will be met with to conduct her to a berth. Anchorage. — There is good anchorage off the entrance to the Dives 1£ or 2 miles from the shore, where, in fine weaxher, a vessel may remain until there is sufficient water in the channel. With a turning wind into the river, it is necessary to anchor in order to retain a favourable position ; for, the velocity of the flood stream is here considerably increased by the indraught of the river Seine, and a vessel remaining under sail would be drifted to leeward of the entrance. No vessel should, however, remain at anchor unless the weather continues fine and the wind is off-shore ; should it come from seaward, with no certainty of entering the river at high water, it is necessary to weigh without delay and seek refuge either at Havre or Honfleur. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the river Dives at 9h. 39m. ; springs rise 21 feet, neaps 16 feet ; but, in the shoalest part of the channel abreast of the eastern beacon, where the bottom is 8 feet above the level of the lowest tides, the water rises about 18^ feet at equinoctical springs, 16^ feet at ordinary springs, and 7£ feet at neaps. Semaphore.- -There is a Semaphore station on the summit of point Beuzeval, about one mile eastward of the entrance of the river Dives ; see page 12. An imaginary line drawn from Beuzeval point to cape de la Heve may be considered the boundary between the sea and river navigation, and approximately, the western limit of the accumulation of sand and mud, forming dangerous shoals in the estuary ; no vessel should approach this limit, unless bound to some port of the Seine, and it is in the neighbourhood of this limit that the indraught of the river begins to gain strength with the rising tide.* Depths, &C — From this outer limit of the estuary to the commencement of the artificial stone embankment of the river Seine, abreast of Berville, the distance is only 13 or 14 miles, and from thence, following the Binuosities of the river, it is about 58 miles to Rouen. At the entrance between the embankments, the width is about 760 yards. At Tancarville, 4^ miles higher, where the canal from Havre opens into the river, it is 515 yards wide, and its width continues to diminish until at Rouen it is only 165 yards wide. In the outer part of the channel between the sand-banks there are only 3 or 4 feet water at the lowest tides, and from 26 feet at high water, springs, to 21 or 22 feet at ordinary neaps. Within the embankments, at no part in the best water is there less than 10 feet at the lowest tides, whilst at many parts it is sufficiently deep to afford anchorage where large ships may remain afloat. At high water, the range of tide decreasing within the river, the least depth varies from 16 feet 10 inches at the slackest neaps, to 24 feet 8 inches at springs. Vessels of 23 feet draught have ascended to Rouen, and it is considered safe for those of 21 feet to do so, at springs. From Tancarville upwards, the whole of the land has been reclaimed up to the embankments. Below that place a considerable tract is overflowed at high water. It may be here mentioned that the great engineering improve ments effected during the last 40 years have no appearance of finality. In March, 1895, a law was passed under which financial arrangements were made for the following vast works : — As regards the navigation to Rouen, the proposed improvements include the repairs of present embankments and removal of shoals, the extension of the embankments as far as Honfleur, the works necessary to maintain at Honfleur an entrance to the Seine equal in depth to that river, works necessary to ensure the navigation of the * See Admiralty charts :— Entrance of the Seine, No. 2,680 ; scale, »« = 2 inches ; and, Plan of the Seine on chart of English channel, No. 2,675e ; scale, »t = 0-5 of an inch.

Chap. X.] 465 DEPTHS.— BANKS. Rille up to Audemar, and all necessary dredgings. As regards Havre, the proposed improvements comprise the deepening of the present S.W. channel to 15| feet at low water, the sea defences of cape de la Heve, the construction of an outer port with the necessary dredgings, and the construction of a deeper and more direct entrance to the Bassin de l'Eure and the Bassin Bellot. Banks. — The principal banks in the estuary and obstructing the mouth of the Seine are, the Trouville, the Ratier, the Amfard, the Hauts de la Rade, and the Eclat, the higher parts of some of which uncover at low water ; the two first are near the southern shore, the Amfard in the centre, and the two last near the northern shore between Havre and cape de la Heve. In 1855, it was found that the Hauts de la Rade and the Eclat had not undergone any perceptible change since 1834, but the banks southward and eastward of them are subject to considerable alteration. The Amfard and Ratier banks divide the mouth of the Seine into three channels, two of which, at low water, are blind channels abutting on the shifting sands, then uncovered, within the estuary. The southern channel is that which leads to and beyond Honfleur ; the northern channel leads to and above Havre on the northern shore ; and the central channel is the main channel, just now described, by which vessels ascend to and above Rouen. This channel is always open though with but little water in it, at low tide, between the end of the embankments and the sea. In these channels, the stream runs 7 or 8 knots at springs, and 4 or 5 knots at neaps, and vessels of deep draught should avoid approaching the outer banks during the flood, for if once they should be carried amongst and ground on these sands they would certainly be lost, for anchors will not hold in the shifting sand, and the violence of the stream, increasing in velocity as it advances eastward, is irresistible. Vessels are exposed to great danger and indeed are forbidden to attempt the main channel without the assistance of the pilots of Quillebœuf, who are specially appointed to conduct vessels above Havre and Honfleur. It is the duty of these pilots to watch the changes in the position of the banks, and to mark the actual direction of the channel by beacons, see page 471. Their principal stations are at Havre and Honfleur, where they are always in sufficient number to meet the requirements of navigation. At See oharte. Nos. 2,«80 and 2,675c.

TIDAL STREAMS.— To comprehend the unusual tidal con ditions of the river Seine, the nature of the offing streams in the vicinity must be taken into consideration. The general channel flood stream, sharply compressed between the head of the Cotentin peninsula and the English coast, again expands eastward cf the meridian of Barfleur, taking four principal directions ; one portion follows the English coast, another strikes the coast of France between Dieppe and cape Grisnez, a third runs in the direction of cape d'Antifer, and a fourth flows round the shores of the Baie de la Seine. It is the last two with which we are now concerned. Of that portion which strikes the coast in the neighbourhood of cape d'Antifer, one part takes a southerly direction, meets and unites with the coast stream from the westward off the entrance of the Seine, and thus causes the tide to rise very rapidly in the first part of the flood. This, in conjunction with the form of the estuary and of its sand and mud banks, is probably the primary cause of the phenomenon known as the Bore, Mascaret, or Barre, which will now be described, the information being mainly derived and abridged from the personal observations of M. A. Dormoy, chief pilot of the Lower Seine, published in 1892, with corrections and additions from the latest information available. THE BORE. — The flood makes in the Seine at the hours anticipated, but under very different aspects, dependent both on the state of the tides (neaps or springs), and also on the seasons. The replacement of the ebb by the flood is thus a complex phenomenon. The general result is, that in weak neap tides the ascending stream replaces the descending stream without any apparent effort, and so easily that an observer may remain in doubt as to the precise moment of the change ; in mean tides, the reversal of the stream, shown by a gentle undulation of the waters throughout the whole breadth of the river, seems to be immediate ; and, in spring tides, the flood rushes in suddenly accompanied by an agitation more or less turbulent, and at times so considerable as to be a real source of danger. The establishment of the flood under these extraordinarily violent conditions is named the Bore, or by the French Mascaret or Barra. It occurs almost invariably every spring tide, and is See charts, Nos. 2,680 and 2,675c.

X.] 467 TIDAL STREAMS.— THE BORE. especially strong about the time of the equinoxes or with high spring tides from any cause ; it is highest with easterly winds and lowest with those from the westward, and as the wave frequently breaks in shoal water, small decked craft unable to avoid it should be battened down or will inevitably be swamped. Let us suppose that this phenomenon is about to occur : — An observer stationed at Rille light a few minutes before low water, springs, and looking towards the estuary, would see the bay laid dry as far as the eye could reach, except where the river, flowing in the direction of Honfleur, covered a breadth of some hundred yards between banks of muddy sand. The ebb stream still runs from 2 to 3 knots, but its speed slackens suddenly and at the same time a slight surf is seen at a distance against the outline of the banks ; its noise is heard and the water invades the uncovered places very rapidly. An irregular swell (for it subsides here and there) ascends the channel, inclining each buoy in succession and marking the course of the flood stream which has thus suddenly set in. It penetrates the embanked part of the river. Its triple or quadruple undulation becomes immediately more marked ; the level rises visibly ; the North dike is fringed with foam. A moment after, on its passage to La Roque and afterwards to Radicatel, waves break, especially near the right bank. Along the left bank there is scarcely any agitation. The boats of Tancarville and Quillebœuf may be seen resting on their oars, bows on to the approaching swell ; they rise to it, turn about when it has passed, and ascend with the stream ; in this manner boats in that part of the river take the flood ; without that precaution they would be capsized. From Quillebœuf, looking in the direction of Radicatel, the river is broken water right across,* the water breaking much more heavily against the right bank than the other, doubtless on account of the bend, as the waves rush upon it obliquely and cover the platform of the dike with their spray. The mass of water reaches Quillebœuf before the agitation of which we speak is at an end at Rille, and it lasts some minutes longer, calm not being restored until the Bore is near the bend of Vieux port. On the arrival of the Bore at Quillebœuf, its height, which increases, may be 7 or 8 feet ; that is to say, there is that difference * Hence the name of Bar re given by the riverside population to the Bore or Mascaret. See charts, Nos. 2,680 and 2,675c.

X- THE SEINE. — ESTUARY AND RIVER. of level between low water and that of the flood which rushes up-stream in this torrent ; so that a boat in front would see before it a liquid wall approaching and capable of engulfing it. The wave comes on in the form of a crescent, concave towards up-stream, and its two points breaking furiously along the banks. Another wave follows at about 200 yards, then a third, and a fourth. Then appear the Eteules, silent waves of a very dangerous character, up to (it is said) 16 feet in height, but subsiding heavily as soon as formed. This state of confusion passed, the river flows steadily on ; the level does not rise more than an additional 3 feet, although the rate of the stream increases to 7 knots and more. From the first appear ance of the Bore until calm is restored after its passage up the river, not more than a quarter of an hour elapses. The Bore is sometimes still higher and more furious at the foot of St. Leonard. It would be very imprudent for any small vessel to be caught in these parts. It subsides very remarkably at La Corvette, where ships, which on account of their draught have not been able to put to sea, await it at anchor ready for weighing and swung to the ebb, for there is no slack water, the ebb ceasing only with the flood, the chain ready to be slipped at a moment's notice. Each vessel at the proper moment sets the engines going astern. Notwithstanding this, the vessel runs ahead and commences swinging, the propeller being then used to avoid the banks. Steam vessels getting under way before the Bore so as to receive it head-on, should meet it at slow speed, plunging into the wave. Sailing-vessels in tow meet it in this manner with a great length of tow-line. Continuing its course up-stream, the Bore passes abreast of Des Flaques with the same violence as at St. Leonard, and calms down in the deep waters of the anchorage of La Courbe ; a little farther on, however, upon the Traverse, it breaks out afresh from one bank to the other. From Villequier it may be seen white with foam, the tide running furiously, leaping up the banks, dragging and submerging everything on its passage. The roar of the approaching Bore is heard from a great distance ; at Villequier, it has been distinctly heard at night on reaching Aizier, 6 miles distant. At Villequier, boats moor near the lighthouse under shelter of a rocky submarine point, behind which the water is relatively calm for a small space. But in heavy Bores they should descend as far as Sec charts, Nos. 2.6K0 and 2,675c.

Chap. X.] 469 THE BORE. Courbe. The boats of Caudebec shelter as well as they can at the Dos d'ane (Ass's back). The appearance of the Bore is particularly attractive at Caudebec as the waves coming on obliquely, as at Radicatel, on account of the very decided concavity of the bank, only display the greater vigour, and the water recoiling adds to the disorder. Tourists came here in crowds to view the scene, especially at equinoctial tides. At La Mailleraye, 3is miles higher, the Bore loses much of its force ow7ing to the bank Les Meules, which produces a situation differing entirely from the localities farther up-stream by the obstacle which it raises to the retreat of the waters. It may be said that La Piette is the ordinary up-stream limit of the Bore, as beyond that it usually becomes only an undulation of greater or less height, according to the bottom over which it passes. At Duclair, it is generally possible for a vessel to remain at the wharf ; and finally at Rouen, the arrival of the undulation only manifests itself, as a rule, by a movement, more or less pronounced, of the vessels moored along the quays. It had been hoped that the great improvements effected by the embankments and the deepening of the Seine would have either destroyed the Bore or reduced to a nullity its effects ; and, indeed, it was for some time currently reported that such had been the case. Unfortunately, time has shown that these hopes have not been verified, though the works have certainly effected some slight modi fications. The latest information up to 1896 shows that the Bore is almost, if not quite, as strong as ever in the lower reaches, and, as a consequence of the deepening, is certainly stronger than before in the upper part, ancl notably so at Rouen, where, quite recently, steamers have been known to break adrift from their lashings alongside the quays. Between the mouth of the Seine and Rouen, the following may be taken as approximately the height of the Bore or tidal wave at places from 15 to 20 miles apart : — At Quillebœuf — strong springs, 7 to 8 feet ; weak springs, 4 feet. Caudebec — strong springs, 7 to 8 feet ; weak springs, 4 feet. „ Duclair — strong springs, 2 to 4 feet ; weak springs, 1 foot. „ Rouen — strong springs, 2 feet ; weak springs, nil. These figures refer to the height of the wave alongside the quays or banks, for it has been observed that in mid-channel, where the resistance to its progress is less, the height of the wave also is less. See charts, Nos. 2,680 and 2,675c.

Propagation Of the flood. — At present, and as a consequence of the embankments, the rising undulation at neap tides traverses the distance from Berville to Rouen, 58 miles, in 7 hours, represent ing an hourly speed of 8'3 miles, which is nearly uniform. In mean tides, its passage is made in 5 hours, at a speed of 11*6 miles, per ceptibly slackened over the shoals and accelerated in deep water. At spring tides, the propagation gains in rapidity and loses still more in uniformity ; its mean speed is 14-5 miles, the flood getting from Berville to Rouen in 4 hours. Before the embankments and dredgings took place the rising undulation travelled from Berville to Rouen in 5 hours, at spring tides. This is the only information of the kind available of that time, but apparently the tide took one hour longer then than now in its transit between the two places. As regards the danger of the Bore and of the strong tides generally of the Seine, M. Bailly, marine surveyor, remarks : " If a vessel from any cause takes the ground, it frequently happens, especially during springs, that when the flood reaches her she is thrown on her broadside and buried in the sand set in motion by the strength of the stream, and becomes, in almost every case, a lost vessel.* The number of masts standing up in various parts of the river testify that these misfortunes are not unfrequent, and the greatest attention should therefore be paid by commanders of vessels ascending the river until they arrive at Quillebœuf, where they can be secured to the quay before their vessels are exposed to the danger of grounding in the channel. If they cannot arrive at this position before the end of the flood they should hasten to take shelter either at Honfleur or Havre, whilst there is yet sufficient water in the narrow channels. Generally speaking, they should not attempt to ascend or descend the river without a leading wind or in tow of a steam-vessel." " Sailing vessels at Havre or Honfleur intending to ascend the Seine, should leave those ports directly they float, and, with a leading wind, they may expect to reach Quillebœuf before the ebb begins to be felt. This navigation, however, can only be undertaken with safety during springs, for, at neaps, the depth of water is not suffi cient for vessels of much draught to navigate the lower part of the * A recent case is that of the s.s. Aberdeenshvre, which vessel, having been com pelled through fog to drop her anchor between Berville and Tancarville. took the ground on a shifting sand bank, heeled over and sank, the crew escaping with their boats, except the chief engineer, who was drowned. Most vessels waiting at Havre for springs to ascend the river, quit the harbour on the ebb preceding the flood which is to take them up to Quillebœuf, and anchor in the Petite. Rade ; by doing so, they avoid the loss of time which the getting out of harbour would occasion with westerly winds, and do not run the risk of losing a favourable tide." ROUEN. — Of the city of Rouen itself it need only be said that its position as practically the port of Paris has amply justified the efforts so far made to improve its waterway. (For Depths, see page 464.) In the three years 1869-1871 the amount of shipping entering and clearing averaged about 500,000 tons, whilst in the three years 1889-1891 the average was over 2,000,000 tons, the tonnage having thus quadrupled in a period of 20 years ; its commerce continues to advance in about the same ratio, the increase being no less remarkable in the size of the ships than in the aggregate tonnage. Vessels lie alongside its quays bordering the river, or in the Bassin Maritime, which has an area of 22| acres. There is also a building slip capable of taking vessels of 1,800 tons, and 312 feet in length. A British Consul is stationed at Rouen. LIGHTING OF THE SEINE.— At Berville, a mile west- ward of the embankments, on the southern shore, is a square turret, from which is exhibited a fixed white light, visible 17 miles. Rille light, fixed white, is at the end of the southern embankment ; here, also, a fog bell is sounded every If seconds, when necessary. At the end of the northern embankment is a red fixed light — both of these lights are visible 7 miles. From thence upwards, all lights on the right or northern bank of the Seine are red, and all those on the left bank are ivhite. In proceeding up-stream, therefore, all red lights are left on the port hand, and all white lights on the starboard hand. Bane de Seine. — The deposits of sand and mud washed down by the river Seine extend far beyond the shoals at the river's mouth and form an extensive submarine flat and slope, agreeing somewhat in shape with the curve of the bank bordering the shore from Port en-Bessin to the meridian of the Dives. The Bane de Seine and the deep southward of it, called by pilots the Parfond, are useful guides in establishing the position of a vessel during fogs or thick weather, when the navigation can only be carried on by means of the lead. From the western extreme of the bank, in 9 fathoms, cape de la Heve lighthouses bear E. by S. £ S. 15 miles, and Ver lighthouse S.W. § W. 13 miles. Bane de Trouville. -This bank of muddy sand, the south westernmost of the shifting banks at the mouth of the Seine, is about 3 miles long in an E. by N. h N. direction, fronting and east ward of the entrance to Trouville, and from 5 cables to 1J; miles wide, with general depths of from 3 to 7 feet water. It is, however, very difficult to define its extent westward, the bank gradually extending in that direction and the water deepening so very gradually that at Is miles farther there are only 9 or 10 feet water. The sea is exceedingly heavy on this bank, with the wind from W.S.W. round by West to N.N.E. Villerville Channel. — The Bane de Trouville is separated from the shore by the Villerville channel, a narrow passage formerly much deeper, but which has now a general depth of only 6 feet with a very small area of 8 or 9 feet. The streams follow the direction of the channel, such as it is, and, in calm weather, the flood, at springs, runs about 5£ hours and ends 15 or 20 minutes after high water at Havre ; its greatest rate is about 4 knots, near half flood ; the ebb is rather weaker. Bane du Ratier, abreast of Villerville and 1£ miles from the shore, with the Ratelets, a prolongation of the bank westward, forms one of the most dangerous shoals at the mouth of the Seine. The bank is of an irregular shape, and its surface, which dries from one to 12 feet above the lowest tides, is covered with a large quantity of stones and rolled shingle ; but, its base is a mass of compact brown clay and consequently not subject to change. That part of the surface which uncovers, including the Ratelets, is 3-j- miles long in a W. by N. and E. by S. direction and forms a shelter from the flood stream to the banks of shifting sand eastward of it. From the western extreme of the Ratelets, in 6 feet, cape de la Heve light houses bear N. by E. \ E. 5£ miles. The eastern limit of the red light at Deauville, see page 478, passes about 6 cables westward of that part of the Ratelets bank which uncovers, in 7 or 8 feet water. The Bane du Ratier covers towards half flood, and the sea runs high over it with strong winds between West and North, but, with the latter wind, it shelters in some degree the channel southward of it. Buoys. — The southern side of the Ratelets and Ratier is marked by three buoys, viz. : — the S.W. Ratier buoy, a black and red buoy near the south-western edge of the Ratelets, a black and white buoy abreast of the outer elbow of the Ratier, and a black buoy near its south-eastern elbow. On its northern side are the N.W. Ratier buoy, a large red buoy with staff and globe ; and a smaller red buoy near the eastern end. The N.W. Ratier buoy lies with Fatouville lighthouse on with the pier-heads at Honfleur S.E. by E. | E. Vessels going up the Seine northward of the Ratier bank, steer for this buoy and leave it on the starboard hand, by which time the Fosse d'Amfard fairway light-buoy is well in sight. Other buoys marking the banks are small, very subject to change of position, and cannot be seen until a vessel is nearly on them. (See note on preceding page.) See chart, No. 2,680.

X.] VILLERVILLE CHANNEL. — BANC D'AMFARD. 475 Bane d' Amfard lies about 2 miles northward of the Ratier, and, like the latter, its base is a mass of brown clay and its surface is covered with large shingle ; it, also, shelters the bank of shifting sand eastward of it. The western part of this bank uncovers only at low water, equinoctial springs, but its surface is subject to great changes ; for, in 1855, it was found that the stones which constituted its inferior part in 1834, were then buried under shingle 6 feet thick, proving that the shingle on it is not so stationary as on the Ratier. Buoy. — A buoy, painted with black and white bands, surmounted by staff and double cone topmark, is moored at the western extreme of the Bane d'Amfard close to a drying patch, and about South If miles from the lighthouse on the eastern side of the entrance to Havre. The position of the buoy is, however, liable to be changed in consequence of alterations in the form and depth of water on and around the bank. Light-buoy. — The Fosse d'Amfard light-buoy is moored in the channel southward of the Bane d'Amfard, which channel forms the main entrance through the estuary to the embankments of the river Seine. It exhibits a. fixed red light, visible about 3^ miles, and has the name painted on it ; the body of the buoy is painted with red and black horizontal bands. The buoy will be moved in accordance with any changes which may take place in the channel. The description of the Eclat, Hauts de la Rade, and other shoals on the northern side of the estuary, chiefly concern the approaches to Havre, and will be included in their proper place in describing that port, which is near the entrance on the right or northern bank of the estuary of the Seine, see page 492. We now return to the left or southern bank. LEFT BANK of the ESTUARY of the SEINE.— From the entrance of the river Dives to the hill of Notre Dame de Grace, which commands the town and harbour of Honfleur, the left bank of the estuary of the Seine trends about 14 miles E. by N. \ N., and the coast is bordered by high hills, terminating abruptly towards the sea in cliffs of brown clay and stone, and in large landslips, except in front of three valleys where the shore is low and sandy. The widest and most remarkable of these valleys is that through which the little river Touques finds its way into the sea. This valley is 2 miles wide at the sea shore, but narrows suddenly 400 yards See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. 476 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. inland ; it may be recognised from a great distance off-shore by the town of Trouville, which is built at the foot of a high steep hill on the eastern side of the entrance of the river ; its suburb, Deauville, being on the western side. Vessels of more than 9 feet draught should be cautious in approaching the coast when within 4^ or 5 miles westward of the Touques, as the flat, with only from 3 to 10 feet water, there extends Lj miles from the shore and increases in width in going eastward, so that off the entrance of the Touques no more than 12 feet water is to be found in any direction at a distance of 2^ miles. Eastward of the Touques, the coast is bordered by uneven rocks which dry at low water and terminate 3 miles E.N.E. from Trouville in Villerville point. This point extends half a mile in a N.W. by N. direction from Villerville village and the ledge off it is dangerous to vessels proceeding through the Villerville channel, but is marked by a red buoy in 6 feet at its edge, 7 cables from the shore. If the buoy should be gone, this rocky point will be avoided when passing northward of it, by keeping Roque point opening and shutting in with Fonds cliff E. § S. Roque point is a high greyish white cliff, perpendicular towards the river side, and may be easily recognised, being the first point on the left bank of the Seine which is seen to open out from Fonds cliff when coming from the South-west. TROUVILLE- — Touques river. — The- entrance to this river lies E. by N. \ N. 7^ miles from that of the Dives, and is between two piers extending seaward in a N. by W. direction. The West pier extends 625 yards from point Deauville on the western side of the river, and the sands dry at low water 4 cables beyond the pier-head. The East pier does not extend so far from point Cahotte on the eastern side, the pier-heads bearing from each other about E.S.E. and W.N.W. The sands of Deauville form the western side of the channel from the pier-head to the low water line, and it is marked by three red buoys ; but, from the East pier-head a low dike of rough stone, intended to prevent the eastern sands from drifting into the channel, extends a considerable distance, the channel curving to the westward ; this dike is marked close to on its western side by three black buoys. Depths. — The channel between the piers is 164 feet wide ; the deepest.water, about 19 or 20 feet, at high water, springs, and 4 feet less at neaps, being towards the West pier. There is a flushing contrivance See chart, K o. 2,680.

Chap. X.] 477 TROUVILLE. — COAL, ETC. of recent construction which appears to be effective in maintaining the depths. Within the piers the harbour opens out, and, on the eastern side are the quays of Cahotte and of Trouville old harbour extending up to the bridge, with good grounding berths alongside for vessels up to 12 or 14 feet draught. On the western side, its entrance facing the quays of Cahotte point, is the wet dock or basin, 986 feet, long 263 feet wide, with 20 feet over the sill at high water, springs, and 16 feet at neaps ; the dock gates are open from 1^ hours before to 1^ hours after high water. This basin is surrounded by extensive quays ; and, in it, vessels of 15 feet draught can lie afloat at all times and unload direct into railway trucks, the railway station being just at the head of the basin, and rails laid along the quays. There is no dry dock, nor can repairs of any importance be effected. A public and also a private hospital are both available for seamen in case of need. Coal, &C- — From 3,000 to 5,000 tons of coal are usually in stock at this port, and steamers are coaled in the basin. The chief import is coal, of which between 60,000 and 70,000 tons arrive annually ; the other imports are wood, cement, ice, &c. The exports are unimportant. In 1895, the trade of the port, exclusive of its large fishing industry, was represented by the entry of 140 vessels, of which 119 were steamers of an aggregate of 45,187 tons ; of this number 113 vessels of 38,000 tons were British. Vice-Consul. — A British Vice-consul is stationed at Trouville. Trouville, formerly a small fishing port and village, has since 1860 expanded into a place of considerable commercial importance, though its trade appears to be now on the decrease, as well as having become a fashionable watering place. Including its suburb Deauville, across the river, it has a population of about 9,000. The railway station is at Deauville, and the communication is through Lisieux with the Cherbourg and Paris line, as well as eastward and westward with Honfleur and Dives. Steamers run daily between it and Havre, for both passengers and goods, the passage lasting about 45 minutes. The small town of Touques is on the river about 2 miles above Trouville, and, at springs, vessels of light draught can ascend as high as Quai-au-Coq, a small place 5^ miles in the interior, where there is sufficient water for them to remain afloat. A Life -boat is stationed at Trouville. See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. 478 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. LIGHTS. — At Deauville, on the western side of the entrance of the Touques river, stands a square lighthouse, 59 feet high, painted in alternate red and white bands, from which, at 64 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed red tidal light, visible 9 miles, between the bearings S. 10° W. and S. 75° E. This light is not shown unless there are 1\ feet water in the entrance channel ; its eastern limit passes over the Trouville bank in 6 feet, and westward of the Ratelets banks in 7 or 8 feet. East pier. — A fixed white light, visible 7 miles, is exhibited from a wdiite iron turret 39 feet from the East pier-end, 33 feet above high water, and 548 yards N. by W. \ W. from Deauville lighthouse ; it is eclipsed eastward of the bearing of S. 7° W. West pier. — At 39 feet from the West pier-head, 33 feet above high water, and 86 yards W.N.W. from the East pier light, from a white iron turret, is exhibited a, fixed green light,- visible 9 miles. Roches Noires pier. — At the outer end of this pier, which is 7 cables eastward of Trouville piers, are exhibited two fixed white lights, placed vertically. The pier extends 400 yards from the shore in a N.N.W. \ W. direction, and has 8 feet water at its head. A narrow wharf has been constructed from near the inner end of this pier, extending 300 yards along the shore to the south-westward. Fog Signal. — A bell is sounded continuously during fogs from Trouville harbour East pier-head. See Fog signals, page 11. Tides and tidal streams. — It is high water, full and change, at Trouville, at 9h. 20m. Springs rise 25£ feet, neaps 21J feet above the level of the soundings, which are "6\ feet below the level of low water, ordinary springs. Springs range 22 feet, neaps range 13 feet. The lowest neaps rise 11 feet above the sands at the entrance in the channel ; springs, 16 to 17 feet. Off the pier-heads, the flood stream takes the direction of the estuary, its greatest strength being only H knots, and for three quarters of an hour about high water there is slack water. Between the piers the flood runs at from 2 to 2\ knots, the ebb only 1\ knots at their greatest strength. Out side the piers the ebb turns to the westward and begins to acquire strength half an hour after high water. Tide signals.— The usual tide signals, see page 12, are shown from a mast at Cahotte point, near the inner end of the East pier. See chart, No. 2,680.

Chap. X.] 479 TROUVILLE. — DIRECTIONS. — HONFLEUR. In addition, a blue pendant during the day, or a green light at night, hoisted at the flagstaff at the harbour master's office at Trouville, indicates that vessels cannot leave the port. Pilots. — Trouville pilots cruise in small sloops, painted black, with the letter T on the mainsail, and carry at the masthead a blue flag with a white anchor ; they are almost certain to be met with in any- weather at the entrance of the channel. Directions. — Nearly all the trade is now done by steamers. For sailing vessels, westerly winds are the most favourable for entering the harbour. They should not enter until half an hour before high water, but, with a leading wind, may continue to enter until an hour after high water, if of suitable draught, as the ebb is easily stemmed. With off-shore winds, small vessels may anchor in about 10 feet water and 1\ miles from the beach abreast of the plain of Villers, which is 3 miles south-westward of the river entrance ; here they may remain until the tide has risen sufficiently for them to enter ; but, with the wind from N.W. they should, if in charge of a pilot, anchor in the Villerville channel between the Trouville bank and the shore, where there is a small space with 2 fathoms water ; if the wind should then freshen and back to West or S.W., they will be able to run through the channel and take refuge at Honfleur. The Coast. — From the mouth of the Touques, the steep coast trends 3 miles E.N.E. as far as the small village of Villerville, which stands rather high ; it then bends more eastward for 4 miles to the hill of Notre Dame de Grace, one of the highest and the most conspicuous hill in the estuary of the Seine, which is 3^- miles wide between this point and Hoc point on the northern shore. The only part between Trouville and Honfleur where the shore is low and accessible at high water is eastward of Villerville, between it and Vasoui. HONFLEUR. — This port is at the entrance of a beautiful valley, open to the North-east, and just eastward of the hill of Notre Dame de Grace. It is sheltered by the land on all sides, and the wind never raises such a sea as to make it dangerous to enter. Being so near Havre, it neither has nor needs much plant for repairing vessels, and its large building yards are now but little used. The See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. 480 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. trade of the port steadily decreases, no doubt owing to the improve ment in the Seine navigation and consequent enormous growth in the trade of Rouen. In 1895, 616 vessels, of a total tonnage of 134,789 tons, entered. The exports are chiefly dairy and agricultural produce ; the imports, timber and coals. The steamers of the London and South Western, and of the London, Brighton, and South Coast railways run regularly between it and Southampton and Newhaven respectively. The railway station is on the eastern side of the harbour, and the line connects with the general system of the country at Lisieux. Honfleur has both a sailors' home and a hospital ; its population is about 8,000. Coal. — An ample supply of coal can always be obtained, there being usually about 2,000 tons in stock. Steamers are coaled lying afloat at their ordinary berths alongside the quays in the basins. Vice-Consul. — A British Vice-Consul is stationed at Honfleur. The oort consists of an outer tidal harbour, and of four wet docks or Bassins-a-flot, viz. : — the Bassin de l'Ouest, Bassin du Centre, Bassins de l'Est, and Bassin Quatrieme. Provision is made by means of sluices, a large Bassin de Chasses, and other reservoirs of water for scouring them, as well as the channel leading into the port ; there is also a small tidal harbour on the western side, which serves chiefly for steamboats and small craft employed in the daily transport of passengers and country produce to Havre. The Bassin de l'Ouest is 427 feet long by 256 feet wide, and its depth is 18 feet at high water, extraordinary springs, 17 feet at ordinary springs, and nearly 10 feet at neaps. The Bassin du Centre is 427 feet long by 296 feet wide, and its depth is 21-J feet at extraordinary springs, 20£ feet at ordinary springs, and 13 feet at neaps. The Bassin de l'Est is 986 feet long by 236 feet wide, and its depth is 22| feet at extraordinary springs, 21f feet at ordinary springs, and 14^ feet at neaps. The Bassin Quatrieme is 1,181 feet long by 243 feet wide, and is 16 inches deeper than the Bassin de l'Est. Quay frontage and storage are very ample, and all modern appliances, steam cranes, &c, are available for the rapid loading or unloading of ships. The entrance of the port is between two piers, partly stone and partly timber, 230 feet apart, and it is open to N. by E. The West See chart, No. 2,680.

Chap. X.] HONFLBUR. — DHPTHS. — TIDES. 481 pier extends 370 yards from the shore ; and, from its head, the northern end of the breakwater of the Bassin de Chasses, which forms the eastern side of the entrance, bears E. \ N. about 300 feet. The East pier is prolonged by a rough stone submersible dike, 650 yards long, constructed in 1886, to direct the channel and periodical flushings in order to overcome the rapid silting up to which this port appears to become more and more liable ; the dike is marked by branches of trees at frequent intervals. The shifting sands uncover 2 or 3 cables beyond the pier-heads. The direction of the channel being very subject to change, is marked by buoys, in accordance with the French uniform system, their positions being shifted as occasion may require. Vessels at high water, springs, usually pass over the small banks which form at the entrance of the channel, but it is dangerous for vessels under any circumstances to enter without a pilot, the sand being so moveable, and the streams, which set obliquely across the channel, so rapid, that a laden vessel grounding during a high tide would run great risk of being totally lost. Depths. — The depths in the old channel were 23 feet at high water, equinoctial springs ; 21 feet at ordinary springs ; and 11\ feet at neaps. Of the new channel, it can only be said that in conse quence of the shifting nature of the sands the depths are very un certain, but are 5 feet less at neaps than at springs. Westerly winds of any duration serve to raise the ! water, and easterly winds have a contrary effect. During rainy weather and at the melting of the snow, the freshets of the Seine are abundant, and with strong westerly winds they contribute greatly to raise the water in the port. Tides and tide Signals.— It is high water, full and change, at Honfleur, at 9h. 29m. ; springs rise 23 feet ; neaps 18 feet. High water slack lasts only 15 or 20 minutes, but the change in height from half an hour before to half an hour after high water not being more than 3 or 4 inches, the basins remain open for that time without inconvenience. The usual tide signals, see page 12, are made from a mast on the East jetty near the lighthouse. In addition are the following local signals :— 1. A blue flag hoisted at the signal flagstaff, signifies that all movement within the port is forbidden. See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. 482 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE, 2. The pilot flag, white with blue border, hoisted at the small flagstaff near the East jetty lighthouse, signifies that the basins are open. 3. Distant signals are made from the West jetty-head with balls, as follows : — One ball ... Entrance forbidden. Two balls ... Leaving the port forbidden. Three balls... All movement in the port forbidden. A Life-boat is stationed at this port. LIGHTS. — Hospital jetty. — From a circular tower on the Hospital jetty at the north-western extreme of the town, is exhibited, at 92 feet above high water, a. fixed white light, visible 15 miles. West pier. — From a white iron tower on the West pier, 39 feet from the pier-head and 33 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed red light, visible 6 miles. Breakwater. — At the north-western extreme of the breakwater of the Bassin de Chasses, E. \ N. about 300 feet from the West pier head, is shown, from a wooden structure, a fixed green light, visible 4 miles. East pier.--Tide light. — From a round brick tower on the eastern pier at the entrance to the tidal harbour, is shown a fixed white light, varied by red and green flashes ; it is 39 feet above high water and visible 9 miles. This light is shown only when there are 6£ feet or more in the channel ; each red flash indicates 3 \ additional feet, and each green flash 10 inches more. Thus, with the white light showing, two red flashes followed by one green flash signifies that the depth in the channel is 13| feet. With the white light showing, one red flash followed by three green flashes signifies a depth of 12 feet. Interior jetties. — Two small fixed white lights are also shown from the interior sides of the jetty-heads of the port. Fog Signal. — During thick or foggy weather, a bell is sounded by machinery eight times every minute during the whole time that the tide light is or would be shown. The signal is made from the West pier-head. See chart, No. 2,680.

Chap. X.] 483 HONFLEUR. — LIGHTS. — DIRECTIONS. Fatouville lighthouse is an octagonal tower 105 feet high, on the high lands of Fatouville 3| miles S.E. by E. \ E. from Honfleur West pier-head ; it exhibits at 715 feet above high water a fixed white light varied every three minutes by a red flash ; the flash is preceded and followed by a short eclipse, which, however, is not total within a distance of 12 miles. The light is visible 21 miles. DIRECTIONS. — Honfleur is accessible to vessels of moderately deep draught during springs ; its trade is becoming year by year more engrossed by steamers, but as a few large sailing vessels still use the port, the following directions, mainly applicable to them, appear to be necessary. Vessels arriving at the mouth of the Seine, at neaps, must wait for water to enter the passages leading to Honfleur either under sail, with the wind from W.S.W. round by West to N.N.E., or at anchor in the Grande Rade off Havre if the wind be off the land ; if remaining only a day or two for sufficient water, they may anchor in Carosse roads, southward of the prohibited anchorage, in from 5 to 7 fathoms, mud and sand, with cape de la Heve lighthouses in line N.E. f N. ; and, Fatouville lighthouse open half a point northward of Hospital jetty lighthouse at Honfleur. At this anchorage, the stream runs towards the Seine until 4 hours flood ; its greatest strength is at 3 hours before high water at Havre and does not exceed 4 knots. Vessels having only a few hours to wait for tide, should keep under sail westward of cape de la Heve lighthouses in line, and a little northward of the line of the Hospital jetty lighthouse at Honfleur on with Fatouville lighthouse bearing S.E. by E. \ E. ; but, should the strength of the tide drift them towards the river, they muss anchor before passing these limits. Passes de Honfleur. — Two narrow passages lead to Honfleur. The North passage is between the Amfard and Ratier banks and across the shifting sands fronting Honfleur. Pilots take sailing vessels through this channel with the wind between W.N.W. and N.N.E. ; but, with contrary winds, although there is room to work, large vessels are usually towed. Hospital jetty lighthouse on with Fatouville lighthouse S.E. by E. h E. leads just northward of the N.W. Ratier buoy, and Honfleur East pier light, open to the right of the Hospital jetty light leads southward of the Bane d'Amfard and up to the Fosse d'Amfard fairway light-buoy, as ter passing which the channel See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. 484 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. up to the piers is indicated by buoys, constantly watched and their positions changed as may be necessary — red buoys to be left on the starboard hand, black buoys on the port hand as usual. No vessel should attempt to enter without a pilot. The South passage is between the Ratier and Trouville banks ; its leading line is, the northern extreme of Fonds cliff, Honfleur, on with Roque point, remarkable for its grey tint and its perpendicularly steep shore. In running through, this mark must be kept on until abreast of Vasoui.; from thence to Honfleur, keep between 2 and 3 cables from the shore. At night, keep Roque light just open of Fonds cliff, but bear in mind that fixed directions cannot be given in consequence of the shifting nature of the sands. This passage is the deepest and is generally taken by sailing vessels with the wind between S.S.E. and W.N.W. ; coasters may run through it at 2\ hours, and larger vessels at 3i hours flood ; but, with a leading wind, during springs, it should not be entered by large vessels until 4 hours flood, as, between Villerville and Honfleur, that stream runs with great rapidity in the direction of the passage. The flood stream, at springs, commences 5 hours before high water at Havre and runs b\ hours ; its greatest velocity is towards half flood and is sometimes 7 knots between Vasoui and Honfleur. Should a vessel arrive abreast of Vasoui much before high water, she should sheer a little in-shore where the tide has less strength, and anchor until nearly high water. With strong southerly winds, vessels should be on their guard against the heavy gusts which rush down the narrow valleys between Penne de Pic and Honfleur ; vessels have sometimes been dismasted by them. Small vessels, when bound to Honfleur from the South-west, may use the Villerville channel ; but, in doing so, they must proceed with caution by the lead and haul off in time to give a good berth to the rocky ledge off Villerville ; having passed the red buoy at its outer extreme, they may proceed by the leading mark for the South channel. Entering Honfleur. — The most favourable winds for a sailing vessel to enter this port are those between W.S.W. and E.N.E. round by North. The channel is crossed obliquely by the flood and ebb streams, and their extreme velocity, at springs, is from 5 to 6 knots. The flood stream runs 5^ hours and ends just at high water \ it is during the 15 or 20 minutes of slack water which then ensues See chart, No. -2,680.

Chap. X.] HONFLEUR.— DIRECTIONS.— CAPE DE LA HEVE. 485 that a pilot prefers to take in a vessel of deep draught, there being then but little difficulty in following the course of the channel. Plenty of sail should be carried in passing through the outer part of the channel, and an anchor should be always ready to let go in case a sudden shift of wind or the heave of the sea should force the vessel out of the channel. In the event of such an accident, a signal for a steam-tug should immediately be made, by hailing the colours under the bowsprit. If the entrance is missed, anchor at once and await the arrival of the tug ; or, failing her, with the commencement of the ebb, quit the river as speedily as possible. With a fresh southerly wind, it is necessary to guard against the sudden off-shore gusts before referred to ; they are frequently felt under the hill of Notre Dame de Grace and blow strongly down the valley at Honfleur. With a head wind or a calm, a steam-tug should always be obtained and when nearing the entrance channel the tow rope should be well shortened in, and great attention paid to follow exactly the wake of the tow-boat, for the smallest deviation in the steerage is here sufficient to run the vessel ashore. RIGHT BANK of the ESTUARY of the SEINE.— The extensive chalky level forming the plain of Caux, of which the mean height is about 375 feet above high water, bounds the northern shore of the estuary of the Seine ; and, from cape de la Heve, its most western point, as far as the meridian of Quillebœuf, the northern or right bank of the river presents, for a large portion of its extent, a face of perpendicular chalk cliffs intersected by deep valleys. About one mile eastward of cape de la Heve, however, commences a broad alluvial flat which, for a distance of 4 miles, fronts the high chalk formation. The town and port of Havre occupies the western portion of this flat, and the little town of Harfleur is at its eastern end, at the entrance to one of the deepest valleys. CAPE DE LA HEVE, formerly called Chef de Caux, is 2\ miles N.N.W. of the entrance to Havre, and forms the western point of the chalky cliffs which terminate the plain of Caux. The cape is perpendicular about half way down from its summit, the foot of the cliff being covered with the debris of frequent slips and fallen masses ; works are now in progress to prevent further destruction, or the lighthouses would very soon be in danger. See chart, No. 2,680.

486 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. [Chap. X. LIGHTS. — On the summit of cape de la Heve stand two square white lighthouses, each Q6 feet high, and their lights 397 feet above high water. They bear N.E. § N. and S.W. § S. distant 107 yards from each other, and are obscured by Bleville hills when bearing S.W. | S. southerly. The southern lighthouse stands 100 yards from the edge of the cliff. The Northern lighthouse exhibits an electric flashing white light with a period of five seconds between each flash, visible 27 miles. Total eclipses intervene, but a continuous light caused by the brilliant illumination of the lantern is visible as much as 15 miles under certain oircumstances. The Southern lighthouse exhibits a fixed white light of the fifth order, visible 10 miles. The lead should be frequently used when approaching these lights from the westward, especially if the Ver light has not been sighted. Telegraph cable. — The telegraph cable communicating with America, via Ballinskellig bay, Ireland, leaves the shore about half a mile north-eastward of cape de la Heve. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on cape de la Heve ; it stands midway between the two lighthouses but westward of their line ; see page 12. Tide Signals. — A signal station is established about 2 cables S.S.E. from cape de la Heve lighthouses, from which is repeated, for the benefit of vessels in the offing or roads, the signals made at the tide signal station at the inner end of the North jetty at Havre. LE HAVRE. — The town, tidal harbour, and large Bassins-a-flot or wet docks of this important port occupy the western part of the low plain, before described. In 1895, the foreign trade entering the port was represented by 2,508 vessels measuring 2,263,000 tons, and the coasting trade by 4,154 vessels measuring 1.012,000 tons. Steamers of the largest size run to all parts of the world, and by means of the railway to Rouen and Paris, as well as by its extensive and constant steam river traffic, Le Havre has excellent means of communication with the interior of France. Large extensions and See chart, No., 2,680.

Chap. X.] 487 CAPE DE LA HEVE LIGHTS. — HAVRE. improvements have received Parliamentary sanction for this port, see page 464 ; it is supposed that at least 7 or 8 years will elapse before they are completed. The principal imports are cotton, coals, coffee, hides, timber, dye woods, petroleum, tobacco, oil seeds, palm oil, wheat, wood, &c, &c. The principal exports are silks and ribbons, broadcloths, dyes and essences, cotton goods, furniture, millinery, wines, brandy, &c, &c. The population of the town at the last census was 116,369. There is a hospital available for seamen in case of accident or illness, a Sailors' Home, and also reading rooms for seamen. Coals are to be obtained in any quantity, the stock on hand being usually from 10,000 to 12,000 tons. Vessels are coaled alongside the quays in the docks either from carts or barges or both. Many of the wet docks have water for the largest sized merchant vessels at all times. Every kind of supply is plentiful and good. Consular service. — A British Consul-General, and also a Vice- Consul are stationed at Le Havre. The Tidal harbour lies S.S.E. 2£ miles from cape de la Heve and is open to the heavy sea which rolls in with strong westerly winds. The entrance is between two jetties, of which the longest is on the northern side and partially shelters it from westerly winds ; the South jetty is short, and joins the dock walls on the eastern side. The bank outside the South jetty is a continuation of that in Heure bay, and, like it, is of shingle cemented together by mud, very hard and bad for anchors. The bottom of the entrance channel is of the same description ; but inside, the shingle is covered with a layer of mud which forms a good bed for vessels to ground on. The harbour is bordered by wide and commodious quays on all sides. The North quay is used by passenger steamers for the Seine and neighbouring ports. Steam-tugs lie alongside the Floride quay ; the rest of the harbour is used by coasters and by vessels waiting tide to go ap the Seine. Depths. — The harbour is accessible at high water to vessels drawing from 22 to 24 feet during five or six days at springs ; that is to say, a day or two before full and change, and three or four days after. At neaps, to those of about 4 feet less draught. It does not dry out at low water, springs, there being always at least 3 feet in the channel within the piers and 7 feet outside them. Any vessel that can enter the port can also enter the principal basins. Dredging operations are constantly in progress both in the harbour and basins See chart, No. 2,680. SO 11886 2H

[Chap. X. 488 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. and periodical flushings tend to preserve and deepen the entrance channel. Basins.— There are at Havre nine basins or wet clocks with ample quay accommodation and storage, which communicate with the tidal harbour and with each other by gates. The basins' are named the Bassins du Roi, de la Barre, Vauban, de la Floride, de l'Eure, Bellot, du Commerce, de la Citadelle, and Bassin-dock. The Bassin de l'Eure is the largest ; the depth of water on the sill at its entrance is 33 feet 9 inches at high water springs, and 29 feet 5 inches at neaps ; that on the sill of the Bassin Bellot is only about 9 inches less ; in both cases, this is a considerably greater depth than the present approaches to the port require. The width of the entrance to the Bassin de l'Eure, which is the basin used by the large trans-atlantic steamers, is 100 feet. The entrance to the Tancarville canal is on the eastern side of the Bassin de l'Eure. The entrances to the other basins are from 6S feet to 37^ feet wide, the latter being the width of the entrance to the Vauban basin, where British colliers lie. The sills of the gates of the Bassins du Roi and de la Barre have 21Jj feet over them at high water, ordinary springs ; the western end of the Bassin de la Floride opens into the tidal harbour, and forms a convenient shelter for coasters and wind-bound vessels ; at its eastern end is a half -tide dock. The gates of the Bassins du Roi and de la Barre can remain open without inconvenience until the water has fallen 2 feet below high water, which, both at spring and neap tides, takes place about 1^ hours after high water slack ; and, as these gates are opened by the pressure of the rising tide about as long before the commencement of slack water, it follows that the basins can communicate with the harbour during 3^ or 4 hours of each tide. Chap. X.] HAVRE. — DOCKS.— LIGHTS.— TIDES. 489 There are also repairing slips, masting sheers, and every convenience for repairs of all sorts to hull or machinery. Life-boats. — Three life-boats are stationed at Havre or in its immediate vicinity. Pilots. — The pilots of Havre are numerous and skilful, and are paid according to the distance piloted. According to regulations, the greatest distance is to cape Barfleur, and the least is, outside the banks at the entrance of the harbour ; there is great competition among them, however, and being provided with excellent boats, they frequently meet vessels as far westward as the Casquets. Those who pilot vessels out of harbour are bound to conduct them clear of the outlying banks ; if they consent to take them farther, they are paid 15 francs, or by special agreement. Steam-tugs are always in readiness, and the signal for their services being required is, an ensign suspended under the bowsprit. LIGHTS. — North jetty. — From a small round tower, 36 feet from the outer end of the northern jetty and 39 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed white light, visible 9 miles. South jetty. — A red flashing light, visible 12 miles, is shown at 27 feet above high water from the end of the southern pier ; the flash is of one second duration, the eclipses of four seconds. Grand Quai. — On the Grand quai within the harbour, a fixed green light, visible 8 miles, is shown from an iron support at 56 feet above high water. This light on with that on the South jetty, N.E. by E. E., leads between the Haut du Sud-Ouest and the Haut de Quarante and up io the harbour entrance. Fog Signal. — In thick or foggy weather, a fog trumpet is sounded near the lighthouse on the North jetty in the day time, from 2 hours before to 3 hours after high water ; at night, from one hour before to 2 hours after high water. It gives a blast of 8 seconds duration, followed by an interval of from 18 to 20 seconds. In addition, in very thick fogs, a smaller trumpet is sounded continuously. Should the trumpet be out of order a bell is sounded ; see fog signals, page 11. Tides and tide Signals.— It is high water, full and change, at Havre at 9h. 18m. Springs rise 25^ feet, neaps 21^ feet above See chart, No. 2,680. 2H 2 SO 11886

The ordinary tide signals, see page 12, are made from the signal-station at the inner end of the northern jetty, and repeated from a signal-station about 2 cables S.S.E. from cape de la Heve lighthouses. Strong and lasting westerly winds have sometimes raised the water to the level of the quay, but this rarely happens. The wind, how ever, has great influence on the height of the tide. The freshets of the Seine, during a rainy season or the melting of the snow, also contribute greatly to raise the water in the harbour, and it has been remarked that the highest tides have almost always occurred during the strongest freshets. Havre has the great advantage over most of the harbours on the French side of the channel, of a long period of slack at high water. The maximum duration of this high water slack has been observed to be lh. 15m., the minimum from 20 to 25 minutes, and the mean interval 57 minutes. This long period of slack water, together with the very slight rise and fall for a considerable time before and after, is very valuable to the traffic of the port, as it allows the basins to be open for 3 or 4 hours, and, therefore, many vessels are able to enter or leave the docks on the same tide. During the months of May, June and July, the duration of slack water is, with some exceptions, generally less than the mean ; the rest of the year it continues almost always an hour or more. At springs, the duration of the flood is 5h. 10m., and of the ebb 7h. 15m. DANGERS Off" HAVRE.— The approaches to Havre are obstructed by banks of stones and shingle which form a belt of dangers fronting the shore from 2 miles eastward of the entrance to cape de la Heve. The highest parts of this belt are, the Bane de l'Eclat, Hauts de la Rade, and Haut de la Petite Rade. By the survey of 1 855, there appeared to have been no perceptible alteration in these banks since 1834 ; the summit of the Eclat is, however, a little higher since then. Bane de l'Eclat is divided into two high ridges 2\ cables apart; 10 feet is the least water on the northern ridge, but the highest part of the southern ridge is awash at low water and is one of the most dangerous spots in the neighbourhood of Havre. The surface of this shoal patch is covered with masses of flint and shingle ; from it, cape de la Heve southern lighthouse bears N.E. \ E. 1| miles ; and, the North jetty lighthouse S.E. | E. 2\ miles. In the depression between the two ridges of the Eclat bank, there is a patch with only 7 feet, and in other parts only 12 or 13 feet water; There is a passage into the Petite Rade at the south-western end of the bank with from 9 to 15 feet water, but it is too dangerous to be taken without a pilot. The Hauts de la Rade commence about 2 cables S. by E. from the shoalest spot on the Eclat, and, with the Grand Placard, the Haut du Sud-Ouest, and the Haut de Quarante, extend 2 miles beyond the entrance to Havre. The Hauts de la Rade consist of three ridges separated from each other by narrow channels with from 10 to 12 feet water and, in-shore of and sheltered by these ridges, is the Petite Rade. The North-west ridge is about 6 cables long and a cable wide ; it has 6 feet water on its highest part, which bears S. by E. \ E. 5^ cables from the highest part of the Eclat. The south-western ridge lies 6 or 7 cables south-westward of this dangerous spot ; it has only 6 feet on it, and 9 feet at its western edge with cape de la Heve lighthouses in line ; it is the outer danger on the parallel of the entrance to Havre. Nearly midway between its edge and the Eclat, is a third rather extensive rocky flat with from 9 to 12 feet water. The Grand Placard is nearly half way between the western edge of the south-western ridge and the harbour entrance, and about 3 cables E.S.E. from it is the Haut du Sud-Ouest ; the latter has as little as 3 feet on it ; the former, only one foot at its eastern side. See chart, No. 2,680.

Chap. X.] HAVRE.— DANGERS OFF.— BUOYAGE. 493 Haut de la Petite Rade, a heap of stones and gravel with 5 feet water, is at the eastern end of the Petite Rado and bears N.W. by W.jW.5 cables from the North jetty-head. The Haut de Quarante is the eastern part of these dangers, and is on the eastern side of the entrance to Havre ; it has as little as 3 feet on its outer part, only 3 cables from a similar depth on the Haut du Sud-Ouest. The two banks are connected by a 6-feet ridge, which forms the outer bar to the entrance. BUOYS. — The following buoys mark the shoals just described and the approaches to them ; and, consequently, indicate the positions of these dangers to all vessels bound to Havre and to those from the northward bound up the Seine. Some of the buoys are numbered and some are not ; the numbers, however, have but little or no reference to their positions, and they are consequently now described in the order in which they would be seen by a vessel approaching from the northward or north-westward. A stranger should under no circumstances pass within the outer line of buoys marking these shoals without a pilot : — An automatic whistle-buoy, painted black and red in horizontal stripes, lies in 7 fathoms, W. \ N. 3g miles from cape de la Heve southern lighthouse. The whistle should be heard under favourable conditions of wind and sea from a distance of several miles. A bell-buoy, striped horizontally red and white with oval top-mark and reflector, is moored just westward of the northern shoal spot of the Bane de l'Eclat, with the Semaphore on cape de la Heve bearing E. by S. \ S. 61 cables. No. 1 buoy, 4^ cables S.W. \ W. from the last buoy described, is a cylindrical black buoy with square top-mark ; from it, the Semaphore bears E. § N. 1-1 miles. No. 2 buoy, 4^ cables S.E. by E. \ E. from No. 1, is a conical red buoy, from which the Semaphore bears N.E. by E. \ E. 7 cables. No. 3 buoy, 5 cables S.S.W. § W. from No. 1 is a light and bell buoy ; from it, the Semaphore bears N.E. by E. \ E. 1^ miles. No. 9 buoy, just southward of the shoal spot at the southern end of the Bane de l'Eclat, and nearly 5 cables E. § S. from No. 3. is a black buoy with cylindrical top-mark. See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. 494 At 9 cables S. £ W. from No. 3 is a cylindrical buoy with diamond top-mark, not numbered, but painted black and white in horizontal stripes. No. 5 buoy, 5 cables S. by W. from that last described, is a light buoy painted black and showing a red light ; it lies with cape de la Heve lights in line, and marks the northern side of the prohibited anchorage. See page 496. At 5 cables South from No. 5, is a light-buoy called Nord du Mouillage ; it is painted red, and marks the southern side of the prohibited anchorage. No. 7 buoy, one mile E. £ S. from No. 5 buoy, is black, and marks the southern edge of the Grand Placard shoal ; from it, Havre North jetty light bears E. f N. 1/3 miles. No. 4 buoy, 4 cables N.E. by N. from No. 7, is a small red buoy ; it marks the north-eastern side of the Grand Placard. No. 6, or Haut de Quarante buoy, is a white occulting light-buoy ; it is painted red and lies E. by S. \ S. 1-6 miles from No. 5. From it, Havre South jetty light bears N.E. by E. \ E. one mile. No. 11 buoy, black with double cone top-mark, lies at the northern side of the Haut de la Petite Rade ; from it, the North jetty light house bears S.E. by E. 5^ cables. PETITE RADE DE HAVRE is the anchorage inside the banks just described between Havre and cape de la Heve. It is well sheltered with the wind from N.E. round by East to S.E., but is open to all others, and strong breezes between North and W.S.W. send in a heavy sea. The holding-ground is good, and anchors take such firm hold in the clay that there is sometimes great difficulty in weighing, especially when vessels have been riding to strong westerly winds. It should, however, only be used as a temporary anchorage where vessels may wait, with off-shore winds, for sufficient water to enter the harbour, but they should not remain there in unsettled weather, nor if it blows strongly from the westward. Vessels of moderate draught anchor in the middle of the Petite Rade in 'from 16 to 27 feet water ; the best of the anchorage is 5 or 6 cables long in a N.W. and S.E. direction and 2 cables wide ; from its centre, in 20 feet, cape de la Heve lighthouses are in line ; and, Fatouville lighthouse, on the southern shore of the Seine, is on with the signal staff on the South jetty, See chart, No. 2,680.

Chap. X.] HAVRE. — PETITE AND GRANDE RADE. 495 Small vessels anchor nearer the shore, with Fatouville lighthouse open northward of the North jetty lighthouse ; but, no nearer than to have cape de la Heve southern lighthouse bearing North. The holding-ground here is so good that, unless she parted, a small vessel with a good scope of cable would be in no danger during a westerly gale. Directions. — The only practicable entrance to the Petite Rade de Havre for vessels of moderate draught at low water, is between the cliffs of cape de la Heve and the northern ridge of the Eclat, but a stranger should not use it without a pilot. The least depth midway between the northern ridge and the shore is 18 feet. To enter this channel, steer for the southern lighthouse on the cape on a S.E. \ E. bearing ; this leads 3 cables north-eastward of the bell-buoy just outside the Eclat bank, and when about 3 cables from the cliffs, the vessel is in mid-channel and must then bear away southward for No. 2 red buoy, moored between the northern ridge of the Eclat and the shore, keeping it on the starboard bow and taking care not to approach so near the land as to entirely lose sight of the lantern of the northern lighthouse. Small vessels, locally acquainted, run for the anchorage in the Petite Rade at low water, passing either northward or southward of the southern ridge of the Eclat ; both channels have 13 feet water, but the lead and chart are the best guides for strangers. GRANDE RADE de HAVRE is simply an anchorage in the open sea, N.W. by W. 5 miles from cape de la Heve. Vessels of deep draught having to wait for springs to enter Havre, sometimes anchor here in quite fine weather or with off-shore winds, but they should be prepared to weigh instantly on any change in the weather. The holding-ground is excellent, and, from a vessel in the centre of the anchorage in 9 fathoms water, cape de la Heve bears S.E. by E. ; Fatouville lighthouse on with the North jetty lighthouse at Havre S.E. \ E. ; and the outer whistle-buoy S. f E. about 2^ miles. When bound into Havre from the Grande Rade, with the wind from E.N.E. round by East to S.W., weigh as soon as the flood has acquired strength, so as to be near the Hauts de la Rade before the stream changes its direction north-eastward. When near these banks, the directions for entering the harbour presently given must be attended to. With a fair wind, weigh so as to be at the harbour's mouth at the proper time for entering. See chart, No. 2,680.

[Chap. X. 496 ESTUARY OF THE SEINE. Prohibited anchorage. — Except in case of absolute necessity, vessels are prohibited from anchoring within the following areas : — 1. In the area enclosed by a line running W. by N. \ N., one mile from No. 5 buoy (black, with red light), and a line on a similar bearing and distance from No. 10 buoy (red with ivhite light). 2. In the area bounded on the West by a line drawn from No. 5 to No. 10 buoy ; on the North by a line joining No. 5 buoy and the North jetty lighthouse ; and on the South by a line joining No. 10 and No. 6 buoys, the latter with a white occulting light. The last section does not apply to sailing vessels not in tow, nor to fishing vessels or boats. TIDAL STREAMS.— Petite Rade.— The flood stream begins in the Petite Rade about 1^ hours after the tide has begun to rise in the harbour, or about 4 hours before high water there. Its first direction is S. by E. for 2 hours, at from 2\ to 3 knots ; it then turns to E.S.E. and the stream becomes imperceptible until high water in the harbour, when it again acquires strength, runs N.N.W., and ends in that direction H hours after. The ebb commences immediately and runs N.N.W. for 3 hours or until 4i hours after high water in the harbour ; it then turns to W.S.W. and ends in a S.W. direction a few minutes before the flood commences. At the northern entrance to the road, the streams follow the same course, but the flood does not end until 2 hours after high water. The ebb runs N.N.W. during 2^ or 3 hours, and then turns W.S.W. and S.S.W. When the tide is out in the harbour, the ebb runs S.S.W. from 1^ to 2 knots, and it ends in this direction a little before the flood stream commences at this spot, or about 4 hours before high water in the harbour. Vessels running into this road at low water should be aware of this stream of tide when passing the shoal patches. Grande Rade. — The flood stream begins to be felt in the Grande Rade about 4 hours before high water at Havre. An hour later, it runs S. by W. about 3 knots, and continues to run towards the Seine until 2\ hours before high water ; its direction is then E.S.E., losing little of its strength, and then E.N.E. In the latter direction, its rate See chart, No. 2,680.
