XL LIGHT. — Berck lighthouse, a circular brick tower, 82 feet high, on the keeper's dwelling, exhibits, at 115 feet above high water, a flashing white light, with a five-seconds period, the flash being of 1^ seconds duration ; the eclipse, ?>\ seconds. The light is visible 17 miles, but is obscured when bearing S. \ W. through an angle of 20', by the tower of the hospital. A life-boat is stationed near the lighthouse, and there is also a mortar apparatus and other life-saving appliances. Directions. — The mouth of the river Authie is dangerous to approach during the flood, especially with westerly winds, as the stream then runs in with great rapidity and might draw a vessel on the banks where she would almost certainly become a total wreck ; the buoys meant for the use of small fishing vessels of about 5 feet draught belonging to Groffliers are not sufficient guides for a stranger to enter the channel. No vessel, indeed, however light her draught, should attempt the entrance, unless in charge of one of the Berck or Groffliers fishermen, who alone are in a position to know the changes taking place in the channel. The COAST from Haut-Banc point trends N.N.E. 8 miles to Touquet point at the entrance of the river Canche. The shore is low, sandy, and bordered by a range of sand-hills of moderate height. A sandy strand 5 cables wide uncovers at the foot of the sand-hills, and joins the accumulation of sand which obstructs the entrances of the rivers Authie and Canche. The low plain adjoining the shore extends to the foot of the hills 3 or 4 miles inland and is divided in its whole length into two nearly equal parts by a chain of sand-hills, much higher than those near the beach, and which may- be seen 8 or 9 miles distant. This chain of sand-hills may be mistaken for those bordering the beach, although they are 1| or 2 miles inland, and it is important to guard against this mistake when turning to windward in-shore in hazy weather. The objects which serve as distinguishing marks on this part of the coast are, the windmills of Verton and St. Josse, on the hills in the interior ; the chain of sand-hills just described ; the lighthouses on Haut-Banc and Touquet points ; the hospital, windmills, and church tower at Berck-sur-mer, the latter standing on the plain E. by N. 1^ miles from Haut-Banc point is an excellent landmark ; and the Semaphore station south-westward of Touquet point lighthouse. See chart, No. 2,148.

Chap. XL] COAST. — ESTUARY OF THE CANCHE.— ETAPLES. 553 The inhabitants of Berck. Merlimont, and Cuque, fit out about fifty fishing-boats of from 2 to 9 tons burden, which they generally beach at high water just northward of Haut-Banc point. The ESTUARY of the CANCHE, known locally as the bay of Etaples, is 2 miles wide between Touquet and Lornel points, the southern and northern limits of the entrance, and runs 3 miles inland in a S.S.E. direction. Like the estuaries of the Somme and the Authie, it is filled by a mass of sand and broken shells which is left dry at half ebb and uncovers at low water about one mile outside the general line of the coast. Like the Authie estuary, also, it inclines to move bodily northward and also to become narrower, Touquet point having extended northward 330 yards between 1835 and 1878, and Lornel point having receded about 200 yards in the same period ; and this northward movement still continues. The entrance points and shores of the river consist of sand-hills of moderate height, of which the shapes are frequently changed by westerly gales. ETAPLES. — From Touquet point, the southern shore of the estuary trends S.E. S. as far as abreast of the small port of Etaples, a place with about 3,000 inhabitants, which, in ancient times, was of considerable importance, but has now only its rather extensive fishery, the general trade having been entirely destroyed by the silting up of the bay, which now only admits vessels of about 9 feet draught, at springs, as far as Etaples ; the grounding berths, of muddy sand, are on the north-western side of the town where there is a wooden quay and mooring posts. The northern shore of the estuary is low and winding ; between Etaples, which stands on the northern bank of the river Canche, and Lornel point, its general trend is N.N.W. and the two shores converge towards each other, the river, abreast of the town, being very narrow. The surf and westerly winds heap up the sand round Touquet point, where it forms a bank barely covered at high water, neaps, and extending in a circuit of nearly a mite between the bearings N.N.W. and N.N.E. from the point. This bank shelters the inner part of the bay, and fishing craft unable to reach Etaples in one tide lie aground in the channel in safety under its lee. A similar bank lies in front of Lornel point and extends nearly a mile in a W.S.W. direction. Between these banks is the entrance channel to the river. See chart, No. 2,148. SO 11886 2-M 2

554 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. XL Depths. — Between Touquet point and Camiers light, the bottom in the channel is 13 feet above the level of the lowest tides, and consequently, there are only 19 feet at high water, springs, and 13 feet at neaps. From the outer end of the dikes (presently described) to Etaples there are from 5 to 7 feet less. At Etaples quay there are 3J feet at high water of the lowest neaps ; 7 feet at mean neaps ; and 10£ feet at ordinary springs. The tide begins to rise at Etaples about 1£ hours before high water, and the harbour dries about 3 hours after high water. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the estuary of the Canche at llh. 20m. ; the rise is 32 feet at springs! and 26 feet at neaps, above the zero of soundings. The rising tide does not check the stream of the Canche until about half flood. Both streams are very rapid through the channel so long as the banks are uncovered, but their rate does not exceed 3 knots during the last hour of the flood and the first hour of the ebb. With westerly gales, the sea is high at the entrance, and the waves caused by a strong south-westerly wind cross it obliquely. The Entrance Channel runs between the banks, as described, in an easterly direction towards Camiers lighthouse on the northern shore of the river ; from thence, it is between two submersible dikes of rough chalk stones, before referred to, for nearly 2 miles up to and abreast of Etaples, where the western dike-end is connected with the southern shore. The channel is only about 70 yards wide abreast of the town quays, but between the dikes it is double that width. The western dike is marked by four red beacons with conical top-marks ; the eastern dike by five black beacons with cylindrical top-marks ; the outer beacon in each case marking the end of the dike. Half a mile above Etaples the viaduct of the Northern railway crosses the river. By means of this line the town is in direct com munication with Boulogne on the North, and also with Amiens and Paris. Pilots. — Two pilots and an assistant pilot are stationed at Etaples. When they are unable to get out to a vessel, they come as far as the weather permits and signal by hand the direction to be taken. The smillest vessel, without local knowledge, should not think of attempting this channel without a pilot. See chart. No. 2,148.

Chap. XL] ESTUARY OF THE CANCHE. — LIGHTS. — DIRECTIONS. 555 Buoys. — The edge of the sands off the estuary of the Canche is marked by two large buoys, viz. : a black spindle buoy to the northward and a red bell-buoy to the southward, these buoys being about 1\ miles apart. The channel between the banks up to the dike-ends is well marked by red and black buoys, the positions of which are frequently changed to suit the variations in the channel. LIGHTS.— Touquet point— Two octagonal lighthouses, 273 yards apart, bearing N. by E. i2 E. and S. by W. W. from each other, stand on Touquet point ; each exhibits, at 174 feet above high water, a fixed white electric light, visible 20 miles. This light is to be altered by the discontinuance of the northern light, and the substitution of a group-flashing light for the fixed light at the southern lighthouse. Camiers. — From a white square stone tower on the northern shore, and at 56 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed red and white light, visible 9 miles through an angle of 90°, i.e., between points Lornel and Touquet. It shows red over the highest parts of the banks which separate the two existing channels into the Canche. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station about a mile south westward from Touquet point, and half that distance W. by S. \ S. from the South lighthouse ; see page 12. Directions. — At night, the heavy sea an sand-banks at the mouth of the river Canche may be avoided by keeping cape Grisnez light well open westward of cape Alprech light. By day, the extreme of cape Grisnez should be kept about half a point open westward of cape Alprech. Though vessels should never attempt to enter the Canche without a pilot or some person of local experience, they may be driven to do so by bad weather, or by finding themselves embayed amongst the sand-banks. The pilots reside at Etaples, and as it is impossible for them to board vessels outside when it blows hard from the west ward, they then meet them under shelter of the bank extending from Touquet point. Vessels without pilots, seeking shelter, should endeavour as soon as possible to get sight of the outer red bell-buoy, and it is important not to pass northward of the parallel of Touquet point before the buoy See chart, No. 2,148.

[Chap. XL 556 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. is sighted, for, if set too far northward by the flood stream, which is running at its greatest strength outside the banks at the time of high water at Etaples, it is impossible to regain the entrance. The most favourable time for entering the Canche is about one hour before high water, for the stream then runs into the channel with sufficient strength to assist a vessel in threading her way , and the water still rises enough to float her should she take the ground. Pass between the black and red buoys, leaving the black to port and the red to starboard, as usual. At springs, pilots place vessels drawing 10 or 11 feet water, when not bound to or unable to reach Etaples, in the elbow above Touquet point ; here they lie in safely even during westerly gales, protected by the high bank which joins Touquet point, and which dries from 21 to 23 feet above the level of the lowest tides. Caution. — The very low land, coupled with the dangers bordering the shore, render the navigation between Cayeux and the mouth of the Canche extremely dangerous in foggy or snowy weather, or during westerly gales accompanied by rain, when the weather is generally dark, the land covered with mist, and the most brilliant lights difficult to distinguish. Moreover, with these gales, a few hours suffice to raise a heavy sea in the eastern part of the Channel, and especially on the edge of the great submarine slope which extends off-shore from St. Valery-en-Caux to the river Canche, and this alone causes a considerable drift ; but, in addition, westerly gales tend to drive the water towards the head of the bight formed between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez, and greatly influence the direction of the tidal streams, see page 571. It may be seen, there fore, how important it is that a vessel should not run into the eastern part of the channel without her position being well ascertained by bearings of cape Barfleur light, or of St. Catherine's light, Isle of Wight, and without using every precaution after these lights are lost sight of. The only safeguard is the frequent use of the lead ; and, if lights cannot be distinguished or the position is from any cause doubtful, vessels should keep in at least 20 fathoms water whatever be the time of tide ; this not only keeps a vessel clear of the dangers near the shore, but also of the off-lying banks between the mouth of the Somme and Dover channel. See chart, No. 2,148.

Chap. XL] 557 CAUTION. — COAST. — CAPE ALPRECH. The COAST from Lornel point trends N. by E. 8£ miles to cape Alprech, and from thence N.E. } E. 2 miles to Boulogne. The shore is low, bordered by sand-hills of moderate height, and runs in a straight line from the mouth of the Canche to that of the Brone rivulet, which finds its way into the sea 2 miles southward of cape Alprech, and is the northern limit of the low sandy shore forming the coast-line for the whole distance of 34 mites from the town of Ault, near Treport. A mile northward of the rivulet the coast is low with hills sloping down towards it, and, on their sides, several houses of the village of Equihen may be seen ; beyond this, the coast is steep, and consists of clay and of schistose rocks of a dark grey colour. The high land separating the courses of the rivers Canche and Liane, which latter runs into the sea at Boulogne, extends westward to within 1^ miles of the shore and terminates near the meridian of Etaples in a chain of hills, of which many are sufficiently high to be seen in clear weather 25 miles distant. These hills are excellent landmarks for the pilots, who call them the terres de Tourmont or Tourmont-land. At 1\ miles inland, and in front of the Tourmont-land, is Mont St. Frieux, 505 feet in height, and one of the most remarkable objects between the river Canche and Boulogne. It consists of four mounds or hillocks, very- near each other, rising from the same base and occupying a space of about one mile. From its isolated position and height, Mont St. Frieux may be seen in clear weather 25 miles distant. On the highest of the hills northward of the Brone rivulet is the church of St. Etienne-au-Mont, Gravois mill, and also the two mills near Alprech, all of which may be seen a considerable distance at sea. The sandy beach, which borders the shore almost to cape Alprech, uncovers at low water 5 cables from the foot of the sand hills, but northward of the Brone rivulet the width of sand gradually decreases and the shore is bordered by a shelf of irregular rocks which dry a cable outside high-water mark. CAPE ALPRECH* is a perpendicular rocky cliff of a brownish red colour, 135 feet above the level of high water ; the foot of the cliff is skirted by a shelf ot rock covered with boulders which dries * See Admiralty chart : — Cape Alprech to Ambleteuse, including Boulogne, No. 438 ; scale, m = 4-9 inches.

[Chap. XL 558 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. a cable out at low water. From the cape, the coast turns sharply north-eastward, and is high and steep-to within 4 cables of the jetties of Boulogne. LIGHTS.— A square lighthouse, 33 feet high, stands on the summit of cape Alprech about 87 yards from the edge of the cliff, near the tower of the old semaphore, and 2J miles south- westward from the entrance to Boulogne. It exhibits, at 161 feet above high water, a flashing red light visible 17 miles ; the flash takes place at intervals of five seconds and lasts a quarter of a second, the eclipse four and three-quarter seconds. A. fixed white leading light is shown from a shed N. | E. 164 yards from Alprech lighthouse ; it is 144 feet above high water, and visible 9 miles. The two lights in line lead 2£ cables seaward of the elbow of the Carnot breakwater. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on cape Alprech just southward of the lighthouse ; see page 12. PORTEL. — The coast between cape Alprech and Boulogne is intersected by valleys, and at the entrance of the largest is the village of Portel. This valley, 6 cables N.E. by E. of the cape, is enclosed by high land, and on the summit of the hill on its northern side stands the fortress of Mont Couple, in which is a Semaphore. The rocks, which uncover at low water, extend 4 cables off-shore from Portel, and, on their summit, N. \ E. about 6 cables from cape Alprech lighthouse, is Heurt fort, from which the Lineur sunken rocks project N. by W. \ W. 2\ cables, and a heavy sea runs on them with a fresh south-westerly wind. The fishermen of Portel have about 40 boats ; during the fine season, they ground them on the south-western side of a small beach in front of the village where they are sheltered during the greater part of the tide by the surrounding rocks. When the weather is threatening they haul them up above high-water mark and place them in the bed of a rivulet which runs through the valley ; in winter they take shelter in Boulogne harbour. BOULOGNE. — This port, occupying the entrance of the valley of the Liane, has during the last ten years undergone great alterations and improvements, and although a very large portion of the projected See chart, No. 438.

Chap. XL] 559 PORTEL.— BOULOGNE. — BREAKWATER. plans have been definitely abandoned, enough has been done to render it one of the most convenient and best sheltered of the French channel ports. The principal objects recognised when approaching Boulogne are, Mont St. Frieux, already described, see page 557 ; Mont Lambert, fortified, 1\ miles to the eastward, the highest land in the neighbour hood of Boulogne ; and the column of the Grande Armee on the high land a mile northward of the town. The entrance to the harbour bears N.W. by W. from the summit of Mont Lambert, and W. \ S. from the column ; the former is 604 feet, and the head of the statue on the column 448 feet above the level of high water. OUTER HARBOUR.— With the object of enclosing a large water space outside the port affording shelter from the prevailing westerly winds, of which space a great portion should be available for ships of the deepest draught at all times of tide, the Carnot breakwater, of stone and of the most solid construction, has been completed. It starts from the shore under the Chatillon cliff, a mile south-westward of the harbour entrance, and runs out 1,410 yards in a N.N.W. \ W. direction ; it then curves for about 220 yards until its direction becomes N.E. by N., when it runs a farther distance of about 715 yards ; the whole extent of this magnificent work being 2,345 yards. A lighthouse stands at its extreme end, and a stone beacon 1,230 yards from the inner end. Whistle-buoy. — A red automatic whistle-buoy is moored W.N.W. 1§ cables from the lighthouse on the breakwater end. Depths.— The Carnot breakwater shelters an area about 120 acres in extent, called the Outer or deep-sea harbour, of which, however, although the work is always in progress, only a portion has yet been dredged ; viz., a space about 4 cables long and 1^ cables wide, next the outer arm of the breakwater, affording anchorage in from 32 to 27 feet at the lowest tides. At 100 yards inshore of this space, there are as yet only from 3 to 6 feet water, and the shallow extends to the beach ; the dredging of an area of 150 acres to a least depth of 26 feet, and the greater part to a depth of 33 feet, has, however, received Government sanction. Alprech lighthouse in line with the stone beacon on the breakwater leads along the central line of the anchorage and up to the western most of two large mooring buoys 130 yards apart. The large mail See chart, No. 438.

560 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. XL steamers of the Nederland transatlantic line use this anchorage for the transhipment of cargo and passengers. In the southern corner of this Outer harbour, and at the inner end of the breakwater, is a small harbour, dry at low water, constructed for the use of vessels loading with stone in the building of the breakwater, and now but little used ; other large works for the prospective accommodation of shipping are in various stages of progress between it and the port of Boulogne. The PORT Of BOULOGNE is formed at the mouth of the Liane, a smnll river whose waters are abundant during rainy seasons or at the melting of the snow. It consists of an Entrance channel, Avant port, Tidal port, Inner port, and Bassin-a-flot or wet dock. The town has a population of about 46,000, of whom about one-fifth are English ; it is divided into Chatillon and Capecure ou the western side, and St. Pierre, Basse Ville, and Haute Ville on the eastern side of the harbour ; it is built in the form of an amphitheatre in and on the sides of a valley enclosed between high hills. The buildings most easily recognised from the sea are the bell-tower and cupola of the cathedral in Haute Ville, the church spire in Basse Ville, the marine baths, the windmill half way up the hill south-eastward of the baths, and the church of St. Pierre des Marins on the cliff. There is a small British Seamen's institute with recreation and reading rooms. Vice-consul. — A British Vice-consul is stationed at Boulogne. Entrance Channel.— The entrance to the port is perfectly sheltered against the prevailing westerly winds by the Carnot break water, which has also modified to so great an extent both the strength and direction of the tidal streams as to have rendered the harbour comparatively easy of access. The two piers enclosing the channel are of unequal length and run out across a sandy strand which extends beyond the pier-heads and uncovers 3£ cables from the shore at the lowest tides. The piers are 230 feet apart, and, from the entrance, which has a S.E. by S. direction, curve slightly eastward. The S.W. pier is 735 yards long and consists of stone-work up to the level of the highest tides, on which is wooden pile-work the whole length of the pier. The N.E. pier, 547 yards long, curves and lies parallel with the S.W. pier, and also consists of a stone f ounda- See chart, No. 438,

Chap. XL] 561 BOULOGNE.— ENTRANCE. — BASINS. tion, rising to the level of the sands only, and surmounted by open pile-work. This pier is prolonged by a submersible dike about 500 yards long, composed of rough stone-work for 150 yards and continued in strong pile-work the remainder of its length ; the top of this dike is from 3 to 9 feet above the level of low water. The Avant port is immediately within the piers and through it is the channel to the Tidal port and also to the entrance to the Bassin-a-flot ; it is in fact a part of the Tidal port. The Tidal port is the most important division of the harbour. At its southern end is the Inner port, which serves as the reservoir or Retenue de Chasses, for flushing the channel, and which might at any time be utilized for shipping if required. The inner end of the N.E. pier joins the quai Gambetta, which extends the whole length of the Avant Port and Tidal port, a distance of about 950 yards, 400 yards of the quay-wall having been just re-built, and on this side are berthed the Thames steamers, and are the landing-places for the goods traffic of the South-Eastern Railway ; La large space over 400 feet long is also being specially prepared for the transatlantic steamers. On the western side is the quai Chanzy, which separates the tidal port from the Bassin-a-flot, and, at its northern end is the railway station and the landing stage for the Folkestone steamers. There is also a slip-way for building or repairing small vessels, and a gridiron and careening place adjoining the slip. Depths. — The port admits vessels of the deepest draught at high water, springs, and of 27 feet draught at neaps. Dredging has been prosecuted with such effect that by the year 1893, where a bar, dry at low water, formerly existed, there was a clear channel up to the pier-heads with a least depth of 13 feet at the lowest tides ; 41^ feet at high water, springs ; and 36 feet at neaps. Between the piers and through the Avant port the depth was about the same, and in the Tidal port the depth was rather greater. Since then, dredging has been energetically pursued, with the view of enabling the largest ocean steamers to lie alongside its quays afloat at the lowest tides. For this purpose a low water depth of 26 feet has to be obtained, and with the greater part of the quai. Chanzy- this has been accom plished, but as regards the quai Gambetta the work is not so far advanced. See chart, No. 438.

CAPK D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. XL 562 > The Bassin-a-flot or wet dock is on the western side of the Tidal port, and its entrance is through a lock at its northern end. The Bassin has an area of 17 acres, being 430 yards long, 186 yards wide, and with a quay frontage of 1,150 yards. The lock has double gates, the entrance is 69 feet wide between them, and 328^ feet in length ; the depth over the sills is 29J? feet at high water, springs, and 23i feet at neaps. The dock itself has rather more water, but the bottom is hard and only lightly coated with mud. The lock gates are open from 3 to 3^ hours every- tide. Coals can be obtained in moderate quantities. Vessels coal without difficulty either in the Tidal port or in the Bassin-a-flot. Slight repairs to machinery can be effected, but, there being no dry dock, serious defects of hull cannot be made good. Stores and supplies generally are cheap and plentiful. Trade, &C. — The general trade of the port is extensive. In 1893 the number of vessels entering was 2,522, of an aggregate of 778,000 tons. The principal imports are coal, wool, machinery, timber, beer, jute, cotton, &c. ; the exports, wine, spirits, cement, fruit and vegetables, Parisian articles, &c, &c. The herring and mackerel fisheries employ a considerable capital and several vessels are fitted out for the Iceland cod fishery. The coasting trade is active ; two lines of transatlantic steamers make this a port of call ; there is daily communication by steamer with Folkestone, thus connecting the South-Eastern Railway of England with the Northern Railway of France, and several times a week with London and Goole. LIGHTS. — The following lights mark the Carnot breakwater and the entrance to Boulogne harbour :— Camot breakwater. — From a lighthouse standing on a white reservoir at the breakwater end is exhibited, at 42 feet above the sea. a flashing white light, visible 8 miles. The light has a period of fifteen seconds, thus : light, seven seconds ; eclipsed, eight seconds ; it is automatically fed and worked by compressed oil gas. S.W. pier.— Tide lights. — From a round tower at the pier-head are shown two vertical fixed white lights of the fourth order, visible 8 miles ; the upper light is 43 feet, the lower light 33 feet, above the level of high water. The upper light is lighted when there are See chart, No. 438.

Chap. XL] BOULOGNE.— DEPTHS.— LIGHTS.— SIGNALS. 563 9| feet on the inner part of the dike, at which time there are 29 feet water in the channel ; the lower light, at the moment of high water ; both are extinguished when the tide has fallen to 29 feet in the channel. From an iron support, 47 yards within the vertical lights and 29 feet above the level of high water, is shown a fixed red light, visible 4 miles. This light is obscured by the tidal lighthouse when bearing between S. 23° E. and S. 27° E. N.E. pier. — A fixed red light, visible 6 miles, is exhibited at 46 feet above the level of high water, from a white tower 33 yards from the N.E. pier-head. A fixed green light is exhibited at 33 feet above high water from an iron pole by a hut on the N.E. pier-head : it stands about 30 yards in advance of the lighthouse. The green and red lights in line show the direction of the sub mersible dike extending from the N.E. pier-head. The S.W. pier red light on with the N.E. pier red light E. by S. I S. leads about 150 yards northward of the end of the Carnot break water. Fog signals. — Two sirens, worked by compressed air, are sounded together on the S.W. pier-head, as follows : — One siren gives a continuous sound, the other of greater power gives a group of two sounds (low, high), about every 50 seconds ; each sound is of about 2^ seconds duration, and the two sounds of each group are separated by an interval of 4 seconds. Should the sirens be damaged, a bell is sounded about 50 times a minute ; see fog signals, page 11. Tide Signals. — The usual day tide signals, see page 12, are made from a signal-staff at the S.W. pier-head, commencing from a depth of 15i feet in the entrance channel. The entrance to the Bassin-a-flot being open, is indicated by day by the pilot flag being hoisted near the lock gates as well as at the pilot house at the inner end of the N.E. pier ; by night, by a green light on each side of the lock entrance, and by a green light at the pilot station. Prohibition to enter the harbour is signalled by day by the hoisting of a red flag at the S.W. pier-head, and also at the pilot station ; at night by the red colour of the tidal lights, and also a red See chart No. 438.

564 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. XL light at the pilot station. Should the prohibition be on account of the dredger being at work, and it would nevertheless be possible for vessels performing the regular passage service to pass, or for small craft entering at their own risk and peril, the red flags are hoisted half-mast, and the dredger, besides the regulation signals, shows a green flag on the side where the passage is free. The suspension of all movement in the port, to facilitate the entrance or departure of a vessel, is signalled, by day, by the hoisting of a retiflag bordered with green at the S.W. pier-head and at the pilot station ; at night, by a red light over a green light at each of those stations. When the sluices of the scouring waters are going to be opened a blue flag and black ball are hoisted at the S.W. pier-head flag-staff, and also at a staff near the sluice gates. Other signals are made from a mast at the inner end of the N.E. pier. A blue triangle indicates a ship approaching ; a red triangle by day, or a red light by- night, signals the approach of one of the regular Folkestone packets. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in the port of Boulogne at llh. 25m. ; ordinary springs rise 28i feet, neaps 23 feet above the zero of soundings, which is about 3J feet below the level of low water, ordinary springs. Ordinary springs range 25 \ feet, n€>aps 15| feet. Strong westerly winds raise the tide a foot or two higher, and those from the eastward have a contrary effect. At springs, high water slack lasts about 20 minutes with westerly, and 1 5 minutes with easterly winds ; at neaps, about 40 minutes. Tidal streams.— At 3 miles westward of Boulogne, outside the Bassure de Baas, the flood or north-eastern stream commences 2j hours before and acquires its greatest strength, 3 knots, about the time of high water in the harbour, maintains it for about 2 hours, and ceases at 3£ hours after high water. The Carnot breakwater effectually- shields the harbour entrance from the tidal streams which are scarcely felt when within the line of that structure. Between the piers both flood and ebb streams run about 1^ knots if the sluices of the Inner port are open, otherwise the stream is almost nil. Steam-tugS. — The services of steam tugs may always be obtained when required. See ohart, No. 438.

Chap. XL] BOULOGNE.— TIDES.— ROAD.— DIRECTIONS. 565 Pilots. — Eight pilots and three assistant pilots are stationed at Boulogne ; they cruise in good decked cutters, well able to keep at sea in bad weather. Life-boats. — There are three life-boats stationed at Boulogne ; one is near the centre of the N.E. pier ; the second, northward of that pier on the beach, near the baths ; the third, southward of the harbour, at the end of the Chatillon sand-hills. BOULOGNE ROADS. — Good anchorage may be found for many vessels of about 20 feet draught under shelter of the breakwater, those of deeper draught than that should moor. There is also good anchorage in about 4| fathoms, 8 cables outside the pier-heads, on a narrow strip of hard clay about 7 cables long, North and South, and a cable wide. This space is bounded on its western side by the rocky bottom known as Vhiiitriere or the oyster bed, which begins at cape Alprech and extends without interruption northward as far as the parallel of Ambleteuse. Deep draught vessels may anchor farther out with Heurt fort, just open of cape Alprech. The best anchorage is between the lines of the colonnade of the cathedral on with the guard-house of Chatillon battery, which stands on the sand-hills a little southward of the S.W. pier; and, the fort on Mont Lambert on with the belfry tower in Haute Ville. Vessels of moderate draught may remain at this anchorage during fine weather, and, with a long scope of cable out, even if caught there by a strong westerly wind ; those of deep draught, however, would be in danger of touching bottom when tailing in-shore at low water. In fine weather, vessels may also anchor, well clear of the entrance channel, in about 10 fathoms, good holding-ground, at the eastern edge of the Bassure de Baas, abreast of Vimereux. If surprised here by strong north-easterly winds, they can make for Ambleteuse road (see page 568) ; or, if a south-westerly gale should oblige them to seek refuge, they can run for the Downs or take shelter to leeward of the coast in the neighbourhood of Calais. DIRECTIONS. — From the Westward. — Sailing vessels approaching Boulogne from the westward, with the wind between South and West, should take the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the Vergoyer bank, and if they arrive on the parallel of Mont St. Frieux at low water, and are of more than 15 feet draught, short tacks should be made in the channel between that parallel and Swichart, No. 438.

566 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. XL the line of the Grande Armee column on with the lighthouse on the S.W. pier-head. With the wind between South and East, the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the shore should be taken, and short boards made southward of the line of the column and lighthouse in one until the tide has risen sufficiently to enter the harbour ; or, weather permitting, they may anchor in Boulogne roads. Vessels of the deepest draught may at all times cross over the Bassure de Baas in front of Boulogne. One of the deepest parts is with the Grande Armee column on with the lighthouse on the S.W. pier, seen over the breakwater, bearing E. by N. ; but, as the harbour is neared, the pier-head lights should be opened of the break water ; and the N.E. pier red fight slightly opened northward of the S.W. pier red light at night, which line leads a cable northward of the breakwater end. From the Northward. — With the wind between North and West, vessels from the northward should pass westward of the Bassure de Baas, and, if the wind is fresh, they should wait outside this bank until the time for entering ; but, with a light wind, the bank should be crossed on the parallel of Creche point, and a position maintained a short distance to windward of the entrance. If the wind is between North and East, it is better to take the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the land and then anchor, if the weather permits, in such a position as to have the wind a point or two free for running into port. The high land in the vicinity of Boulogne modifies the direction of the wind in the harbour, and sometimes when it is S.S.W. outside it is South or S.S.E. within. Strong winds from the N.E. come off in violent squalls from the high land northward of the harbour. The best time to enter is during the last hour of the flood, when there is scarcely any stream. Sailing vessels should carry plenty of sail on entering the channel, in order to stem the eddies which may be found between the pier-heads, and, if the wind is off-shore, a boat should be sent for the tracking rope. Generally speaking, when the wind is from West round by South to N.E., steer close to the S.W. pier-head : with a fresh breeze from anywhere between N.E. and West keep in mid-channel ; and, in light winds, procure a steam-tug, or steer for the S.W. pier to take in the tracking rope. See chart, No, 438,

Chap. XL] BOULOGNE. — DIRECTIONS. — COAST. 567 Should a vessel miss the entrance during strong westerly winds and be unable to claw off the land, she should endeavour to pass close round the northern side of the N.E. pier and run ashore under its lee. If this occurs at half or three quarters of an horn- after high water, there is some chance of getting her afloat again, and at all events the crew are safe. Sailing vessels leaviug the port for the northward should do so as soon as they are afloat, and with a favourable wind may make sail at once from their berths. Those bound westward, unless with a fresh fair breeze outside to enable them to over-run the flood stream, should not quit the entrance channel until the latest moment, or they may have to anchor outside to await the ebb stream. The COAST.— Creche point, bearing N.E. by N. 1J- miles from Boulogne S.W. pier-head, is, as well as the intermediate coast, high and steep, and is at the western extreme of the range of hills separating the valley of the Liane from that watered by the river Vimille, on one of the highest points of which range stands the column of the Grande Armee, before described. The coast continues steep for nearly a mile from Creche point, but from thence to Vimereux it is bordered by high sand-hills. About 8 cables N.N.E. from Creche point and 2^ cables from the shore is the small semi-circular fort of Croi with two tiers of embrasures, built on rocks which uncover at low water, and rising 50 feet above the level of the beach. From Vimereux to Oies point, which bears N.N.E. easterly 2 miles from Creche point, the coast is steep, but from thence to Audrecelles village, 2 miles farther northward, it is bordered by sand-hills of middling, height covered with verdure. At 1| miles northward of Oies point is the village of Ambleteuse, built on the northern side of the remains of its harbour, and, with the windmill on the high ground northward of the village, easily recognisable from the sea. Amble teuse fort, like that of Croi, had two tiers of guns. From Ambleteuse to the village of Audrecelles, the shore consists of sand-hills covered with bent grass and intersected by small rivulets, through which the sea runs in upon the land at high water. This village stands on the shore, and the church and windmills behind the village are conspicuous objects. From Audrecelles to Riden point, about 2 miles farther northward, the land adjoining the shore gradually rises and forms a succession of hills separated from Sec chart. No. 43s. SO 11886 2 X

[Chap. XI 568 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISIJEZ. each other by valleys, of which some run down to the coast ; but, between Riden point and cape Grisnez, the land is more level and the cliff perpendicular, and, being nearly as high as cape Alprech, may be seen 12 to 15 miles distant. Between Ambleteuse and the rocks at Oies point, the beach is of sand and dries out 3i cables ; but, from Ambleteuse to Riden point its breadth decreases and it consists of rocks covered with sand. The coast from Riden point to cape Grisnez is bordered by a rocky shelf of which the projecting points do not extend beyond 1^ cables from the foot of the cliffs. Coasters, with off-shore winds, should be cautious when approaching the shore between Croi fort and Audrecelles, as a shoal bottom of uneven rock, with about 10 feet water, extends 5 or 6 cables from the coast. Vimereux, formerly a harbour, is 1£ miles north-eastward of Creche point, at the head of a small elbow in the shore between that and Oies point. The harbour was formed, at the commencement of the present century, at the mouth of the river Vimille, to accommo date vessels of the flotilla intended for the invasion of England ; a freshet of that river having in after years broken down the sluice gates, the channel and piers were soon destroyed and the harbour filled up with sand and shingle. The waters of the river still follow their old channel but the bottom has risen so much that, at springs, there are only 5 or 6 feet in what used to be the harbour ; its destruction has caused the almost total desertion of the village which is now nearly covered with sand. Ambleteuse, a mile northward of Oies point, is, like Vimereux, so far as its harbour is concerned, in a complete state of ruin ; it is at the mouth of the little river Slack and great improvements were made at the beginning of the ipresent century with the same object as at Vimereux. The ruins of a stone jetty-head and some piles in the north-western part of the harbour still mark the outline of a basin in which the vessels of the flotilla were placed, but it is now filled with sand and mud and has only 4 feet water in it at springs. The village has some reputation as a watering place. Life-boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Audrecelles, about a mile northward of Ambleteuse fort. Ambleteuse road comprises the space between the Bassure de Baas and the coast, and extends from the parallel of Vimereux to that See chart, No. 438.

Chap. XL] VIMEREUX. — AMBLETEUSE ROAD. — -TIDAL STREAMS. 569 of Audrecelles. Vessels of deep draught bound to the northern ports of the channel, or to Calais or Dunkerque, await spring tides in this road if they arrive during neaps with northerly winds, and are fairly sheltered during gales from N.E. round by East to South ; the sea, however, is very heavy- here when it blows strongly on a weather tide. The best anchorage is between the parallel of Vimereux and the line of the church towers of Ambleteuse and Bazinghen in one E. | N., and a little in-shore of the rocky ground forming the western limit of the anchorage of Boulogne and which extends northward to the parallel of Ambleteuse. By not anchoring eastward of the small tower of Renard, a mile south-eastward of Portel, on with Boulogne S.W. pier lighthouse S. \ W., large vessels are in a good position to weigh should it blow strongly from the westward. A good berth for a vessel of deep draught is N.W. by W. of Vimereux, with Renard tower open 3° westward of Boulogne S.W. pier lighthouse, in about 8 fathoms hard muddy clay ; or, in 9 fathoms, good holding-ground of muddy sand, with the lighthouse and Renard tower in line ; and, Bazinghen church tower open a little northward of Ambleteuse fort E. by N. Large merchant vessels may anchor in 7 fathoms, hard sand and broken shells, on the latter bearing ; and, with the column of the Grande Armee on with Croi fort. Boulogne pilots call the space between the eastern edge of the Bassure de Baas and the rocky bottom which bounds the anchorage in Ambleteuse road, the Parfondingue ; they state that ships of the deepest draught, requiring to remain some days in the road, should be placed in the Parfondingue between the lines of the column of the Grande Armee on with the southern slope of Creche point, and Bazinghen tower on with Ambleteuse fort ; here they have sufficient room to weigh and round cape Grisnez if it comes on to blow hard from the S.W. ; or, if it shifts to West or N.W., the crest of the bank shelters them from the heavy sea. To ride out a gale, they should be moored with open hawse to the westward and their anchors laid with a long scope of cable N.E. and S.W. in the direction of the tidal streams. Tidal Streams. — Abreast of Ambleteuse, at equinoctial springs, the greatest rate of the flood or north-going stream is from Se,- chart. No. 438. 2 N 2 SO 11886

XL 570 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. 3^ to 4 knots, and, in ordinary weather, this rate continues nearly 2^ hours ; the stream follows nearly the direction of the channel and ends about 3| hours after the time of high water at Boulogne. The south-going stream is less rapid, continues longer, and ends 2^ hours before high water. The direction of the wind has great influence on both streams. CAPE GRISNEZ is 8^ miles northward of Boulogne ; from it, cape Alprech bears S. by W. f W. 10^ miles ; Dungeness W.N.W. 2H miles ; South Foreland N. by W. 17| miles ; and, Beachy Head W. -| N. 52^ miles. This cape, 167 feet high, is one of the most remarkable headlands on the northern coast of France and is visible in clear weather 14 or 15 miles ; from it, the coast changes its direction abruptly eastward, and this precipitous rocky sandstone cliff, as well as those southward and eastward of it, is of a dark grey colour and takes a purple tint when lighted up by the sun. A lighthouse stands on the south-western extreme of a small spot of level land crowning the cape ; some works of defence may also be seen rising above the same level land, and a guard-house at its extreme near the crest of the cliff. Large masses of rock lie at the foot of the cape, and a rocky shelf, partly covered with sand, dries at low water 2\ cables out from the cliffs ; the cape should therefore, be given a berth of at least 4 cables when passing it. LIGHT. — Cape Grisnez lighthouse is circular, 79 feet high from base to vane, a quarter of a mile southward of the cape, and about 100 yards from the edge of the cliff : it exhibits at 226 feet above high water an electric groupj-fiashing light, showing three white flashes followed by a red flash. The white flashes are of J seconds each, the red flash, \ second ; the total eclipse between the white flashes is of If seconds duration ; between the white and red flash, 4^ seconds. It is visible 22 miles, but, in ordinary weather, the luminous glare caused by it can be seen as much as 35 or 40 miles distant. This light cannot be mistaken for the light at Calais, which is also electric and white, but shows successive groups of four white flashes, with an interval of six seconds between each group ; nor for the red flashing light at cape Alprech, which has a five seconds period. Fog Signal. — During thick or foggy weather, a siren, worked by compressed air, gives a blast of three seconds duration once a minute ; .see fog signals, page 11. See chart. No. 1.895.

Chap. XL] CAPE GRISNEZ.— PAS DE CALAIS.— TIDAL STREAMS. 571 Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station close to cape Grisnez lighthouse ; .see page 12. PAS de CALAIS.— The narrowest part of this channel is 8| miles wide, between the Ridge or Colbart shoal and cape Grisnez ; from thence, it runs nearly parallel with the coast as far as Boulogne, and then in a S.W. by W. \ W. direction between the Bassurelle and Vergoyer shoals. With easterly winds, it is to be preferred to the Dover channel between the Varne and the English shore ; it is both wider and deeper, and is a continuation of the deep soundings channel of the North sea in which the depth is above 20 fathoms. It is easily navigated by the lead either with a leading or beating wind, and even during fog or snow, the only danger being the northern end of the Ridge which rises abruptly from a depth of 20 fathoms. To avoid the northern end of the Ridge, a vessel turning to wind ward in the Pas de Calais, either by day or night, when northward of the parallel of cape Grisnez and standing westward, should not bring the South Foreland lighthouses eastward of N. £ E. ; and, when southward of that parallel, she should not go into less than 20 fathoms A bearing of the Varne light-vessel is also very useful for avoiding this shoal. Tides and tidal streams. — (See also table, page 573) — It is high water, full and change, on the beach a little eastward of cape Grisnez at llh. 27m., extraordinary springs rise 27 feet, ordinary springs 21^ feet, neaps 16| feet above the level of the lowest tides ; at Dungeness, at lOh. 45m., springs rise 21 1 feet, neaps 19 feet ; and, at the Varne and Ridge shoals, at lOh. 40m. Within a circuit of 2 miles round the cape, the streams run stronger than at a greater distance from the shore ; the flood, or north-eastern stream, beginning 2 hours before and ending 3£ hours after high water at Boulogne, and running 4 knots when at its greatest strength, at springs. Between the Ridge and the French shore, the north-eastern stream runs with much greater strength than the south-western. The tidal streams, on the French coast, in the northern in-shore part of the English channel are nearly of the same duration as in the bay of the Seine, the north-eastern stream running about 5£ hours, and the south-western stream 6i hours. Towards the middle of the channel, the streams run straight, throughout its length, until they See chart, No. 1,895.

572 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. XL have attained their greatest strength, when they follow the bends of the coast to a distance of 7 miles in the offing. In-shore of these limits, as soon as the north-eastern stream begins to be felt it turns towards the shore, but, as its strength increases, it tends more to its principal direction, viz., that which it follows when at its greatest strength and retains for the greatest length of time ; when its rate begins to decrease, it turns off-shore and takes different directions until the end of the tide. The south-western stream runs with less velocity and undergoes the same changes, but with this difference, that it varies much more in direction. At the Varne and Ridge shoals, the tide rises for 4^ hours before the north-eastern stream commences, and falls for 4f hours before the south-western stream begins ; making 6^ hours of north-eastern and b\ hours of south-western stream. Strong south-westerly gales prolong the north-eastern stream nearly an hour, and retard propor tionally the south-western stream ; so that on some occasions, on the Ridge especially, 8 hours north-eastern and only 4 hours south western streams have been found. The rate of both streams increases in proportion to the narrowing of the channel. Between the Ver goyer and the shore, both streams make about an hour sooner than farther in the offing. Caution. — The deep bight in the coast between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez constrains the flood stream to change its direction about the meridian of point d'Ailly, and to turn E. by N. obliquely towards the coast Between the river Somme and cape Grisnez ; but, with strong westerly winds, it runs much farther eastward and turns suddenly only a short distance from the shore, causing a high sea. Vessels from the westward bound to ports in the northern part of the channel, and running with a strong westerly wind, cannot be too attentive to the effects of this stream ; as soon as they have sighted either cape Barfleur light, or that on St. Catherine point, they should act with great caution to avoid being set over on the French coast and should sound frequently after passing the meridian of cape d'Antifer, for, if they take the ground on any of the banks off the Somme or on the low coast in its vicinity, it will in all probability involve the loss of vessel and crew. See chart. No. 1,895.

The COAST from cape Grisnez trends E. by N.fN. 6 miles to cape Blanc-Nez, the intermediate land is high and may be seen in clear weather from 15 to 20 miles distant ; but, beyond the latter cape, the shore bends more eastward, the high land turns in a south-easterly direction towards the interior, and a level plain extends from its foot to the coast where it terminates in a low sandy shore bordered by ranges of sand-hills, of which the highest are visible only from 7 to 10 miles. Between the capes, the shore forms a slight bay, at the head of which is the village of Wissant, inhabited by fishermen. At 2 miles inland from Wissant is Mont Couple, 525 feet above the sea level. From about a mile eastward of cape Grisnez, where the sandstone cliffs of that cape terminate, to 1^ miles north eastward of Wissant, where steep chalk cliffs recommence, the coast is low and bordered by sand-hills.* Cape Blanc-Nez owes its name to the high chalk cliff in which it terminates. It forms no marked projection, but its position may be recognized from a good distance at sea by the guard-house on the summit of the steep mound which crowns it, and which is the northern extreme of a range of hills joining Mont Couple. The last slopes of the high land forming the cape, as well as the steep coast in which they terminate, extend 1^ miles eastward, nearly as far as the village of Sangatte, and at this village commences the low sandy shore, which is the distinguishing feature of the remaining part of * See Admiralty Charts: — Dover strait, No. 1,895; scale. m= 0'68 of an inch ; North sea, sheet 1, Dover and Calais to Orfordness and Scheveningen, No. 1,045 ; scale, m = 03 of an inch ; and, Calais to river Schelde, No. 1,872 ; scale, m= 0'7 of an inch.

Chap. XII.] COAST. — BANC A LA MGNE. 575 the French and of the Belgian coasts. The sand-hills are low to within 1| miles of Sangatte, but they gradually rise in height as they approach Calais, spreading into parallel ranges which approach within 2 or 3 cables of the shore. The principal objects on this part of the coast are, a beacon on a hill about 1,200 yards inshore of cape Blanc-Nez, the windmill of Coquelles about 2 miles inland on the last slopes of the range of hills extending eastward of cape Blanc-Nez ; the windmill at Nieulay, northward of this ; the red buildings at Trouie or the Salines, about half way between Sangatte and Calais and about N.N.E. from Coquelles windmill, which are useful marks to the pilots, who call them les maisons rouges • and, the ramparts and citadel of Calais, with the spire of its cathedral as well as that of the church of St Pierre-les-Calais farther to the South, which rise above the sand-hills and may be seen some distance at sea. The strand in front of Sangatte is only 2-i- cables wide at low water but near the West pier at Calais it dries out 5 cables. At 2 or 3 cables outside it, are several shoal patches of 7 or 8 feet, and no vessel should get amongst them at low water. Telegraph cables. — The shore end of the cable connecting with the English coast, westward of Dover, is landed in the bight just eastward of cape Grisnez. Another cable leaving the shore at Sangatte is landed at the South Foreland. Bane a la Lig"ne. — The great prominence of cape Grisnez, together with the sudden change in direction of the coast which there occurs, occasions an extensive eddy north-eastward of it during the flood. The eddy no doubt caused the formation of this bank of sand and broken shells, which extends E.N.E. 4^ miles nearly from the cape, and If miles from the shore abreast of Wissant. Its shoalest part uncovers from 4 to 6 feet at low water, springs, and towards its north-eastern extreme are several heaps of sand, named La Barriere, on the highest of which are only from 3 to 9 feet water : the sea runs high on them with a fresh breeze on a weather tide. The south-western end of the bank has gradually joined itself to the land just eastward. of the cape, leaving no channel at low water between the bank and the land where formerly there existed a passage several feet deep ; but a new channel, called the North-west channel, has been formed near the middle of the bank. See chart, No. 1,895.

[Chap. Xll 576 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Buoy. — A red buoy with a triangular top-mark lies at the north eastern end of the Barriere sand, 2£ cables northward of the 4-feet patch. From it, Wissant bears S. § E., and Cape Grisnez lighthouse S.W. by W. Gardes rocks. — The shore between capes Grisnez and Blanc-Nez is bordered by a sandy strand, uncovering iu some places 4 cables seaward at low water. In front of all the steep parts of the coast flat rocks rise above the sand, and amongst them and farthest from the shore are the Gardes rocks which uncover 7 feet ; from their outer extreme, Wissant church tower bears S.W. by S. 2 miles ; and, the guard-house on cape Blanc-Nez, E. by N. 1^ miles. The Quenocs and. Rougre-Riden.— A rocky bottom, joining the shore and partly covered with sand, extends from the Gardes rocks to Sangatte village, and 2 miles into the offing between N.N.W. and E.N.E. from cape Blanc-Nez ; its shoalest part forms two distinct dangerous flats of irregular rocks, named the Quenocs and Rouge-Riden. The Quenocs, the western flat, is about 5 cables in diameter, it has two heads with only 9 feet water ; from its centre, the guard-house on cape Blanc-Nez bears S. by E. f E. about 1^ miles ; and, Sangatte church tower E. by S. \ S. southerly 2\ miles. The Rouge-Riden is nearer the shore, and nearly a mile in extent W.S.W. and E.N.E. ; from its shoalest head of 6 feet near the western end, the guard-house on cape Blanc-Nez bears S. \ E. one mile. A shoal head of 9 feet also lies on the eastern edge of this flat, with the guard-house bearing S.S.W. \ W. 1£ miles, and Sangatte church tower E.S.E. 1\ miles. The sea runs high on both flats with a fresh breeze on a weather tide. Sangatte church tower on with Coquelles windmill S.E., leads 5 cables northward of the Rouge- Riden. Bell-buoy. — A red bell buoy, No. 4, with reflector, is moored in 3 or 4 fathoms water off the northern side of the Quenocs ; from it, Calais West pier-head bears E. \ S. 6 miles ; the Barriere buoy S.W. by W. \ W. 2^ miles ; and, the shore is distant nearly 1^ miles. Riden de Calais. — This bank, about 4 miles long E.N.E. and W.S.W., commences N. by E. 1^ miles from Sangatte, and ends N. | E. about 2^ miles from the entrance to Calais. Its general depth varies from 5 to 8 fathoms ; the shoalest part is near the centre where See cliarts, Nos. 1,895 and 1,872.

XII.] OFF-LYING SHOALS.— RADE DE CALAIS. 577 for 11 miles may be found spots of from 25 to 28 feet water ; from the south-western shoal head of 25 feet, the entrance to Calais bears S.E. by E. f E. 2| miles. The bank is dangerous at low water for vessels of deep draught only, but it occasions strong eddies and during fresh northerly winds there is a heavy sea on it, and breakers in north-easterly gales. Buoys.— A black buoy, No. 1, with staff and St, Andrew's cross top-mark, is moored in about <6\ fathoms water in the deep between the Riden de Calais and the Quenocs ; from it, Calais West pier-head bears E. by S. £ S. 3£ miles ; and, the Quenocs buoy' W. by S. southerly nearly 3 miles. A red buoy, No. 6, with perch and globe, lies in 10 fathoms near the eastern end of the Riden de Calais : from it, Calais pier-heads bear S. | E. 2£ mites ; Walde light bea'con S.E. by E. \ E. 3| miles ; and, Outer Ruytingen West buoy N.E. by N. 5£ miles. Ridens de la Rade, also named the Tetes, their western end in 30 feet commencing nearly a mile N. by W. from Calais pier heads, extend from thence eastward and south-eastward, and consist of many heaps of sand, on the highest of which are only 4 feet water. This spot bears N.E. by E. \ E. easterly, 9^ cables from the East pier-head. Another patch of 18 feet bears N. by E. \ E. 9 cables from the same pier-head, and at varying distances between these bearings are several spots of from 6 to 9 and 16 feet water. These banks have steadily decreased in depth during the last fifty years and appear still to have the same tendency. A heavy sea runs on them with on-shore winds. Buoy. — About f>\ cables eastward of the 18-feet patch on the Riden de la Rade and close northward of two patches of 9 and 6 feet respectively, is a black conical buoy, No. 1, with cylindrical top-mark. From it, the entrance to Calais harbour bears S.W. \ S. rather over one mile. RADE de CALAIS, comprised between the Riden de Calais and the sands westward of Calais harbour, affords anchorage with off-shore winds to vessels arriving off the harbour a few hours before the tide permits them to enter. A convenient position, in about 9 fathoms and one mile from the shore, is, with Sangatte church tower on with cape Blanc-Nez guard-house W. by S. | S. ; and Calais lighthouse S.E. \ E. At night, keep cape Grisnez light opening and shutting in with the cliffs at cape Blanc-Nez and anchor when Calais light bears S.E. \ E. See charts, Nos. 1,895 and 1,872.

The holding-ground is not so good near the shore. w— >'. Cf-"" The anchorage is sheltered by the land from W.S.W. round to S.E., but it is quite open in all other directions. The Riden can scarcely be considered as a shelter, although the waves break with great violence during a northerly gale on its whole extent ; the sea, how ever, is much quieter here than in the offing, and a vessel with good ground gear might ride out a gale in the northern part of the road. Semaphore.— There is a Semaphore station on the shore about 6 cables westward of Calais West pier ; see page 12. CALAIS.* — This port is entirely artificial and consists of an Entrance channel, Outer port, Import dock, and the small Bassin du Petit Paradis, all of which are tidal, but well sheltered from wind and sea ; though when it blows strongly from the northward all the tidal portion of the port is more or less affected by the swell. Also of a Wet dock under the ramparts of the citadel, opening from the Import dock ; the Bassin Carnot, entered from the south-eastern end of the Outer port, with a dry dock at its head ; and, at its south western corner, an inner basin, communicating with a basin for small craft, which latter communicates also with the western Wet dock and Import dock, and with the general canal system of the country. The quays are all connected by rail with the central railway station and thus with all parts of Europe ; they are well equipped with hydraulic cranes and all the most modern appliances for the speedy discharging and loading of vessels, and with extensive sheds and bonding stores. The entrance of the port is 11^ miles eastward of cape Grisnez ; S.E. \ E. 21^ miles from Dover pier-head : and, S.E. 20^ miles from the South Foreland. Calais owes its importance to its geographical position, which makes it the most convenient port for passengers and mails between the Continent and the United Kingdom, when time is the all important object. The harbour has undergone great improvements both in depth and general accommodation of late years, including vast * See Admiralty plan of Calais, No. 2,556 ; scale, m = 5 inches.

Chap. XII.] 579 CALAIS.— ENTRANCE CHANNEL. works, completed in 1896, for widening the entrance, as also constant dredging to maintain the depth gained. It is not only connected direct with Paris by rail, but also both by rail and canal with Gravelines, Dunkerque, and all the industrial region of Belgium and the North of France. Mariners should also remember that when it blows strongly from between West and South and the approach to Boulogne is hazardous for sailing vessels, Calais can be entered with comparative ease ; and, on the contrary, when it blows hard between North and E.N.E. and it is impossible to enter Calais, Boulogne can be entered with safety. Calais had, in 1891, a population of about 60,000 ; it has consider able foreign and a brisk coasting trade ; the vessels belonging to the port are chiefly employed in the cod, herring, and mackerel fisheries. The principal imports are coal, iron, machinery, wood, jute, petroleum, woollens, cottons, &c. ; the exports, sugar, metal ware, glass and porcelain, eggs, silks, Parisian goods, <fcc. The number of vessels entering the port annually is about 2,000, of an aggregate of 350,000 tons. Mail steamers cross the channel between Dover and Calais three times each way daily, the distance being accomplished under ordinary circumstances in about 1^ hours. Consulate. — A British Consul and Vice-Consul are stationed at Calais. Entrance Channel. — Great improvements have been made in this channel by the construction of the new East pier, which is now completed and the old pier entirely removed ; the channel is therefore now 430 feet wide between the pier-heads, and still wider within; it runs about 4| cables in a S.S.E. direction from the pier-heads to the Outer port. About 800 feet of the outer part of both piers consists of open pile-work, intended to prevent the accumulation of sand ; through this open work, as well as across the entrance, both flood and ebb streams sweep with great strength and at right angles to the direction of the channel, causing serious inconvenience and requiring much skill in the handling of vessels entering or leaving at or near high water when the north-eastern stream is running at its greatest strength. The West pier has a small opening, about 1£ cables from the end, to enable boats to load with sand from that side. At its inner end, it terminates in the towing path passing under the glacis of Fort Risban. See plan, No. 2,556.

Scouring basins. — On each side of the Entrance channel are large scouring basins, their united area being about 440 acres ; these are filled each tide and discharged through the channel at low water in order to maintain the depth and disperse any bar formation, but it is intended eventually to convert both these scouring basins into wet docks. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Calais harbour at llh. 49m. ; springs rise 22| feet, neaps 19 feet above the level of the soundings, which level or zero is about H feet below the level of low water, ordinary springs. With westerly gales, the tide rises a foot or two higher than in fine settled weather. High water slack lasts, at springs, for about 20 minutes ; at neaps, for as much as 45 minutes. Depths. — Caution. — In 1890, the entrance channel was dredged to a least depth of 10 feet below the zero of soundings. In 1892, there was a general average of 6 inches deeper water, and at the present time, December 1896, a depth of 13 feet below the zero of soundings is maintained ; this gives a depth in the entrance channel of 35Jj feet at high water springs, and of 3i feet less at high water, neaps. It must, however, be borne in mind that from the exposed condition of Calais harbour, unusual difficulties lie in the way of maintaining an equable and thoroughly reliable depth in the entrance channel, for during a continuance of heavy weather the movement of the sand along the coast has always a tendency to the formation of a bar across and in the channel ; and although, on the one band, great improvements in depth have been made and fairly maintained, it must not be forgotten, on the other hand, that temporary shoaling may take place, against which possibility the mariner should be on his guard. The Outer port is tidal and begins where the East pier joins the wall of the quay opposite Fort Risban. This quay is 600 yards in length and is that used by the Dover and Calais mail steamers ; its space is wholly occupied by the railway station. There are 16 feet water alongside this quay at low water, springs, the central depths of the Outer port leading up to the lock entrances to the Bassin Carnot being from 19 to 25 feet, and its width 186 yards. The South quay of the Outer port is 273 yards long, with 25 feet water alongside at low water, springs. See plan, No. 2,656.

Chap. XII.] CALAIS. — DEPTHS. — BASINS AND DOCKS. 581 The Bassin Carnot is opened 2| hours before high water and closed 2 hours after high water slack. It is entered from the Outer port by two locks, one 436 feet, the other 451 feet long ; the first is 69 feet wide in the entrance, the other 46| feet ; both have 28 feet 9 inches over the sjll at high water, springs. The mean length of the Bassin Carnot is 1,033 yards, its width 158 yards, its area 23 acres, and its bottom is 1 foot 8 inches below the level of the lock sills. On its eastern side is a 40-ton hydraulic crane, besides, as before mentioned, railways and every convenience for loading and discharging cargo, storage, &c, on all its spacious quays. Dry dock. — At the head of the Bassin Carnot is the dry dock, 508 feet in length over all, width of entrance 68| feet, and depth over sill at high water, springs, 28| feet. This dock can receive a vessel 498 feet in length. Space has been reserved for the construction of two additional docks. Inner basin and Canal dock. — At the south-western corner of the Bassin Carnot is the Inner basin, a space about 200 yards long and 66 yards wide, from which the Canal dock or basin for small craft is entered by means of two locks 236^ feet long, with entrances 19 j feet wide. The Canal dock also communicates with the western Wet dock, presently described, by means of a lock 230 feet in length by 17 feet 1 inch in width. The Canal dock has an area of 10 acres, and from it the largest sized canal boats of 400 tons can proceed by the inland waterways of the North of France, and between Belgium and Paris. Import dock. — Reverting to the Outer port ; on its south-western side is the wide opening into the Import dock, also tidal, as well as the Bassin du Petit Paradis on its southern side. This dock dries at low water and has a depth of 20^ feet at high water, springs. It has, including the Bassin du Petit Paradis, 1,800 yards of quayage, with all facilities for loading and unloading, and excellent grounding berths. A careening gridiron is established at the western end of this dock. Wet dock.— The western Wet dock has its entrance at the head of the Import dock ; it is opened 2 hours before high water and closed l-\ hours after high water slack. It has an area of 20,000 square yards, with 590 yards extent of quays. The entrance between the gates is 55f feet wide, and the sill is at the level of low water, springs. Its length is 410 yards, and its width 82 yards. It Set plan, No. 2,556.

LIGHTS.— Calais lighthouse, an octagonal brick tower 167 feet high, stands at the north-eastern side of the town, and exhibits, at 190 feet above high water and visible 20 miles, an electric, group-flashing, white light, showing successive groups of four white flashes ; each flash is of three quarters of a second duration ; the total eclipse between each flash of a group is of two seconds, and, between each group, of six seconds duration. West pier. — A fixed red light, 26 feet above high water and visible 4 miles, is exhibited from an iron pole erected on an iron shed at the outer end of the West pier. This light is not shown in bad weather, access to the West pier-head being then impracticable. East pier. — Tide lights. — From a white metal tower on the East pier-head, at about 31 feet above high water, the following tide lights, visible 10 miles, are shown ; they consist of fixed red, green, and white lights, varied by red and green flashes, and. indicate by colour and flashes every ten inches of rise after the tide has risen 6Js feet above the zero or level of the soundings on the chart, thus : — A fixed red light indicates less than 6^ feet above the zero of soundings, but tide rising. A. fixed green light indicates less than 6^ feet above the zero and tide falling. A fixed white light indicates from 6^ feet to 1\ feet above the zero. A fixed white light varied by groups of red and green flashes indicates depths of more than 1\ feet above the zero. The groups of coloured flashes are separated by intervals of eighty seconds, and the flashes in each group by intervals of five seconds ; each red flash showing an additional 3 feet 4 inches to the initial height of 65 feet above the zero of soundings, and each green flash adding 10 inches more. Whilst the tide is rising, the fixed, light, whether red or white, is eclipsed for a short interval every eighty seconds ; and, when it is falling, the fixed light, white or green, is eclipsed twice in quick succession every eighty seconds ; these eclipses occur nearly in the See plan. Caution. — When unforeseen circumstances make the entrance to the harbour dangerous, the night tide signals will be replaced by a red fixed light shown from the round point of the East pier-head. Day tide Signals.— The usual day tide signals are made from a flagstaff near the lighthouse on the East pier-head ; see page 12. Fog Signals. — A bell is sounded continuously in foggy weather at the East pier-head if the port is accessible ; and, in addition, when a mail steamer is clue, a gun is fired from the same pier-head every five minutes ; see fog signals, page 11. Harbour Signals. — A white flag with blue border, hoisted at the Harbour Master's office indicates that the dock gates are open ; the same flag at the look-out on the East pier, near bastion No. 1, indicates that the Bassin Carnot is open ; when hoisted near the entrance to the western sluicing basin, that the western dock is open. At night, two green lights are shown on each side of any lock entrance which may be open, but neither the Carnot nor the western wet dock are open at night, except after due notice given. Pilots. — Fourteen pilots are stationed at Calais ; they cruise in two small schooners, the one as far westward asDungeness, the other as far northward as the Galloper light-vessel. The first pilot met with should be taken, but the pilotage fee does not increase for any distance beyond 10 miles from the port. When pilots are not able to get to sea, they indicate to approaching vessels the course to be steered by means of a mast working on a hinge at the East pier head ; this mast is inclined towards the side towards which the vessel should steer. Coal, Supplies, &C. — A moderate quantity of coal at reasonable prices is always in store, and there is every facility for vessels of the largest size to coal afloat, either in the wet docks or alongside the South quay of the Outer port. Supplies of all sorts are plentiful and good. Repairs can be executed, and the facilities for doing so are improving as the new dry dock comes more into use. Steam-tugS. — Several steam-tugs are attached to the port. See plan, No. 2,556. 2 O SO 11886

Life-boats.— In case of shipwreck, there is a life-preserving mortar and apparatus at three distinct stations at Calais, and also two life-boats ; one of the latter is stationed on the eastern side, the other on the western side of the harbour. Tidal Streams. — The mean duration of the flood or east-going stream, at springs, in front of the entrance is 5| hours, and of the west-going stream 7 \ hours. At 5 cables outside the piers, the eastern stream runs for 2\ or 3 hours after high water in the harbour, aud with strong westerly winds, for 4| or 5 hours after; with easterly winds, it continues only 1\ or 2 hours after high water in the harbour. The rate of the flood at extraordinary springs is 4^ knots. DIRECTIONS. — From the westward. — As a general rule, cape Blanc-Nez should be sighted when bound either to Calais, Gravelines, or Dunkerque. The most favourable winds for a sailing vessel entering Calais harbour are those from W.S.W. round by North to East. Moderate on-shore winds only cause a heavy swell on the beach, but when strong they send in a heavy sea, and it is then dangerous to enter. Under these circumstances, which are frequent in winter, vessels bound for the northern ports of France should immediately run for Boulogne ; and, it should be borne in mind that at this, and at all French ports of any importance a red flag is shown at the tide signal-staff when the port is rendered inaccessible by weather. Vessels running for Calais from the south-west, when on the parallel of and about a mile from cape Grisnez, should steer about N.E. by E. \ E., taking care not to bring the extreme of that cape westward of S.W. \ W. in order to keep outside the Barriere and Quenocs rocks. When Sangatte church tower is on with Coquelles windmill, S.E., steer about E. by S. \ S. towards Calais lighthouse, and, when Audinghen church tower, near cape Grisnez, is hidden behind the cliff at cape Blanc-Nez, if there is water sufficient to enter the harbour a course should be shaped for the entrance ; if not, anchor in the southern part of Calais road. Small vessels may pass at all times of tide between the Quenocs and the Barriere, by keeping Sangatte church tower on with either of the three towers of Calais ; they may also pass between the Rouge-Riden and the shore, from half flood to half ebb. See chart, No, 1,895,

XII.] CALAIS. — DIRECTIONS. — ENTERING HARBOUR. 585 At night, cape Grisnez light should not be brought westward of S.W. £ W., to avoid the Barriere and the Quenocs, and when Calais light bears E.S.E., steer about E. by S. ; then if the ebb or western stream is running, anchor as soon as cape Grisnez light is about to be hidden behind the cliff at cape Blanc-Nez ; but, if the flood is making, and there is sufficient water in the entrance, steer for the red light on the West pier-head which must be rounded fairly close to, if the tide is setting to the eastward. From the northward.— Between one third flood and two thirds ebb in Calais harbour, either by day or night, vessels from the north ward with a fresh fair wind may run directly for the entrance over the Riden de Calais, where there is then sufficient water. If late on the ebb, run on the meridian of Blanc-Nez until Sangatte church tower is on with Coquelles windmill S.E. ; then steer, if the weather is favourable, for the anchorage in the southern part of Calais road. At night, steer for Calais light on an E.S.E. bearing until cape Grisnez light bears W.S.W., then steer about E. S. and look out for cape Grisnez light becoming masked behind cape Blanc-Nez, when anchor if the ebb stream is running ; or, if the flood, steer for the harbour. Entering the harbour. — The most favourable time for entering Calais harbour with an on-shore wind is at high water ; but, with the wind abeam or ahead, half or three quarters of an hour sooner, so as to allow time to be tracked or towed up to the quays, or to the dock entrances. The set of the tidal streams should be borne in mind, however, see preceding page, and, therefore, whatever the direction of the wind, if the eastern stream is running, the West pier-head should be steered for, and this precaution is particularly necessary when standing for the harbour on the starboard tack ; anchors should be ready for letting go, and hawsers ready to run out in the event of being drifted on the East pier. Plenty of sail should be carried, especially with the wind right aft, to stem the flood and to pass quickly through the swell at the entrance. Should a vessel with a strong westerly wind and without a pilot miss the entrance, she should anchor immediately as near as possible to the East pier-head and take in a pilot, whose assistance will then be indispensable. See chart, No. 1,895. SO 11886 202
