BANKS off the NORTH COAST of FRANCE.— The approach to the low and dangerous coast between Calais and the river Schelde, for the description of which, see p. 602, is obstructed by numerous banks of grey and black sand, which extend 15 miles from the shore on the meridian of Calais, and 42 miles in a north-easterly direction from Dunkerque. They are all long and narrow, and con verge in direction towards the straits of Dover. Their shoalest parts may be touched upon by vessels of almost any draught, and the eddies they occasion cause a hollow sea which breaks when it blows hard. Those farthest from the land lie on the eastern side of the 20-fathoms line of soundings, which, in the southern part of the North sea, is the eastern limit of the Deep-soundings channel, which begins in Dover strait and ends in about lat. 53° 20' N. The banks are all steep-to on their in-shore edge and extend with a gentle slope towards the offing, and, as they rise from the submarine bank of sand, gravel, and broken shells which joins the shore, and on which there are everywhere less than 20 fathoms, the simple precaution of not going into less than that depth ensures keeping outside all these banks. The lights at cape Grisnez and Calais are in a good position to point out at night their western limit ; the electric flashing light at Dunkerque, seen in clear weather 20 miles, gives notice of approach to the greater part of them, and the navigation is still further facilitated by the two light-vessels moored within the Hinder banks, by that north-eastward of the Ruytingen, and by others more in-shore. The dangers of the in-shore navigation can only be avoided by placing the vessel in charge of a good pilot, for the banks are all so liable to changes in their formation that no description of them can be considered permanently reliable ; generally speaking, none of the banks should be approached except a vessel is bound for one of the harbours on the coast. The banks are divided into. two groups, those nearest the shore eleven in number, being named the Dunkerque banks ; others, six in number, lying .some distance from the coast and northward of the Dunkerque banks, were but little known until surveyed by the late Captain W. Hewett, R.N., in H.M.S. Fairy between 1831-1840 ; Set charts, Nos. 1,895 and 1,873,

DUNKERQUE BANKS, eleven in number, extend 15 miles from the coast between the meridians of Calais and the frontier of Belgium. Their names are, the Sandettie, Outer Ruytingen, Inner Ruytingen, Bergues, Dyck (the north-eastern part of which is called the Clif-d'Islande or East Dyck), Inner Katel, Outer Ratel, Haut-fond de Gravelines, Breedt, Smal, and the bank bounding Dunkerque road to the northward, of which different parts are named Snouw, Braeck, Hills, and Traepegeer. Sandettie, in Flemish the Zand-detie, called also by local French mariners the Ourting, is the, outer and westernmost of the Dun kerque banks ; it is l?,i miles long E. by N. \ N. and W. by S.-|.S., its breadth varying from 4 cables to a mile. Its southern and south eastern edges are steep-to, having from 19 to 20 fathoms water at less than half a cable from the southern edge, but its slope is move gradual towards the North-west and this side may be easily! avoided by the lead. \ '•- There are two shallow flats on' this bank over which it is dangerdtis to pass in bad weather. A 19-feet patch on the western flat bear's N.W. northerly 20 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse, and N.N.E. 15J miles from that at Calais ; and, the centre of the eastern flat, .on which there are only 21 feet, lies E. by N. 3i miles from the western flat. Besides these flats, other heaps of sand, with from 21 to 25: feet water, extend H miles in a W. by S. direction from the western flat, but, on other parts of the bank, the depths vary from 31 to 46 feet. The north-eastern end of the Sandettie, on which there are 9 fathoms water, bears N.N.W. f W. 6f miles from Ruytingen light-vessel! The Sandettie, rising suddenly from comparatively deep water, causes strong ripplings, and, with a fresh breeze, the sea is heavy around it and breaks on the shoal flats. -From the south-western end of the bank, which is steep-to, in.-8iOr 9 'fathoms, the following lights may be seen in clear weather :— Cape Grisnez S.W. \ S. 20 miles ; Calais S. f W. 12^ miles; Dunkerque S:E. by E. 22 miles and occasionally visible ; and, South Foreland See chart, No. 1,872.

The Outer Ruytingen, midway between the coast of France arid the Sandettie, is separated from the latter by a channel from 5 to 6 miles wide, with soundings of from 14 to 20 fathoms. Its western end is about 7 miles from the shore on the meridian of Calais lighthouse ; from thence, it extends 7 miles eastward and then curves 9 miles in an E.N.E. direction to the position of the light vessel, beyond which to the 10-fathoms line it extends 2\ miles farther, but with nothing less than 7 fathoms. The bank rises almost perpendicularly from the bottom on its south-eastern side, but falls with a gentle slope north-westward. Those parts on which there are less than 5 fathoms water form two flats, with a channel of from 5 to 9 fathoms and 2 miles wide between them ; from the centre of this channel, Gravelines light house bears S.S.E. \ E., and Calais lighthouse S.W. \ S. ; vessels bound to either of these ports may pass over the shoal between these flats at any time of tide, leaving Nos. 2 and 4 buoys on the starboard hand and No. 7 buoy on the port hand ; see Caution, page 589. The eastern flat within the 5-fathoms line is 9 miles long, and from 4 to 9 cables wide ; on its northern part are patches with only 12 to 15 feet water ; on other parts, the depths vary from 18 to 23 and 26 feet. The Outer Ruytingen occasions strong eddies and with a fresh breeze the sea breaks on the shoalest parts and is heavy on its edges. There are irregularities of bottom extending westward of this bank as far as Calais lighthouse bearing S. \ E., and small vessels should avoid crossing them in bad weather on account of the high sea they occasion. . . Inner Ruytingen.— The body of this bank lies 2\ miles eastward of the northern part of the Outer Ruytingen, and, including all shoal soundings of less than 8| fathoms, it is 8 miles long W.S.W. and E.N.E., and its greatest width is 3 miles. The Inner Ruytingen is of triangular form and its irregular depths cause an uneasy sea. The parts with less than 26 feet water form two flats, separated by depths of from 4 to 5 fathoms. The western flat occupies the centre of the bank and is 2 miles long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and 5 or 6 cables wide, with as little as 9 feet in the centre, from which depth, Dunkerque lighthouse seen midway between Cassel and the spires at Bergues bears S. | E. ; and, Ruytingen light- vessel N.W. 2\ miles. The eastern flat is at the north eastern part of the bank and is 1^ miles long ; its shoalest spot has 14 feet water. The channel between the Inner and Outer Ruytingen has depths of from 15 to 8 fathoms. Vessels may pass through by keeping Ruytingen light-vessel on with Gravelines lighthouse bearing S.S.W. | W., and, having passed the light-vessel on either side, by keeping her on the opposite bearing astern ; and, by night, by keep ing in the while sector of Gravelines light. Bergues. — The western end of this bank lies one mile northward of the north-eastern flat on the Inner Ruytingen, and from its least depth, 23 feet, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. \ W. 13 miles. The eastern end of the bank is on the meridian of and 15 miles distant from Dunkerque ; from thence it extends 7>\ miles W. by S. Some ridges with from 6 to 8 fathoms extend 4 miles eastward of the shoalest part of this bank, and, with a fresh breeze against tide, a heavy sea runs in the eddies on their edges, as well as on the edges of the Bergues. Buoy. — No. 1 black conical buoy with staff and cylinder, lies in 11 fathoms on the northern side of the shoal part of the Bergues ; from it, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. \ W. 13f miles ; Ruytingen light-vessel S.W. by W. \ W. about 5 miles ; and, West Hinder light-vessel N.E. by E. 8 miles. See chart, No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] INNER RUYTINGEN.— DYCK BANKS. 591 THE DYCK BANKS form one continuous narrow shoal, on which the several banks are separated by depths of less than 6 fathoms. The south-western end of the shoal in 8 fathoms commences N.N.E. | E. G miles from Calais lighthouse, and S by E. \ E. 2 miles from the Outer Ruytingen West buoy ; from thence, it extends eastward nearly parallel with the shore for 18 miles, almost to the meridian of Dunkerque, and then trends N.E. \ E. 13| miles. The part between its western extreme and the meridian of Gravelines is named the West Dyck or Orteil ; the central part, between Gravelines and Grande Synthe, the Middle or the Dyck ; and, the eastern part is the East Dyck or Clif-dTslande. West Dyck or Orteil is 9 miles in length, and its greatest breadth is about 5 cables. From the least depth, 18 feet, Gravelines lighthouse bears South 5fj miles ; and, the Dyck light-vessel S.S.E. f E. 3} miles. For 1} miles eastward and 2\ miles west ward of this Shoal part, the depths are from 19 to 25 feet, and, near the western extreme of the bank are patches with 33 feet. Small vessels should avoid passing near some patches of from 7 to 10 fathoms which lengthen out this bank westward almost to the meridian of Calais, as there is a confused sea on their edges with a fresh breeze and weather tide. Middle Dyck or The Dyck is one continuous flat, f>\ miles long E. by N. and W. by S., from 5 to 8 cables wide, and has from one to 5 fathoms water, the shoalest spot being near the eastern end. The 5-fathoms limit of the bank commences N.N.E. \ E. 6 miles from Gravelines lighthouse, and ends N. by W. £ W. 7 miles from Dun kerque lighthouse. The shoalest part of this flat is 4 miles long, on which the depths vary from 6 to 12 and 18 feet. From the centre to the eastern end it is extremely dangerous, being steep-to on all sides, but especially towards the North-west, where, at 2 cables distance, there are from 14 to 15 fathoms water, The Dyck light-vessel in line with Gravelines lighthouse S.S.W. \ W. leads between the West and Middle Dyck in about 19 feet water. East Dyck or Clif-d'Islande is separated from the Middle Dyck by a channel nearly 2 miles wide, in which the least depth is about 6 fathoms. The south-western end of this bank lies N. \ W, See chart, No. 1,872.

592 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. [Chap. XII. 7 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse, and, from thence, it trends N.E. \ E. about 14 miles. It is very dangerous throughout its whole extent, as it rises abruptly like a wall from soundings of from 11 to 17 fathoms. Its shoalest part, a flat 3 miles long, on the greater part of which there are only from 6 to 9 feet, commences near the south western end of the bank and extends north-eastward to the meridian of Dunkerque lighthouse. On the other flats of the bank the depths are irregular, varying from 10 to 17 feet. The north-eastern end of the East Dyck is a formidable danger ; here there are only from 3 to 4 fathoms and the sea is always disturbed around it, as it rises abruptly from depths of 15 and 17 fathoms and is therefore difficult to be avoided by the lead, however quickly hove. From the shoal spot of 3 fathoms, the West Hinder light-vessel bears N.W. westerly 3| miles ; Dunkerque lighthouse S.W. by S. 19 miles ; and, Ostende lighthouse S.E. \ E. 16^ miles ; but, this end of the bank being so far from the low land, the most remarkable objects can be recognised, even from the mast-head, only in very clear weather ; at such times, Dunkerque light may be seen 5 or 6 miles farther. DYCK LIGHT- VESSEL, moored in about 6 fathoms, 3 miles in-shore of the shoalest part of the West Dyke, with Gravelines pier-head lights bearing S.W. westerly 2| miles, shows at 39 feet above the sea, a flashing ivhite light visible 11 miles. The flashes occur every twenty seconds and are of five seconds duration, the eclipses being of fifteen seconds duration. The vessel is painted with red and black bands, has the word Dyck in white letters on each side, and carries a red cage at the mast-head. Fog bell. — In foggy weather, a bell is sounded for one minute every three minutes, and continuously in reply to a passing vessel. From the Dyck light-vessel, the Snouw light-vessel bears E. § S. 3 miles. The two light-vessels in line lead through the West Pass into Dunkerque road, but there is an intention to remove the Snouw light-vessel altogether. Inner Ratel. — This bank is, properly speaking, only a branch of the Middle Dyck, being joined to its south-western end by a narrow 4-fathoms sandy ridge ; it is high and steep-to on all sides, and, from its western end in 22 feet, N. \ E. b\ miles from Mardick church tower, it trends E. | N. 7 miles, where, on and near its eastern end, See chart No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] DYCK LIGHT- VESSEL. — RATEL & GRAVELINES BANKS. 593 between 6 and 7 miles N.N.E. from Dunkerque lighthouse, shoal ground of from 15 to 25 feet rises suddenly from soundings of 7 or 8 fathoms. Its extreme breadth, about a mile, is near the middle of the bank where there is a shoal flat 2 miles long with only from 1 to 9 feet water, and with less than 6 feet for more than a mile of its extent. From this dangerous part, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. by E. | E. 5} miles. The channel separating the Inner Ratel from the Breeds in-shore of it, is barred between the western flats of these banks by a heap of sand on which are about 3} fathoms. There are 8 and 12 fathoms in the channel at a short distance eastward and westward of this bar. Outer Ratel is an isolated bank, and within the 5-fathoms line is 9 miles long and about a mile wide ; it lies south-eastward of and parallel with the East Dyck, from which it is separated by a deep channel from 2 to 2\ miles wide. Its name, meaning rattle, is perhaps derived from the noise caused by the heavy sea on it in bad weather. Near its south-western end, about a mile northward of the eastern end of the Breeds, is a dangerous flat with only 8 feet water. From this shoal spot, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S.W. f S. 10 miles and from thence the bank extends N.E. byT E. 8^ miles, including the shoal patches of 3} and 4 fathoms near its north-eastern extreme. The Outer Ratel, having for 1\ miles of its extent only from 9 to 15 feet water, should not be crossed, even by small vessels, without great care. It is separated from the East Dyck, as well as from the eastern end of the Breedt, by soundings of from 7 to 12 fathoms. A bank, 1} miles long with only 25 feet water, lies N.N.W. \ W. 1^ miles from its north-eastern end, and is separated from it by soundings of from 8 to 13 fathoms. Clearing marks. — When in-shore of the West Hinder, by not bringing Ostende lighthouse eastward of S.E. \ S., a vessel keeps north-eastward of all the banks between the East Dyck and Middelkercke bank, which latter is the most western of the Ostende banks. The West Hinder light-vessel also affords a good mark for clearing them, but constant attention should be paid to the lead. Haut-fond de Gravelines, a small sandy flat a mile in extent on which the least water is 18 feet, lies 1\ mites westward of the See chart, No. 1,872.

XII. 594 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. western end of the Breeds bank ; from the shoalest spot, Gravelines lighthouse bears S. by W. £ W. 3| miles ; and, Dunkerque lighthouse open northward of the Snouw light-vessel E.S.E. 9f miles. Buoy. — A spindle buoy painted with red and white horizontal bands, and surmounted by two cones, points together, marks the southern extreme of the Haut-fond de Gravelines ; from it, the Dyck light-vessel bears S.E. \ S. !•£ miles, and Gravelines lighthouse S. | W. 3£ miles. Breeds bank. — This is the largest of the Dunkerque banks, and joins the Inner -Ratel by a bar of sand with 3£ fathoms water. Its western extreme in 5 fathoms bears N. by W. 3-J- miles from Gravelines point ; from thence, it trends E. § S. 6| miles, and then E. by N. J N. 8f miles to its eastern extreme Ln 5 fathoms, from which Dunkerque lighthouse bears S.W. \ W. 10 miles. There are three dangerous flats on the Breeds, with channels across the bank between them with not less than 15 feet water. The western flat, with only 2 feet least water, is 2^ miles long, lies 3 miles from the shore, is 5 cables wide, and, from its centre, Mardick church tower bears South. The middle flat, which is the largest, is 3 miles long by 1\ miles wide ; from its shoalest part, where, in 1879, 2^ feet was the least depth found, though formerly it used to uncover 5 feet, Dunkerque pier-heads bear South about 3 miles. The narrow channel between this and the western flat has from 3 to 3j fathoms. The eastern flat is 5 miles long N.E. by E. \ E. and S.W. by W. 32 W., and 6 cables wide ; it commences N.N.E. \ E. 4 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse and extends to within 1£ miles of the eastern end of the bank ; there are shoal patches of only 6 feet, and general depths of from 8 to 9 feet, on this flat ; its western end is separated from the eastern end of the middle flat, by an interval of one mile, with from 2 to 2f fathoms water ; but all these banks are very liable to temporary changes in form and depth. East Breeds bank is a continuation north-eastward of the Smal bank ; within the 5-fathoms line, it is one mile wide and 5 miles long N.E. \ E. and S.W. \ W. ; its shoalest part, commencing near the south-western end, is 3 miles long and 5 cables wide, with from 13 to 18 feet -water. From the south-western end of this flat, See chart, No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] BREEDT BANK. — SNOUW AND OTHER BANKS. 595 Nieuport pier-heads bear S.S.E. \ E. 65 miles. , The north-eastern extreme of the bank terminates in some shoal patches of 25 feet, of which the most eastern bears N. \ E. from Nieuport and is 9 miles distant from the pier-heads. From this position, Ostende lighthouse bears S.E. \ E. 10| miles. Smal bank. — The western end of this bank lies 2| miles from Dunkerque lighthouse, with the lighthouse and church tower in line ; it is connected with the middle flat of Breedt bank by a bar with only 12 or 13 feet water, and has as little as 2 feet within 5 cables of this end. From its western end, it trends E. J N. 6 miles and then N.E. by E. J E. 9 miles to its north-eastern end, which bears about N. \ E. from Furnes, and N. by W. § W. 5i miles from Nieuport pier-heads. The southern part of this bank, near its north-eastern end, joins Nieuport bank by a narrow bar with 18 feet water ; here the towers at Furnes are on with the eastern part of Brours Duin sand-hill, bearing South. These banks bound Nieuport road on the North, and are extremely steep-to near their point of junction. Besides the small 2-feet flat at its western end, a dangerous flat about 8 miles long, with from one to 9 feet water, rises from the Smal bank, commencing N.E. \ N. 3-| miles from Dunkerque lighthouse and extending without interruption as far as N. by W. \ W. from Furnes. It is joined to the flat on Hills bank, in-shore of it, by a shoal bar of from 10 to 15 feet ; from the centre of which bar, Dunkerque church tower is just open eastward of Leuguenaert tower. Between the eastern end of this flat and the north eastern extreme of the bank, are several patches of from 9 to 16 feet water. BANK bounding DUNKERQUE ROAD.— The successive parts of this long bank are, the Snouw, Braek, Hills, and Traepegeer. From the western end of the Snouw in 5 fathoms to the point of junction with the shore of the eastern part of the Traepegeer, the length of the united banks is not less than 16^ miles ; their width, from 3 cables to a mile. They give shelter to Dunkerqne road, which is entered from the westward by the West pass, and from the eastward by the Zuydcoote pass, the whole of the southern side of the banks being well buoyed. See pages 608, 609. See chart, No. 1,872,

596 [Chap. XII. CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Snouw bank, the western part of the long bank just described, is 4 miles in length E. % S. and W. \ N. with less than 3 fathoms, and its highest parts form a narrow flat 2\ miles long with as little as 2 feet water at one part. The western end of the Snouw is 2 miles from the shore at Gravelines point ; from the 5-fathoms limit at its western end, Gravelines lighthouse bears S.W. \ W. 4 miles ; and, Dunkerque lighthouse, E. by S. § S. 1\ miles. Light-buoy. — No. 1, black light-buoy, showing a red light, is moored at the western end of the Snouw bank. LIGHT-VESSEL. — The Snouw light-vessel, painted with red and black bands, a red cage at the mast-head, and Snouiv, in white letters on the sides, lies in about 11 fathoms in the West pass, If miles E. by S. f S. from No. 1 buoy, and shows a fixed red light, visible 8 miles. This light-vessel bears E. f S. 3 miles from the Dyck light-vessel ; the two light-vessels in line lead into Dunkerque road, but notice has for some time been given of the intention to withdraw this light-vessel. Fog bell. — In foggy weather, a bell is sounded for one minute everjr three minutes, and continuously in reply to passing vessels. Braek bank is only separated from the Snouw by a narrow 21-feet channel. It is about 5 miles long E. by S. and W. by N., beginning abreast of the centre of the Snouw, about 1| miles from the shore on the meridian of Mardick, and ending just eastward of the meridian of Dunkerque. On its highest parts, which form a flat from one to 3 cables wide, are only from one to 2 feet water, and some patches even dry at the lowest tides. The Braek is steep-to, its sides rising from the bottom like a wall, and with northerly winds the sea breaks upon it with great fury. Its western end in 3| fathoms and the shallow flats extending from the shore, are connected by a sandy shoal or bar running in a W.S.W. direction across the West pass. On this bar, there are from 5 to 54/ fathoms, deepening to 7 or 8 fathoms the moment it is passed in either direction. Hills bank is a continuation of the Braek, extending 3^ miles farther in an easterly direction and terminating suddenly in the Zuydcoote pass, the narrow 19-feet channel which separates it from the Traepegeer bank. This end of Hills bank, at its south-eastern angle, is only 1^ miles from the shore ; and, N. \ W. from Zuydcoote See ohart, No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] DUNKERQUE ROAD BANK & BANKS NORTHWARD OF. 597 tower, in ruins, called also Sables or Sands tower. From this angle, the edge of the bank extends N.E. \ N. 1 \ miles, forming the north-western side of the Zuydcoote pass. The highest part of the bank forms a flat from 2 to 8 cables wide, on the southern part of which, large patches dry as much as 6 feet at low water about N.E. by E. from Dunkerque lighthouse ; and, on the remainder, are only from one'to 6 feet. The southern side rises precipitously from depths of 7| and 10 fathoms, rendering it exceedingly dangerous, but for the buoys marking its edge, to vessels turning to windward in the eastern part of Dunkerque road. Traepegeer bank bounds Dunkerque road eastward, and its western end forms the eastern side of the East or Zuydcoote pass. The Traepegeer joins the shore in the neighbourhood of Brours Duin, the high white sand-hill before mentioned, and from thence, as Brours bank, extends along the shore to the entrance of Nieuport. Its western extreme, on which there are from 7 to 13 feet water, is only 2 cables from the south-eastern angle of Hills bank, and bears N. \ E. from Zuydcoote tower ; the outer part of the bank extends from 2^ to If miles from the shore, and the depths vary between 6 and 18 feet, though one part, near the centre and on the outer side, has only one foot water. BANKS NORTH Of DUNKERQUE BANKS— These banks, referred to at page 587, are dangerous, not only from their shallowness and their being so liable to change in form that anything but the latest charts may be very misleading, but also from their being at so great a distance from the shore and directly in the route of vessels bound for the Schelde. See also the caution at pages 622, 623, as to the slight rise of tide on these banks. Fairy bank, a high sandy ridge with from 3| to 9 fathoms water, is on the eastern side of the Deep-soundings channel, and the channel between it and the West Hinder is 2| miles wide. From its southern end in 8 fathoms, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. | W. 18 miles ; and, the West Hinder light-vessel E. £ N. &\ miles. From thence, it extends N.E. 9| miles, its greatest breadth not exceeding 8 cables. There are two flats on this bank ; that near the middle, with less than 5 fathoms water, is 2\ miles long, and, from its shoalest spot of 3| fathoms, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. by W. westerly See chart No. 1,872,

The other flat is near the northern end of the bank ; from its shoalest spot of 5£ fathoms, the West Hinder light-vessel bears South 6 miles. Dunkerque lighthouse may be seen in clear weather from the southern end of the Fairy bank. A shoal about 8 miles in length, with from 6^ to 9 fathoms water, lies 2 miles westward of and nearly parallel with the Fairy bank. North Hinder, a dangerous sand-bank, situated like the Fairy on the eastern side of the Deep-soundings channel, is 7 miles long N.E. by N. and S.W. by S., and from 5 to 8 cables wide, the general depth being from 6 to 9 fathoms ; but, on its southern part, a narrow flat with only 4 and 5 fathoms extends 2\ miles southward from about the middle of the bank, and is steep-to on its eastern side. From the northern end of the bank the Galloper light-vessel bears W. by N. h N. 24^ miles ; and the southern end lies N.E. \ E. 8 miles from the Fairy. Buoy. — A red buoy with the word Hinder in white letters is moored in 6 fathoms at the northern end of the shoal flat of the North Hinder, and 2 miles North from the light-vessel. Vessels of deep draught should keep northward of the buoy if crossing the North Hinder, and must bear in mind that the buoy being in its correct position cannot be depended on. In line between the North Hinder and the Fairy are three flats, of which two, with from 8 to 10 fathoms water, occupy a space 3 miles in length midway between the banks ; the third, with 9 fathoms, lies 2 miles eastward of the northern end of the Fairy. LIGHT- VESSEL.— The North Hinder light-vessel is moored in 20 fathoms water, on the eastern side of the bank ; and exhibits, at 40 feet above the sea, a flashing white light at intervals of ten seconds, visible 11 miles. The vessel has two masts and a red ball at the mainmast head, is coloured red, and has Noord-Hinder in large white letters on the sides. Fog Signal.— In thick or foggy weather a bell is sounded every ten minutes, preceded and followed by blasts on a horn. Sec chart, No. 1,406.

Chap. XII.] 601 EAST HINDER. — THORNTON RIDGE. Bligh bank, also of sand, is 10^ miles long, from 5 cables to l-\ miles wide, and lies about 3 miles eastward of and nearly parallel with the East Hinder. Its northern end in 10 fathoms is in lat. 51° 41£' N., long. 2° 48' 45" E. Its southern end, in 5£ fathoms, lies E. by N. 5 miles nearly from the southern extreme of the East Hinder. It is steep-to and has irregular depths of from 4f to 9 fathoms. About 3 miles from its southern end, a flat, 1^ miles long with 4| fathoms water, rises abruptly from depths of 14 to 18 fathoms. There is also a 5-fathoms patch near the northern end of the bank. Another patch, with 9 fathoms water, lies 1^ miles northward of the Bligh bank. Thornton ridge.— Within a depth of 9 fathoms, this sand-bank is 13 miles long E. by N. \ N. and W. by S. \ S. with a mean but very varied width of H miles ; it rises from soundings of from 12 to 17 fathoms about 15 miles from the coast of Belgium. The general depth on the other parts of the ridge is from 6 to 9 fathoms. The land in the neighbourhood of West Kapelle, and the lights of West Kapelle and of Ostende, may be seen from this ridge in clear weather. The COAST.— The sand-hills forming the. coast between Calais and Gravelines may be seen in clear weather at 8 or 9 miles, but some parts are so low that embankments are thrown up as a protection against the sea. The only objects that can be recognised on the level land adjoining the shore are, the two windmills at Walde, Oye church spire, the two windmills near Oye village, and the telegraph beacons at the Huttes d'Oye. At low water, the sandy strand extends a mile from the shore between Calais and the meridian of Walde windmills, as well as off the entrance to Gravelines ; but, along the intermediate coast, its breadth varies from 5 to 8 cables. Depths of less than 4 fathoms adjoining the beach, extend nearly 2 miles from the shore N.N.E. of Calais church and abreast of Gravelines, and about a mile from the shore between Walde and Oye windmills ; between the outer edge of these soundings and high water mark, the slope of the bottom is steep and somewhat irregular, which tends to cause a heavy sea with on-shore winds. WALDE LIGHT.— Near the outer edge of the sandy strand which dries at low water, springs, 8 cables from the shore at Walde point, and 3 miles E.N.E. from Calais lighthouse, is an iron hexagonal beacon 59 feet high, from which, at 36 feet above high water, is exhibited a light, visible 11 miles, showing ivhite and red alternately during tiventy seconds, the red flash lasting six seco?ids, the white flash fourteen seconds, with no eclipse between. Telegraph cable.— The telegraph cable between France and Denmark (from Calais to Fano island), leaves the shore near the Huttes d'Oye, in long. 2° 2^' E., and lies in a N. \ E. direction for U miles to lat. 51° 7' 10" N., long. 1° 59' 39" E, at which point it takes the direction of N.E. § N., passing close westward of No. 7 Outer Ruytingen buoy. The first of these directions is indicated by the two beacons on the shore before mentioned, each of which is surmounted by a hexagonal prism, partly white and partly red. Vessels should not anchor on or near the direction indicated by these beacons. Se,: charts, Nos. 1,406 and 1,8 '2,

Chap. XII.] COAST. — WALDE LIGHT.— GRAVELINES. — DEPTHS. 603 CAUTION. — Shipwrecks are frequent between Calais and Grave lines ; they are in great measure attributable to neglect of the lead, and to inattention or want of knowledge as to the times of change of the tidal streams, which are much later at the Galloper light-vessel, from whence vessels from the North Sea usually take their departure, than on the French coast. GRAVELINES.— The entrance to this small tidal harbour lies 10 miles eastward of Calais, and its position may be easily recognised bjT the houses of Fort Phillippe village, built close to the sea on each side of the entrance channel, by a windmill about a quarter of a mile eastward of the village, and by the fine tower of the lighthouse. The port itself is under the ramparts of the north-western part of Gravelines, at the mouth of the river Aa, but about a mile within the coast-line ; from the offing only the towers of the Cathedral are seen, the town being hidden from view by trees. About 200 vessels, of which a fair proportion are steamers, enter the port annually bringing about 25,000 tons of merchandise ; the principal imports being wood, coal, woollen goods, bricks, and cement ; the exports, eggs, fruit, vegetables, &c. Vessels are also fitted out for the herring, cod, and mackerel fisheries. The popula tion of the port is about 8,500. Bar. — Depths. — The entrance to the channel leading into Grave lines harbour is frequently obstructed by a bar formed of the sand driven in by westerly winds and sea. The height and extent of this bar depend both on the duration of these winds and on the body of fresh water running out of the harbour. At its medium state, it is 5 or 6 feet above the level of the lowest tides ; at such times there are 15 feet over it at high water, springs, and 11 feet at neaps. When the great freshets of the river Aa are accompanied by north easterly winds, it sometimes disappears altogether for several days. The harbour is accessible to vessels of 14 feet draught at high water, springs. At weak springs, those of 1H or 12 feet can enter it during 5 or 6 days, that is to say, for 2 or 3 days before full and change, and 3 days after ; but at the lowest neaps it is only accessible to vessels of about 8 feet draught. It affords good shelter, at springs, to vessels of about 12 feet draught during westerly gales, especially those between W.S.W. and W.N.W., when the sea is not heavy at the entrance ; but, the bar should be crossed at about high water. See chart, No. 1,872.

[Chap. XII. 604 TAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. In a gale from E.N.E. or East, vessels should run in with the flood, for, after high water, there is some difficulty in stemming the ebb. The tide rises much higher with strong northerly winds, but, as the sea is then very high at the entrance, no vessel drawing more than 12 feet should attempt to enter, unless embayed and with no possibility of reaching Dunkerque road, which is the only place on this coast where, with strong northerly winds, a vessel may find a partially sheltered anchorage. The Entrance Channel runs S. by E. f E. 2 miles in almost a direct line from the pier-heads and consists of two distinct parts, one bounded by the piers; the other, by the land from Fort Phillippe village to Gravelines. The outer part of the channel, 8 cables long and 305 feet wide at the entrance, is enclosed between two stone piers, their outer part terminated by about 330 yards of woodwork to the pier-heads. Abreast of the pier-heads, the level of the fresh water of the river when the tide is out, is 3 feet above the level of the lowest tides. The deepest water in the entrance channel is nearest to the East pier ; on the western side the sand dries alongside the West pier 7 or 8 feet at low water. The inner part of the channel, between Fort Phillippe and Gravelines, is rather more than a mile long and half a cable wide, and is enclosed between embankments which serve for towing paths. The channel has a steep slope on either side, forming good grounding berths for the numerous fishing craft which frequent this part of the harbour. In the summer, the depth is maintained by scouring waters released by sluices from the fosses of the fortifications ; but, at other seasons, the abundant freshets of the river Aa caused by rain and by the melting of the snow, clear both harbour and entrance channel, as previously mentioned. The Tidal harbour is on the north-western side of the town, and is only about 1^ cables long, occupying half the breadth of the channel by which the course of the Aa has been straightened between the ditches of the western part of the fortifications and the entrance channel. There is a small gridiron and careening place in this harbour where vessels of 150 or 200 tons can be received. The berths of muddy sand, alongside the stone or wooden quays See chart. No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] GRAVELINES. — ENTRANCE. — LIGHTS. — TIDES. 605 bordering the whole length of the harbour on the town side, are 4| feet above the level of low water, springs. The swell from outside never reaches the tidal harbour. The Wet dock, or Bassin-a-flot, is 1,083 feet long by 147 feet wide ; it is entered from the tidal harbour by dock gates 32| feet wide, and it again communicates with the river Aa, and hence with the inland navigation by other gates. It is also in communication with the railway by means of a siding. The sill at the entrance is on the level of low water, springs ; at high water, springs, there are 18 feet water, and at ordinary neaps, 15 feet over it. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station close to the light house ; see page 12. LIGHTS.— Gravelines lighthouse, a white circular tower, stands at the Eastern side of the entrance near the inner end of the East pier. It exhibits, at 95 feet above high water, a fixed light' visible 15 miles within the following limits, viz. : — white between S. 29° W. and S. 36° W. ; red between S. 36° W. and S. 43° W. The red illuminating power is only about half that of the white. West pier. — A fixed green tidal light, visible 4 miles, is exhibited from iron supports above a shed on the West pier-head ; this light is 25 feet above high water and is shown from two hours before to tivo hours after high water. East pier. — A fixed red light, visible 4 miles, is shown from a similar structure on the East pier-head ; this light is exhibited all night, and is also 25 feet above high water. Tide signals. — The usual day tide signals, see page 12, are in use at this port. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Gravelines harbour at noon, springs rise 21 feet, neaps 17 feet above the zero of soundings. A deduction of 5 feet from these heights gives the depth on the bar when in its medium state. The tide rises very slowly in the first 3 hours of the flood, but rapidly between the third and fourth hours. High water slack lasts from 10 to 25 minutes in the harbour, but there is very little change for about 1\ hours at and near high water. Strong winds from N.W. to N.N.W. cause the tide to rise higher, and those from S.E. have a contrary effect. See chart, No. 1,872.

[Chap. XII. 606 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Off the pier-heads the East-going stream is at its greatest strength, about 3 knots, at the time of high water in the harbour. Pilots. — Eight pilots are stationed at Gravelines ; when the sea is too high on the bar for them to board vessels in the offing, they go as far as they can and wave a flag to indicate the direction to be steered ; in such cases, however, it is most dangerous to attempt the entrance. A Life-boat is stationed at Gravelines. Directions. — Vessels arriving off Gravelines some time before the tide serves, may anchor northward of Oye church spire (being careful to avoid the telegraph cable mentioned at page 602), at 1\ or 2 miles from the shore, in from 5 to 8 fathoms, excellent holding ground ; this anchorage, however, is only safe during fine weather, for the sea is heavy with on-shore winds. The most favourable winds for entering the harbour are those from N.N.W. to N.E., but, if fresh, they cause a high sea at the entrance, and it is then necessary to be quite certain there is sufficient water over the bar to avoid striking. With fresh winds from W.S.W. to W.N.W., the sea is smooth on the bar, but care is requisite or the east-going stream and sea may drift a vessel on the East pier. The entrance is easy with north-easterly winds when sufficiently strong for a vessel to stem the stream. With a head wind, a vessel must be tracked in. The best time for entering is about an hour before high water, although the stream at that time runs strongly across the entrance and there is some difficulty in keeping in the deepest water ; but, if the vessel takes the ground off Fort Phillippe, with a rising tide, she will float again before high water and get up to Gravelines. Bower and stern anchors must be ready to let go, and hawsers to run out, should she be drifted on the East pier. Sufficient sail should always be carried to ensure good steerage, especially during the autumn and winter months when it often blows fresh in the offing whilst the breeze is light near the shore ; vessels, therefore, under suitable sail in the offing, must be prepared to make more sail as they approach the harbour or they may be in considerable danger in the heavy swell on the bar. In entering the channel with westerly winds, whatever their strength, or with light easterly winds, keep close past the West pier-head. With fresh easterly winds, run directly for the middle of the entrance. See chart, No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] GRATELINES. — DIRECTIONS. — COAST, BEACONS. 607 The COAST.— From the entrance to Gravelines, that of Dunkerque bears E. £ S. 10^ miles ; the low plain behind the shore between the two places presents no remarkable objects visible from any considerable distance at sea. The only high lands visible in clear weather are, the Great and Little Cassel, two isolated hills S. i W. from Dunkerque. The town of Cassel stands on the summit of the Great Cassel ; the other hill is of a conical form. The buildings recognisable near the coast are, the tower and light house at Dunkerque, and the church towers of Grande and Petite Synth e and of Mardick. Gravelines point.— Beacon. — This point bears East, southerly, 4 miles from Gravelines pier-heads, is of a rounded form, and the sand-hills composing it lie in several parallel ridges and are visible in clear weather 9 or 10 miles ; at its outer extreme is a large wooden beacon. A chain of sand-hills covered with verdure extends 2 miles in a W.S.W. direction from the point, and those bordering the shore for about 2 miles eastward are about the same height as those at the point, but, beyond this, and to within a short distance of Dunkerque, they are covered with bent grass and lie in parallel ridges half a mile in the rear of an embankment, fronted by a low strand which covers at high water, springs. Between the entrance of Gravelines and Gravelines point, the sands dry more than 5 cables out from the beach, at springs ; abreast of the point, they dry 3 cables ; and, between the point and Dunkerque, 6 or 8 cables. The sand carried eastward by strong westerly winds, is arrested by the jetties at Dunkerque and accumulates between Mardick and Dunkerque, where it forms an immense heap of which the highest parts barely cover at springs. Of all the obstacles to the improvement and deepening of Dunkerque, this high bank of drifting sand has always proved the most difficult to combat. Beacons. — Besides the beacon on Gravelines point, several wooden beacons are placed along the shore between Gravelines and Dunkerque ; they are used in fixing the positions of the most important buoys marking Dunkerque banks. About one mile west ward of Gravelines point are the Gravelines beacons, one on the shore, the other about 4 cables to the northward at low water mark. The Mardick beacon, surmounted by a cone and ball, stands on the Set chart, No. 1,872.

[Chap. XII. 608 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. sand-hills between Gravelines point and Mardick church. Four other beacons of lesser size occupy positions on the sands between high and low water mark between Gravelines point and Dunkerque. Mardick bank, Fosse de Mardick, &c— The soundings off this part of the coast, within a depth of 5 fathoms, are very irregular and the sea heavy with on-shore winds. Between the entrance to Gravelines and Gravelines point, these soundings extend in places 2 miles and upwards from the shore ; and, on these shallows, the Mardick bank, with a general width of 5 or 6 cables and from 7 to 18 feet water, extends 3| miles parallel with the shore, its western end joining the shore sands about one mile eastward of Gravelines piers. Another shoal, of which the outer edge is steep-to, joins the strand between Mardick and Dunkerque, and, extending H miles from the shore, forms, with the Mardick bank, the southern side of the West pass ; its western end in 3 fathoms is 6 cables east ward of the eastern end of the Mardick bank, and bears N. by W. \ W. from Mardick church tower. In-shore of this and of the Mardick bank, is the Fosse de Mardick, which has from 19 to 24 feet water, but should always be avoided as each end terminates in a blind channel. WEST PASS into DUNKERQUE ROAD.*— Buoyage — From No. 1 light-buoy, marking the western extreme of the Snouw bank, described at page 596, to abreast of Dunkerque jetty-heads, this pass is 7 miles long, and it lies between the shoal flats joining the shore and the Snouw and Braek banks. The entrance to it is marked by the Dyck and Snouw light-vessels, and its limits as well as the direction it follows, by seven buoys on each side of the channel, black on the northern side, red on the southern. The black buoys bear odd numbers from 1 to 13, the red buoys even numbers from 2 to 14 ; the numbers commencing from the westward. Of the black buoys on the northern side, Nos. 1, 5, 9, and 13 are light-buoys showing red fixed lights; Nos. 3, 7, and 11 are conical with cylinder top-marks. Of the red buoys marking the southern side, placed near the edge of the Mardick bank, and of the shoal bank extending from the shore, Nos. 2, 6, 10, and 14 are light-buoys, 2 and 14 each showing a fixed- white light, whilst 6 and 10 show fixed green lights. Nos. 4, 8, and 12 are conical buoys, each having a cone point downwards for top-mark. * See Admiralty plan : — Dunkerque road, No. 1,352 ; scale, m = 4'2 inches.

Chap. XII.] DUNKERQUE ROAD.— WEST PASS.— ZUYDCOOTE PASS. 609 ZUYDCOOTE PASS and EAST PASS into DUN KERQUE ROAD.— The Zuydcoote pass is very narrow at the point where it opens into the East pass ; it lies between Hills and Traepegeer banks and has from 19 to 22 feet water, see also page 597 ; the limits of Hills bank are defined by four red buoys with even numbers from 2 to 8, commencing from the eastward ; the Traepegeer bank by two black buoys. Of the red buoys, Nos. 2, 4, and 6 are conical, each with a cone point upwards as top-mark ; No. 8 is a light-buoy showing a fixed red light ; Nos. 2 and 4 mark the eastern end of Hills bank in the Zuydcoote pass ; Nos. 6 and 8 the southern side of Hills bank ; the latter is a good mark for Dunkerque road. No. 1 is a black spindle buoy surmounted by a cylinder, and marks the north-western edge of the Traepegeer at the entrance to the Zuydcoote pass ; from it, No. 2 red buoy bears about W. by S. \ S. 1^ miles. The other black buoy, conical, lies If miles eastward of No. 1, and is not numbered ; it marks the northern edge of the Traepegeer in the approach to the pass. LIGHTS. — Life-boat. — A small fixed red light, visible 2\ miles, is shown from a pole on the shore at Braye-dunes, near Zuydcoote, about 6 miles eastward of the entrance to Dunkerque, and 1| miles south-eastward of No. 4 buoy. About 3 miles farther eastward, at La Panne, is a green light, visible 5 miles, and a life-boat station. Caution. — The red buoys on the eastern slope of Hills bank, which is very steep, have sometimes drifted across the Zuydcoote pass to the western slope of the Traepegeer ; this has frequently happened to No. 4 red buoy. Mariners should therefore be on their guard, though the greatest care is taken to keep the buoyage of both passes in proper condition, a Government steamer being specially assigned for that duty. Directions. — The general direction through the Zuydcoote pass from the eastward is about S.W. \ W., with No. 4 red buoy on the port bow until past No. 2 red buoy, when No. 4 should be brought gradually on the starboard bow ; this leads through in the deepest water. When the east-going stream begins to be felt in Dunkerque road, which is about the time of half flood in the harbour, the tide has risen 9 feet in the Zuydcoote pass, and the largest vessels that can enter Dunkerque may at that time pass over the south- Set plan, No. 1,352, and chart, No. 1,872.

610 [Chap. XII. DUNKERQUE ROAD AND PORT. western end of the Traepegeer by keeping the spires of Bergues church open about 1° westward of Leffrinckoucke church tower bearing about S.S.W. } W. If a vessel's draught permits of turning through the Zuydcoote pass between half flood and half ebb, the lead must be hove quickly to avoid coming suddenly upon Hills bank ; and, in standing east ward, she should not open the spires of Bergues more than 2° eastward of Leffrinckoucke church tower. At night, when doubtful of the colour of the first buoy seen, small vessels entering by this pass cannot do wrong in passing close eastward of it ; for, if it should be No. 1 black, buoy of the Traepegeer, there is enough water for them for 4 cables eastward of it, and if it should be No. 2 red buoy of the Hills bank, by keeping eastward of it they will be in the middle of the pass. DUNKERQUE ROAD being narrow, and only sheltered by banks of which the greater part are always covered, should be used only as a temporary anchorage by merchant vessels intending to enter the harbour. In heavy weather, sharp vessels deeply laden might be in some danger from the sea, but, with this exception, pilots consider that a vessel with good ground tackle may ride out a gale from the offing ; and, in the winter of 1870-71, a French squadron remained for many months in the road and reported favourably of it ; the banks, even at high water, affording sufficient shelter for large ships. The road is comprised between the 5-fathoms line in-shore, and the Braek, Hills, and Traepegeer banks, on the off-shore side. It extends from the western end of the shallow flat of the Braek, north-eastward of Mardick church, to the entrance of the Zuydcoote pass. The Great or western road, with from 8 to 9 fathoms, good holding-ground, commences N.E. of Mardick church and extends rather beyond the line of Nos. 13 and 14 buoys to about a position from which Dunkerque lighthouse bears S.E. by S. ; it is in some degree sheltered during northerly gales by the high flat on the Braek bank. It is in this part of the road that vessels of deep draught anchor, with westerly winds and a heavy sea, when they have to wait for high water to enter Dunkerque. Small vessels under similar circumstances, and all vessels with off-shore winds, See plan, No. 1,352, and chart, No. 1,872.

Chap. XII.] 611 ROAD. — TIDAL STREAMS. — PORT. may anchor N.W. about a mile from the harbour entrance, the holding-ground being good. The Little or eastern road commences with Leuguenaert tower on with Dunkerque lighthouse, and extends to the Zuydcoote pass ; the depths vary from 8 to 11 fathoms, and the holding-ground is good, especially N.N.E. of Dunkerque. Large vessels remaining some time in the Little road should anchor between the lines of Leuguenaert tower touching the eastern side of the lighthouse, and the same tower on with Dunkerque tower ; here, during gales from N.N.W. to E.N.E., they are better sheltered than in the Great road by the high flats on Braek and Hills banks ; and, in the event of parting, it is much less dangerous to run ashore eastward than westward of Dunkerque. In any part of the road, vessels should have a spare anchor ready if the wind veers and threatens to blow hard from the northward. Tidal Streams. — The tidal streams turn at about half tide ; the first of the flood or east-going stream in Dunkerque road runs about S.S.E. ; as it gains strength it turns more eastward, and, at its greatest speed, 3^ knots, which lasts about two hours, it runs straight through the road. Its strength then decreases rapidly, and, after a few minutes slack water, the ebb or west-going stream commences, running N.N.W. at first, and, as its rate increases, turning westward, and running parallel with the shore when at its greatest strength ; towards the end of the tide, its direction is W.S.W. and S.S.W. The east-going stream runs for 2$ or 3 hours after high water in the harbour ; see tides, page 616. DUNKERQUE, 10 miles eastward of Gravelines, formerly an arsenal and naval port, is now the principal French commercial port in the North Sea. The town stands at the junction of the Bergues, Bourbourg, and Furnes canals, and the public buildings are spacious, handsome, and regular. As this port is one principal outlet for the great manufacturing Departement du Nord, the trade by sea is very large. Cod and herring fisheries are also carried on with great activity. In 1893, the trade of the port was represented by the entry of 2,888 vessels, their aggregate tonnage being 1,526,442 tons ; of this tonnage, considerably more than one half, and nearly one half in number of the shipping, was British. The number of sailing vessels using this port gradually decreases and the steamers increase. The population in 1891 amounted to 40,513. Set plau, No. 1,352,

612 DUNKERQUE ROAD AND PORT. [Chap. XII. There is a town hospital at which foreign sailors are received at two francs per diem ; cases of small-pox or typhoid are sent to the Lazaret, where the charges are much higher. There is also a Sailor's Home and British Seamen's Institute. A British Consul is stationed at Dunkerque. The principal imports are, ores, coal, cereals, seeds, molasses, nitrate of soda, wood, wool, flax, petroleum, jute, and pig iron. The exports are coal, forage, potash, rails, and casks. Dunkerque is in railway communication with all parts of France and the Continent, and through Furnes with Belgium. The telegraph service is also very good. By sea, there is regular steam service to London, Hull, Goole, Leith, Rotterdam, St. Petersburg, Havre, Bordeaux, and Marseilles. Coal is always plentiful and moderate in price, that of French coal delivered on board being about 14s. per ton. Vessels usually coal in the Basins ; if they coal alongside the wharf in the tidal harbour, they lie aground in about 8i feet at low water. The port consists of an entrance channel leading in to the tidal harbour, of four wet docks or basins, and of four dry docks of which two only are completed. There are also building yards where fishing craft of from 30 to 150 tons are built, and also vessels up to 800 tons for the foreign and coasting trade. Great improvements have been effected in the entrance and tidal harbours of late years by dredging and otherwise, and extensive works are still (1896) in progress, of which, perhaps, the most important is the widening of the entrance channel to nearly double its present width by the construction of a new East pier, now in a forward state, to be followed by the removal of the old pier, the site of which will, in fact, become about the centre of the channel. Entrance. — Depths. — The entrance channel is about one mile long N.N.W. and S.S.E., and at present only 230 feet wide ; it is enclosed partly by the citadel quay and the extension of the town quay as far as the Cunette sluice, and partly between wooden jetties extending across the sands which uncover at low water. As far up as the North lock entrance to the Bassin Freycinet, it is dredged and maintained at a uniform depth of 9| feet below the zero of soundings, which is 2-\ feet lower than low water of ordinary spring tides ; therefore at high water, springs, there are 28| scut in the See plan, No. 1,352.

Chap. XII.] PORT. — ENTRANCE.— DEPTHS.— BASINS. 613 channel and at neaps 3|- feet less. Water from the canals of the interior and from the ditches of the town, is used to scour the harbour and entrance channel, but, although the stream is rapid, it has so far to run that its effect does not extend much beyond the jetty-heads, and constant steam dredging in conjunction with flushing is necessary to keep the entrance clear. Northerly gales cause such a high sea outside the jetties that vessels above 18 feet draught should not attempt to run in at such times unless the pilots judge the entrance practicable ; smaller vessels may enter at the top of high water by carrying all possible sail to get through the heavy sea, and, at neaps, the entrance is inacessible during these gales to all but small vessels. During rainy weather, and at the melting of the snow, when the water in the interior is abundant, the stream runs strongly out of the channel so long as the flood is weak, and is checked only when the tide rises rapidly ; it recovers its outward direction when the rise of tide slacks, about half an hour before high water, and as soon as the tide begins to fall it runs out with great strength. The stream causes very little inconvenience to sailing vessels of deep draught entering before high water, but, as soon as the tide begins to fall, they must have a strong fair wind to get through against it. Tidal harbour. — From abreast the entrance of the new North lock to the head of the tidal harbour, the distance is about 6| cables, and the width from 200 to 500 feet ; it is surrounded by quays where several lines of steamers have their regular berths. As far as the North lock entrance to the Bassin Freycinet, there is a central depth of 9| feet, but in the upper part only from 3 to 5 feet, with H to 2 feet alongside the quays. At the quai de l'Estran, and also at the quai de Maree, on the western side of the entrance to the Bassin Freycinet, the depth is 6^ feet. Strong northerly winds cause the swell to enter the tidal harbour for about 2 or 3 hours each tide, but it does not inconvenience a vessel well secured. Wet docks. — The four wet docks or bassins-a-flot are named respectively, the Bassin Freycinet, du Commerce, de la Marine, and de l'Arriere Port. The Bassin Freycinet has been greatly enlarged of late years, having an area of about 67 acres ; it is entered by the new North lock and also by the East lock, and admits merchant vessels of the See plan, No. 1,352,

614 [Chap. XII. DUNKERQUE ROAD AND PORT. largest size. Three moles extending from its western side divide it into four open compartments, named respectively Bassins Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 4 ; these moles afford large quayage accommodation with railways and ample facilities for loading and discharging cargo. The northern half of the Bassin Freycinet, including the compartments 3 and 4, is dredged to a depth of 14^ feet below the zero of soundings ; the southern half, including Nos. 1 and 2, has 6^ feet less water. The two halves are divided by lock gates, over which trains can pass. The North lock communicates directly with the northern division and the East lock with the southern division of the Bassin Frey cinet ; the North lock is 582 feet long, 69 feet wide, and has 35j feet over the sill at high water, springs. The East lock is 394 feet long, G6 feet wide, and has 23| feet over the sill at high water, springs. The Bassin Freycinet has communication also with the Bassin de la Marine, and also by two locks with the general canal system of the country. The Bassin du Commerce, of 13i acres area, communicates with the Tidal harbour, and also with the Bassins de la Marine and de l'Arriere Port. It has good stone quays on both sides. The Bassin de la Marine, of l-\ acres area, is surrounded by quays, and the Bassin de l'Arriere Port, of 6 acres, has a wooden quay on its western side, and communicates with the canal system. The depth over the sills of the Bassin du Commerce, de la Marine, and de l'Arriere Port, is in each case about 20 feet 9 inches at high water, springs ; and the length of the entrances 1 64 feet. The width of entrance to the first is 52^ feet, and of the others only 43 feet. Dry docks. — Of the four dry docks, Nos. 1 and 2 are completed and in use, each is 393| feet in length over all, by 46 feet width of entrance, but No. 2 has about 24| feet over the sill at high water, springs, whilst No. 1 has only 20 feet. Nos. 3 and 4 docks are nearly completed ; their dimensions are : — No. 3, 295^ feet length over all, 46 feet width of entrance, and about 20 feet over the sill at high water, springs. No. 4, 656 feet length over all, 69 feet width of entrance, and about 24^ feet over the sill at high water, springs. All the dry docks are entered from the Bassin Freycinet. See plan, No, 1,352.

Chap. XII.] 615 BASINS. — DOCKS.— LIGHTS. Patent Slip. — There is a patent slip capable of taking a vessel of 1,000 tons and 262 feet long. LIGHTS— Dunkerque lighthouse, a yellow brick tower 187 feet high, stands S. 17° E. 875 yards from the entrance, between the sluice and the ruins of Fort Risban. It exhibits, at 193 feet above high water, a group-flashing white electric light, visible 20 miles, showing successive groups of two flashes each, the flashes are each of three fourths of a second duration, the interval between them one and a half seconds, the interval between the groups four and a half seconds. Leuguenaert or Hueguenar— A fixed ivhite light of the fifth order, and 85 feet above high water, is exhibited from the Leugue naert tower, an octagonal stone tower S.S.E. 2,406 yards from the entrance. This light, specially intended to indicate the direction of the entrance channel, shows brightest in the direction of N.N.W., and on that bearing is visible 15 miles. Right or left of this direc tion, the light is visible only within an angular space of 10° or 12°, and from a distance of 5 or 6 miles. East Jetty-head. — A fixed red- light, visible 4 miles, is shown from an iron post and shed at the East jetty-head, at 26 feet above high water. Tidal light. — West jetty. — From a white tower 49 feet within the West jetty-head, at 33 feet above the sea, is exhibited a tidal light, visible 9 miles, varying in colour, and indicating by colour and flashes the state of the tide, so long as it is 65 feet above the zero of soundings, at which time there are 16^ feet in the entrance channel. Every 10 inches of rise above that level is shown, thus : — When the tide is less than 6\ feet above zero, i.e. the depth of the lowest tide known, and rising, the light shows red ; when less than 6k feet and falling, the light shows green. A fixed ivhite light indicates depths from 6^- and 1\ feet. With 1\ feet and upwards, the light shows white with groups of coloured flashes at intervals of eighty seconds. The flashes in each group are shown at intervals of five seconds, each red flash adding 3 feet 4 inches to the initial height of 6\ feet, and each green flash 10 inches more. With a rising tide, the fixed light of each colour is eclipsed for a short period every eighty seconds ; and, with a falling tide twice in quick succession during the same period. At or near high water no eclipse takes place. See plan. No. 1,352. 2Q SO 11886

[Chap. XII. 616 DUNKERQUE ROAD AND PORT. Fog signal. — In thick or foggy weather, a large bell at the West jetty-head is rung for one minute at intervals of one minute, and continuously in answer to fog signals from an approaching vessel ; see Fog signals, page 11. Tide signals. — The day tide signals are those in use at all French ports, see page 12. They are made from a flagstaff a little within the lighthouse on the West jetty. Tides.— It is high water, full and change, at Dunkerque, at Oh. 13m. ; springs rise 19 feet, neaps 15f feet above the level of the lowest tides or zero of soundings, which is about 2\ feet below the level of low water, ordinary springs ; and 9| feet added to the rise gives about the average depth at high water throughout the entrance channel. Strong northerly winds may raise the tide 2 or 3 feet higher, but the sea is then heavy at the entrance. When easterly winds prevail, springs do not rise much higher than do neaps with fresh westerly winds. In the harbour, in calm weather, high water slack lasts about 15 minutes ; with westerly winds, 20 or 25 minutes ; and, with off-shore winds, 10 minutes. A short distance outside the jetties, the flood or eastern stream runs 2f or 3 hours after high water in the harbour. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station at Dunkerque ; it is just in front of the principal lighthouse ; see page 12. . Pilots are unable to get out of harbour when there is a heavy sea at the entrance, which is frequently the case ; but, three pilot vessels are always cruising at sea. Their stations are, one between Dunge ness and the Downs, another near the Ruytingen light-vessel, and a third near the Dyck light-vessel. They all have Dunkerque in large black letters on the mainsail and a large black anchor beneath that name. They always endeavour to meet large vessels, but small ones requiring a pilot should make the signal directly they sight a pilot vessel. Steam-tugS. — The port is well supplied with steam-tugs, whose services are always available. A Life-boat is stationed at Dunkerque. From thence, the course to the Dyck light-vessel, at the entrance of the West Pass into Dunkerque road, is E. i S. 14 miles ; this leads about 8 cables northward of the red perch and globe buoy marking the eastern end of the Riden de Calais. In approaching the West Pass, the Dyck and Snouw light-vessels in line E. f S. affords a good lead so long as the latter remains in position, but, as previously remarked, notice has been given of the intention permanently to remove her. Pass northward of the Dyck light-vessel, and southward of the black light-buoy at the western end of the Snouw bank, and of the Snouw light-vessel, and run in, leaving all black buoys on the port hand and red buoys on the star board hand up to Dunkerque Great road ; but if proceeding eastward beyond the entrance of the harbour to the Little road, it must be borne in mind that the colour of the buoys is reversed, red buoys marking that road on the port hand, if coming from the westward. Vessels of deep draught running in with a strong westerly wind, at low water, should avoid the 21-f eet spit which extends 5 cables west ward of No. 9 black buoy, by keeping over towards No. 10 red buoy in this part of the Pass. Large vessels, having to wait for high water to enter Dunkerque, anchor in the Pass between Nos. 11 and 13 black buoys. With the wind between N.N.E. and E.N.E., long boards should be made in the Pas de Calais until Calais bears S.S.E. \ E., when a vessel should stand in for the land, keeping the lead going quickly to avoid crossing the Riden de Calais. Boards of about 3 miles may be made between the West Dyck and the 5-fathoms edge of soundings towards the shore, but, from the meridian of Gravelines lighthouse to the entrance of the West Pass, short tacks should be made near the edge of these soundings, bearings of the Dyck and Snouw light vessels enabling this to be done with great confidence. At night, with westerly winds, after running past cape Grisnez as directed, until Calais light bears S.E. \ S. and cape Grisnez light S.W. \ W., steer E. \ S. for the Dyck light-vessel ; the Snouw light vessel will be sighted shortly after the Dyck, then steer for them in line bearing E. § S., and, passing them as described by day, run on through Dunkerque road, anchoring in about 8 fathoms, with Leu guenaert tower light seen between the two jetty lights S.S.E. DUNKERQUE ROAD AND PORT. 618 From the Northward. — When bound from the North sea to Dunkerque, or other French ports on this coast, endeavour to make the land about cape Blanc-Nez whatever the direction of wind or time or tide. The land south-westward of this cape, as far as cape Grisnez, may be seen in ordinary weather about 18 miles, and Mont Couple and the hills around it, 22 or 23 miles. The course from about 3 or 4 miles eastward of the Galloper light- vessel is S.S.W. |W.; this leads eastward of the Four-mile knolls or North Falls Head, and when the North Foreland lighthouse bears W. by N. \ N., steer about S.W. \ S. to pass midway between the Falls Tail and the south western end of the Sandettie bank. In clear weather, there is no difficulty in turning to windward over this ground ; when thick or foggy, the lead must be kept going quickly to avoid standing into less than 20 fathoms. From a well-defined position, ships may pass between the Great and Little banks of the Outer Ruytingen by steering for Gravelines light house bearing S.S.E., and taking great care to maintain that bearing ; the least water in this route is '6\ fathoms, on crossing the West Dyck bank. On bringing the Dyck and Snouw light-vessels in line, proceed as before directed for Dunkerque roads. At night, the lights at the South Foreland, cape Grisnez, Calais, and even Dunkerque, may be seen in clear weather when a vessel is midway between the Falls Tail and the south-western end of the Sandettie ; from this position, if the wind is from the eastward, Calais light may be steered for, bearing South, or, if from the west ward, the land between Calais and cape Grisnez ; but, to keep a safe distance from the shores on either of these courses, it is necessary in the former case not to bring cape Grisnez light westward of S.W. by W. ; and, in the latter, not to bring cape Grisnez light westward of S.W. \ W., nor Calais light eastward of S.E. by S. Having attained either of the positions indicated by these bearings, the Dyck light-vessel and Dunkerque road may be steered for as before directed from the westward. With strong northerly winds, it is not prudent to approach within 5 miles of the shore. With strong north-westerly winds, vessels sometimes pass west ward of the Galloper and the Falls, or between the Galloper and Four-mile knolls and then westward of the Falls, in order to get iS '■ chart, No. 1,872, and plan.
